TITLE: Mogae Speaks on Corruption in Nigeria [document]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); RULE OF LAW (75%); LITIGATION (71%); DRIVERS LICENSES (63%); IMMIGRATION (50%) Botswana; Nigeria
TEXT: The following is the text of the speech delivered by former Botswanan President in Nigeria on corruption. It is indeed an honour and privilege for me to be given this opportunity to deliver a keynote address at the third launch of such an important campaign - the Anti-corruption Revolution. I must from the outset congratulate your Economic and Financial Crimes Commission for initiating such a campaign. It is more pleasing to note that the Anti-Corruption Revolution concept is designed to provide a platform for citizens' participation in the fight against corruption, economic and financial crimes in Nigeria. This is an important recognition that the Government cannot fight corruption alone, but needs the active participation of ordinary citizens, the public sector, the private sector and the civil society. Corruption is a problem that affects us all; we are all its victims; therefore we all have to be involved in fighting against it. I applaud you for reaching out to the public and civil society because corruption is a problem of immense proportions. It is complex and threatens national development and service delivery. Public education and mobilisation is therefore, crucial because we do not only need people's active participation but their confidence and support as well. Corruption should never be allowed to grow roots in any society. It must be nipped in the bud before it becomes widespread and sophisticated to a point where it threatens the very fabric of society. When corruption reaches endemic proportions it impacts on all aspects of life, and nothing can be done unless a palm is greased. For example, a bribe to the right person will enable one to pass an examination, get a driver's licence, land a contract and win a law-suit. Corruption should never be allowed to become an acceptable culture in any society. It is therefore, pleasing to note that as a nation you have taken it upon yourself to start a process of uprooting the germination of such a dangerous tumour. Nobody is going to come from somewhere to weed corruption in Nigeria, but it is up to the Nigerians themselves, at all levels, to shoulder that responsibility. I am, therefore, happy that what we are witnessing, in the form of the Anti-corruption Revolution campaign, are efforts of a people taking up the responsibility of building a clean society. Corruption retards development because it leads to loss of Government revenue; it leads to a slowdown in the development of essential services; it is a threat to democracy - because it can enable those involved to win power and influence; it can circumvent the will of the people and undermine the rule of law. It is enemy number one of law and order and good governance. Corruption also exacerbates poverty in that it effectively transfers resources from state coffers to the few rich and powerful. However, it is not confined to the rich and powerful, but corrupt Licencing Officers, Immigration and Customs Officials, Police Officers, Army Officers, can inflict untold damage to an economy and society. A corrupt bureaucracy can ruin the integrity of a nation, retard national development and impede service delivery. Greedy, selfish and corrupt public officers and that includes politicians, are a danger to development and law and order. Countries that have attained the dubious distinction of being some of the most corrupt nations in world attained that unfortunate label because of their corrupt bureaucracies and politicians. Corruption also distorts factor prices, to the extent that those at the receiving end are rewarded for little or no work done and the cost of a project turns out higher than it would be. Corruption distorts priorities in that those who are corrupted tend to give priority to development projects of little or no national benefit. What you are embarking upon requires a realistic and honest assessment of the extent of corruption in your country and its dimensions. Above all, ask yourself whether you have adequate political will to ensure that combative action is taken. Without political will this campaign will not go anywhere. It is also important to emphasis that for an anti-corruption campaign to succeed, the Government must be prepared to risk potential embarrassment to itself, and there must be an accompanying realisation that whatever mechanisms are put in place, they must be so organised and structured that the campaign and the campaigners have unfettered operational autonomy. The Government must also ensure that the campaign enjoys adequate human and physical resources, and that irrespective of the possible political consequences, there will be no slackening of resolve. You should also bear in mind that any anti-corruption campaign, which seeks to provide immunity to any group of people is bound to fail because it will lack public confidence and support, which is essential to its success. Allow me now to briefly tell you how we fight corruption in my country, Botswana. In addition to the constitutionally-entrenched oversight organisations such as the Auditor-General and the Directorate of Public Prosecution, we have established independent organisations such as the Directorate on Corruption and Economic Crime, the Ombudsman and the Public Procurement and Asset Disposal Board. These key anti-corruption and accountability institutions ensure strict adherence to proper financial management practices and good corporate governance. They have strong legal mandates and powers to investigate and report on possible abuses and departures from financial laws and regulations, designed to protect the public interest with regard to, among other things, safeguarding of the collection, custody and use of public funds and assets, including land, the security of private property, as well as the freedom to trade anywhere in the country. An independent judiciary underpins these institutions, and we continue to exercise vigilance to ensure that they all adapt to the changing times. In Botswana we are committed to the goal of 'zero tolerance' for corruption. Our resolve is that corrupt practices must remain a 'high risk low return undertaking'. This has earned Botswana a rating, by Transparency International, as the least corrupt country, in Africa and the developing world, and indeed among the best in the world. Our anti-corruption agency was established in 1994 as a response to the unfolding of incidences of corruption in the country which were threatening our hard earned economic development and good reputation as a society. The DCEC, as it is popularly known, is an operationally autonomous agency armed with special powers to investigate acts of corruption. We have charged this agency not only with the responsibility of investigation and prosecution, but also modelled it upon other successful examples from the Far East, given it the responsibility for corruption prevention studies and public education. Public education is a major component of the DCEC mandate. This anti-corruption agency has made corruption a public issue, bringing it to the forefront of our citizens' attention. Because of public education and involvement the agency receives reports of alleged corrupt practices from members of the public and they investigate them to establish their nature. Those that happen to fall within its purview are followed and some end up as court cases. The agency also follows media reports on allegations of corruption. We also have a long established Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, or PAC, to ensure transparency and accountability in public spending. The PAC, whose members are Members of Parliament from both the ruling and opposition parties, holds permanent secretaries to account for any misdeeds in their ministries. They have to account for their budget expenditure and that includes under-expenditure and over-expenditure. We have also embarked upon an intensive campaign to make the whole of the public service accountable and performance-oriented with a view to providing the tax payers with the services they have a right to expect. We inculcate codes of ethical conduct, transparency and accountability into the whole of the public service. Chairperson, let me conclude by reiterating the point I have already made that, the task of fighting against corruption cannot be left to Government alone. It needs partnership between the public sector, the private sector, civil society and the general public. Public participation, confidence and support are paramount in any anti-corruption campaign. I have noted with satisfaction that this is what you are doing - building partnerships between the government and other critical stakeholders - general public, public sector, private sector and civil society. There is no other way but for everybody to be involved. Your theme for this campaign - 'Popular Participation for National Rebirth'- is very much appropriate but it should not remain just a slogan; it should be translated into reality through the mobilisation of the general public. I thank you for your attention and wish successful in this crucial campaign.

TITLE: ACC Mourns Corruption in Schools
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); STUDENT EXPENSES (72%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (65%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption; Education
TEXT: Deputy head of the Anti-Corruption Commission, ACC has voiced out his commission's frustration at the number of alleged corrupt practices reported in some schools across the country. Addressing members of the conference of principals in Freetown, Morlai Buya Kamara said the ACC was inundated with several reports of illegal charges, extortion, unfair treatment of pupils, illegal sale of pamphlets and extra school charges from the general public. "The commission is seriously disturbed and worried about these problems in our schools. The commission's patience has been over-tested. What we have in our schools today is complete system failure," he lamented. Kamara said as a responsible commission, the ACC would not sit by and allow the educational system to collapse due to corruption, adding that they would ensure they enforce what was inside the ACC Act. "This time around, we are very much determined to prove the conference of principals wrong. Let us try and improve the system because if we leave it as it is right now, posterity will not be kind to us," he maintained. Kamara said some principals need commendation because of their role in ensuring that the education system is improves. ACC's director of systems and processes review unit, Neneh Dabo said the commission has realized that since the release of the education report last year, not much has been done. She encouraged the school authorities to report to the commission issues of importance. Some of the schools that were reported to the ACC include; St. Augustine secondary school in Lungi for increase in school fees; Government Rokel secondary school; Government Model; and Albert Academy for illegal sale of pamphlets to pupils; and Prince of Wales for unfair treatment to pupils.

TITLE: Nyamabuye Local Leaders Accused of Corruption
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EXECUTIVES (88%); WETLANDS (55%) Rwanda
TEXT: Local leaders in Nyamabuye sector along with local defence in the area have been accused of taking bribes. Nyamabuye Sector Executive Secretary, Jean Babptiste Mugunga made the remarks on Saturday, after a resident Sosthene Minani- said he bribed grass-roots leaders and local defence personnel in an effort to get authorisation to construct a house in a wetland. Minani, whose house was being demolished by local leaders and security official said: "I cannot understand why my house is being demolished yet I have already handed Rwf600,000 to some local leaders including police and local defence personnel in Gahogo cell." He added that he paid the last instalment of Rwf100,000 on February 4 through a third party. The District agronomist, Jonathan Sunzu, said Minani was informed of the illegal activity and asked to halt the construction, but didn't heed. Reacting to the claims, Mugunga said, 'we are going to investigate this case and culprits involved will be severely punished."

TITLE: Clergyman Cites Corruption in Church
SUBJECT: RELIGION (94%); CLERGY & RELIGIOUS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (90%) Zambia; Religion
TEXT: UNITED Church of Zambia (UCZ) Synod Bishop Mutale Mulumbwa has called for transparency in the manner members handle finances as the church should be free from underhand activities. Bishop Mulumbwa regretted that issues pertaining to church finances in some congregations were being done 'underground.' The Bishop was speaking in Ndola yesterday during a sermon at Northrise Congregation under the theme 'finding out what pleases the Lord'. He said in some instances, church treasurers and other congregation leaders did not want to make public financial positions and revenue of the church because they lacked accountability. "There is corruption in church. Things are being done underground. There should be transparency in the way things are done," he said. Bishop Mulumbwa, however, expressed happiness that at Northrise Congregation, church leaders were able to outline every income and expenditure to congregants and appealed to others to do the same. "I am happy that things here are being done transparently. The announcements about money are important. This building is beautiful because of the manner you are handling matters. I was here when it was just a plot some years back," he said. In an apparent reference to the need to contribute to the church, he said God had his own way of doing things and advised Christians to always establish what the Lord wanted. "You should pay attention to what God requires us to do. Many Christians ask God to give them what they want, but they don't want to give to God what he wants," he said Quoting from Luke chapter 6 Verse 38, Bishop Mulumbwa said Christians should give willingly to others, so that in return they would continue to receive with the blessings of the Lord. "God is not the beneficiary, beneficiaries are ourselves. People should learn to please God. Give and it shall be given to you. When you do what God wants, you are inspired," he said. He said people should not get discouraged by fellow Christians who disparage them when they contribute to the Church's development, as it is those who give in good faith that will enhance God's work. Northrise Congregation minister-in-charge, Mwape Chilombo said she was elated that the Synod Bishop found time to deliver a sermon when the congregation launched the first English service. Reverend Chilombo said the English service was introduced because the congregation had grown and some were not conversant with the vernacular language, Bemba.

TITLE: Immigration Dept Admits Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); IMMIGRATION (93%); EXECUTIVES (90%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (90%); TERRORISM (52%) Sierra Leone; Migration; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Chief Immigration Officer has admitted to the public that his office was guilty of corruption. Alpha Kholifa Koroma said he was not surprised when President Ernest Bai Koroma accused the institution of being corrupt. The department was counted among institutions which the president recently upbraided for not performing to the expectations of the government and members of the public, and also for being corrupt. The Immigration department was particularly scolded by the president for issuing out passports to foreigners. Koroma revealed that there were workers who were bent on derailing the president's agenda for change. He accused some unscrupulous immigration officers of issuing out passports to foreigners thereby imperiling the country's image. The Immigration boss totally condemned the act of criminally selling Sierra Leonean passports to foreigners saying, "Terrorists can use it to create havoc elsewhere while Sierra Leone will carry the blame". He promised to put stringent measures in place to curb all corrupt practices currently plaguing the establishment. "I have put in place watertight measures to stop all corrupt activities in the department," Koroma maintained.

TITLE: Parliament to Assess Anti-Corruption Measures
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (92%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (78%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Members of Parliament, Senators and Parliamentary support staff are expected to meet in a day-long meeting today to assess the progress made in fighting corruption and lay new strategies to boost the role of Parliament in curbing the vice. The consultative conference organized by African Parliamentarian Network Against Corruption/ Rwanda- Chapter (APNAC-Rwanda) will be graced by the president of the Senate, Dr. Vincent Biruta. A concept paper from APNAC-Rwanda, a copy of which The New Times has obtained, indicates that the meeting will address root causes of corruption, policies put in place against it and how to improve service delivery as a strategy to fight corruption. The document adds that the main objective of the meeting is to sensitize lawmakers from both Chambers to take the prime role in promoting several anti-corruption policies. "Members of Parliament are expected to come up with concrete and harsh measures against corruption and related crimes," the document reads in part. Several experts in the fight against corruption are expected to address the Parliament during the extraordinary plenary meeting. "There will be several presentations on the current status of corruption in the country and the role of the Parliament in fighting corruption," the concept note from Parliament adds. Currently, APNAC- Rwanda has 63 registered members. Senate President Biruta, Speaker Rose Mukantabana and Ombudsman Tito Rutaremara are the honorary members of APNAC-Rwanda.

TITLE: Speaker Calls for Intensive Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); EMERGING MARKETS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (90%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); AIDS & HIV (70%); GLOBALIZATION (67%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (66%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Speaker of the Lower Chamber of Parliament, Rose Mukantabana, yesterday urged lawmakers to intensify action against corruption saying that the vice can significantly derail the nation's economic growth. She made the call while opening a day-long parliamentary anti-corruption meeting organized by African Parliamentarian Network against Corruption/ Rwanda- Chapter (APNAC-Rwanda). The meeting brought together all MPs, Senators and parliamentary support staff. "Corruption is a vice that is hard to eliminate and that is why collaborative efforts are required," said Mukantabana. She equated corruption to the HIV/AIDS saying that the two are closely related since both involve victimization. Mukantabana called upon the entire House to be exemplary in the fight against corruption articulating that Parliament should take a lead by being a corrupt-free institution in the country. "Intensified curbing of corruption is one way to progressive development and economic growth," she said. The Speaker, however, accused nationals who do not invest in their country and opt to bank their money in foreign banks. "Corrupt officials do not invest their money in the country; they instead opt to channel the money to foreign banks leaving people back home in extreme poverty," she said. The Chairperson of APNAC-Rwanda, Constance Mukayuhi, a member of the lower chamber, said that by virtue of Rwanda's position as one of the poorest countries in the world, it has to protect its economy by strengthening measures against corruption. "In order to catch up with the pace at which globalization is moving, we need to do away with all forms of corruption," said Mukayuhi. During the meeting, lawmakers hailed government policies and strategies and pledged to increase their collaboration with State institutions charged with fighting corruption.

TITLE: Stop Looting and Corruption - Ntuane
SUBJECT: ETHICS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BUDGETS (89%); NATIONAL SECURITY (88%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (79%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); RECESSION (77%); ECONOMIC NEWS (77%); CONTRACT AWARDS (76%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (76%); MANUFACTURING OUTPUT (76%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (73%); BUDGET CUTS (72%); GOVERNMENT BONDS (71%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (69%) Botswana
TEXT: Member of Paliament for Gaborone West South, Botsalo Ntuane has called on government to adopt ethics that will curb corruption if it is serious about attracting investors here. He said there is a developing trend by some people close to power, to loot the government. Ntuane was making a comment on the budget speech on Monday. He cited instances where some ministers own companies that tender for the supply of government goods and services. This is wrong, he said, adding that it is unethical. He said people should make choices between either being ministers or businessmen. Though he did not mention any names, the MP was probably referring to recent reports that a company owned by the wife of Minister of Justice, Defence and Security Ramadeluka Seretse has won tenders to supply equipment to government security organisations. When contacted for comment late last year, the minister said he did not see any conflict of interest when his wife's company won a tender to supply the government ministry he heads with equipment, because the President had no problem with it. Ntuane suggested that it should not only be the President who declares his assets and liabilities but that all public office holders - MPs and members of the judiciary should do the same. He said the current system where Cabinet ministers only declare to the president could be a breeding ground for corruption. This, he warned will turn investors away as some of them prefer to do business with transparent countries. He alleged that Botswana is run by a few individuals who are looting the riches of the nation, as has happened in those African countries known for corruption and nepotism. The MP further told the House that government should reduce the budgets of the Botswana Defence Force (BDF) and Directorate of Intelligence and Security (DIS) because Botswana is not under siege. He also said courts should be given time to litigate on cases involving people who have been declared Prohibited Immigrants by the President adding that it is wrong for them to be kicked out of the country, whilst their cases are still incomplete. The MP did not hide his discomfort with the constituency league saying it should also be set aside because the economy has suffered a recession and there is no money. He said money spent on the games should be spent on important areas of social services such as trucks for garbage collection, repairing streetlights and provision of water system toilets. Meanwhile, Bagalatia Arone told the house that the BDP has for many years failed to develop his constituency. He said the President of Zimbabwe Robert Mugabe is a better man compared to the BDP government because he has educated his people. He said in Botswana the manufacturing sector has not been fully exploited despite abundant raw materials. On sport development he suggested that the constituency league be abolished and Botswana football Association allowed to run football in the country. He said the league does not develop sport in any way.

TITLE: MDC-T Riddled With Corruption - Chamisa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); SENTENCING (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); ETHICS (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (88%); INVESTIGATIONS (88%); VERDICTS (87%); JAIL SENTENCING (70%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: MDC-T has admitted its ranks are riddled with corruption. In an interview on Wednesday, party spokesperson Mr Nelson Chamisa said they needed a code of ethics to rein in their errant rank and file. Councils dominated by MDC-T all over the country have come under investigation over allegations of rampant corruption. Recently, Government had to dismiss Israel Marange as Chitungwiza mayor after the courts found him guilty of corruption involving residential stands and sentenced him to serve prison time. Marange is appealing against both conviction and sentence. "When people vote leaders into office, they do it because they want better service delivery and development and not for individual gratification," Mr Chamisa said. In other corruption cases, senior party officials are accused of plundering thousands of dollars in South Africa and the United Kingdom. The most recent incident of corruption in the party involves three Highfield councillors who are accused of clandestinely transferring houses into their names.

TITLE: Tsvangirai Slams Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (75%); AGREEMENTS (72%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: MDC-T leader Morgan Tsvangirai has publicly admitted that his party is riddled with corruption that is threatening its integrity and vowed to fire all members found guilty. Addressing party supporters in Chitungwiza yesterday, Mr Tsvangirai said corruption had become a deep-rooted cancer in the party structures. "What is happening now is a manifestation of a party yapindwa napongwe. This is a reflection of a party eroding as a result of corruption. This is a serious matter and recently we fired the Chitungwiza executive because of corruption. "We again fired the Chitungwiza council that was also mired in corruption. As president of the party, I have an obligation to protect the integrity of the party and in pursuit of this obligation, I prefer to become the most unpopular leader for a very popular reason," he said. He maintained that the Chitungwiza councillors that were dismissed by the party for corruption did not have legitimacy to continue serving in the local authority. Mr Tsvangirai said he would meet the responsible minister over the issue soon. However, Local Government, Urban and Rural Development Minister Ignatius Chombo has already indicated that he will not fire the council over party squabbles. Mr Tsvangirai said some of the party officials who secured Government positions were abusing them for self-enrichment. "Vamwe venyu manga musina kana nebhutsu chaidzo asi mave kufamba nemota six-six. We are very serious about this issue. Some of you are already building white houses, saka chii ichocho?" he asked. Mr Tsvangirai's remarks on corruption come at a time when there are reports of corruption and maladministration in Chegutu, Bindura and Kadoma. Sources close to the party said a report that was tabled before the party's national council last week had shown alarming levels of corruption, with councillors being accused of enriching themselves. Turning to the ongoing talks over the implementation of Global Political Agreement issues, Mr Tsvangirai said the negotiations should come to an end to allow the inclusive Government time to rebuild the economy. He said people were waiting for the Government to deliver, hence the need to conclude the dialogue. Before addressing the rally, Mr Tsvangirai planted a palm tree at his Strathaven home in the morning in memory of his late wife Susan who died in a car accident on March 6 last year. He was assisted by his son Edwin.

TITLE: Cast Anti-Corruption Net Wider [editorial]
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (91%); DRIVERS LICENSES (91%); TRANSPORTATION LAW (90%); INSPECTIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LICENSES & PERMITS (90%); VEHICLE INSPECTIONS (90%); DRIVER EDUCATION (89%); TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (77%); INFRASTRUCTURE (73%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (71%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: INCREASED carnage on the roads is no doubt a reflection of deteriorating standards of driving compounded by the deplorable actions of some Vehicle Inspection Department officials issuing out drivers' licences to unqualified and undeserving people who are prepared to pay bribes to get the document. A motor vehicle is a very tame machine in the hands of a competent driver, but a dangerous contraption in the hands of an incompetent handler. This explains why prospective drivers have to undergo rigorous testing to determine their competence. This process should never be short-circuited by cash or kickbacks. To this end, we hail Government's cancellation of 199 drivers licences issued at Chiredzi Vehicle Inspection Department depot between January and June last year. The people holding those licences have to acquire genuine ones failing which they must stay off the roads. Learner drivers licence testing requirements are the same countrywide and there is no reason why those who fail to make it in Harare or Bulawayo end up making it in Chiredzi or Nyamapanda. We urge the Ministry of Transport, Communication and Infrastructure Development to thoroughly investigate the goings on at the VID depots. We have reason to believe Chiredzi could just be a tip of the iceberg as VID officers have for long been accused of soliciting bribes from all prospective drivers to the extent of failing competent learners who will have refused to pay bribes while passing dullards willing to grease their palms. Such a situation is a sure recipe for disaster and may account for the carnage on the roads. To this end we urge the relevant authorities to work to flush out the bad apples. This might warrant setting up whistle blower funds and sending plain clothes law enforcement agents to identify the bad apples who must be dealt with severely to send a message to all bent on corrupt dealings. It goes without saying that all the 199 drivers who got their licenses at Chiredzi during the period in question should undergo re-testing, and if they fail the officers who signed the certificates of competence should face the wrath of the law. It is also vital to categorically stipulate the requirements learner drivers have to meet so that they are not taken advantage of by unscrupulous testing officers. If the process is cumbersome and unclear, it fuels corruption because the learner drivers will not know whether they have genuinely failed or been made to fail in lieu of kickbacks. There is no doubt that the persistent allegations of bribery have tainted the VID's image to a point where many have lost confidence in it. Bribery is corruption of the highest order and the Government should clamp down on all offenders. Some driving schools are also known to work in cahoots with some VID officials to issue licences to incompetent drivers who have money to pay and there is need to monitor their operations and de-register all found on the wrong side of the law. When a minister goes public about dealing with corruption, like what Minister Nicholas Goche has done, it helps the public will feel encouraged to report any corrupt activities that they come across; safe in the knowledge that corrective action will be taken.

TITLE: "Quiet Corruption" Derailing African Economies - WB Report
COUNTRY: AFRICA (96%); RWANDA (93%); BURUNDI (92%); UGANDA (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (92%); KENYA (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (78%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (76%); SCANDALS (73%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption; Banking and Insurance; International Organizations and Africa
TEXT: The World Bank on Monday released the 2010 Africa Development Indicators (ADI) Report, revealing a new phenomenon of "Quiet corruption" that is pervasive and widespread especially across Sub-Saharan Africa. This new type of corruption is also said to have a disproportionate effect on the poor, with long-term consequences for development. According to the report, it is mainly attributed to the failure of public servants to deliver goods or services paid for by governments. The 2010 ADI report, notes that most corruption studies in the past focus on an exchange of money - bribes to powerful political designees or kickbacks to public officials. This year's report, however, focused on the way "quiet corruption" leads to an increasingly negative expectation of service delivery systems, causing families to ignore the system. "Quiet corruption, although smaller in monetary terms, is particularly harmful for the poor, who are more vulnerable and more reliant on government services and public systems to satisfy their most basic needs," the report observes. Rwanda fared better than other countries in the region. It has the lowest percentage in the incidences of corruption and perceived corruption. "Quiet corruption does not make the headlines the way bribery scandals do, but it is just as corrosive to societies," said Shanta Devarajan, Chief Economist for the World Bank's Africa Region. "Tackling quiet corruption will require a combination of strong and committed leadership, policies and institutions at the sectoral level, and - most important - increased accountability and participation by citizens," he further added. Rwanda registered 19.96 percent of corruption incidence -where firms' informal payments are likely to be made or kickbacks given to have things done while in the area of perceived corruption the country registered 4.35 percent. Kenya on the other hand registered 79.2 in corruption incidences-making it the most corrupt country in the East African Community followed by Burundi with 56.46 percent, Uganda with 51.7 percent and Tanzania with 49.47 percent. In perceived corruption Kenya scored 38.35 percent, Uganda 23.57, Tanzania 19.73 and Burundi 19.71 percent. D R Congo registered the highest corruption incidences in the Great Lakes region with 83.79 percent and 20 percent of perceived corruption.

TITLE: Impunity, Poverty = Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); CIVIL SERVICES (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); BUDGETS (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (76%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (76%); EXECUTIVES (74%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (74%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (73%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); INFLATION (73%); ECONOMIC NEWS (73%); COUNTIES (71%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (66%); PETROLEUM REFINERIES (50%) Liberia
TEXT: Some causes of pervasive corruption have been advanced in the current US State Department report, amongst them 'the culture of impunity, poverty' and low salaries for civil servants. Civil servants' salaries have however risen from about US20 during previous tears, to now US100, although correspondingly with rising inflation. The Report said: "The 2008 Anticorruption Act, which established the Liberian Anti-Corruption Commission (LACC), does not provide criminal penalties for corruption, which remained systemic throughout the government. Official corruption was exacerbated by low pay levels for the civil service, lack of job training, and a culture of impunity. On October 8, the auditor-general said that boards of directors of public corporations in the country were being used as "cover-ups" to justify illegal transactions. The LACC and the Ministry of Justice are responsible for exposing and combating official corruption, but it was unclear whether the commission or the ministry had responsibility for prosecuting corruption cases. The LACC, which had a minimal budget and insufficient staff, had completed no corruption investigations by year's end. "Despite her strong emphasis on decentralization, President Sirleaf urged the legislature during the year to withdraw from allocating and implementing local development projects financed by County Development Funds; such funding was intended to support local projects to reduce poverty. The move to reclaim centralized executive administration of local development projects was widely seen as a result of inadequate management at the local level, which often funnelled development funds to support political interests rather than to reduce poverty. The government dismissed or suspended a number of officials for corruption. For example, on September 5, President Sirleaf dismissed the managing director of the state-owned Liberia Petroleum Refining Corporation (LPRC) after an investigation revealed alleged irregularities in awarding a no-bid 1.75 billion Liberian dollars ($36 million) concession.

TITLE: Ex-NA Secretary Denies Three Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); INDICTMENTS (78%); LEGISLATION (78%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); LAWYERS (75%); ARRESTS (73%); WAGES & SALARIES (62%); HOLIDAYS & OBSERVANCES (55%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: FORMER National Assembly Secretary Nama Goabab and parliamentary accountant Abraham John George pleaded not guilty to all charges when their trial on three counts of corruption started in the High Court in Windhoek this week. The charges against Goabab (52) and George (49) are all based on allegations that they illegally hired two vehicles at Government expense for Goabab's private use in March and April 2007. The total cost of the vehicle rental is alleged to have been N$23 552,20. Goabab alone is also accused of having illegally used a Government-owned vehicle for private purposes on the public holiday of May 25 2007. With his former position at the National Assembly having been on the level of a Permanent Secretary in the Public Service, Goabab is the most senior public official to have gone on trial on charges under the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003 to date. Together, Goabab and George are charged with two main counts of corruptly using their offices or positions for gratification, alternatively fraud and fraud or theft respectively. Goabab alone is also accused of corruptly using his office or position for gratification, alternatively using a motor vehicle without the owner's consent. "Not guilty," Goabab and George both told Judge Marlene Tommasi when they were asked to give their pleas to the charges on Wednesday. In a plea explanation that Goabab's defence lawyer, Lucius Murorua, provided to the court, Goabab specifically denied that he had corruptly used his position as National Assembly Secretary, whether directly or indirectly. Goabab admitted that he had instructed George to hire a rental car for his use. The rental was to be at his own expense, he indicated. Goabab also stated that he agreed with George on April 24 2007 that the costs of the car rental would be deducted from his salary in instalments. The first rental is alleged to have been at a cost of N$5 055. Government did not lose that money, Goabab indicated. The second rental is alleged to have been at a cost of N$18 497,20. He paid that amount to the National Assembly on June 12 2007, Goabab stated. That was the day after he and George had made a first joint court appearance following their arrest on June 8 2007. On the third charge over his alleged unlawful use of a Government-owned vehicle, Goabab stated that he had the necessary permission to use the car for an official function, which was a memorial service for the late former Cabinet member Richard Kapelwa Kabajani. Goabab charged that the indictment under which he and George are being prosecuted "is a mental construct of the Anti-Corruption Commission with an air of unreality". He charged that his prosecution is based on bad faith, with the State having "in an arbitrary and high handed manner criminalised otherwise non-penal administrative acts". The State alleged corruption "in wanton disregard" of the arrangement he had to pay the car rental costs by way of deductions from his salary, Goabab stated. George's defence lawyer, Christie Mostert, also provided a plea explanation to the court. George stated that at the time covered by the charges, he was the Chief Accountant at the National Assembly. As Secretary, Goabab was in charge of George and other employees at the National Assembly, and they were therefore obliged to comply with his orders, George stated. With regard to the first car rental at the start of March 2007, George stated that he had been instructed by Goabab to hire a car for him. He claimed he only found out about the second rental when Goabab presented an account from the car rental company to him for payment. Goabab "instructed me to pay the amount from our office's budget and indicated that he will make arrangements for the repayment of the money back to the Government," George stated. One of the prosecution's witnesses, Ulf Thaumuller, told the court yesterday that he was still employed at Budget Rent-a-Car when Goabab and another National Assembly official visited his office on April 24 2007 and asked to be provided with copies of invoices for two car rentals that had been done with the company. Thaumuller testified that Goabab told him that he would be paying for both rentals by cheque. Goabab also asked him not to charge the second vehicle rental on the credit card that had been used when the car was hired, since a cheque payment would be done instead. On a question from Judge Tommasi, Thaumuller said it was not indicated to him whether a Government or a private cheque would be used to make the payment. The trial is continuing. Deputy Prosecutor General Orben Sibeya is conducting the prosecution. Goabab and George are both free on bail.

TITLE: Minister Engages Regional Workers On Corruption
SUBJECT: PREGNANCY & CHILDBIRTH (93%); WOMEN'S HEALTH (90%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (90%); DEATHS & DEATH RATES (90%); MEDICAL CHARITIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INFANTS & TODDLERS (77%); CHILDREN'S HEALTH (77%); TRENDS (73%); PUBLIC HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (72%); BREASTFEEDING (72%); INFANT MORTALITY (67%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (52%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption; Labour; Health and Medicine
TEXT: Deputy Minister of Health and Sanitation has concluded a week-long training of health personnel in the Bombali and Kambia districts in northern Sierra Leone ahead of the free health care service delivery for pregnant women, lactating mothers and children under five. The training focused on the need for medical personnel to stay away from corruption as the president launches the free health care package on Independence Day April 27. "Let us stay away from corruption; very soon this ministry will be given free medical service to pregnant women and under five children in the country. Health personnel should not take money for the services they will be rendering, which is why we held the training sessions in the two districts," Mohamed D. Koroma said. The clinic started on April 6 and ended on Monday April 12. According to Koroma, a survey conducted by his ministry showed that maternal and infant mortality rates were highest in the north "because people are still very much attached to traditional birth and delivery practices." According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), Sierra Leone has the world's highest death rate among pregnant women and children. "We are determined to bring down the deplorable figures of deaths among pregnant women and children and reverse the trend which is not good for the country's image," he said.

TITLE: EALA Should Enact Laws to Fight Corruption [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); BRIBERY (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (73%); CLINICS & OUTPATIENT SERVICES (69%); HOSPITALS (69%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: At the opening of the East African Legislative Assembly (EALA) on Wednesday, President Paul Kagame, called upon the members of the EALA to use their positions to improve the lives of EAC citizens. He further reminded the lawmakers that there should be zero tolerance for corruption. It is one vice that is probably the greatest hindrance to public and private sector service delivery, with adverse consequences to the welfare of the people. When a road isn't built, or is built in a shoddy manner, because someone took a kickback, it's the road users and pedestrians who are at risk. When a public hospital doesn't get enough life saving drugs because someone in the ministry has diverted the funds, or even worse when hospital staff sell those drugs, it's the poor citizens, who can't afford to visit a private clinic, that suffer. When policemen and women accept bribes from errant drivers, they simply endanger the lives of road users. While corruption is often seen as a 'victimless crime' by the perpetrators, this isn't the case. EALA has a role to play in the fight against corruption. The first thing that they can do is enact an East African Anti-Corruption Bill. Additionally, they can use their visibility as eminent citizens to launch anti-corruption campaigns and sensitize their constituents against either receiving and offering bribes or engaging in any sorts of corruption. The fight against corruption needs everyone's involvement and the East African legislators can take the lead.

TITLE: Finance Minister Denies Corruption Allegation
SUBJECT: BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (90%); PRESS CONFERENCES (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); AUDITS (89%); US DOLLAR (78%); CORRUPTION (73%); PUBLIC DEBT (71%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (69%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (55%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Finance Minister Augustine Ngafuan has reacted sharply to media reports, that he is involved in the disappearing of millions of dollars at the ministry. Addressing a press conference Saturday in Monrovia, Minister Ngafuan said the report alluded to by the media was gathered from previous audit conducted during the administration of his predecessor, Dr. Antoinette Sayeh. Min. Ngafuan said Liberia is operating on 12 triggers, which have to be implemented by a host of Government Institutions and not for an individual to rush into the coffers of the country to use tax payers' money. He said the twelve triggers are to prepare a full Poverty Reduction Strategy through a participatory process and implement satisfactorily its recommended actions for at least one year. The Finance Minister also said the country is not retrogressing when it comes to accountability, transparency among others. The Minister noted that he will not be teaching auditing at the University of Liberia and turn his back to what he is teaching. Minister Ngafuan stated also that he will never allow himself to be a thief, or form part of thieves, but rather do everything possible in the interest of the Liberian people. Minister Ngafuan further stated that the statement published in the Front Page News Paper Friday under the caption "Mess at Finance Ministry" is worrisome, and as such he wants reporters to double check their stories before publication. He said reporters should exhibit their professionalism so as to avoid future embarrassments. He said, he will not allow himself to be a part of thievery attitudes, because he does not want to serve the Liberian people with dishonesty. The Minister also made reference to a publication in the media that the HIPC which is intended to establish whether Liberia has a sound and responsible financial management policies as a way of protecting state resources from plunder and abuse as was done in the past. On the contrary, the Minister said, audit has uncovered a lot of mess which include massive abuse of ghost transactions, ghost workers including others unwholesome financial practices bent on defrauding the Liberian people of thousands of United States dollars.

TITLE: President Passes Corruption Ball to PUL
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SUITS & CLAIMS (87%); JOURNALISM (78%); BRIBERY (78%); LITIGATION (74%); PRESS CONFERENCES (73%); WRITERS (73%); LAWYERS (71%); HUMAN RIGHTS (69%); BANKING LAW (68%); BANKING & FINANCE (68%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (51%) Liberia; Press and Media; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf on Tuesday boomeranged a reporter's question on escalating corruption in the country to the Press Union of Liberia, which received US$100,000 from her last year to build its headquarters, but the project remains at a standstill. During her press conference, the president added: "In fact I am waiting to hear you people (to) tell me what happened to the US$100,000 to build the Press Union Building." The current PUL administration and its predecessor are now locked in a lawsuit over the use of the money, with allegations that former PUL leaders misused the money. Reports say that President Sirleaf's brother-in-law Estrada Bernard, who is also her legal counsel, allegedly disbursed the US$100,000 to former PUL President George Barpeen in violation of PUL's constitution and banking regulation. There are other reports that former President Charles Taylor offered a similar amount to the PUL for the same project but there is no result. The US State Department's human rights report on Liberia, including the most recent assessment, accused unnamed local journalists of receiving bribes in return for favorable or damaging stories on politicians and other people.

TITLE: Political Will Against Corruption Must Be Mustered
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (88%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); ANNIVERSARIES (70%); AUDITS (50%) Liberia
TEXT: The wave of corruption in the country is hindering economic growth and development, Foreign minister Olubanke King-Akerele has said. For the country to transcend its current state, the Minister said, Liberians must avoid corrupt practices and that a political will should be mustered to arrest such menace. "...Let us do away with corruption. Because if we don't, we cannot move ahead like our neighbors," She said Tuesday, when Sierra Leonean Embassy here commemorated its country's 49th independent anniversary. She furthered that Sierra Leone's economic development poses a challenge to the Liberian government to move forward. The Charge d' Affairs at the Sierra Leone Embassy Tamba Edward Juana outlined his government's achievements including the building of "sustainable infrastructure" and its "robust fight" against corruption. In the fight against corruption, he said the country has reformed its anti-corruption laws and has legislated a "tougher anti-corruption act," which "grants the commission sufficient latitude and independence to investigate and prosecute offenders without political interference. To the contrary, the Anti Corruption Commission here does not have prosecuting power, while audit findings are settled at the Legislature and the Executive.

TITLE: Paying Lip Service to Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (87%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (72%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (72%); WRITERS (72%); PRIME MINISTERS (72%); MISDEMEANORS (72%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (70%); CHEMOTHERAPY & RADIATION (70%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: "IT is said power corrupts, but actually it's truer that power corrupts the corruptible. The sane are usually attracted by other things other than power," said David Brin, the 20th century American fiction writer. One year after the inception of the inclusive Government, the moderate gains that have been achieved are on the brink of going down the drain because of corruption. There seems to be no willpower on the part of Government or the political parties to apply chemotherapy to the growing cancer. Forget about politics and the so-called outstanding issues. Corruption has become endemic and so entrenched into the nation's bloodstream that it has become the biggest threat to the country's survival. The major problem we now have is that when people talk about corruption, be it politicians or the common man in the street, it is as if it is some theoretical issue and not something that is happening under our noses. Corruption has led to cronyism and the growth of a criminal state, whose future is but gloomy. This is the tragedy of Zimbabwe today. It is also common cause that the so-called independent media, for political expediency, have by and large ignored these acts of corruption. After having for so long presented themselves as watchdogs, reporting acts of alleged corruption by Zanu-PF officials, they have largely turned a blind eye to the scourge, as the MDC officials continue to abuse their positions of authority. This hypocrisy is understandable, for any negative coverage may derail the regime change agenda and offend their funders. MDC-T spokesperson Nelson Chamisa confirmed that some ministers, councillors and legislators were under investigation for engaging in corrupt activities. He, however, refused to disclose the names of the people under probe, but said there would not be any sacred cows to demonstrate the party's zero tolerance of corruption. Chamisa was earlier on quoted acknowledging that the MDC-T had "rotten apples" in their basket. He probably failed to notice that the whole basket has become rotten and needed to be thrown into the rubbish bin. As a party "we are a party of excellence. Transparency, accountability and good governance are part of our fabric," he said. "We expect these from our Prime Minister, from our ministers and from, most importantly, our councils." However, the party's actions to date have contradicted what they are saying in public. It would seem that they are paying lip service to corruption. While they are quick to point out alleged Zanu-PF misdemeanours, they seem reluctant to deal with even reported acts of corruption from within the party. "Is this the new beginning that they promised us? They are surely excelling in corruption and misgovernance," said a dejected MDC sympathiser. For a party that promised "a new beginning", and economic emancipation, it is busy eroding the base created by those who fought for the independence of this country. Chamisa said the party's biggest challenge at the moment was to deal with corruption and plans were underway to weed out those people involved in any corrupt activity, irrespective of their position in the party. "Unfortunately, others are now falling for this culture of corruption. Our crusade to get rid of bad apples is unstoppable. There will be no sacred cows -- this goes for ministers, MPs, councillors," he said. It remains to be seen whether the party will carry out its threat to dismiss the hordes of affected officials. The irony was lost on the MDC-T leaders, with their multiple properties both in the country and outside and top-of-the-range vehicles that the ordinary person can only dream of. This contradiction symbolises the MDC-T today. It is the outcome of a double think of the so-called "national democratic revolution" gone awry. But it is not hard to understand Chamisa's publicity stunt. The MDC-T's local government leadership has been accused of ineptitude. Thus the party has had to resort to such theatrics to respond to the accusations that it is blatantly corrupt. Growing reports of corruption by MDC-T councillors have further raised questions about the willingness on the part of the MDC-T to curb the scourge. One would have thought that the party, as per their election manifesto, would have breathed a "new way" of doing things in the governance of local authorities. The authorities are agreed that all is not well but it is the indifference to the acts of corruption that has left more questions than answers. "A lot of our councillors have breached the citizen's charter and flouted tender procedures we need to nip this corruption demon," said Chamisa. The party tried to pacify the nation by instituting a commission of inquiry led by Tapiwa Mashakada to probe the allegations. While the "commission's findings", are not yet out, at least for now, the party has tried to defend the indefensible by trying to portray the alleged perpetrators as victims of political chicanery by Zanu-PF. Why would a political party or anybody for that matter establish a commission of inquiry to protect from scrutiny those nobs that have used their political influences to enrich themselves? Trying to gloss over the acts of corruption by going public about instituting a commission of inquiry, whose findings remain a mystery, does not instill confidence in the people. Trying to apportion blame and claiming conspiracy theories does not help either. Reports of corruption within the party, save for the dismissal of the Chitungwiza councillors, who were dismissed for refusing to carry out a corrupt directive, i.e. imposing an outsider to become mayor of the town, have largely gone unchecked. Millions of party funds are said to have been looted by known culprits both in the United Kingdom and Zimbabwe. The party's director of elections, Denis Murira, is said to have fleeced the party of thousands of dollars and was rewarded with a senior post in Government. The question that needs answers is: Can such people be trusted to lead the country? Are their promises to deal with corruption a political gimmick? There is need for self-introspection amongst Zimbabweans as the country is faced with a bigger threat. Very soon many people might find themselves without houses and other property, falling prey to the marauding breed of new politicians, who are using their positions to fleece the public.

TITLE: Supreme Court Warns Reporters Against Corruption, Partiality
SUBJECT: LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (91%); SUPREME COURTS (90%); INTERVIEWS (78%); CONSULTING SERVICES (73%); CORRUPTION (70%); COMPUTER SOFTWARE (53%) Liberia; Press and Media; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The Supreme Court of Liberia has endorsed the introduction of three newly trained court reporters into the judicial system of the country. Senior Associate Justice Francis Korkpor said the insertion of the new reporters will immensely assist in the timely conduct of court proceedings. Florence Harris, Fayiah Tambah, and Roselyn Simpson were selected among dozens of applicants, after passing a detailed test and interview. They completed a six-week intensive training in Atlanta, USA. The training prepared them for pioneering the high advanced equipment in Liberia's court. The new technology works to allow the court reporters to produce a precise verbatim record of legal proceedings. As the court reporter hears the words spoken by each person in the courtroom, he/she repeats those words very carefully into a microphone. These sounds are automatically translated into text on the screen by computer software, and each person in the courtroom is also recorded. This allows the reporter to later re-listen to proceedings and make any corrections. Justice Korkpor urged the reporters to 'demonstrate complete professionalism' in their reportorial duties in to uphold the credibility of the judicial system and also pave the way for the training of more court reporters. For her part, Justice Gladys Johnson warned the reporters against 'partial reporting', terming it as 'corruption' on the part of the reporters in the judiciary. The Country Representative of the International Legal Assistance Consultancy ((ILAC), Mr. Michael R. Euwall, told the reporters that his organization decided to introduce such new idea into the Liberian judicial system, due to delays in court proceedings. According to him, such delays are responsible for the over crowdedness of courts dockets with numbers of cases which said needed to be dealt with in shorter time. He put the cost of the training of the three reporters at US$120,000.

TITLE: MPs Must Partake in Anti-Corruption Drive [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (79%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (78%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (78%); CITY GOVERNMENT (77%); SMUGGLING (76%); INVESTIGATIONS (75%); POLITICAL PARTIES (74%); POLITICS (71%); EVICTION (63%); INFRASTRUCTURE (50%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: CORRUPTION has been cited as one of the cancers that have bled the country, impacting on economic growth. The Zimbabwe Chapter of the African Parliamenta-rians Network Against Corruption issued a statement castigating the scourge of corruption and called on relevant authorities to institute measures that would compel public officials to declare their assets and business interests. The grouping is a voluntary body of legislators from all political parties in Parliament and is an affiliate of the African Chapter that was founded in 1999. The practice to disclose assets has been adopted by a number of countries as they attempt to stem abuse of public resources. Some may question the benefit of such disclosure. While I acknowledge that corruption is impossible to completely eradicate, the disclosure of assets and other business interests is important as it helps in tracking any other deals an individual in a senior position may enter into. It also helps even those individuals in high positions from being viewed as corrupt when they could have acquired their wealth legitimately. While Government has initiated a number of measures to deal with this menace, a lot can still be done to safeguard resources. The call by APNAC has, therefore, come at an opportune time. As a country, we are currently in the process of writing a new constitution and we should therefore include provisions that ensure that public resources are safeguarded. However, declaration of assets should not only be confined to public officials. I believe even those executives especially in public listed companies should also be compelled to do the same. There is a general belief that corruption is in the public sector but the private sector has also contributed to the abuse of resources. A few years ago, Reserve Bank of Zimbabwe Governor, Dr Gideon Gono said the country had lost approximately US$2 billion through smuggling of diamonds. Other precious minerals like gold are also being smuggled daily while the country continues to suffer from inadequate funds to finance a number of public works programmes. All these nefarious activities have cost the country dearly and have to be stopped. The call by the legislators could also not have come at a better time given the ongoing constitution-making process. We need to ensure proper use of resources is enshrined in the new constitution. Most local authorities have been afflicted by this scourge with councillors in some urban areas allocating or illegally acquiring stands for themselves, flouting tender procedures, evicting poor residents from council accommodation and so on. In some countries, abuse of public resources attracts heavy penalties and I think we should be moving in that direction to discourage such crimes. We also have to ensure that the police are adequately resourced to investigate corruption. Corruption is white-collar crime that requires expertise to expose. Zimbabwe should, therefore, invest heavily in this fight. So when the Anti-Corruption Commission is constituted, we hope it will work hard to curtail the cancer. However, the fight against corruption should not be used to settle political scores and then degenerate into a farce like what the Scorpions of South Africa ended up doing. The South African special police unit was disbanded after accusations that it was being used to settle political scores. Parliamentarians should be actively involved in the fight against corruption and APNAC should be commended. Last week, the Zimbabwe Power Company, a subsidiary of Zesa Holdings responsible for electricity generation said it would activate two more units at Hwange Power Station a situation that would increase output from 200MW to 500MW. However, soon after that announcement, power cuts appeared to have worsened and the question that begs an answer is whether the Parliamentary Portfolio Committee on Mines and Energy was misled. The increase in generation at Hwange should have brought some relief to the cuts that we have been experiencing but this has not come to be. While we acknowledge the challenges that Zesa is facing, it does not help however, that increase at Hwange is not enough. What is baffling is that the frequency of the power cuts seems to have increased following the announcement. A number of people have been calling complaining that the information that ZPC gave was misleading, so I hope they will clear the air and tell us what is really happening. Another disturbing matter concerning another subsidiary of Zesa, this time the Zimbabwe Electricity Transmission and Distribution Company, is the switching off of power to Shabanie that caused flooding and damaged equipment worth over US$450 million. The same fate also befell a number of mines. While it is a fact that electricity cannot be obtained for free, it becomes another thing to destroy equipment worth close to half a billion over bills. It is shocking insensitivity and lack of appreciation of national resources. Zesa also owes a number of institutions but I don't think there is anyone who has threatened to shut down its plants over debts. In this instance, there is no one who benefited because valuable equipment has been lost while Shabanie Mine's ability to pay its debts is next to zero since its source of income has been closed. It is going to be very expensive to resuscitate the company and the costs are also great in that a number of people were made redundant. The environment that we are operating under is abnormal, therefore it does not make sense to take a drastic measure like the one taken by ZETDC when everyone is struggling to make ends meet. The Secretary in the Ministry of Regional Integration and International Co-operation, Mr Tedious Chifamba said South Africa appeared not keen on setting up a One-Stop Border post at Beitbridge similar to the one set up at Chirundu with Zambia last year. A number of observers have said the One-Stop Border concept is a positive development as it reduces bureaucracy and congestion at border posts. This is because all immigration procedures from countries involved would be done under one roof. We hope that with further engagements, the South Africans will change their minds on that one. We also hope that talks to ensure that Zimbabweans with the new Temporary Travel Document are allowed access into South Africa will be completed soon to prevent continued inconveniences being experienced by the public. Registrar General Mr Tobaiwa Mudede said Zimbabwe did all procedures internationally recognised when it introduced the new travelling document. He said he was baffled why South Africa was the only country rejecting the document. Lastly, former deputy clerk of Parliament, Ms Helen Dingani, was recently appointed to take a similar position in the Pan African Parliament. This is another feather added to Zimbabwe's cap and recognition of the country's intellectual prowess. There are a number of eminent Zimbabweans that have been honoured to take up important posts in various international bodies and we thank Ms Dingani for continuing to make us proud. We wish her the best in her new position at PAP.

TITLE: Tejan-Cole's Resignation And the Complexities of Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (87%); TRENDS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (73%); LAWYERS (63%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (60%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Back in 2002, a summit of the African Union on corruption clearly highlighted just how serious this evil is within African societies. The statistics for the cost of corruption to the continent was an estimated 148 billion dollars annually. In Sierra Leone, the legacy of corruption had already seen the Athens of West Africa become the laughing stock of the world. A country that was once the bedrock of British colonial rule in the sub region, wherein the bureaucracy was prided as one of the best in the entire British colonial empire, was surely taking a downward trend. By mid 1970s, that positive reputation had already slipped off and by the 80s the saying "Usai den tie cow na dae e dae eat", was already a common adage. And as the late Professor  Akintola Wise put it in a paper presentation on the socio-political history of Sierra Leone; a society that once valued virtue and scholarly achievements now tend to have lost it completely by the late 80s as the widespread maxim then indicate; "Den say Bailor Barrie, u say Davidson Nicol." At the end of war, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission noted that one of the war's main causes had been the rampant corruption that had infested every level of government in the preceding decades. If Sierra Leone was to avoid a repeat of the 1990s, corruption was the biggest vice to be eradicated. Yet even after the commission published its conclusion in 2004, Sierra Leone's post-conflict government is still struggling to solve this ever growing problem. Inaugurating the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) on February 6, 2000, then president Kabba told the country, "My government and the ordinary people of Sierra Leone now have a new war to wage. This is the war against corruption. And in this fight, nobody will be above the law, including myself." Ten years after that epoch-making statement there is no doubt that corruption is still an entrenched menace in Sierra Leone today. In the two years after its launching, ACC statistics showed the cases investigated by the Commission paint a picture of a country rotten with corruption. By 2002, the ACC had investigated 500 cases and submitted its findings to the Justice Ministry with recommendations that it follow up. The snag there as many pointed then was that only the justice minister can charge cases of corruption. By force of the constitution, only he can decide whether to prosecute or not to prosecute. However, now that the 2008 ACC Act empowers the commission to use the shortcut option of bypassing the law officers department, (not only can the ACC investigate corruption, as before; it can also now launch prosecutions on its own, without having to refer cases to the  attorney-general, a political appointee.) On the backdrop of the resignation of ACC boss, Abdul Tejan-Cole, does his resignation indicate something much deeper? How has the fight against corruption gone? Is it that our country has been doomed to live with corruption? Is it that our political leaders lack the political will to swallow the bitter pill and enforce a robust anti-corruption campaign or is it that we are making an exaggeration and corruption is not the real issue here? Desmond Johnson, acting director of public education - an external outreach of the ACC - who defines corruption as not having any clear-cut definition, but they see it as misusing offices for personal gains and also as when someone fails to act or act in an inappropriate manner believes that dishonesty is the main problem: "It is affecting our socio economic development and in the ACC we believe that it is a fight that we can only succeed in if we have the support and cooperation of the general public." When I put it to the ACC PR chief whether the government has genuine intentions towards the fight against corruption he replied; "I believe so, if not the government would not have the commission existing." Desmond Johnson cited the ACC Act 2008 as an instance to back up his claim that the government is serious about the fight against corruption. He referred to the ACC Act 2000 as 'very weak' and said the 2008 Act now gives them more strength to fight corruption. Is the ACC equipped and using the right approaches to fight corruption and are we not seeing the same trend of those found in ACC net? According to Mr Johnson, the ACC is doing its best and it is using the three pronged approach, namely punitive, which involves investigating and prosecuting alleged acts of corruption. The preventive and education approach. Contrary to what many believe he claimed the ACC is daily carrying out intelligence investigations and prosecutions; "We don't make  our intelligence works public and we have a proactive and intelligence wing that secretly goes out there but you cannot see them." Interestingly, Mr Johnson told me that although the ACC was able to convict 11 people in 2009 the greatest challenge to the institution is public support; he thinks the ACC needs more support and cooperation from the general public. He also pointed out what many fear it might be the stumbling block to minimising corruption. "We need logistical support; the commission works throughout the country and if we are to succeed logistics like vehicles and other gadgets are vital. Finance and office is another problem," he said. Whilst the ACC boasts its success stories such as raising the public's awareness of the dangers of corruption and recovering billions of Leones for the government, David Tam-Baryoh - a political commentator in Sierra Leone said that the issue about whether the fight against corruption is being done in the proper way should be assessed on the amount sacred cows the current and previous governments have, something he humorously said he is not prepared to enter. But Charles Mambu, director of the coalition of civil society told Sierra Eye; "A fish is a fish, whether it is big or small. If the ACC wants to succeed in its fight against corruption, we believe it should investigate and prosecute any sacred cow or special personality but the best option  for the ACC is that it should set an example at all levels of corruption; that is the best way it can minimise the evil," said Charles Mambu. The civil society leader also criticised the ACC and said it should be 'more open and transparent'. To Charles Mambu, his greatest fear is that of government interference; "We will continue to talk to the government not to interfere into any of the functions and activities of the ACC. We will also talk to ACC officials not to allow themselves to be used by selfish politicians and members of the public because of the money or power they wield." He believes that leaders should be an example for progressive change and that the fight against corruption, though not only reliant on them, should be key in enabling its success. The Kenyan Nobel Peace Prize Laureate, Wangari Maathai in her book "The Challenge for Africa", powerfully argues that the continent is in urgent need of a revolution in leadership and "those in power - the presidents, prime ministers, politicians, and other elites - have to recognize that the way Africa has been conducting its affairs of state has neither protected nor promoted the welfare of the continent's citizens nor provided for the long term growth and stability of its nations. According to James Taiwo Cullen, a broadcaster for VOH FM 96.2 radio station, the greed and selfishness of government officials is to blame for high-level corruption in Sierra Leone. But meagre salaries within the civil service--which can be as low as US$1 a day--may have as much to do with the problem. This brings us to the point of poverty and corruption, in the latest edition of Development Drums, titled DOES CORRUPTION CAUSE POVERTY, OR IS IT THE OTHER WAY ROUND? by Daniel Kaufmann and Mushtaq Khan. Both authors argue that though poverty and corruption come from quite different  points of view, there is quite a lot of convergence between them. They agree that there is much more corruption in poor countries than in rich countries; that nobody should put too much faith in econometrics to decide whether corruption is a reason that poor countries remain poor; and that you do not fight poverty by only fighting corruption. But whereas Daniel Kaufmann believes that you have to tackle corruption to create the conditions for markets to work and to create economic growth and prosperity, Mushtaq Khan believes that you should focus on policies to promote growth and that a certain amount of corruption is an inevitable (albeit undesirable) corollary of the transition to a capitalist economy. Most Westerners they say believe that corruption is one of the most important reasons why poor countries remain poor; and yet a lot of them working in development seem to be willing to tolerate some corruption as an inevitable fact of life in poor  countries. According to a Human Right Watch briefing paper on Sierra Leone, petty corruption, extortion, and bribe-taking, particularly by police officers or low ranking officials, is rampant. Money has to change hands in order to secure entrance for children into public school, receive treatment in a public clinic, obtain a permit, authorisation, or letter from a ministry, or even file a police report. Corruption has historically bought the support of both the police and the army, making them subject to political interference and undermining their duty to protect. Personal gain through corruption remains the primary motivation for those entering the civil service..... the efforts of those seeking redress through the legal system are often frustrated by  corruption within the very system designed to combat it. So is it a way of life for many in Sierra Leone. Mabinty Sillah residing at Moyiba in the hilly side of Freetown is a very mother of five, struggling to send his children to school and provide them with basic meals but she was forced to bribe as she went for her national ID card at the National Registration Secretariat; "I didn't even have enough money to feed my children that day, I had no option but to pay a bribe of Le 5,000 to officials filling our forms. Those who didn't comply were made to endlessly sit down and wait. I needed the ID to enter into the micro credit scheme, so I had to ensure I got my ID otherwise I will not be considered for credit," said Mabinty who told me that because of that bribe she could not feed her children on  that day. A young graduate, Andrew Conteh believes that ordinary Sierra Leoneans should resist the temptation of corruption and stop bribing public officials; "In the words of Elbert Hubbard "All that is necessary for evil to succeed is that good men do nothing. Therefore we should openly oppose and expose anyone who encourages any form of bribery. We are ourselves aiding corruption in our little corners and at the end blaming government for all our problems," he said. Whilst leaders such as Tejan Kabbah in the past have stated that lower salaries should not be the reason for the high corruption in our society, many ordinary Sierra Leoneans I spoke to believe any effort to stamp out corruption should be matched up with what some described as 'decent salaries' for lowly paid government officials. "I don't care what any moralist or man of God tells me, but I know that you don't expect a man to be free of corruption when his salary is so meagre but handles millions of daily transactions. Except the government tries to augment the salaries of workers, then we are only fooling ourselves," said a civil servant who prefers anonymity. Another civil servant tells Sierra Eye that despite the fact that he is a  Master's holder he is ashamed to say his salary to his wife; "My colleagues in the private sector earn five times more that what the government pays me and yet every emphasis is now being laid on corruption and they are ignoring a grave problem that is threatening our livelihood, paltry salaries."
