Is the ACC being used as a tool to stifle opposition and other dissent in the state? At the initial setting up of the commission some Sierra Leonean journalists and politicians claim the ACC is nothing but a political tool used to hunt opponents of the government. Victor Foh, now the ruling party secretary for the incumbent All Peoples Congress, said back in 2000; "The ACC is an albatross and a tool to grab those who do not see things the way the government sees them." A signal to that criticism came to the fore back in November 2, 2001; acting on direct orders from then president Kabbah, the ACC began investigating outspoken critic, For di People editor Paul Kamara for tax evasion. Kamara, who has been a blunt critic of the Kabbah government, was eventually cleared of the charges, but the investigation sent a clear message then. Sierra Leone still has a long way to go in its battle against corruption. That officials from the government waging the battle against corruption are themselves corrupt compounds the problem for the ACC investigators, who must depend on the government's good graces to continue their work. As a senior British diplomat stationed in Sierra Leone put it, "A greater percentage of the president's men are from the old block, and this is where corruption breeds in this country. In order for government to win the uphill battle against corruption," he says, "The president must continue to distance himself from the older politicians who have had their hands in every political pile since Sierra Leone gained independence in 1961." Clare Short, former British Development minister, described corruption as endemic and ingrained within both the public and private sectors in Sierra Leone. "It permeates all levels of government and most business transactions. Scandals involving the looting of state coffers and development aid are commonplace." However, African economy expert, Dambisa Moyo in his work titled; Why Foreign Aid Is Hurting Africa, stated that money from rich countries has actually trapped many African nations in a cycle of corruption, slower economic growth and poverty. Cutting off the flow would be far more beneficial, and many times he pointed out when the west talks about corruption in Africa it usually refers to huge  mineral monies or aid monies. Citing World Bank figures he referred to nations such as Rwanda, Somalia, Mali, Chad, Mauritania and Sierra Leone, countries which from 1970 to 2002, have had over 70% of total government spending coming from foreign aid but still struggling with problems such as corruption that hampers growth. So is there the feeling within the ruling elite that aid money is just money from abroad and not the people's money? In a presentation titled GOVERNANCE, DEMOCRACY AND DEVELOPMENT IN AFRICA: A CULTURAL APPROACH, presented by: The Ghana Center for Democratic Development (CDD-Ghana) corruption is identified as a universal problem, with complex causes. "Its net effect is commonly regarded as negative for all societies, especially developing countries. It leads to economic inefficiencies; distorts development; inhibits long-term foreign and domestic investments; misallocates talents to rent seeking and away from productive activities; induces wrong sectoral priorities and technological choices." What are the solutions to corruption in our societies? The paper states that there should be a creation and sustenance of a low corruption environment, and it requires the establishment of effective mechanisms of discovery and punishment. An institutional framework conducive to fighting corruption must promote easy oversight, assessment of wrongdoing and punishment for those convicted of wrongdoing. Equally important, the institutions established to oversee, expose and punish corruption must be insulated from the very actors they are supposed to be controlling (Diamond 1998). "Here too, we must build institutions for preventing, detecting and punishing corruption instead of relying on individual morality," it  concluded. As challenging as the fight against corruption may be, despite all the impediments faced by the ACC in Sierra Leone, there has been some positive features that could be signs that all is not lost. Twenty-seven public officials have been indicted for corruption in the past year or so, including judges and the heads of the post office and the national broadcasting service.  The number of prosecutions has soared from nine in 2008 to 29 in 2009. The ACC has clawed back around 3 billion leones in assets from those found guilty of corruption. Such changes brought some joy to now resigned Abdul Tejan-Cole who said they have given the ACC 'more teeth'. This will tempt one to further ask the question, do we need  more reform in the state to enhance the fight against corruption. Because it is certain that no matter how capable and robust an ACC commissioner is, there are extra dynamics to ensure success in the fight against graft in Sierra Leone. In a November 2009 article in the Economist Magazine titled, Sierra Leone's corruption problem, A mortal enemy, the ACC was praised for its lead on a very tough challenge in fighting corruption in Sierra Leone as indicated in the annual Corruption Perceptions Index by Transparency International, a Berlin-based lobby, which showed Sierra Leone steadily climbing up the rankings, albeit only to number 146 out of the 180 countries surveyed. The magazine hailed Abdul Tejan-Cole for introducing a system whereby every public official must declare all his or her assets and also for persuading parliament to change the law governing the ACC's operation in the ACC Act of 2008. Abdul Tejan-Cole clearly set a legacy at the ACC that can be hard to emulate, he was like a radical outsider calling for what many in state establishments will see as drastic measures. He called for the repeal of the criminal and seditious libel laws; he also called for the enactment of an access to information act among others. Although he did not clearly state any reason for his resignation, it was very clear for all to see that Abdul Tejan-Cole, a man who had a very strict disciplinary record was certainly put off by political pressures from some sacred cows. But whosoever will replace him have a very huge task to carry on, it is clear for all to see now that the ACC position is one of the most challenging assignments in the land.

TITLE: APC - the Inconsistency in Fighting Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); POLITICS (72%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (72%); FISHERIES ADMINISTRATION (71%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (71%); NATURAL RESOURCES (71%); FISHERIES (68%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Corruption is a social enemy that is responsible for the backwardness of Sierra Leone. Each and every Sierra Leonean has suffered one way or the other from the ills corruption. The 11-year rebel war in the country was largely as a result of this social ill referred to as corruption. With the help of the TRC report after the war, there was a general call to set up a commission to champion the fight against graft. One would therefore commend the SLPP government under the able leadership of Alhaji Dr. Ahmad Tejan Kabbah for setting up the Anti-Corruption Commission, an independent body to fight this social enemy, though it was not given much power. When Ernest Bai Koroma assumed power in 2007, he declared zero tolerance for corruption. In view of this, he helped to strengthen the Anti-Corruption Commission by giving it prosecutorial powers. Initially some public officials, including the former Health minister, were investigated, prosecuted, and convicted by the Anti-Corruption Commission. This however earned President Koroma praise in and outside the country. But the case of the former Minister of Fisheries and Marine Resources has started raising many questions in the minds of Sierra Leoneans as to how consistent is the APC government to fighting corruption. The resignation of the Anti-Corruption Commissioner, Abdul Tejan-Cole as a result of alleged government interference into the case of Haja Afsatu Kabba is indeed a slap in the face of the APC government. This has somehow justified suggestion by some sections of the media that Afsatu Kabba is a sacred cow and a strong member of the APC who can commit the worst crime and get away with it. Why is it that the APC youth leader is in solidarity with Afsatu Kabba while being tried in the court? One would conclude that he is being sent under the guise of government solidarity. One thing I want the APC government to realize is that they are meddling with the people's power and Sierra Leoneans are no longer prepared to accept any mess from politicians. A source from the Anti-Corruption Commission told this writer that the APC government tried in vain to influence the Commissioner not to charge the case of Afsatu Kabba to court. After failing to influence the Commissioner and the case being charged to court, government was said to have spoon fed some political stooges like the APC youth leader and other mediocre to stage a riot while the case was in progress. It is indeed a big disappointment to the expectations of the people who were hoping the APC would allow the Commission to operate independently so as to nip corruption in the bud. Again, it was revealed that the APC government had called on the Anti-Corruption Commission to relax the procurement law so as to allow them dupe the people of their resources. This is a clear indication that the APC wants to accumulate money for the 2012 elections, which they think perhaps would not go in their favour. Mind you, the APC government must have learnt lessons from the 2007 election when the people played the watermelon politics by receiving money from Berewa and then refusing to cast their votes for him. I'll make bold to tell the APC government that they would be treated likewise if they fail to do what the people want. The APC government should realize that 'what goes around comes around'. Finally, am appealing to the President for him to continue as he started because the whole world is looking forward to him for credible governance.

TITLE: Tejan-Cole's Resignation And the Complexities of Corruption in Sierra Leone [opinion]

TITLE: Greaves - "Corruption a Big Problem "
COUNTRY: LIBERIA (94%); SIERRA LEONE (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); BRAZIL (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (74%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (90%); IRON MINING (89%); INTERVIEWS (89%); OILSEED PROCESSING (86%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); PETROLEUM REFINERIES (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); NATURAL RESOURCES (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); CONFLICT MINERALS (74%); TREASON (72%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (71%); DIAMOND MARKETS (69%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (69%); MISC OILSEED PROCESSING (68%); RUBBER & SILICONE (68%); REBELLIONS & INSURGENCIES (67%); CHILD SOLDIERS (66%); WAR CRIMES (66%); EXPORT TRADE (65%); IRON & STEEL MILLS (62%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The dismissed Managing Director of the Liberia Petroleum Refining Corporation (LPRC), Mr. Harry A. Greaves, Jr., has now conceded that "corruption is a big problem" in the government hindering development. Mr. Greaves, who rejected similar allegations from the UN Panel of Experts in the past, and suggested that Auditor General John Morlu be charged with treason for reaching similar conclusions, in an interview with Reuters, said Liberia at this moment is not an investor friendly country. "This is not a very investor-friendly place," said Harry Greaves, a local businessman and former head of the national petroleum refinery. "The legal system is tough, laws are too favourable to debtors, people in government constantly harass business, doing all kinds of inspections. Corruption is a big problem," he told Reuters. In its analysis 'Liberia faces hurdles on road to prosperity', Reuters observed: Mining and agriculture companies are preparing to pour billions of dollars into Liberia, but the battle-scarred nation faces big hurdles if it is to turn these investments into a robust post-war recovery. After 15 years of near constant conflict that killed tens of thousands and left its infrastructure in tatters by the time it ended in 2003, the small West African nation is opening up to foreign investment, especially into its rich iron ore deposits. Since coming to power in 2006, President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has tried to restore stability and woo investors to a country that was more often associated with child soldiers and conflict diamonds than billion dollar projects. "This country is so rich," national investment commission chairman Richard Tolbert told Reuters in an interview. "Iron ore, gold, diamonds, rubber, coffee, cocoa, timber, oil palm. We've got the land, labour and natural resources. We need the finance, knowhow and access to markets. Better jump on this band wagon, because it's moving fast." Top steelmaker ArcelorMittal   have large concessions in Liberia, as does Russia's Severstal . Officials are in talks with Brazilian miner Vale  , the world's biggest iron ore producer. The largest single investment in the country is China Union's $2.6 billion iron ore project, which officially opened towards the end of last month. Asian palm oil companies are seeking plantation concessions in the well watered countryside. Production of rubber, still Liberia's biggest export until iron gets underway, is on the rise. Such things were unthinkable during war-wracked reign of former President Charles Taylor, ousted by rebels in 2003, and now on trial for war crimes in neighbouring Sierra Leone. The numbers look impressive, but transforming Liberia from a broken into a prosperous nation is a huge task. Around three quarters of Liberia's 3.5 million people are unemployed, Tolbert said, and the country is heavily dependent on donor aid to help run almost every aspect of government. Liberia hosts the second largest U.N. peacekeeping mission in Africa, after Democratic Republic of the Congo. U.N. police vehicles ply the streets of Monrovia on routine patrols for which Liberian police lack the resources. Outside the capital, warlords are kept at bay largely by U.N. troops. Diplomats say the mission even helps draft legislation. Few jobs will be created by the iron ore projects. Tolbert estimates each project will create between 2,000 and 3,000 direct jobs, though farming would have more of an impact on employment: a palm oil project signed with Sime Darby will bring 30,000 jobs. Another being negotiated with Indonesia's Golden Agri Resources  would create 40,000. While mining giants have been welcomed, smaller businesses complain of red tape, high taxes, corruption and harassment. Officials say efforts have been made to tackle this, pointing out that registering a business now takes 27 days, instead of 90, and that the nation has been praised by the World Bank for its reforms, moving it up the ease of doing business index to 149th this year from 173rd in 2008. But poor roads and power shortages remain a big deterrent. "The biggest challenge we have is the cost of electricity, which has made people uncomfortable about business here," Deputy Commerce Minister Frederick Norkeh told Reuters. "But still, the potential is high. We're one of the last frontier markets."

TITLE: PIN Vows to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); RELIGION (90%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (90%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (89%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); FAITH BASED SCHOOLS (77%); PROTESTANTS & PROTESTANTISM (77%); VIRUSES (70%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: A local non-governmental organization known as Peace Interaction Network (PIN) yesterday launched its campaign to fight corruption in the Liberian society. The program which was held on the campus of the United Methodist University (UMU) was held under the theme: "Using the bottom to the level approach in the fight against corruption". Speaking at the occasion, former Information Minister Rev. Dr. Lawrence Bropleh encouraged students of the school to remain steadfast in the fight against corruption. Dr. Bropleh said corruption is a disease in our society that needs to be eradicated by all cost. According to him, corruption started in Liberia before its birth in 1847 Speaking further, Dr. Bropleh said corruption can be seen in every fabric of the society, including the religious communities. He named commercial honoring programs, Father of the Year, Mother of the Year, Special Brother and Sister that can always take place in religious institutions as areas where religious people carry out corruption. He observed that segregation in families is also a recipe for corruption. Also speaking at the program, the Chairperson of the Liberia Anti Corruption Commission (LACC), Cllr. Frances Johnson-Morris warned against demonizing people who are helping to fight corruption. Cllr. Johnson-Morris said the fight against corruption must be done with justice, equality and fairness without favor. She said despite the LACC's determination to fight corruption, both the Judiciary and Legislative Branches are not cooperating, as evidenced by their failure to declare their assets. She however used the occasion to admonish the student body to encourage their respective lawmakers to declare their assets. For his part, PIN Executive Director, Mr. Emmanuel Gonquoi lauded the students for their participation and promised to extend similar program to every school in the country. He told the well attended gathering that PIN will love to partner with the LACC in the fight against corruption owing to the fact that corruption is deadly virus.

TITLE: Namugongo Guilty On Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); MAGISTRATES (90%); SENTENCING (90%); TESTIMONY (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (89%); FINES & PENALTIES (89%); LICENSES & PERMITS (88%); GAMING (88%); ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENTS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TOURISM DEVELOPMENT (78%); TOURISM (78%); JAIL SENTENCING (77%); WITNESSES (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); CRIMINAL FINES (77%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (77%); LAWYERS (74%); ARRESTS (72%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (71%); DOCUMENTARY FILMS (61%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: FORMER Ministry of Environment and Tourism official Sackey Namugongo became the most high-profile victim of the Anti-Corruption Act to date on Friday, when he was convicted in the Windhoek Regional Court on 19 counts of corruption. At the age of 58, Namugongo should be sent to prison for ten years, Deputy Prosecutor General Orben Sibeya suggested to Magistrate Sarel Jacobs after the magistrate had convicted Namugongo on almost half of the 40 charges he faced. Defence counsel Titus Mbaeva suggested Namugongo should be sentenced to pay a fine. As for Namugongo himself, he continued to insist he was an innocent man when he got his turn to testify in mitigation of sentence. "I did not receive money from them," he said, referring to the string of witnesses who told the court they paid tens of thousands of dollars to him for what they thought would be gambling house licences that would be issued to them. "I did not commit these crimes," Namugongo added. Earlier in his testimony he told the court he did not have words to describe the effect the case in which he has been facing charges since his arrest in mid-September 2006 has been having on him. "I am rejected, I am condemned, and I live in isolation," he told the court. Namugongo also asked the court to sentence him to pay a fine, rather than send him straight to prison. Although he does not have money available to pay a fine with, he is confident that he would be able to raise funds from friends, relatives and comrades, Namugongo said. Magistrate Jacobs postponed the sentencing to June 11. Namugongo pleaded not guilty to 20 counts of corruption and 20 charges of fraud when his trial started on July 1 2008. He was accused of having corruptly received hundreds of thousands of Namibia dollars from people who wanted to apply for gambling house licences that would allow them to operate gambling machines in Namibia. It was alleged that Namugongo, who at the time was the Deputy Director of Gambling, Casinos and Lotteries in the Ministry of Environment and Tourism, received the money from gambling house licence applicants from March to September 2006. This allegedly took place while a freeze on the issuing of such licences was in place. The moratorium has been in force since 1997. In the course of the trial, 17 of these applicants told the court they handed over supposed licence application fees to Namugongo either in cash, or by making deposits into his bank account. Namugongo pocketed a total of N$332 500 in this way, the court heard. In his own testimony Namugongo however denied having received most of these payments. He denied he received any of the cash payments, and only admitted having received three payments, totalling N$43 000, for which documentary proof existed. This money, which was deposited into his bank account, was lent to him, Namugongo claimed. After all of the evidence in the trial had been placed before the court, Sibeya and Mbaeva agreed that the fraud charges in essence were a duplication of the corruption charges. This led to Namugongo's acquittal on all of the counts of fraud. The prosecution did not present evidence on one of the corruption charges, leading to Namugongo's acquittal on that charge as well. Magistrate Jacobs rejected Namugongo's denial that he received cash payments from State witnesses as "inherently false". On his claims that the money paid into his bank account were loans from friends who were assisting him in a time of financial need, the magistrate commented: "The court can find no reason why these good people who voluntarily assisted accused when he needed them will now try to mislead the court to believe that the payments made were for gambling house licences if it were indeed intended for the purposes as explained by the accused." The magistrate found that Namugongo acted corruptly when he received applications for gambling house licences, issued acknowledgement letters to the applicants and received payments from them while a moratorium on the issuing of licences was in place. Namugongo is remaining free on bail until he is sentenced.

TITLE: Corruption Remains Root of Business Evil
SUBJECT: POLLS & SURVEYS (92%); EXECUTIVES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); STOCK EXCHANGES (72%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: "CORRUPTION needs to be addressed - it is overshadowing every deal." This quote, by one of the 60 business executives who participated in the first Old Mutual Namibia/Namibian Stock Exchange's Executive Opinion Survey, sums up the local perception of corruption. Nearly 60 per cent of the respondents view corruption as a serious problem, while about 18 per cent regard it as a "very" serious problem. A far greater number, 72 per cent, think corruption is on the increase. Ten per cent believe it is increasing fast. "Overall the perception is that the Anti-Corruption Commission has not succeeded in reducing corruption in the country: only 12 respondents rate it as having done a good job and only one a very good job," the survey concludes. In contrast, 34 per cent said the ACC is doing a "poor" job, while 37 per cent said it is "average". Seven per cent slammed the ACC's performance as "very poor". "The ACC seems to have solved a very low percentage of cases," the survey quotes another executive. According to the 2009 survey, released last Thursday, a large number of executives have had direct experience of corruption. The tender process is central to the problem. "The overall perception of the tender process is fairly negative with a significant majority of respondents believing that the tender process is only sometimes fair and transparent," the survey states. About 43 per cent of the respondents experienced corruption "a few times" in 2009, while 11 per cent encountered it "often" during the year.

TITLE: Ellen Creates New Battle Front on Corruption - Ministers Drawn in
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (89%); ETHICS (78%); US PRESIDENTS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); DISMISSALS (72%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The battle against corruption in Liberia has continued unabated with President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf ordering members of her cabinet to become more assertive in dealing with corruption and other problems in their respective ministries. In her inaugural address on January 16, 2006, President Sirleaf declared corruption as a public enemy number one of the government of Liberia. The battle to eradicate corruption has continued, with more people still adamant and deeply involved in the practice. But, speaking at a special cabinet meeting Friday following her return from meeting with President Barack Obama in the United States, President Sirleaf said, "people who have responsibilities should carry out their responsibilities, for if they don't carry them out, they sabotage the whole government." According to Dr. Momo Rogers, Director General of the Cabinet, President Sirleaf urged ministers to take the "hard decisions" necessary to root out corruption in government. She ordered that "When you find corrupt individuals in your ministries, you should fire them em-masse," She said this would change public perception that the government does not have the "political will" to act against corruption. The Liberian leader told members of the cabinet that from now on, when she fires any government official, she will tell the public exactly the reason for which the person is being fired rather than letting the Ministry of Justice determine later what the person is guilty of. She raised qualms with the court system, describing it as very slow and has asked the Ministry of Justice to know whether there was any way to speed up cases of corruption already at the courts without infringing on the rights of the individuals involved in terms of their innocence or guilt. President Sirleaf said the Ministry of Justice has to win more cases to show that the government is serious about fighting fraud and corruption. The government has demonstrated over the past four years its commitment to fighting corruption by putting in place many initiatives, including the GAC and LACC. These measures against corruption are ongoing as evident by the one-day Ethical Leadership Interactive Forum beginning Tuesday, June 8, hosted by the Civil Service Agency (CSA), for members of the Cabinet and selected heads of Government Agencies and Commissions, at the Robert L. Johnson Kendeja Resort.

TITLE: U.S.$10,000 Corruption Scheme Bursts at MOF-Ngafuan - More 'Crocodiles' at Finance
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); ARRESTS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); TAX AUTHORITIES (89%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (89%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (89%); TAXES & TAXATION (89%); NATIONAL SECURITY (89%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (77%); TAX LAW (76%); EVIDENCE (63%); PRESS CONFERENCES (57%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Three officials of the Ministry of Finance are in the custody of the National Security Agency (NSA) after they were caught red-handed in the act of corruption I the tone of US$10,000, Finance Minister Augustine Kpehe Ngafuan told a news conference in Monrovia yesterday. Minister Ngafuan said the three officials (Mr. Dawo Z. Morris, Principal Director Large Tax Division, Madam Brenda Dahn Caine Tax Clearance Supervisor and Mr. Kollie Dougba, Tax Analyst) were arrested in a corruption syndicate that would have robbed the state coffer of at least US$200,000. The disappointed said the individuals, who are among the highest paid staff of the Ministry based on their strategic functions, demanded and accepted a bribe of US$10,000 to perform their official duties, from the Cocopa Rubber Plantation in Nimba County. "They are undergoing investigations for bribery and economic sabotage and will be dumped out of the ministry to face the law for their action, Ngafuan said. The Finance Minister related that circumstances leading to the arrest began on Friday, June 4, when he was contacted by a senior official of the Cocopa Rubber Plantation that the arrested employees of the Ministry of Finance were soliciting a US$10,000 bribe in exchange for a downward adjustment of Cocopa's "tax liability" from US$229,394.21 to US$25,989. "My initial reaction" Minister Ngafuan said, "was that of consternation and the urge to take immediate drastic actions against those concerned. However, considering previous incidents wherein individuals we dismissed for criminal behaviors obtained security clearances and rulings compelling us to reinstate them for lack of sufficient evidence, I had second thoughts and opted for a situation wherein they will be booked red-handed." He said he therefore suggested to the Cocopa official for them to enlist the expertise of the National Security Agency as part of a "sting operation". The company, through its Chief Accountant and the Superintendent, and, with the prior understanding and endorsement of the NSA, agreed to provide the US$10,000 to facilitate the transaction, he explained. Upon being told that the company was prepared to pay the bribe, Mr. Morris, Madam Cain and Mr. Dogba reduced the tax penalty from $229,394.21 to $25,989 at the detriment of the Liberian government and people. "Having been informed that the US$10,000 was ready for payment, Mr. Dawo Morris suggested that the two parties meet in one of the bathrooms on the 3rd Floor of the Ministry of Finance. The bathroom is located in an area that was formerly used by the Large Tax Division, but is currently undergoing renovation. Unlike other parts of the MOF Building this area is relatively isolated and free of human traffic," the Minister stated. The Minister said at the appointed moment, Mr. Morris personally appeared and received the amount of US$10,000 which he put into the right front pocket of his trousers, and in what amounts to "criminal kindness", Morris returned US$500 to the company representatives (NSA operative) as a goodwill token for paying the requested amount. The company representative left and in a very short space of time, as pre-arranged with the NSA, Mr. Morris was arrested by security officers who had been given prior tip-off of the entire operation. Brenda Dahn Caine and Kollie Dougba were later arrested on the premises of the Ministry of Finance. "I am awaiting the full and official report from the National Security Agency, which will lead to the dismissal and/or contract termination of the three individuals involved pending prosecution," the saddened Minister vowed. Minister told journalists that the solicitation of bribe and the arrested of those involved have both its positive and negative dimensions. On the positive side, he said, it once again reaffirms the stance of his administration that he will not tolerate corruption or anybody who acts corruptly at the Ministry of Finance. Ngafuan: "This is the vow I made when I took over the administration of this Ministry almost two years ago. And as I said then, and I will reaffirm here, the Ministry of Finance I was inheriting was like a river of crocodiles that appeared calm on the surface but very dangerous underneath." "So I promised that I would jar the river so that the crocodiles could be exposed and fearlessly confronted. This has been my mission since, and this will continue to be my mission, no matter how powerful the crocodiles are," the Minister noted. The Minister reaffirmed that he will fight fiercely and relentlessly to make the Ministry of Finance increasingly uninhabitable for these beastly and dangerous creatures. "The controls we are putting into place and our openness in dealing with tax payers have brought up these three culprits from the deep river of bribery." He said another positive note is that the incident shows what happens when businesses and other taxpayers are willing to cooperate in the fight against corruption and graft. "The three tax collectors would not have been caught, maybe not so soon, if Cocopa Management had succumbed to these unwholesome advances from staff of the Ministry of Finance." Instead, he said, they acted like good corporate citizen and reported the matter, not because they wanted their tax penalty waived, but because they wanted to ensure that whatever they paid was just and fair. "I therefore call on all persons and business entities to resist any staff and/or official of the Ministry of Finance who demand bribe as a condition for executing his/her duty, whether at the ports, at the border posts, in their offices or anywhere else," Minister Ngafuan pleaded. The negative dimension of the development, Mr. Ngafuan explained is the fact that the individuals involved were among the well remunerated in order to bolster their ability to withstand such temptations. "Beside" Ngafuan went on, "Mr. Dawo Morris was competitively recruited as Tier 1 Senior Executive Service (SES) person and assigned to the Ministry of Finance, given his credentials which included among other things, being one of the authors of the Liberia Revenue Code of 2000 and a university lecture in taxation. That he could be involved in such a scandal is very disappointing, to say the least." We will continue to take a host of measures to prevent fraud.... If I receive credible information that any of my employees, Director, Assistant Ministers and Deputy Ministers are involved in corrupt behavior, I will take appropriate action," the Minister vowed and said: "Similarly, if anyone has any information of my involvement in corrupt practices, please do not hesitate to inform the Liberia Anti Corruption Commission, the Ministry of Justice and the President." He then announced the following hotlines that can be used by anybody who possesses information on the untoward behavior of the Ministry of Finance staff.: 02 42 0000 1 - Direct line to the Office of the Minister of Finance, 06 808 654 and 06808655.

TITLE: Chitungwiza Councillors Cleared of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); DISMISSALS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); CITY LIFE (89%); MAYORS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CITIES (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); ELECTIONS (79%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); APPOINTMENTS (77%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (75%); LAND USE PLANNING (75%); HUMAN RESOURCES (74%); NATURAL RESOURCES (74%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (72%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (69%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (65%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Government has absolved 20 MDC-T Chitungwiza councillors fired by the party for alleged corruption of any wrongdoing. However, one councillor, Tineyi Kanyama, was fired for abuse of office. The two Zanu-PF councillors, Darlington Nota and Godwell Mafuratidze, who are part of the council were also cleared. Government also cleared special interest councillors Brighton Chirongwe and Tichaona Chapfika. Kanyama joins two others_ former mayor Israel Marange and Clr Godfrey Mangoma -- who were fired by Government on corruption charges. The Government's decision to clear the councillors follows an investigation into the operations of the council by a committee headed by the Local Government, Rural and Urban Development director of human resources Ms Erica Jones. Local Government, Rural and Urban Development Minister Ignatius Chombo wrote to Kanyama informing him of the decision yesterday. Kanyama was also reported to the police for using fake documents to acquire three stands. "Following an investigation team appointed by the minister . . . you were found guilty of abusing the office when you used non-existent companies and false bank statements in the process of acquiring stands," he said. Minister Chombo said Kanyama ceased to be a councillor in the interest of "promoting good corporate governance and protection of public interests". "You shall forthwith cease to be a councillor. Your council should advise the Zimbabwe Electoral Commission of the vacancy," he said. However, Kanyama -- who was fired by the party together with others early this year -- said he was never given an opportunity to defend himself. "I feel the minister should have offered me a chance to defend myself. I believe he was under pressure to fire me," he said. However, he could not name the people after his head. The report by Ms Jones was presented to Minister Chombo yesterday after a meeting attended by the municipality's senior managers and councillors. The investigation team delved into issues of land allocation, the three stands acquired by Kanyama and issues of corporate governance. Observers, however, said the decision by MDC-T to fire the Chitungwiza councillors on allegations of corruption were just a flimsy cover-up after the councillors defied a directive to elect senior party functionary Dr Vincent Gwaradzimba as mayor to replace Marange. However, the report makes scathing remarks on the management of land and human resources. Ms Jones said the administration of land in the municipality was "shambolic" and no systems were in place to verify the amount of land owned by the council. "Our findings were that land management in Chitungwiza is an administrative shamble with no proper systems in place. The manual for management of urban State land was never used," she said. She said the municipality's finances were in bad shape, describing the situation as "horrific". Ms Jones said statutory remittances to such bodies as the National Social Security Authority, the Zimbabwe Revenue Authority and the Local Authorities Pension Fund dues were not paid. "The so-called income-generating projects are loss-making ventures with ratepayers subsidising liquor outlets," she said. Ms Jones said the wage bill was chewing up to 70 percent of the council's revenue implying only a little went into service delivery. Meanwhile, some councillors have confirmed that the MDC-T has started moves to reinstate them with a view of following proper procedures in dismissing them. The party fired the councillors without hearing their side of the story, a move viewed as undemocratic. Recently, the MDC-T spokesperson Mr Nelson Chamisa refuted the reports. "We are a party of excellence and our position to fire them stands," he said.

TITLE: Cental Slams Govt War on Corruption - Takes Ellen to Task on Promise
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (85%); HISTORY (78%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); WAR & CONFLICT (78%); AUDITS (78%); EXECUTIVES (77%); PRESS CONFERENCES (76%); POLITICS (75%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (75%); US PRESIDENTS (72%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (64%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (64%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Center for Transparency and Accountability in Liberia (Cental) has criticized the Liberian Government's professed war on corruption claiming that the menace of "corruption remains rife and arguably on the increase" in the country. The Executive Director of Cental (the local contact group of Transparency International) told a news conference yesterday (June 10) in Monrovia that the government has failed to clamp down hard on corrupt officials, who are living better lives, while majority of the people live in looming poverty. Mr. Thomas Doe Nah claimed that corruption has become pervasive in the country, enveloping the three branches of government, and is having a negative impact on the country's poverty reduction strategy: the government's blue print for the country's development and the thinning of acute poverty, which stands at nearly 70 percent. The government has repeatedly said it is "making gains" in the war on corruption, but has admitted that there are challenges. President Sirleaf has frequently admitted that corruption, which she declared 'Public Enemy Number One' during her inaugural address on January 16, 2006, remains a "serious challenge" to her administration, because the vice is 'endemic, systemic and culturally rooted'. This week she announced new measures to deal with corruption and corrupt officials in government. The Liberian leader, fresh from the U.S. where she received praises from President Obama, ordered cabinet ministers and top-level government officials to fire anyone engaged in acts of corruption under their noses. In the past she had asked government officials implicated in corruption to honorably resign without telling the public what actually happened, but warned on Monday that the days of such diplomacy in the war on corruption were over. More than 60 corruption cases are warehoused at the Ministry of Justice pending investigation since last year, the President has said, but nothing has been heard about those cases, opposition politicians and critics say. Finance Minister Augustine K. Ngafuan argues that the too many noise about corruption in government indicates that the "fight is succeeding", because "people have the opportunity to see and talk about it" -- a strange phenomenal in the country's history. But Cental said its interest is heightened by the apparent lack of political will by the President and other public officials in the three branches of government to take action that will halt the wastage of scarce state resources and checkmate blatant acts of corruption in the public sectors. "CENTAL is convinced that despite the promulgation of laws, formation and rejuvenation of agencies to fight corruption, the menace corruption remains rife and arguably on the increase. This is the case because the government is refusing to operationalize laws and exhibit the political will require to address substantive issues raised in media reports and the findings of GAC [General Auditing Commission] audit reports, as well as deal sufficiently with corrupt officials at the national and local levels of government," Mr. Nah said in his seven-page press statement. There are so many Liberian living very diligently within the means and bounds of their salaries while other Liberians who purport to be sacrificing for their country are corrupt and intent on undermining systems and keeping the rest of the people in poverty, the Cental boss alleged. "We cannot be serious about poverty reduction when corruption pervades all the projects that we brag about accomplishments to improve the livelihood of the people at the national and sub-national levels," Mr. Nah noted. He said words, rhetoric and meeting the conditionalities of multilateral institutions and foreign governments are insufficient to meet head on the ingrained tendency to commit corruption in Liberia. "What is required is concrete and consistent action." He said allowing corrupt and dismissible officials of government to resign honorably is also not responsive to fighting corruption, suggesting, "What is needed and or expected include investigation, prosecution and punitive actions when officials are found culpable." The local civic anti-corruption organization boss asserted that the fight against corruption in Liberia is more than just passing laws. "It is more than dismissal or just asking people to resign. The fight is really about robust implementation of laws, so that corrupters are deterred by the action we take - people have to be investigated, prosecuted and if found guilty locked up and made to restitute public funds." Mr. Nah highlighted and criticized the criticized the feeble role each of the three branches of government, the GAC, the Liberia Anti-Corruption Commission, the Public Procurement and Concession Commission and the private sectors have played in the fifth against corruption. He claimed that Legislators as representatives of the people who should be the last ones to betray the trust of the people have already done so. He said the Legislature as the branch of government with direct oversight of the GAC has a responsibility to ensure that the GAC is supported, monitored and held to perform its role, but has failed. "To date," he said, "the legislature has failed to respond substantively to the numerous issues raised in audit reports released by the GAC. We are alarmed by the indifference shown by the National Legislature, which has oversight of the GAC to act on these reports." Cental said "the National Legislature's flagrant failure to opine on the GAC reports has allowed auditees to harangue spinelessly in a bid to discredit the GAC while they festoon in all the trappings of their corrupt acts." On the Executive, Mr. Nan evoked President Sirleaf's January 16, 2006 robust statement to defeat corruption and noted that "No President in our history has spoken so forcefully about the need to fight corruption and reduce the power of the presidency." "CENTAL," stressed Nah, "believes that the President needs to do and translate those forcefully spoken words in to substantive deeds. She has caressed corruption and dwelled on symbolic posturing and rhetoric why failing to deal substantively with corruption." He claimed that President Sirleaf "has failed to wage the war against corruption regardless of where it exists, or by whom it is practiced." "Selective justice and the failure to act on the many substantive issues raised in audit reports undermine the fight against corruption and the poverty reduction strategic," the Cental chief said. Awarding a plus to GAC as a government institution in the fight of corruption, Cental admonished that Commission to that it and its staff are not above reproach and, like every other institution in post war Liberia, suffer from capacity constraints and are prone to errors in their work. He said despite its good work, GAC must be open to criticism because as much as it wants to interact with the public and ensure the passage of judgment on its reports, then findings and recommendations contained therein would be challenged. "Therefore, it is only rational that the GAC responds professionally to counter opinions to its audit findings and refrain from wars in the press that undermine its professional disposition." Central challenges the Anti Corruption Commission to be forceful and recommended reduction in the number of commission from five to three. The LACC is more than two years old and with the strong mandate enshrined in its Act of creation it has to be more proactive in arresting the surge of corruption in Liberia, Nah asserted. "CENTAL believes that the upkeep of five commissioners is costly and an amendment of the LACC Act to reduce the commissioners to three and funds channeled to more investigation and prosecution as required," the organization suggested. He described the Ministry of Justice as playing a meaning less role in the fight against corruption and painted the judicial system as itself being a bastion of fraud. Cental Boss: "The Ministry of Justice and the Judiciary have distressingly failed to support the fight against corruption. The Ministry of Justice has shown lack of spine in the prosecution of officials involved in corruption. It appears that the Ministry lacks independence, direction and operates on presidential orders." He alleged that bribery in the courts is pervasive and lawyers without integrity and professional restrain bid for justice by compromising jurors, sheriffs and other courts officials.

TITLE: Fight Against Corruption to Bring in Private Sector, NGOs
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (91%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); INTERVIEWS (88%) Rwanda; NGOs and Civil Society; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Office of the Ombudsman has revealed that a new policy is being drawn to incorporate all Non Governmental Organisations and the private sector in the campaign against corruption. In an interview with The New Times, the Deputy Ombudsman, Augustine Nzindukiyimana, revealed that the new policy will emphasize that civil society organisations, the private sector and all government institutions take part in the campaign. "In this new anticorruption policy, we are going to put much emphasis on NGOs and the private sector to get involved in fighting against corruption, because that is when we shall be able to combat it effectively and efficiently" Nzindukiyimana said. He said that the new policy will require civil society and the private sector to report any case of corruption that they come across. Nzindukiyimana revealed that cases of corruption reduced this year compared to the previous years; however he added that they still have a long way to go.

TITLE: Clash over USAID Boss' Obama Anti-Corruption Directive
COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); LIBERIA (93%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); AFRICA (76%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); US PRESIDENTS (91%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2012 (90%); US PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES 2008 (90%) Liberia; United States, Canada and Africa; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Following USAID chief Ms. Pamela White's comments that a key agenda item during the recent meeting between President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and US President Barack Obama was the latter's concern over spiralling corruption in Liberia and the need to fight it, the Ministry of Information has taken an exception, saying the only spokesperson for America here is its ambassador. "At no time has President Obama or the US government authorized this government to strengthen its fight against corruption," Deputy Information Minister Norris Tweh said Thursday. The USAID director, during a program last week, said corruption was a key agenda when President Sirleaf met the American President earlier this month. She revealed that the United States Government urged President Sirleaf to pay "tremendous" amount of attention to fighting corruption. The US official further said that President Sirleaf was instructed to intensify her fight on corruption because it was on everybody's "tongue and mind."

TITLE: Margai Cheshire Home Management Accused of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); FAMILY (87%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (78%); CHARITIES (72%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (72%); SCHOOL PRINCIPALS (70%); EDUCATION ADMINISTRATION (70%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (50%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Some in-service users and staff of the Sir Milton Margai Cheshire Home in Bo have accused the home's management of corruption. The aggrieved members who preferred to be anonymous confided in Concord Times that the vehicle which was donated by the Leonard Cheshire International was presently being used by the management of the home for personal activities. The said vehicle, according to them, was donated purposely to transport in-service users to and from their various schools and for the day-to-day activities of the home and not for personal use, adding, "The vehicle should be used for eight years." "Sometime in 2006, the vehicle was used by the chairman to travel to Bo on his private business. The vehicle was involved in a serious accident between Moyamba Junction and Mile 91 and that left it beyond repairs. The home was without a vehicle from 2006 to 2009," one of them alleged. He said the home which was built by government has now been converted into a dwelling house by the families of the home's mother, Janet Massaquoi Damba and secretary, Aprilus Damba. "We are not benefiting from the Le20 million subvention from government, donations from charitable organizations in the form of cash and food. The home mother, secretary and their family members benefit from it," they claimed. The aggrieved members also alleged that even the food prepared for them at the home was not fit for human consumption. They called on the government to immediately intervene and investigate the current management of the home, stating, "We want the entire management of the home to be repalced." When contacted, home secretary, Aprilus Damba said the management was not in any corrupt practice as being alleged by the in-service users and staff. "The home management comprises of the ministry of social welfare, education, agriculture and head teachers among others. Decisions are taken by the management of the home and not by an individual. The claims made against the management by the in service users and staff are baseless and untrue," he said.

TITLE: Row Over CoD Corruption Motion
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); RESIGNATIONS (88%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (77%); POLITICS (77%); AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS (72%); PRIME MINISTERS (72%); BOYCOTTS (71%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: A MOTION on the state of corruption in Namibia and possible solutions to combat this scourge, introduced by Ben Ulenga of the Congress of Democrats (CoD), angered Swapo Members of Parliament yesterday after Ulenga questioned a former Cabinet Minister's ownership of vehicles. "The Executive of our Government does not even as much as pay lip service to fighting corruption any longer. Full-blooded cronyism has won the day instead. If it were otherwise, why on earth has Peter Tshirumbu-Tsheehama, former Cabinet Minister and former Member of Parliament, been allowed full use of two Government vehicles, a sedan and an off-road 4x4, two full years and more after his resignation from Parliament and the Cabinet?" Ulenga asked when motivating this motion. "The concerned politician resigned from both Parliament and Cabinet on April 8 2008 due to health reasons, and was replaced by another from his political party. "However, up until November 2009 Mr Tsheehama was still in possession of three Government vehicles, the executive Volvo S60, accorded him as part of his remuneration and use as Minister, a Volkswagen Citigolf, and an off-road Toyota Hilux," Ulenga alleged. "In November 2009, one year and six months after the termination of his parliamentary and Cabinet membership, Mr Tsheehama bought the Volvo S60, but retained the full, free use of the two other vehicles 'until further notice'. "It is appreciated that the Honourable Tsheehama has been unwell for some time. Government could however have provided for its Members through proper and lawful coverage without sliding into dubious practices," the CoD president criticised. Presidential Affairs Minister Albert Kawana and Agriculture Minister John Mutorwa reminded Ulenga that people's names may not be mentioned in the House unless the things said about them could be substantiated. Safety and Security Minister Nangolo Mbumba, who now heads the Ministry formerly run by Tshirumbu-Tsheehama, said the use of the vehicle was surely authorised. "He has fought for this country," Mbumba defended the retired minister. Youth, Sport and Culture Minister Kazenambo Kazenambo claimed that "the motion is corrupt, it defies any logic." Prime Minister Nahas Angula said Ulenga's allegations against the retired minister were the "highest form of moral decay". Local and Regional Government Minister Jerry Ekandjo criticised the opposition benches, saying Henk Mudge, president of the Republican Party who is currently boycotting sessions due to opposition parties' election challenge in the courts, was allegedly still making use of his former office in Parliament. This was not right, according to Ekandjo.

TITLE: Global Witness Welcomes Debt Relief -Calls for Financial Control to Prevent Corruption
SUBJECT: PUBLIC DEBT (92%); AUDITS (92%); EXTERNAL DEBT (91%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ENVIRONMENTAL & WILDLIFE ORGANIZATIONS (90%); MINES & MINING (90%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (90%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); EXTERNAL DEBT REDUCTION (90%); CONFLICT MINERALS (89%); EXPORT TRADE (89%); DIAMOND MARKETS (89%); POSTWAR RECONSTRUCTION (89%); NATURAL RESOURCES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (87%); IMPORT TRADE (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); ECONOMIC RECOVERY (76%); ENERGY DEPARTMENTS (76%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (75%); MINING & EXTRACTION SECTOR PERFORMANCE (75%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (74%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (73%); EXPORT CONTROLS (71%); EXPORT & IMPORT LAW (70%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (63%) Liberia; Debt; Crime and Corruption; Human Rights; NGOs and Civil Society
TEXT: The decision by the World Bank to grant debt relief to Liberia under the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative (HIPC) is welcome but more needs to be done to prevent corruption in the post-conflict country, said campaign group Global Witness yesterday. Global Witness is calling upon the Government of Liberia to promote better financial governance by implementing the recommendations of audits carried out as part of the HIPC process. Five key ministries were audited by the Liberian Government's General Auditing Commission as a requirement under HIPC, including the Ministry of Lands, Mines and Energy. Reforms in the latter are particularly important to ensure accountability and transparency in the mining sector. "Being granted debt relief is an important step on Liberia 's road to economic recovery. The next will be to ensure that revenue from Liberia 's natural resources is not lost to corruption and mismanagement but instead helps to fund the country's reconstruction," said Natalie Ashworth , campaigner for Global Witness. An audit of the Ministry of Lands, Mines and Energy reported financial irregularities amounting to over US$2.8 million. It also identified major weaknesses in the internal controls within Liberia 's diamond sector. These threaten the Government's ability to implement the Kimberley Process the international certification scheme to prevent the trade and export of conflict diamonds. The audit recommends that the mining ministry provides receipts for its unexplained expenditures and ensures that the Kimberley Process guidelines are followed. HIPC aims to ensure that no poor country faces a debt burden it cannot manage. The debt relief should free up resources to fund Liberia 's reconstruction effort following years of resource-fuelled conflict. "The Liberian government will only be able to make the most of this debt relief and harness the revenue from the country's natural resources if it is gets serious about stamping out corruption, institutes the necessary financial controls and implements the findings of the audit of the mines ministry," said Ashworth. The Kimberley Process is a rough diamond certification scheme, established in 2003. It brings together governments, industry and civil society, and aims to eradicate the trade in conflict diamonds. Member states are required to pass national legislation and set up an import/export control system. HIPC provides assistance to eligible countries that commit to poverty reduction through policy changes that institute sound economic governance. Global Witness investigates and campaigns to prevent natural resource-related conflict and corruption and associated environmental and human rights abuses.

TITLE: Corruption a Cancerous Growth - Ulenga
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (89%); POLITICS (89%); CANCER (89%); ETHICS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (73%); INVESTIGATIONS (66%); FREEDOM OF INFORMATION (64%); CONTRACT AWARDS (60%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (50%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: THE "cancerous disease" of corruption continued growing and spreading throughout Namibian society despite measures and laws to fight it, opposition leader Ben Ulenga said in the National Assembly on Tuesday. Ulenga of the Congress of Democrats (CoD), who tabled a motion calling for a debate on how to reduce corruption, said President Hifikepunye Pohamba in his inaugural address in March 2005 "declared zero tolerance of corruption and pledged to fight corruption with a sledgehammer", but not much had come of it. "Soon after his speech everyone jumped on the anti-corruption bandwagon and even songs, ditties and lullabies were composed on the anti-corruption theme. In 2006 the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) came into existence, adding to the high expectations the nation had about dealing with the malady," Ulenga said. However, the enthusiasm faded and some people said the Head of State had been too quick to "declare war on a devious foe, against whom he had no dedicated army". Despite the loud anti-corruption noises there was no national strategy against corruption, according to Ulenga. "It became apparent that political leadership in the fight against corruption had been limited to the President's speeches and there was no sufficient political will among the rest of elected political representatives at executive and legislative levels." There had been no enthusiasm among the majority of politicians to adhere to clear-cut codes of conduct, and not much willingness to declare assets publicly, Ulenga charged. "As far as the duties of politicians and especially members of this House are concerned, a holistic legal and legislative approach has been lacking. To date there is no strong, rigorous, comprehensive and complementary legal and legislative reform to fight corruption," he criticised. He said Namibia had no law dealing with the forfeiture of proceeds from corrupt transactions. "Our law does not provide comprehensive protection of whistleblowers, we have no legal mechanism to investigate people with unexplained wealth, individuals who are wealthy beyond their known sources of income. Our regulations concerning the declaration of assets by public individuals are very patchy and ad hoc." 'Tenderpreneurship', being the practice of self-enrichment through obtaining Government tenders via personal, family or political connections in Government, had emerged as possibly the most malignant form of the cancer of corruption, Ulenga added. A rigorous transparency regime was needed including freedom of information laws to publish all short-listed companies and those awarded Government tenders, plus the names of all individuals behind such companies, he proposed. This would assist the anti-corruption authorities as well as the public to access information and act on corrupt practices. It was also time for a law to regulate political funding of parties by business, Ulenga said. He also wants the Office of the President to receive reports on the "so-called political loans given in recent years to businesses," especially in northern Namibia. Another proposal by Ulenga was a law on the forfeiture of the proceeds of corrupt activities. The debate on the motion continues.

TITLE: World Bank Official Wants Corruption Tackled
SUBJECT: INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (92%); BANKING & FINANCE (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (90%); PUBLIC DEBT (78%); EXTERNAL DEBT (78%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (70%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (69%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (66%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (65%) Liberia; International Organizations and Africa; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Liberia's US$4.9 million debt owed various financial institutions, now waived, affected its integrity relative to borrowing,World Bank country Manager Ohene Owusu Nyanin said Wednesday. "The debt was something that did not go well for Liberia's integrity," he said noting its waiver requires celebration but warned, the post HIPC era would be challenging. The World Bank official said government should establish an effective system that will eventually straighten financial and economic governance and tackle corruption head on. He said corruption undermines development and subjects the country to abject poverty with the poor being its prime victims. Mr.Owusu Nyanin made these statements at the official launch of the National Integrity Forum in Monrovia. The Forum, according to its crafters, is designed to support the fight against corruption and establish integrity standards in government and private institution. It consists of both public and private institutions including the General Auditing Commission and the Press Union of Liberia. United States Ambassador Linda Thomas Greenfield has however admonished members not to reduce the organization to an 'empty talk shop" but one that will practically ensure there exist a society and government with high degree of integrity.

TITLE: Salone London Mission Faces Corruption Probe
COUNTRY: SIERRA LEONE (94%); BELGIUM (79%); EUROPE (79%); AFRICA (79%); UNITED STATES (78%)
CITY: LONDON, ENGLAND (94%); BRUSSELS, BELGIUM (79%); CONCORD, NH, USA (78%)
SUBJECT: GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (92%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (78%); SCANDALS (76%) Sierra Leone; Europe and Africa; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The government of Sierra Leone has authorized the Auditor General's office to inspect and probe into the financial records of all foreign missions with the High Commission in London slated as the first to give account of itself. A letter of notification from the Auditor General's office has already been dispatched to the Sierra Leone High Commission in London, informing the mission of the pending investigation. The letter dated 29th June 2010, and which has been made available to Concord Times, states that the "audit inspection" will cover the period from August 2004 to date. Some of the country's embassies and/or high commissions have in the past years been embroiled in massive corruption scandals, the latest being Sierra Leone's embassy in Brussels in which its ambassador, Dr. Christian Kargbo, was at the center of a corruption allegation. "In accordance with the constitutional mandate vested in the Auditor General, Mrs. Lara Taylor-Pearce, Deputy Auditor General has been assigned to undertake an inspection of the Sierra Leone High Commission in London," the letter states. It urges the commission to make available "all accounting records and documents" in its possession "covering the period August 2004 to date for inspection". State House is said to be monitoring the activities of the nation's foreign missions as they continue to be ensnared from one scandal to another, and this could well be a major test case for Mrs. Taylor-Pearce.

TITLE: Corruption Derailing Economic Growth, Development Efforts [opinion]
SUBJECT: ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); ECONOMIC POLICY (90%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (90%); EMERGING MARKETS (88%); BUDGETS (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (76%); IMPORT TRADE (75%); BANKING & FINANCE (73%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (73%); PRIME MINISTERS (71%); IDENTITY SECURITY (69%); OIL & GAS OUTPUT (66%); OIL PRODUCTION STATISTICS (66%); NATIONAL IDENTITY CARDS (64%); MONETARY POLICY (51%) Zimbabwe; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: I DON'T require the services of Paul, the German-based Octopus to point out where corruption is in my beloved nation because we experience it everyday. The issue of corruption has been talked about on countless occasions and in different forums and the general agreement is that it is a fatal cancer, which has to be eradicated once and for all. On its part, Government has gone to the extent of creating an Anti-Corruption Commission to address it. In his maiden address to the August house, Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai promised to open more avenues of accountability by creating a website for interaction with the general public. The Treasury boss, Mr Biti also unequivocally stated in his three-year macro-economic policy and budget framework (2010-2012) that measures to enhance integrity and accountability will be central to the successful implementation of economic reforms during the framework period. What remains in the hearts and minds of the ordinary Zimbabweans is whether Government has enough stamina to tackle and expunge this social ill. We believe corruption tends to diminish the effectiveness of an economic policy by at least 10 percent from what could have been achieved if it was non-existent. Different Fiscal and Monetary policies can be introduced to spur economic growth but corruption reverses these good intentions as stated in those documents. I came face to face with corruption tendencies just few days ago as I was hastening to replace my national identity card to be able to attend the budget presentation. I was asked to fork out US$30 to secure the ID timeously, I defied the culture at the institution until I secured the document without paying anything because that is supposed to be how it was done. I believe that can be a first step in arresting corruption. I also questioned whether those people appreciated the economic meaning of US$30, because it is a significant sum of money. In this article, I will try analysing how the important pillars for economic growth and development are compromised by corruption hence failing to drive the economy in a desired direction. These pillars include but are not limited to education, economic empowerment, political positions, human resource development and even in talent identification and development. Statistically, Nigeria is considered the most corrupt nation in Africa and the costs of this vice to the West African state are there for all to see. Besides contributing about 3 percent to total world oil output there are constant queues for fuel, most of the refinery plants are outside their country so they have to import the special liquid, in addition they still have the worst traffic jam in Lagos than anywhere else in the world. The reason for this is corruption and not a population explosion. Let me begin with education, most of the schools and tertiary institutions in Zimbabwe have been involved in asking for kickbacks during enrolment even when the prospective does not possess the right qualifications. The economic cost of this is that the students that would be churned out would be half-baked graduates in almost all disciplines be it Commerce, Medicine, Law, Engineering and so on. It is a case of garbage in, garbage out. This has its multiplier effect in the professional world where productivity seems to have been significantly curtailed. Our research shows that only between 15 and 20 percent of managers in the country are qualified for their positions with the rest being actors and actresses. In terms of directors, 8-2 percent deserve to be sitting in different boards across the economic sphere. This state of affairs will not improve soon since our indigenisation policies will continue promoting the status quo. The solution lies in recruiting the right students at college not the right employee. Economic empowerment though a noble policy is also being compromised. Authorities should guard against backroom transacting of share ownership schemes. It would not be pleasant to experience the status where the haves will continue having by virtue of their deeper pockets and connections. If this vice continues, they won't be any fruits of empowerment since it will be a case of replacing the white skin with the black pigment, ours is not a Black Economic Empowerment (BEE) project, it's the empowerment of local Zimbabweans I suppose. This will naturally narrow the tax base, which has a risk of even eroding it in case of tax avoidance and evasion by the few privileged ones. According to the World Bank report on Africa, Zimbabwe is lowly ranked in terms of " Ease of Doing Business" index. Irregardless of this foreigners are flocking into the country. This is because of corrupt tendencies by some of the involved parties. In the end no foreign currency is earned, the expatriates who come will transfer their wealth back to their home country at the expense of this nation. The costs for starting a company in Zimbabwe are relatively high and they are worsened by kickbacks to be honoured if one is to shun bureaucracy. A lot of "tender-preneurs" seem to be arising in our midst, remember these are not entrepreneurs. They wait to pounce on any tenders coming out without adding value to the Gross Domestic Product. Government must be wary of such personalities since some of them can sound so vocal in defence of transparency and honesty when they are actually the culprits. The film and music industries are among some of the most celebrated industries in the World, how much is United States of America government amassing out of the fame and fortune of Hollywood. Is that revenue not enough to support smaller states such as Vermont and Rhode Island? In Zimbabwe, those responsible for talent identification and development are not forthcoming and some of the radio presenters seem to be inclined to specific musicians. If ever they are receiving bribes, the obvious effect is killing the spirit of Zimbabwean music in general and that special musician in particular. The music industry is a journey and getting airplay is a privilege not a right, it is also a function of the product quality. If people continue being bombarded with similar lackluster music, they will resort to pirated DVDs from abroad hence continuously impoverishing the music stakeholders and the Government through failure to levy tax on such musicians. Those who are corrupt tend to have infectious tendencies of spreading corruption tentacles, in shona they call that "kutonyora". The perpetrators of this include our police force, the legal stakeholders and even the complainants. We want a scenario where after the treasury boss fails to raise the salaries of the civil servants, no Zimbabwe residents should carry the cost by using bribes to receive the service. It has to be noted that even in the private sector, corruption is rife. The vice of corruption is not only limited to African states, it is the effect which it poses to African states which is more disastrous considering that you will be "extracting" from the almost empty granary. One of Barack Obama's campaign messages in the run-up to his election was to eradicate corruption and bureaucracy especially in Washington, Hillary Clinton was linked to the Whitewater scandal during her stint as a first lady of the USA. Silvio Berlusconi, the Italian premier was implicated in countless cases which involve financial impropriety and Jacob Zuma of South Africa came into office on his way from the courts to answer charges on arms deal scandal together with Shaib Shaik. In Togo, using the name Faure is a ticket to promotion in the civil sector. Faure is the surname of the presidential family in Togo. We cannot condone corruption as a nation simply because we are living below the poverty datum line. What corruption does is to make us worse off at the same time suffocating economic development since we will continue taxing the helpless members of society who are struggling to make ends meet. I rest my case. God bless you. Christopher Takunda Mugaga is Head of Research, Econometer Global Capital.

TITLE: Karas Governor Facing Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: MAGISTRATES (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (73%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A LARGE crowd of people are expected at the Keetmanshoop Magistrate's Court today to support Karas Governor Dawid Boois when he makes his first appearance on corruption charges. The Namibian understands many of those who will throng to the magistrate's court will be wearing T-shirts displaying the Governor's face. Boois is expected to appear on 24 counts of corruption in the Magistrate's Court before his case is transferred to the Regional Court. On each count Boois is accused of corruptly using his office or his position for gratification by allegedly pocketing a monthly housing subsidy of N$7 500 over a 24-month period while he was living in a council house. A legal expert that The Namibian spoke to believes Boois is likely to be let off the hook, arguing that the matter is more an administrative error than a criminal issue.

TITLE: Boois Corruption Case Postponed to August
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); MAGISTRATES (90%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (90%); ELECTIONS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (77%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (72%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (70%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (70%); POLITICS (65%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE corruption case against Karas Governor Dawid Boois was postponed to August 20 to fix a trial date following his brief appearance in the Keetmanshoop Magistrate's Court on Friday. Boois faces 24 charges of corruption for allegedly pocketing a monthly housing subsidy of N$7 500 for a year while he was living in a council house. Boois indicated that he had enlisted the services of lawyer Sisa Namandje. He remains free on warning. Boois's supporters staged a demonstration in front of the courthouse and rolled out a red carpet for him, but the Police ordered that it be removed. The governor's supporters also shielded him from being photographed by a reporter for the Republikein newspaper. The Police had their hands full with a huge crowd who tried to storm into the courtroom. Only some of the people were allowed in due to limited space, while the others had to stand outside. Shortly after the case was adjourned, Boois's supporters gathered at the town's central park, where a statement was read by Tses Swapo branch co-ordinator Petrus Witbooi, who doubles as Tses Village Council chairman. Witbooi claimed that the corruption charges against Boois were part of a political campaign to tarnish this political credibility on the eve of this year's regional and local authority elections.

TITLE: To Fight Corruption - 'Koroma Must Stop Special Interest'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (90%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (89%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (88%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (77%); EDUCATION FUNDING (76%); US STATE GOVERNMENT (76%); BUDGETS (76%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (75%); COMMERCE DEPARTMENTS (74%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (73%); MILITARY RULE (72%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (69%); TRADE DEVELOPMENT (69%); ECONOMIC POLICY (62%); ECONOMIC NEWS (62%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (62%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: For the fight against corruption to be comprehensive, fair and effective, President Koroma must stop shielding friends, family members and special interests, charged SLPP 2012 flag bearer contender, Rtd. Brig. Julius Maada Bio. The former National Provisional Ruling Council (NPRC) chairman made the call on his recently created website, as he launches his bid with the hope of returning to State House come 2012. "Printing more or new money is not the answer to the severe and worsening hardships the citizens of this country are going through," Bio commented. "If President Ernest Koroma was listening to international experts, he would have known that at the 2008 meeting of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), experts advised that governments must have well-designed plans for attracting foreign investors with an attractive investment environment and with internal conditions that make their investments worthwhile. A government that cuts the education budget and on whose watch this country has received the worst public exams records sends negative signals to international investors that it is not ready and willing to invest in  workers' education and skills as well as the nation's human resources."
