According to Bio, young Sierra Leoneans are unemployed and that the APC government has rendered them unemployable. "When will any APC government learn that investing in the youth is investment in the future of this nation?" he asked. Regionalism and nepotism, the former military ruler observed, weaken the strong institutions which his party, the SLPP, built over ten years. "Nepotism is a denial of social justice and fairness. For a post conflict nation like ours, this does not augur well for good governance and our young democracy," he said. "The IMF recently announced that this APC government has failed to create the fiscal space to finance investment in basic infrastructure and implement structural reforms to promote higher sustainable private sector-led economic growth. The badly thought out and implemented GST is not making the situation any better. Poor handling of the economy plus hardship for ordinary Sierra Leoneans equal incompetent leadership," noted and then campaigned: "Choose Julius Maada Bio for SLPP presidential flag bearer, vote for a new direction - a new direction to economic reform and national development, governance and institutional reform; transparency and accountability, peace building and national reconciliation, social justice and fairness." Reacting to Bio's charge, minister of information and communication, Alhaji Ibrahim Ben Kargbo, who also doubles as government spokesman, said his ministry does not want to politicize national issues but noted that the Bio propaganda website issue will be dealt with accordingly. Mr. Kargbo said his government has done much during the three years of their reign in areas like agriculture, health, education and energy - all within a very short time. "What has the SLPP done during their 11 years added to the NPRC 5 years; it accumulated to 15 years in governance? It was during our reign that donor funding resurrected and on corruption, the president is firmed on his decisions regarding his relatives or closed allies. Ministers are arrested and put on trial for corruption; government doesn't interfere with the work of the ACC," the information minister said. Kargbo said Bio does not know civil issues as he once ruled a military government. Stay tune for more on this story next issue.

TITLE: For Alleged Embezzlement of Local Tax Money-Konike Chief Faces Corruption Probe
BYLINE: Ben Samuel Turay Just Back From Tonkolili
SUBJECT: REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (92%); EMBEZZLEMENT (91%); INTERNAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); BANKING & FINANCE (76%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Paramount Chief of Konike chiefdom in the Tonkolili district and the district council management team would soon face an investigation committee to explain the alleged misuse of the 2007, 2008 and 2009 local tax money paid by the chiefdom people. Program manager of civil society movement in Tonkolili district, Alhassan Bakarr Kamara told Concord Times that Hon. PC Bai Kurr Kanagbaro Sanka III, Dauda Kamara and the district management team will soon be quizzed to give a detailed account of how the said funds were utilized and for what purpose. He said it was news to them to hear that the Tonkolili district council did not receive the local tax money for 2007, 2008 and 2009 in respect of Konike chiefdom. Deputy chief administrator of the Tonkolili district council, Michael M. Turay said: "We've made several complaints to the minister of internal affairs and local government that we have not been receiving local tax money from Hon. PC Kanagbaro Sanka but he didn't pay heed to our concern." However, deputy minister of internal affairs and local government, Raymond Kabia told Concord Times that they had not received any official complaint from the council with regards the alleged embezzlement of local tax money by the Paramount Chief. "No complaint was made to us officially by the council. We only listen to complaints in written and not verbally," he said. But according to Kabia, it was discovered in 2009 by his ministry that the Konike Paramount Chief has not been sending tax money to the district council. "We instructed Hon. PC Kanagbaro Sanka to pay to the district council the money collected as local tax in his chiefdom. After that, we were informed that the chief had deposited some amount of money to the chiefdom bank account," he explained. A senior staff of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) who preferred anonymity said the commission and civil society would work as a team to investigate the said matter. Efforts to get Hon. PC Bai Kurr Kanagbaro Sanka III on his mobile numbers 076-601794 and 077 200111 for his comment on the issue proved abortive.

TITLE: Region Nearly Corruption Free - Study
COUNTRY: RWANDA (94%); BURUNDI (94%); UGANDA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (94%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (94%); KENYA (94%); AFRICA (93%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (63%) Rwanda
TEXT: A report released yesterday by transparency International Kenya, reveals that Rwanda is the least corrupt country in East Africa,. It attributes the achievement to the government's implementation of several measures aimed at tackling corruption within both public and private sectors. According to the East African Bribery Index (EABI), Rwanda's corruption prevalence is at 6.6%; Tanzania comes second as least corrupt with 28.6%, followed by Kenya with 31.9%, Uganda with 33.0% and Burundi as the most corrupt in the region with 36.7%. "On government's commitment to fight corruption, Rwanda proves to be the most committed with 97.1%, followed by Uganda with 30.5%, Tanzania with 29.4%, Burundi with 22.2% and the least committed being Kenya with 22.1%," a statement from Transparency Rwanda quotes the EABI. Rwanda also tops the report's projected level of corruption decrease in the next one year, after scoring 90.3%, followed by Burundi with 23.5%, Kenya with 22.9%, Tanzania with 21.1% whereas Uganda is with 18.9% projection. The EABI states a number of reasons Rwanda has succeeded in fighting corruption among which, is the establishment of the Office of the Ombudsman in 2004 to monitor transparency and compliance to laws in all government sectors. "The Ombudsman's office regularly exposes cases of fraud, malpractice and corruption at the top, middle and bottom levels of the public sector. This is evident through the stern action taken against a number of senior government officials implicated in corruption," the report reads. The EABI survey was carried out in EAC member countries as a fulfilment of the region's goal aimed at capturing corruption experienced by ordinary citizens when interacting with officials of public and private organizations. It was initiated by Transparency International Kenya in 2002 and later implemented in Uganda and Tanzania in 2008, and was concluded in Rwanda and Burundi in February this year.

TITLE: EAC Needs a Common Strategy Against Corruption [opinion]
COUNTRY: EASTERN AFRICA (95%); RWANDA (94%); AFRICA (94%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); BURUNDI (79%); UGANDA (79%); KENYA (79%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (90%); RANKINGS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); ETHICS (77%); BUSINESS ETHICS (68%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (68%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption; International Organizations and Africa
TEXT: In a survey that measured bribery levels in the private and public sectors in East Africa, that was released on Thursday, Transparency International, ranked Rwanda, the least corrupt country in the region. The anti-corruption watchdog's East African Bribery Index (EABI) sates that Rwanda's corruption prevalence is at 6.6 percent and that government's commitment to fight corruption is rated at 97.1 percent. Tanzania came second in the rankings with a prevalence of 28.6 percent, followed by Kenya 31.9 percent, Uganda 33 percent and Burundi 36.7 percent. These findings and various political and socio-economic achievements registered by Rwanda practically indicate that this nation is run in the most transparent manner. Corruption is a dangerous vice which undermines governance, sustainable development, democratic process, and fair business practices. And indeed, Transparency International warned that the level of corruption in East Africa threatens to hold back the recently launched common market's full potential. Therefore, the fight against corruption should be a regional battle and should start from the grass root. Other EAC countries can also learn from Rwanda and create strong Ombudsman offices capable of regularly exposing cases of fraud, malpractice and corruption at the top, middle and bottom levels of the public sector. Moreover, private companies in collaboration with relevant authorities must put in place strict internal controls and establish ethics and compliance programs, as part of a strategy to combat corruption in their businesses. Otherwise, corruption will undermine the fruits of the EAC integration through holding back economic development in all sectors.

TITLE: Kabandana Gets Five Years for Corruption
SUBJECT: EMBEZZLEMENT (92%); SENTENCING (91%); JAIL SENTENCING (90%); FINES & PENALTIES (90%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CONTRACT AWARDS (90%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); APPEALS COURTS (89%); VERDICTS (89%); LITIGATION (78%); GUILTY PLEAS (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (77%); ARRESTS (74%); BRIBERY (74%); ADMISSIONS & CONFESSIONS (72%); INTERNAL AUDITS (66%); AUDITS (61%) Rwanda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The intermediate court of Nyarugenge, yesterday sentenced Marc Kabandana, the former Director General of Rwanda Institute of Administration and Management (RIAM) to five and a half years in prison for embezzling public funds and flouting tendering procedures. Kabandana was sentenced alongside Faustin Mugisha, the former Director of Finance and Annette Mbabazi, the institute's former accountant, who also received the same sentence as their former boss. Kabandana was also fined Rwf 25,000 for embezzlement and Rwf250,000 for flouting tender procedures while Mugisha and Mbabazi were also handed fines, Mugisha was fined Rwf25,000 for not declaring his wealth with the Ombudsman's office while Mbabazi will pay the same for embezzlement. Seven more accomplices in the high profile corruption case were also sentenced to varying stints in jail for conniving with RIAM officials to embezzle millions from the institution, leading to a loss of over Rwf 203m. The officials were found guilty of awarding themselves bonuses and travel allowances as well as conniving with 'businessmen' to award illegal tenders from which they pocketed massive kickbacks from alleged tender winners. Others sentenced along with the RIAM bosses include Robert Butera, Dominic Rwaka and Fidele Nkubito who were handed similar sentences. Samuel Mupenzi who posed as a supplier along with Rwaka, Steven Kagame, Alex Bazatsinda, Gerard Shyaka, Sylvere Kwiringira and Richard Mugabo were dully handed 7 years and 6 months in prison. The whole group which has a chance to appeal the verdict in 30 days, will also be fined Rwf329,000 and also Rwf700,000 for being party to the "circle with a calculated plan" to embezzle public funds and cause public loss. Court also found Kabandana and Mugisha, who partly admit to the charges, guilty of deliberately pocketing huge allowances meant for travelling and "lump sums" in form of bonuses, deposited on their accounts, at times twice a month. Kabandana, who did not appear at the ruling, was arrested in September last year after an internal audit by the Auditor Generals offices unearthed gross mismanagement of resources and embezzlement in the government capacity building institution.

TITLE: Father Tikpor Condemns Corruption and Sectionalism
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (88%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (78%); NATURAL RESOURCES (72%) Liberia
TEXT: This year's 163rd Independent Celebration Orator, Rev. Monsignor Robert G. Tikpor of the Catholic Church has said that corruption and sectionalism remain a major barrier to development here in Liberia. "...sectionalism, persistent corruption caused by selfishness and greed, in high places, lack of patriotism are some of the detractors stalling our progress and achievement," revealed Rev. Tikpor. Delivering this year's key note address on the theme, "In National Unity we will stand" at the Independent celebration in Sanniquellie, Nimba County, Father Tikpor emphasized that for Liberia to progress, corruption must be buried. The Catholic Monsignor also revealed that in the 70's, Liberia's economy was comparable to Japan stressing; "Liberia's capital income was second to that of Japan. Then, Japan was the richest country in the world while Liberia came second. Even the Great USA would be placed underneath Liberia." "All these were due to our natural resources more especially the rubber. But because of corruption and other ills, Liberia's economy cannot be compared to Japan." Though Father Tikpor did not suggest a specific language to be spoken as a national dialect , he disclosed that the lack of a common language, sectionalism and lack of blood relationship amongst others greatly contributes to the current retrogression of the country.

TITLE: Poverty, Corruption Undermine Progress
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (90%); CHRISTIANS & CHRISTIANITY (88%); RELIGION (78%); CATHOLICS & CATHOLICISM (78%); ANNIVERSARIES (78%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; Sustainable Development
TEXT: The Doyen of the Catholic Church in Liberia Monsignor Father Robert Tikpor who served as National Orator of the 163rd Independence anniversary celebration held in Sanniquellie, Nimba County says several factors are responsible for the slow pace of Liberia's progress and achievements. The 84 year old catholic prelate said corruption in both private and public sectors, selfishness, greed and lack of patriotism are the root causes of poverty the country is experiencing. Father Tikpor observed that people are continuing to put personal interest over national interest, adding, this led to serious division during the war years. Speaking on the theme: "In National Unity We Will Stand", Father Tikpor, urged all Liberians to work together to surgically cut-off what he calls cancerous tissues from our records. He believes this can be achieved if we put the welfare of our country over our personal cravings and wants. The orator also calls for the identification of a national language, and revision of the country's motto to enhance unity. He observed "the love of liberty brought us here" promotes sectionalism as there were people here when the settlers arrived. It can be recalled, the 2008 Independence Day orator also called for action on the language and motto but no concrete step has been taken to address them. President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf had assured that the Governance Commission would review them.

TITLE: 'Impunity, Corruption, Human Rights Violations Are Root Causes of Conflicts' -TRC Commissioner
SUBJECT: HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (90%); RULE OF LAW (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (73%) Liberia; Conflict, Peace and Security
TEXT: The Chairman of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) Cllr. Jerome Vedier says injustice, impunity, corruption, human rights violations, nepotism, cronism, lack of participation and the exclusionary governance policies of the past were the major root causes of the Liberian conflicts being identified by the TRC The TRC Commissioner made the statement recently during the closing of the trc headquarters and major activities of the TRC relating to its mandate as a corporate institution of government. Cllr. Verdier said the nightmare is not over if these conflictual or conflict induced issues are not addressed by a society which to date bears the fresh scars, hate, division and disunity founded in the history of the country and the policies of all governments past and, unfortunately, present. "We have no illusion of the difficulty and intricate nature of issues associated with the implementation of the TRC's recommendations which without doubt cannot be implemented over night. Like reconciliation, it will take years before full implementation is achieved, but we need to commit ourselves to the implementation and begin in earnest a process or framework for implementation. We are exceedingly gratified that the United Nations peace building fund have allocated funds to support implementation of TRC recommendations "that enhance reconciliation," Cllr. Verdier asserted. He said this is a valuable contribution to building a new society in Liberia as we hasten to point out that it is not only the "palava hut" process recommendations that enhance reconciliation but that the entire TRC process and all its recommendations, when considered, enhance, contribute to and promote peace and reconciliation in Liberia. The former Catholic Justice and Peace Commission (JPC) Boss said reconciliation is a process and not a commodity purchased in the absence or without the building of a just and equitable society founded on the rule of law with abiding conviction that all is equal in rights, privileges and entitlements to justice, security and self actualization, adding, we agree with those who say that peace is not just the absence of war, but the presence of justice. The former TRC Chairman further indicated that without justice or a credible threat of prosecution impunity will flourish in our society. The rich and powerful will trample on the rights of the weak and poor without remorse or redress. Authority will be abused, innocent citizens and police officers will be continuously flocked for doing what is right and nothing will come out of it: there will be no justice, he said. "Liberia have bred, nurtured and built a perverse and oppressive society in which the status quo is never wrong and the ultimate end of our struggle is bread and butter. This is wrong, immoral and it has to change; otherwise our society will never progress and we will be nothing but a society of thieves and beggars. where the thieves suppress, cheat and deprive the beggars and the beggars on the other hand continuously glorify, follow, defend, protect and praise the thieves because they want to continue begging for bread and butter from the crumps of the thief's table; and with little ambition, no dreams and abounding complacency they (the beggars) relish the status of associating with thieves, because they aspire to becoming thieves themselves someday soon," he said. "The state structure in Liberia is pervasive and predatory; its structures are abusive; its authorities are top headed and its subjects are ignorant, helpless and gullible victims of over a century old culture of patronage and sycophancy. So pervasive is this culture that we have become impervious to truth and justice. This too, should not be the new Liberia; this too, has got to change. "Our President, Her Excellency, has an enormous responsibility on hand and must lead with abiding faith in god and commitment to justice and the rule of law to change Liberia completely from the deeds of the past that have left Liberia walloping at the bottom of the human development index; disconnected by centuries of unpaved roads and no roads at all; with very little access to quality health and education; without a patriotic citizenry and a nation every one flees from and never proud to call a home beyond mere citizenship. Wihtout adorning the cult of the historical imperial presidency, the president will have to be "strong" for peace, reconciliation, unity, justice and the rule of law," He asserted. "To date, Her Excellency the President is lagging behind in her statutory commitment to report quarterly on the implementation of the TRC recommendations and not a voice including that of the National Legislature have been heard. The entire country is mute on the nonperformance of the president on a major duty that should have happened more than a month ago. While not much was recognized in the president's first quarterly "report" in march 2010, it was noteworthy for recognizing the good work of the commission and the far reaching implications of the recommendations on the future of Liberia. This obligation to report to the Liberian people quarterly on the implementation of all recommendations of the trc is imperative and vital to our continued drive for lasting peace and reconciliation. We urge Her Excellency, the president not to renege but be strong in faith and do what is right so that this glorious land of liberty will continue to exist under god's command, He urged.

TITLE: Goabab Cleared of Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); SUPREME COURTS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); APPEALS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); ACQUITTAL (77%); JUDGES (77%); ARRESTS (73%); WAGES & SALARIES (61%); BUDGETS (61%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: FORMER National Assembly Secretary Nama Goabab and National Assembly accountant Abraham George are off the hook - for now at least - on the main charges of corruption on which they have been on trial in the High Court in Windhoek. Judge Marlene Tommasi discharged Goabab on all three main counts of corruption he had been facing, while George was discharged on two main counts of corruption, in a ruling given in the High Court yesterday. She however refused an application to also find them not guilty on the alternative charges they are facing. This refusal to discharge them on all counts leaves Goabab and George facing an alternative charge of fraud under the first count, alternative charges of fraud or theft under the second count, and in respect of Goabab alone an alternative charge of use of a motor vehicle without the owner's consent under the third charge. Following the ruling Deputy Prosecutor General Orben Sibeya told Judge Tommasi that the prosecution's next step would be to ask to be allowed to appeal to the Supreme Court against the ruling. If the State is given leave to appeal at this stage of the trial already, it could result in a long postponement of the trial while a decision from the country's highest court is awaited. Judge Tommasi's ruling hinged on her reading of the Anti-Corruption Act's definition of a corrupt act, and the question whether this definition would cover the acts Goabab and George are charged with. She concluded that the Anti-Corruption Act does not clearly criminalise the acts they are accused of. The main charges against Goabab (53) and George (49) were counts of corruptly using an office or position for gratification. Two of the charges related to the renting of vehicles for Goabab's use at Government cost between March 1 and April 24 2007. In the end no public funds were used to pay for the first rental. The second rental was paid for out of the NationalAssembly's budget, but Goabab repaid this money - an amount of N$18 487,20 - to Government within days after his arrest on the charges in June 2007. According to Goabab it had all along been the arrangement that he would finally be responsible for the costs of the vehicle rentals. The third charge, faced by Goabab alone, stemmed from his use of a Government vehicle on May 25 2007, while he was receiving a vehicle allowance as part of his salary as National Assembly Secretary. In her ruling, Judge Tommasi referred to the definition of corruption in previous laws on the issue that had applied in Namibia - being the 1928 Prevention of Corruption Ordinance and the 1985 Prevention of Corruption Amendment Act - as well as in South Africa's Prevention and Combating of Corrupt Activities Act of 2004. In all of these laws, the definition of corruption included the presence of someone who corrupts someone else, and a person who is being corrupted, she indicated. From these definitions, she concluded: "The offending act is receiving a benefit (from any other person)." The Anti-Corruption Act of 2003 does not contain a similar definition clearly stipulating that the source of gratification should be from another person, she said. From the historical perspective of the laws on corruption in Namibia, it is clear though that the actions of both the person being corrupted and the person corrupting someone else were criminalised, the judge said. She indicated that she also took into account the principle of legality, which is that an accused person may not be convicted of a contravention of a law unless the law clearly criminalises the conduct. Given the history of the offence of corruption in Namibia and the principle of legality, Judge Tommasi said, she came to the conclusion that the meaning of section 43(1) of the Anti-Corruption Act, under which Goabab and George were charged, should be interpreted strictly. This provision only relates to someone being corrupted, she found. "It follows then that the State needed to prove that gratification was obtained from another person, that is, that the public officer allowed himself to be corrupted," she reasoned. The evidence placed before the court however did not include anyone playing the role of a corruptor, she said. "The legislature could not have intended for the courts to usurp the State's function to discipline its staff unless it falls within the framework of the criminal law," she remarked. In these circumstances it has become "abundantly clear" that the State has not produced evidence to support a conviction on any of the main counts, she said. The case is now scheduled to return to court on Wednesday next week. Goabab is being represented by Lucius Murorua, while Christie Mostert is appearing for George.

TITLE: Boois Corruption Case Goes to Regional Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (90%); MAGISTRATES (90%); SCANDALS (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (73%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (68%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE corruption case against Karas Governor Dawid Boois will be heard in the Keetmanshoop Regional Court on November 29. That is where more serious cases are prosecuted. Boois again briefly appeared in the Keetmanshoop Magistrate's Court on Friday on 24 charges of corruption under the Anti-Corruption Act. Magistrate Philanda Blockstein-Christiaan transferred Boois's case to the Regional Court for plea and trial. He remains free on warning. The charges against Boois relate to a housing subsidy scandal dating back to 2004. On each count Boois is accused of corruptly using his office or his position for gratification by allegedly pocketing a monthly housing subsidy of N$7 500 over a 24-month period while he was living in a council house. Boois's supporters and relatives, who had protested outside the court during his first court appearance, again packed the court gallery on Friday. Notable faces among Boois's supporters at Friday's court hearing were the former chief of the Berseba /Hai-/Khaua Goliath faction, Johannes Fleermuis, and some of the faction's traditional councillors. A strong contingent of the Police Special Reserve Force was deployed at the court's entry points and searched people who entered.

TITLE: Claims of Corruption Filed Against Regional Councillor
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (88%); PROPERTY LEASES (86%); LAND LEASES (86%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: A corruption complaint has been filed with the Anti-Corruption Commission against Karasburg Constituency regional councillor Paulus Efraim. ACC director Paulus Noa said last week his office was verifying whether there was truth in the allegations against Efraim. It is alleged that Efraim is living free of charge in a house located on a plot rented by the Karas Regional Council while receiving a monthly housing subsidy of N$6 500 too. The council leased the land from a certain Mr Schultz to operate the Noordoewer settlement office from a building located on the plot. It is also charged that the municipal rates and taxes of the house in which Efraim lives is being paid by the council.

TITLE: Region Wants Stronger Anti-Corruption Laws
COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); RWANDA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%) East Africa
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (79%); PUBLIC FINANCE (79%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (79%); LAWYERS (75%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: Officials from EAC partner states have called on the regional bloc to ensure that there are strict laws that will pave way for recovery of government funds stolen by corrupt government officials in the region. The recommendation was made during the just concluded two-day, 2nd EAC Good Governance conference in Nairobi, Kenya. "Legal instruments for recovery and forfeiture of ill-gotten wealth should be developed and effectively implemented," the over 100 delegates recommended in a statement issued shortly after the closure of the conference, on Friday. They called for full exploration of alternatives to prosecution including measures such, exposure, and voluntary surrender of the proceeds from corruption. Amaible Havugiyaremye, a Principle State Attorney in the Ministry of Justice underscored the need to sensitize people on the ills of corruption, adding that it's a vice when not dealt with early enough can negatively affect the larger population in society. Officials also said that there is need to expedite conclusion of the protocol on good governance with emphasis on entrenching provisions that promote popular participation and people centeredness in good governance issues. The EAC Deputy Secretary General (Political Federation), Beatrice Kiraso, had earlier said that the draft protocol on good governance was yet to reach the partner states for consultation, and that the process had begun with broader stakeholders like Chiefs of Justice and National Parliamentarians. On the role of media in promotion of good governance, delegates recommended the need to develop and implement regional mechanisms that guide development of a media that is responsible, responsive, professional and accountable. Fred Mufulukye, the Director General of Territorial Administration and Governance in the Ministry of Local Government, said that the media requires quality control to ensure that its role does not jeopardize national sovereignty, national development and social cohesion. The resolutions from the conference will be incorporated in the ongoing EAC programmes towards promoting good governance.

TITLE: Corruption Cases Down By More Than 50 Percent - Report
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (90%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); ARRESTS (73%); INTERVIEWS (68%) Rwanda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The number of corruption cases has reduced by 52.6 percent since 2005, a report on crime recently released by the Rwanda National Police (RNP) indicates. The report indicates that only 91 cases were registered by June this year compared to 192 cases recorded six years ago. Corruption was at a record high in 2007 where it increased by 138 percent from 145 cases the previous year to 345 cases, according to the report. Police Spokesperson, Supt. Eric Kayiranga said that the reduction was mainly due to the establishment of a section within the Criminal Investigation Department (CID) specifically charged with investigating corruption-related crimes. "Rwanda has made significant strides in fighting corruption and the Police force is committed to continue with this fight until it is significantly reduced," Kayiranga said in an interview yesterday. He added that thorough investigations into corruption have been made and a number of suspects arrested. Kayiranga added that the community had been sensitized in the fight against corruption through community policing and working hand-in-hand with law enforcement institutions and other stakeholders. "All these have contributed to a significant reduction of corruption and related crimes which made Rwanda the least corrupt country in the region in recent rankings," he said. He observed that the Police leadership initiated a spirit of fighting corruption within all police officers, to ensure that every one embraces the commitment to deliver the best services. "This goes with self discipline that characterizes most of our Police officers," Kayiranga noted He, however, noted that there are officers who succumb to corruption despite existing mechanisms, but he said that most of them have been caught and sacked. "Those elements that were found corrupt were expelled from the police. Such officers go against the promotion of the core values and tarnish the image of the institution, which we cannot tolerate," Kayiranga said. Last year, RNP expelled about 10 officers for corruption and some of them have since been prosecuted.

TITLE: Gasabo Employees Vow to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS (79%); INTERVIEWS (73%); LIVING STANDARDS (70%); EXECUTIVES (65%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption; Labour; Company News
TEXT: Employees of Gasabo District, in their respective capacities, have vowed to fight against corruption while encouraging residents in the district to be persons of integrity. The employees made the pledge, yesterday, during a swearing in ceremony committing to implement the district's performance contract, a function that took place at Kinyinya Sector offices. The district mayor, Willy Ndizeye, urged the employees to work hard and always strive to improve the living standards of residents through the promotion of hygiene. "We should not take this swearing in for granted it is your responsibility to make reality what is contained in the district's performance contracts through delivering better services," Ndizeye said. In an interview, the mayor expressed optimism that the swearing in ceremony would add value to the performance contracts saying that employees will always work keeping in mind that they took oath both before God and the district administration. He called upon the employees to always evaluate themselves to ascertain how far they have gone in implementing the contracts, instead of waiting for the general evaluation all districts. Those who participated include, Sector Executive Secretaries, cell coordinators and executives, heads of department at the district and the district Executive Secretary.

TITLE: Swakop's Former Traffic Chief Wants Closure on Corruption Allegations
SUBJECT: REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); EXECUTIVES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); CORRUPTION (77%); FINES & PENALTIES (71%); FORENSICS (60%) Namibia; Transport and Shipping
TEXT: SWAKOPMUND'S former Municipal traffic chief Fanie Kruger, who served the town for 22 years before he retired end 2009, is still concerned about certain serious allegations made against him and for which the local council still has to answer. Several attempts to communicate with the town's CEO amicably about the matter has proven fruitless as he has received no answers. In fact, it was eventually communicated to Kruger that he was no longer an employee of the municipality and therefore there was no need to process any work-related issues with him. "I am now on pension. I have done my work faithfully and served the Swakopmund municipality diligently. Everything I did was to the advantage of the council and of the rate payers. I did my job 100 per cent. They made accusations against my person and my profession. Until now I have been waiting for answers from them which they are seemingly trying to avoid," Kruger told The Namibian. In 2008 Kruger and his colleague Herman Engelbrecht, also a long-serving senior traffic officer, but who is no longer employed at the municipality, were suspended for 45 days. This was for allegedly abusing their powers as traffic managers in an incident concerning a member of public that was fined for an alleged traffic offence. After a complaint from the person and a legal inquiry by Kruger into the merits of the complaint, Kruger made the decision to withdraw the charge against this member of public. "The reason I did this was because what we did was legally wrong and therefore I wanted to protect the municipality from unnecessary claims and possible embarrassment," he said. This decision led to rumours and accusations that reached the CEO and the Council Management Committee's ears and, heeding to these rumours, allegedly without approaching Kruger for his side of the story, a suspension followed - while Kruger was on leave. "Why did the Chairman of the Management Committee and the CEO not approach me first, as municipal policy stipulate, to hear my side. This could have been settled very simply if we had talked. But instead they jumped the gun, suspended me, and we were dragged to court," he said. "They allowed a totally lob-sided grievance committee to submit a report to council without approaching us before charging us on several charges pertaining to municipal employment irregularities." The two men were found innocent in court and the suspension was lifted. Shortly after their return to office a forensic investigation was launched into the traffic department for alleged irregularities. During this investigation Kruger submitted his grievances of a staff member who had allegedly "insulted" him through a letter which, according to him, was never dealt with. The staff member later also allegedly insulted council for 'poor work and management' and then only, according to Kruger, was the person disciplined and warned. "Why did they not act against this person when I submitted the grievance?" he asked. During this time Kruger was also busy investigating a matter of the alleged illegal issuance of a driver's licence, where the rules and regulations were not followed. It was during this internal investigation of his that the municipality's Corporate Services and Human Resources departments interfered and stalled the investigation. Forensics, however, later found that the licence was indeed issued illegally. His question was why no disciplinary action was taken against the people. "I know from very reliable sources that this forensic investigation was completed while I was still employed (June last year) and that the finding blew up in council's face because there was nothing against me," he said. "My questions are, why until today, council has not given any feedback whatsoever on the findings internally, or to the ratepayers who paid N$384 000 for the investigation? Why is this being held under covers? The only answer that I received,in June this year, is that the matter is personal in nature, and that I am no longer an employee and therefore it has nothing to do with me." For Kruger, this is not a matter of vengeance. It is rather a matter of accountability and transparency and just to have closure on the matter which is seemingly being withheld, he said. "Besides, they are very right that I am no longer an employee, but I am a ratepayer of Swakopmund and I have the right to get answers to these questions." The Namibian attempted to get comment from Swakopmund CEO, Eckard Demasius, but he will only be back in office on September 20.

TITLE: Judiciary Urged to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: JUDGES (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (57%); DISMISSALS (53%) Rwanda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE President of the High Court, Johnston Busingye, has urged judges and court clerks in Kigali City to fight all forms of corruption in the judiciary as a way of improving the quality of services they offer. Speaking during a one-day conference for over 100 judges and court clerks serving in Gasabo, Nyarugenge and Gicumbi districts, Busingye said that the judiciary must work hard to maintain their independence and act impartiality. "Rwanda has set a record as a country with zero tolerance to corruption; the whole world is now watching us to see if we can uphold our laws or give way to corruption. It's therefore your obligation as judges and court clerks to take on your responsibility of protecting the image of our profession," Busingye said. He later revealed in an interview that corruption and bribery in the courts had dropped tremendously in the last ten years, to almost negligible levels. "Last year, only three court clerks were dismissed from work because of corruption-related cases. However, this year there has not been a single case so far. This implies that we are on the right track," he said. On the issue of a heavy backlog of cases pending in the courts, Busingye said that there are strong government measures, backed by stakeholders' support, aimed at improving the situation. "Every judge is required to deliver a minimum of 15 judgments every month; on top of this requirement, we need to work out creative ways of resolving conflict at the domestic level; this way, all cases shall be concluded fast," he said.

TITLE: 'Corruption Can Be Dealt With...' ...Deputy ACC Boss
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (77%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (74%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (56%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Deputy head of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has voiced his belief that corruption can only be dealt with when it is looked at systematically. Speaking at the opening of a two-day training on policy formulation and implementation organized by his commission for councilors of the Freetown City and the Western Rural District councils, Morlai Buya Kamara said: "We will only deal with corruption when we look at it systematically to know its root cause." He said the picture being seen today was a very scaring one, thus giving them a very daunting task in the fight against graft in the country. "We need to be serious about reforming our system to be able to fight corruption. It behoves all of us to know what we are doing because most of the problems we encounter as a nation have to do with our system," he observed. The anti-graft commission deputy boss urged participants to make the training more meaningful by putting into practice what they had learnt. "Policy formulation and implementation should be given prominence in your various local councils," Kamara urged. Deputy Mayor of Freetown, Gibril Kanu, thanked the ACC for bringing them onboard to identify the problems in policy formulation and implementation. He assured the commission that they would put into practice the knowledge gained during the course of the training, noting that the training was important and timely. Capacity building manager at the Decentralization Secretariat, Jonathan Kpakiwa, said if governance was to improve and people were to realize their dreams, "it is but fitting to collaborate with the ACC". He said the training would be very much useful for local councils because they were there to implement the policies formulated by government. Kpakiwa encouraged participants to make good use of the training, while imploring the ACC to replicate the exercise to all the 19 local councils across the country. Director of local government in the ministry of Internal Affairs, Aiah Joseph Lebbie, said policy formulation ensured effective performance and served as a guide on what should be done. "The training will broaden participants' understanding of policy formulation and implementation. We should be good at making and implementing policies; making sound policies without implementing them is a waste of time," Lebbie maintained. He commended the ACC for embarking on measures to prevent corruption, while urging them to also look at ministries, departments and agencies on policy formulation.

TITLE: Media Urged to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); JOURNALISM (90%); WRITERS (90%); NEWS REPORTING (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (86%); HOTELS & MOTELS (56%) Rwanda; Press and Media; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: MEDIA practitioners have been urged to take up a leadership role in the fight against corruption. The call was made yesterday by Ombudsman Tito Rutaremara, while addressing over 40 journalists from various local media organizations at the opening of a three-day workshop on the role of journalists in fighting against corruption and injustice at Alpha Palace Hotel, Kigali. "I advise you to take responsibility of fighting against corruption and injustice among Rwandans because this is a crosscutting issue that requires everyone's contribution," he said, adding that journalists should desist from reporting stories based on rumours and instead carry out thorough investigation. The Ombudsman said his office had trained the population on how to report corruption cases, particularly through the use of the existing ICT tele-centres. He said his office had not received any complaint of extortion by a journalist and called on the public to report such cases, should they arise. Rutaremara said since February his office had received over 200 corruption cases and over 9,000 injustice cases across the country.

TITLE: Is 'State-Sponsored Corruption' On the Up? [column]
SUBJECT: STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (91%); PRIVATIZATION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICS (89%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); TAKEOVERS (78%); LOBBYING (78%); POLITICAL PARTIES (77%); WITNESSES (77%); CUSTOMER RELATIONS (72%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (71%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: IT all started with the notion that the privatisation of State-owned companies was the way to better manage our resources but actually this process just strengthened the relationship between the business class and the political elite. We have seen BEE entities (close to the ruling political party) buying shares in State companies. Today, many of these BEE managers have become business tycoons, and they now even exercise a strong influence on parliamentary decisions and continue to lobby for legislation that will ultimately secure their own wealth. We have also seen State-run companies (public enterprises) remain a playground for post-election party bargaining, with top company posts offered as a reward to loyal party supporters, and very often as cash cows. Talk of Air Namibia, NamPower, NamWater and many others. First it was the attempted GIPF takeover by a company of political elites now it's a consortium vying to supply 50 per cent of all fuel in Namibia to replace Glencore as Namcor's partner. Who knows what will be next? There is nothing wrong with Namibians trying to have a stake in Namcor, GIPF or any other State institution, especially when such Namibian companies are guided by the tenets of hard work and have the necessary expertise, but the question is: does the current political leadership allow for transparency to guide such a highly charged political process? It seems plausible to say our Government is now in the business of benefiting only the wealthy and the corrupt politicians. One wonders whether we have a 'people's party any more'. It seems as if political corruption has become so ingrained in Namibian politics to the extent of constituting some form of a political institution. I think what we see is that the political scene in Namibia today is a neo-patrimonial form of governance that is characterised by this 'official corruption' and patron-client relations that is forever seeking to take over the formal operations of the State. At the surface level, one notices that there is some appearance of some political will and power to fight organised corruption, but in actual sense there is no real power anymore because the events we continue to witness are aimed at making a few well-connected individuals rich and ignore the plight of the masses. I am not surprised that in this environment, characteristic of institutional weaknesses such as the ACC, that the political elites will not stop at nothing until they loot every last bit of wealth that this country has. What we are witnessing is what I call 'state-sponsored corruption' because the political leadership has allowed this moral degradation to carry on unabated. I call it 'state-sponsored corruption' because our hard-won constitutional democracy is used to advance the selfish economic gain of private individuals. It's a form of political corruption because the behaviour of public officials (leaders of trade unions and youth groups) has deviated from the public interest to serve their private ends. Sad to note is the fact that Namibia with its so called anti-corruption laws is a victim of selective enforcement of corruption laws. When you start to see that Government implements policies which burden the majority of disadvantaged groups in society to the benefit of the wealthier minority, you must know that such a government is reducing its own legitimacy and anarchy is on its way. When a political system becomes blurred in separating public and private resources, then know for a fact that the political leadership has lost its vision. The strange thing about these BEE consortiums is that they are presented to the public as broad social compacts, allegedly incorporating the interests of diverse groups, including disenfranchised groups. But in actual fact, these BEE entities are just but a cast of political elites who are after the country's riches under deceptive names and initiatives. If Government allows these BEE companies to co-own Namcor, it is actually a clear sign that our own leaders are implementing policies which increase inequality instead of reducing it. Whereas in more developed and equitable societies the reaction to economic unfairness such as this might take the form of public demonstrations and political pressure, in a developing country like Namibia with a high unequal distribution of wealth, the reaction to such unfairness will take the form of distrust in political institutions, especially the ruling party. Slowly but surely, when the masses get fed up with this state-sponsored corruption, we might witness very disturbing reactions from society. I have always argued that democracy has distinctive shortcomings that are made worse by the deception that Namibia enjoys a transparent leadership. What makes matters worse is that when political elites take over State companies without the nation's interests at heart we will witness a poor record of service delivery, and new opportunities of corruption will be the norm of the day. It's time that Namibians learn to demand more than free and fair elections alone. We need to demand that between elections our political leaders be responsive and accountable to the nation. Unless otherwise convinced, I am left to conclude that the formal rules for popular political accountability have become persistently weak in this country. There are a number of steps that can be taken to avoid or minimise 'political corruption', but all depend on having leaders with a strong political will. Such steps include greater transparency across all areas of Government, and having a better oversight of State-run companies and public tenders.

TITLE: Journalists Set Up Anti-Corruption Committee
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); JOURNALISM (90%); WRITERS (90%); HOTELS & MOTELS (73%) Rwanda; Press and Media; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: day media workshop on corruption concluded, yesterday, at Alpha Palace Hotel in Kigali, with participants putting in place a journalists' committee that will spearhead the media's role in the fight against corruption in the country. The committee will work closely with the Ombudsman's Office. Assumani Niyonambaza, the chief editor of Rugari newspaper was elected to head the committee. Participants said they had acquired important skills from the workshop and pledged to tackle the vice. Closing the workshop, Cabinet Affairs Minister and Acting Information Minister, Protais Musoni called on journalists to always expose corruption and injustices, and to be characterized by integrity in their work. "Corruption and injustice hinder development in any society, so let us work together as a whole nation to combat these vices," he said.

TITLE: Is Corruption Still a Menace in Nation?
SUBJECT: UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (91%); JOB CREATION (89%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (89%); CORRUPTION (89%); CHILD LABOR LAWS (88%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (78%); US INDEPENDENCE DAY (78%); CONSTRUCTION (77%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (77%); TAXES & TAXATION (76%); LABOR DEPARTMENTS (76%); UNEMPLOYMENT RATES (76%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (76%); HIGHWAY FUNDING (71%); FRUITS & VEGETABLES (71%); BANKING & FINANCE (69%); COMMODITIES PRICES (69%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (69%); ANNIVERSARIES (69%); COMMERCIAL BANKING (60%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (51%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption; Children and Youth
TEXT: In the latest report that the United Nations Secretary General Mr. Ban Ki-Moon read to the UN security council in New York on the activities of the UN Integrated Peace Building Office in Sierra Leone (UNIPSIL) several pertinent issues were raised, including the immense challenges that remain in generating jobs for young people in Sierra Leone's prevailing climate, noting that currently 800,000 young people are unemployed in the country. He also expressed concern over the increase in corruption. This assessment of the realities of the situation on the ground in Sierra Leone is of course not a fantasy but authentic. It should be treated by government with every degree of seriousness. Presently many aspects of government's focus delve around efforts to celebrate in grand style the country's 50th Independence anniversary and the re-election of the APC Government to a second term mandate. Indeed it will equally pay dividends to government's popularity ratings, and positioning for the 50th independence day celebrations, and for efforts to receive a second term mandate on a silver platter, if government increases initiatives in the areas of job creation for the youth; health, tourism, agriculture, education, road construction etc with the interest of the nation paramount over all other parochial considerations. Certainly the saying goes that a hungry man cannot stand especially in these days of global economic doldrums as a result of decline in food, petroleum and other basic commodities on the world market. As President Ernest Bai Koroma has been hinting, we must be faster and on the move to catch up with the realities and challenges of national development. Every Sierra Leonean should be involved in the patriotic duty of monitoring the prices of basic commodities on the local market to mitigate the tricks of unscrupulous business people. Business people should especially take note of the dangers in toying or hiking the prices of commodities that are not affected by the Goods and Services Tax (GST)  such as rice, pepper, palm oil, banana, cassava etc, at least as a patriotic duty. What is worth noting about youth employment is that there had been more rhetoric than positive actions on the ground in the interest of the people. The deposed SLPP government appears to have re-oriented its policies in favour of youth employment by laying some foundations such as the establishment of the Youth Employment Scheme (YES) and by opening its account at the Sierra Leone Commercial Bank (SLCB) with funds provided by the UNDP. One aspect of the SLPP regime's approach in resolving the problem was to diversify youth job creation initiatives among various stakeholders such as the Ministry of Youth and Sports, Ministry of Labour, Education, Economic and Development Planning as well as the National Commission for Social Action (NaCSA), the Sierra Leone Roads Authority etc. But when the APC Regime came to power, they had not wanted to put old wines in new bottles. Thus they introduced the new approach of dissolving the Ministry of Youth and Sports and devolving its functions to that of the Ministry of Education as well as announcing the establishment of the National Youth Commission (NYC), an agency for coordinating youth employment activities in the country. Unfortunately up to now only the last of the members of the Board of Directors of the NYC has been nominated and confirmed by Parliament; the Act creating the NYC has also been ratified by Parliament. The NYC however is yet to become operational due to administrative red-tapes. Another important loophole in the youth employment saga in the country is the overlapping of functions among various stakeholders, something that should be nipped in the bud before the NYC becomes operational. Many observers feel that it is time government unravels the mystery that was behind why the Youth Employment Scheme (YES) fund that the SLPP left at the SLCB had to be later returned to the UNDP donors for safekeeping? What happened is that there was a conflict of interest in who should control the fund that became visible between the Ministry of Finance, Education, Labour, NaCSA etc. This is because of the stigma of overlapping of functions and the lack of comprehensive coordination and personality cult among certain government officials, the fund had to be retrieved by the UNDP for safe-keeping. The UNIPSIL latest report equally mentioned that the number of corruption cases to the Anti-Corruption Commission had increased in recent times instead of decreasing. Indeed one of the crucial challenges facing the ACC had often been political interference that compromises its independence as a neutral body. During the SLPP era the pendulum was swinging in favour of SLPP political stalwarts in government as government was sometimes giving blind eyes to their shortcomings while castigating others from other political parties. This was something that cast ugly aspersions on the performance of the party. Today a similar scenario is unfolding as despite that the APC Regime had updated and reviewed its mandate to conform to changing realities there are still evidences of APC-SLPP power rivalry in the way corruption cases are being handled. This is why the issue of some senior government officials especially opposition party officials such as the Minority Leader, Hon. Momoh Pujeh and the Minister of Lands, Housing and the Environment Dr. Dennis Sandy failing to declare their assets ought to be treated as a constitutional obligation and national concern rather than with party politics allegiance.

TITLE: Noa and Erna Get Another Term at Anti-Corruption Commission
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (87%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: THE director and deputy director of the Anti-Corruption Commission will stay in their posts for another five years. Prime Minister Nahas Angula tabled an unopposed motion in Parliament yesterday afternoon requesting the National Assembly "to reappoint Paulus Noa and his deputy Erna van der Merwe for another five years" at the graft watchdog. The motion was agreed to.

TITLE: Police to Clamp Down on Corruption
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); INTERVIEWS (77%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (75%); LOBBYING (73%) Zimbabwe; Transport and Shipping; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Police have purchased an undisclosed number of vehicles with state-of-the-art equipment that will record officers' activities at roadblocks in a bid to curb corruption. In an interview yesterday, Police Commissioner-General Augustine Chihuri said they wanted a record of what happened at roadblocks. "We will purchase these vehicles by end of this month and through the recordings we will be able to know what has been happening and what they will be doing. "Let me express my uttermost displeasure at some unprincipled police officers who, in contrast to the dictates of the organisation's values and ethos, engage in corrupt activities thereby tarnishing the revered image of the organisation. "It is disgusting to note that some police officers now have the courage and audacity to ask for bribes even in full view of the public without guilt," he said. He said professional policing required integrity. Comm-Gen Chihuri warned members of the public who offered bribes to the police. "In such instances, our police officers on the ground should remain professional and take a bold stance in rejecting such offers of bribes. "It is my firm belief that if those who offer bribes are snubbed, they are less likely to insist," he said. Comm-Gen Chihuri said he was aware that salaries were low and he would continue to lobby Government for more resources improvement of working conditions.

TITLE: Nation Still Gripped by Corruption
COUNTRY: SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); NAMIBIA (90%); BOTSWANA (53%); CAPE VERDE (53%); MAURITIUS (53%); SEYCHELLES (53%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); TRENDS (73%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Namibia remains "highly corrupt" in the eyes of the world, having slipped further down the 2010 graft ladder of Transparency International (TI). The latest Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI), released by TI yesterday, gave Namibia a score of 4,4 out of ten, a slight drop from the 4,5 it received last year. Any country scoring less than five points is perceived as "highly corrupt" by the global watchdog for domestic and public sector graft. Namibia was ranked 56th out of 178 countries this year compared to 56th out of 180 countries last year. In 2008 it held the 61st position, compared to the 57th spot in 2007. The recent trend is a far cry from the period of 1998 to 2002, when Namibia was continuously ranked amongst the top 30 least corrupt countries in the world. In Sub-Saharan Africa, Namibia slipped to the sixth position from fifth last year. From 2001 to 2003 Namibia held the second spot. The top five countries in Sub-Saharan Africa this year are Botswana (5,8); Mauritius (5,4); Cape Verde (5,1); Seychelles (4,8) and South Africa (4,5). Although Namibia's 2010 score is better than its all-time low of 4,1 points from 2004 to 2006, it is a drastic drop from its record-high of 5,7 points in 2002.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission to Bring Suspected Illegal Phone Operators to Court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (91%); ETHICS (90%); INTERNET TELEPHONY (90%); EVIDENCE (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); TELEPHONE SERVICES (90%); BAIL (78%); INTERNET CRIME (78%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (78%); ARRESTS (78%); COMPUTER SOFTWARE (78%); MOBILE & CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS (78%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (78%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT (67%); SMALL BUSINESS (66%) Ethiopia; ICT and Telecom; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The Federal Ethics and Anti-corruption Commission (FEACC), which has been leading the investigation of 18 suspects detained for running illegal internet telephone services, is to bring them before the Federal High Court on Monday, November 22, 2010, after two consecutive extensions of time to collect evidence. The FEACC arrested 43 suspects during a raid conducted in different areas of the city in October 2010. At their appearance in front of the Federal High Court First Criminal Bench within 48 hours of the raid, the police requested more time to conduct its investigation. The hearing was adjourned to November 9, when investigators again asked for more time, which the court granted, adjourning the case until this week. In the interim, 25 of the suspects were released due to lack of evidence, according to Gelanan Asefa, advisor of Public Relations for the FEACC. "Some were just employees," he told Fortune. The others were denied bail because the investigation involves corruption, for which bail rights are denied. "The Anti-corruption Commission is involved because employees of the Ethiopian Telecommunications Corporation (ETC) are suspected of involvement in these businesses," Gelanan told Fortune. Many small businesses in the city charge less than ETC for international calls. While ETC charges 12.65 Br per minute, the prices of these businesses, using various Voice-over IP (VoIP) software, depend on the country and mode of communication used: land line or wireless. On average, the cheapest price charged is to the United States (US) at three Birr; the most expensive is to Eritrea, to which ETC does not allow calls. Account numbers, similar to the recharge card used for mobile phones, for Ras Addis, one of the most popular software programmes circulating the capital, valued from 25 dollars up to 100 dollars, are sold at different places in town. It was particularly agents selling these account numbers who were targeted by police during the raid, disclosed sources close to the investigation who are not authorised to comment. Although some of those in custody are suspected of being agents, investigators are hard at work to find the others, the sources disclosed.

TITLE: Help Us Stamp Out Corruption, Ombudsman Urges Journalists
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (99%); JOURNALISM (90%); PRESS CONFERENCES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (68%) Rwanda; Press and Media; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Ombudsman, Tito Rutaremara, has urged media practitioners to take the lead in the fight against corruption. Addressing a press conference at the launch of the National Anti-Corruption Advisory Council in Kigali over the weekend, Rutaremara said that although a lot had been achieved, much more remains to be done. "In general, our country has made tremendous progress regarding the fight against corruption and injustices, but we still have a long way to go; so I encourage you as journalists to always expose those involved in injustice and corruption cases because that's one of the best ways of combating the vice, " said the Ombudsman. Rutaremara, however, cautioned journalists to carry out investigations before exposing those alleged to be corrupt. In reference to the recent Transparency International's ranking of Rwanda as the eighth least less corrupt country in Africa, he said that mission is to make Rwanda the least corrupt country in the world. The country was ranked 66th in the world. Rutaremara said that the objective of creating the Council was to ensure that the anti-corruption institutions join hands in their fight against corruption and injustice by exchanging information on corruption. The launch was also attended by the Vice President of the Supreme Court, Professor Sam Rugege.

TITLE: Civil Service Must Condemn Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); CIVIL SERVICES (90%); POLITICAL PROTESTS (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); PUBLIC EMPLOYEE RETIREMENT SYSTEMS (90%); PENSION FUNDS (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); MISAPPROPRIATION (77%); SCANDALS (73%); APPOINTMENTS (73%); PETITIONS (73%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: IT would perhaps be more meaningful if the civil service took a strong stance towards corruption as a whole, rather than confine itself simply to protests over the Government Institutions Pension Fund (GIPF) issue alone. While it is undoubtedly so that the GIPF misallocations of millions in loans is a matter of huge concern, this is by no means the only, or the worst, example of misappropriated monies. It does concern the pension monies of civil servants, which is certainly the reason GIPF is featuring more prominently than other financial scandals, but it is also clear that the pensions themselves are not at risk. For the National Union of Namibian Workers (NUNW) therefore to confine their proposed protest action simply to demand the suspension of GIPF trustees, could quite conceivably be a waste of time and resources. If their stance concerned corruption in general, and calling Government to account for all the missing monies, it may be a wake-up call for the ruling party in a country where graft is clearly increasing. This in spite of the window-dressing of a so-called zero tolerance approach and an Anti Corruption Commission (ACC), among others. The newly appointed 'media' advisor to President Hifikepunye Pohamba, Mukwaita Shanyengana, has condemned the planned mass protests as 'premature', adding that they "would only disrupt the provision of services and affect the national economy negatively. For this reason, President Pohamba would find it difficult to accept a petition from the workers in this regard. He added that President Pohamba did not in any way condone misappropriation of funds at GIPF or any other Government institution, and also wanted to get 'to the bottom' of the matter. The President has been joined in his opposition to the planned mass protests by other key Government officials, and most recently Cabinet Secretary, Frans Kapofi, warned government permanent secretaries against granting leave to public servants who wanted to protest next Wednesday. The Constitution obviously gives Namibians the rights to peaceful protest and demonstrations and the standoff between NUNW and Government on this matter was not resolved at the time this editorial was written. There is merit in the arguments on both sides of the coin. But Namibia and Namibians have probably not yet spoken out clearly enough against corruption in all its manifestations, and the proposed protest therefore, should not simply be confined to GIPF alone. There have been times and occasions in the past where the NUNW and other unions have been complicit in their silence over corruption and graft, and their voice must be unequivocal on this issue. If the civil service, and all Namibians by extension, are serious about combating corruption, then they should also be prepared to sacrifice to this end, if necessary, demonstrating over a lunch hour or on a weekend to show that they are serious. Corruption after all, affects everyone in Namibia and not the civil service alone. We would support a strong stand by the civil service, the unions and all Namibians against corruption, and a call for Government to account on all missing monies, the GIPF funds included, and should not be selective when it comes to such protests.

TITLE: EAC - Fight Against Corruption Stepped Up [opinion]
COUNTRY: AFRICA (97%); BURUNDI (95%); KENYA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (93%); RWANDA (79%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); NOVELS & SHORT STORIES (75%); SURGERY & TRANSPLANTATION (73%); WRITERS (69%); POLICE FORCES (66%) Rwanda; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Is Africa, at last, wriggling out of the clutches of corruption? This question has been inspired by recent declarations of zero tolerance by governments in the East African region to the evil that has bedeviled the continent for far too long. The vice of corruption may not be of African descent but the continent has appropriated it and its extent, both in depth and breadth, on the continent, has surpassed the levels of whoever might have invented or pioneered it. African scholars, notably Chinua Achebe, were disturbed by the extent of corruption practiced by the new African leadership during the early days of independent Africa. In his novel, A man of the people published in 1960s, Like Kenyan writer Ngugi wa Thiongo in Petals of Blood, Achebe explicitly showed how our leaders colluded with agents of neocolonialism to exploit, not only African resources, but also to undermine the dreams of Uhuru Africans had fought for; The dreams of prosperity, dignity, equity and equality ad infinitum. Corruption is indeed a cancer that slowly eats in the social fabric, and when not diagnosed, and treated early would need a major surgical operation that may entail severing off the affected organs. As it is now, the operation at this stage calls for the most senior surgeons - the ladies and gentlemen occupying the highest dockets of our governments. The presidents, the judges, senators, members of parliament, cabinet ministers and ministers of the church. Starting from Burundi which fared badly in the recent corruption rating by Transparency International, I was impressed by President Pierre Nkurunziza's declaration of zero tolerance to corruption (Igiturire), which has been roundly applauded by Burundians at home and abroad. One gentleman said on BBC Imvo n'Imvano Kinyarwanda/ Kirundi programme that he had to leave his country because he saw no future in a country so corrupt, echoing the Achebe and Ngugi premonition decades back, that corruption and inept leadership were bound to be serious impediments to postcolonial progress. The story told by the Burundian was indeed more absurd than the fictional character of Chief Nanga in A Man of the People. Having lost his passport abroad and equipped with necessary documentations from his Embassy, the gentleman returned to Bujumbura to apply for a new passport but he was stunned by a passport officer who rejected his photographs on the grounds that they were so clear t that hey could not have been taken in Burundi. This serves to show how corruption has been entrenched in Africa. Stories of corruption on the continent abound, so in this article we use only two countries for the purpose of illustration. In Burundi, like in Kenya, there are specialized institutions to fight corruption which include special police forces and courts. The integrity centre in Nairobi houses the Kenya Anti-corruption Commission. These institutions can only work effectively if the leadership does not merely pay lip service to war against the vice. How do we exterminate the culture of "man eateth where man worketh"? The answer can only be found in total commitment at all levels and of course civic education. During the corruption debates on BBC in the last two weeks, Rwanda was repeatedly cited as exemplary. Although I don't have any corruption indices to be able to tell levels of corruption, as a person who lives in Rwanda, I know that the leadership has no tolerance for corruption. I have seen big shots in real trouble-that is deterrent enough, but also, in addition, there has evolved anti -corruption discourse that reminds us all of the evil. Kenya seems to have taken the fight against corruption to the highest quarters, with both the Executive and Parliament determined to show the way. Three ministers have been suspended to pave the way for investigations and a number of Permanent Secretaries and parastatal bosses have been sidelined or face charges related to corruption. Kenya's re-energized war against corruption has won praise from other countries and will certainly improve business and investment opportunities. I have heard a few social friends trying to rationalize corruption saying that it sometimes helps individuals out of problems. That is double faced corruption because it used to impinge on laws established to regulate society. There is no good or bad corruption and, as veteran Kenyan Politician, Koigi wa Wamwere, wrote in The Daily Nation of 4th November, corruption is theft whether we conceal it in unclear terms like misappropriation and corrupt people are, simply, thieves. They steal from the public who are the losers if roads and other infrastructure are 'eaten', hospitals working below capacity; schools are inadequate because some individuals have to satisfy their unquenchable lust for wealth. The war against the evil can only be won if the men and women in top public positions, the media and civil society, show incorruptible integrity themselves. It is only then that Africa will occupy a decent position it deserves in the international community.

TITLE: EAC Must Battle Corruption to Promote Trade - Kiraso
COUNTRY: EASTERN AFRICA (95%); BURUNDI (92%); AFRICA (79%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); RULE OF LAW (89%); HUMAN RIGHTS (87%); ETHICS (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); CRIMINAL LAW (77%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%); EXTRADITION (73%); NONTARIFF BARRIERS (72%); TAXES & TAXATION (70%) Trade; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Deputy Secretary General of the East African Community (EAC), Beatrice Kiraso, has reaffirmed the bloc's commitment to fighting corruption, saying the vice is negatively affecting trade in the region. The official made the remarks during the just concluded East African Law Society annual general meeting in Bujumbura, Burundi. While emphasizing that corruption is an evil that undermines development and provision of social services, Kiraso said that the challenge has not been the absence of instruments to fight the vice at national level, but implementation and enforceability. "It increases the cost of doing business and in the case of EAC it can be a non-tariff barrier to trade," she said. "To effectively market the EAC as a single tourist and investment destination and trade zone and to negotiate effectively as a bloc in international fora, it calls for high levels of integrity, transparency and accountability." Kiraso added that a protocol on preventing and combating corruption has been developed covering asset recovery and forfeiture, transfer of criminals and criminal proceedings among other key provisions. The protocol provides for extradition, judicial cooperation and mutual legal assistance and establishes a financial intelligence unit. On human rights, Kiraso said that the EAC notes the need for harmonisation of strategies and benchmarks in the region towards promotion and protection of human rights, adding that the EAC regional plan of action is under development. "In this regard, the extension of jurisdiction of the East African Court of Justice to include human rights is pertinent," she added. The regional bloc has developed a draft protocol on good governance with four pillars which include; constitutionalism, rule of law and access to justice, democracy and democratization processes. Others are; protection and promotion of human rights and equal opportunities; and combating corruption and enhancing ethics and integrity.

TITLE: Joint Efforts Will Eradicate Corruption Within EAC
COUNTRY: RWANDA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (93%); BURUNDI (79%); UGANDA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%); KENYA (79%); AFRICA (79%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); BUDGETS (90%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (89%); POLLS & SURVEYS (73%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (72%); BEST PRACTICES (64%) Rwanda; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: The Deputy Secretary General of the East African Community (EAC) last week announced that the Economic Bloc Has Developed a Protocol On Preventing And Combating Corruption in the Five Member States. Research has indicated that corruption levels vary drastically across the EAC member states. According to a recent survey by Transparency International, Rwanda is the least corrupt in the EAC region, with only 6 percent of its national budget believed to be lost, yearly, through corrupt tendencies, while Burundi was found the most corrupt where graft was rated at 38 percent of the country's total national income. Uganda was rated the second most corrupt, losing an average total of 36 percent of its national income to graft, Kenya came third with an estimated 29 percent of national income lost annually through corruption, while Tanzania emerged the second least corruption in the bloc, losing about 28 percent of national income to corrupt officials.
