District Coordinating Officer Kenema district, Mohamed Sylvanus Blake said that the commission is only providing leadership in the fight against corruption and that it is the responsibility of every Sierra Leonean including the pupils and teachers to support it in its fight to eradicate corruption in Sierra Leone. Mr. Blake explained the procedure for reporting corruption and encouraged both pupils and teachers to report corruption not only as their support to the commission but also as a demonstration of their love for the country. He gave out the hot lines through which they can report corruption and left them with the slogan "what is not for you don't take it". A question and answer session formed part of the programme. The following schools were visited: Holy Rosary Secondary School (JSS &SSS); Holy Trinity Secondary School (JSS &SSS); Islamic Secondary School (JSS &SSS); and the Kenema Government Secondary School (JSS &SSS).

TITLE: Regional Blocs Intensify Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); NONTARIFF BARRIERS (92%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (92%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); BRIBERY (77%); COMMERCE DEPARTMENTS (72%); ECONOMIC POLICY (71%); ECONOMIC NEWS (71%); INTERVIEWS (69%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: As the three regional blocs (COMESA, EAC and SADC) continue to integrate their economies, countries have been advised to emulate Rwanda's mechanism of fighting corruption. The call was made, in Kigali on Tuesday, by Helen Kenani a trade expert from COMESA during a two-day meeting of sensitizing nationals on mechanisms of eradicating Non-Tariff Barriers (NTBs) in the region. The trade expert said that the regional economic integration cannot be fully realized if some tripartite member states have to deal with corruption. "We wish to see all member states corruption free as Rwanda has done; otherwise if such non tariff barriers still exist in our member states we shall not achieve the economic integration," Kenani said in an interview. The NTBs mentioned include corruption, unnecessary roadblocks, weighbridges and lack of mutual recognition of quality standards, as these have become impediments in regional economy. Member states of the EAC have, for the past few years, embarked on reducing these barriers to trade. She added that online mechanism had been established to enable stakeholders to report and monitor non-tariff barriers encountered in SADC, COMESA and EAC as way of eradicating them in the region. "If, for example, a driver transporting cargo is stopped at the border and is asked for a bribe, he has authority to submit complaint through email to the tripartite secretariat," she said. Meanwhile, Peace Basemera, a trade negotiator in the Ministry of Trade and Commerce commended the online mechanism, saying that it will tackle corruption and enhance economic cooperation. "We have been meeting regularly to discuss traders' problems and this online mechanism will help to reduce NTBs," she said The Tripartite comprises 26 member countries from the three regional blocs.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption Will Foster Regional Economic Intergration [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (92%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); BRIBERY (78%); NONTARIFF BARRIERS (78%); EMERGING MARKETS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (77%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (77%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%); TAXES & TAXATION (73%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (72%); ECONOMIC NEWS (68%); RULE OF LAW (68%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: This week, countries in the region were advised by trade experts to emulate Rwanda's strategies of fighting corruption, as three regional blocs (Comesa, EAC, and SADC) continue to integrate their economies. Comesa members pointed out, during the two-day meeting, in Kigali, to examine how to eradicate Non-Tariff Barriers (NTBs) in the region, that if the war against corruption is not fought collectively, the region would fail to attain economic prosperity. For the region to succeed at all fronts better mechanisms to fight corruption must be adopted and there must be a strong will on the part of the governments. The vice should concern the entire region. A corrupt free-environment will not only foster trade, but will improve the welfare of the citizens. Findings from World Bank reveal that corruption is evidently Africa's greatest threat to economic development, as well as human survival. Indeed, like the trade experts noted, regional economic integration cannot be fully realized if some partners continue to render lip services. Corruption undermines the rule of law and weakens the institutional foundations upon which economic growth depends. Bribery, nepotism and other forms of corruption exist in the region and this, if not eliminated, remains the greatest obstacles to economic and social development.

TITLE: Corruption Laws Challenged [analysis]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LAWYERS (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (78%); INDICTMENTS (78%); CRIME PREVENTION (78%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (76%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (76%); APPOINTMENTS (76%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (71%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (70%); COMPUTER SCANNERS (63%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Two of the main weapons in Namibia's arsenal for the fight against corruption and organised crime are set to face a constitutional attack in the High Court. Key parts of the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003 and the Prevention of Organised Crime Act of 2004 are unconstitutional, corruption and fraud suspects Teckla Lameck and Kongo Mokaxwa are arguing in a case that was filed with the High Court yesterday. Public Service Commission member Lameck and Mokaxwa, who is a business partner of Lameck, are asking the court to declare parts of the two laws, which provide the backbone of eight of the 18 charges they and a co-accused, Chinese national Yang Fan, are facing in the High Court in the city of Windhoek, as unconstitutional. They are also questioning the legality of the appointment of senior Cabinet member Pendukeni Iivula-Ithana as both Minister of Justice and Attorney-General in 2005. Lameck and Mokaxwa are asking the court to declare that Iivula-Ithana's appointment as Justice Minister and as Attorney-General was against the Constitution. If they succeed in getting such a declaration from the court, the operation of the entire Prevention of Organised Crime Act is in danger, as it was Iivula-Ithana who, in her capacity as Justice Minister, announced in the Government Gazette in April 2009 that the Act was coming into operation from May 5 2009. Defence lawyer Sisa Namandje, who is representing Lameck and Mokaxwa, informed Judge President Petrus Damaseb of the constitutional challenge that his clients have launched when they and Yang made another pre-trial appearance in the High Court in Windhoek yesterday. Lameck, Mokaxwa and Yang are facing charges over an alleged corrupt deal in which Chinese-made security scanning equipment was bought by the Ministry of Finance in 2008. They are charged in an indictment containing 18 counts. Lameck is facing all of the charges, while Mokaxwa is charged with 12 counts and Yang is charged with six. The charges against all three include a count of fraud, in which they are accused of having defrauded Government between October 1 2006 and March 17 2009 when the Ministry of Finance bought security scanning equipment from a Chinese company, Nuctech, at a price of US$55,3 million (then about N$477 million). It is alleged that the price of the equipment was inflated to enable Nuctech, which was being represented by Yang, to pay a "commission" of at least US$12,828 million to Teko Trading, a close corporation of Lameck and Mokaxwa. This "commission", of which about N$42 million was paid, allegedly was to be shared between Lameck, Mokaxwa and Yang. Lameck and Mokaxwa alone are also accused of having defrauded a Swapo-owned company, Namib Contract Haulage, between December 16 2006 and June 10 2009 by getting the company to pay inflated prices for trucks that it was buying in China. Lameck was a director of Namib Contract Haulage, while Mokaxwa was an employee of the company. Lameck alone is facing six charges under the Anti-Corruption Act, based on allegations that while being a Public Service Commissioner she was engaged in other paid work - primarily the activities of Teko Trading CC and its alleged corrupt involvement in the Chinese X-ray scanner deal - without the permission of President Hifikepunye Pohamba. Lameck, Mokaxwa and Yang are also jointly charged with two counts under the Prevention of Organised Crime Act. The three suspects have pleaded not guilty to all charges that they faced when their case was still before the Windhoek Magistrate's Court. In the constitutional challenge filed yesterday it is being argued that Iivula-Ithana was not lawfully appointed as Justice Minister and Attorney-General in 2005. This, Lameck is arguing in an affidavit, is because the Constitution does not allow the Attorney General to also be a member of the Cabinet. "Clearly the Constitution demands an independent legal functionary, who may not, by the very wording of the Constitution, be a member of Cabinet, and bound by the principles of Cabinet allegiance and responsibility," Lameck argues. She claims that because Iivula-Ithana's dual appointment as Justice Minister and Attorney-General was unlawful, her determination of the date that the Prevention of Organised Crime Act came into operation was also unlawful, with the result that the Act never started operating. The Anti-Corruption Act's definition of the term "corruptly" is being attacked as unreasonable, vague and too wide. The Act defines "corruptly" as meaning "in contravention of or against the spirit of any law, provision, rule, procedure, process, system, policy, practice, directive, order or any other term or condition pertaining to any employment relationship; any agreement; or the performance of any function in whatever capacity". States Lameck on this score: "(M)any thousands of laws, provisions, rules, procedures, processes, systems, policies, practices, directives and orders are to be found in Namibia. (. . .) These rules may be found in every conceivable printed document, whether stored in a drawer, on the top of a cupboard, or even in the national archives. They may not even be in writing. But when the Anti-Corruption Act became of full force and effect, it is not only the contravention of these rules which may constitute a crime. Also a perceived transgression of the relevant 'spirit' of those rules may constitute a crime." The main thrust of the challenge to the constitutionality of the Prevention of Organised Crime Act is directed at that law's provision that it also covers "unlawful activities" that took place before the Act came into operation. Such a provision that makes the Act operate retrospectively "is patently unconstitutional", Lameck claims. She argues: "(T)he retrospective effect of the definitions 'unlawful activity' and 'proceeds of unlawful activities' has the potential of criminalising activity, which was not an offence at the time it was committed, and make property which was previously legally obtained (. . .) subject to confiscation." All of the acts over which they are charged in connection with the Chinese scanner deal took place before the Prevention of Organised Crime Act came into operation, Lameck points out. The case filed yesterday appears set to keep the criminal case against Lameck and her co-accused pending until the constitutional matter has been dealt with. Lameck, Mokaxwa and Yang now have to attend another pre-trial hearing in the High Court on April 7. Lameck and Mokaxwa are remaining free on bail of N$50 000 each. Yang is free on bail of N$1 million. He spent a year and four months in custody before his bail was paid in November last year.

TITLE: Senate Fears Dumping Morlu is Lost War On Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); PRESS CONFERENCES (68%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The debate over the rejection or re-nomination of Auditor General John Morlu has hit the Senate, with some senators warning that if he is dumped, the President's declared war on corruption will be lost. "If Morlu is replaced, it would have to disrupt the fight against corruption," a UP Senator who preferred to be anonymous told this paper Thursday. There has been a public frenzy over speculations that Mr. Morlu, regarded as one of the prime champions for transparency who has transformed the GAC from a moribund institution to an internationally respected one, will be shown the door once his contract ends sometime next month. These speculations are rife despite the President's acknowledgement, in her State of the Nation Address, that the AG has been unwavering and committed in the fight for transparency. But Presidential Press Secretary Cyrus Badio told journalist last week that media speculations on the alleged pitfalls of sacking Mr. Morlu will not help the AG because, he added, the President will not bow to pressure. Speculations are that the President is determined to get a new Auditor General that she is comfortable with, although there is no confirmation of this. However, speaking to this paper at a press conference Thursday, Sen. Blamo Nelson [of the Alliance For Peace and Democracy (APD) Grand Kru County], said although it is not an easy decision to make, the President's impending decision on Morlu could either continue the fight against corruption or stop it. Senator Nelson: "Other leaders reached a similar point in the past, and we saw how their stance against corruption was defeated when they chose a path that they think was good. Re-nominating Morlu would mean well for all of us. "Morlu has done a very good job. Personally, I would regret if he were not retained by the President. Therefore, this administration should not back away like others. We should remain on course. There was no Chart of Account. Today we have a chart. This fight against abuse and corruption should definitely be retained." Mr. Morlu has been at odds with several government officials listed in his audits for their failure to account for hundreds of thousands of dollars meant for government projects and programs. On the other hand, his work has been endorsed by several donors, including the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Mr. Bruce Wharton, who recently observed that: "Liberia's Auditor General has aggressively and thoroughly tracked government revenue from practically every ministry, but the government follow-up has been very disappointing. Some crucial bills affecting key resources such as timber and maritime revenue have been passed without adequate attention to key details. Furthermore, the government must begin addressing a wide variety of issues affecting national reconciliation."

TITLE: Prince Johnson Vows Executions for Rape, Corruption, As President
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (89%); ELECTIONS (79%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); CAPITAL CRIMES (78%); WAR CRIMES (78%); MILITARY & VETERANS LAW (75%); BUDGETS (75%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (75%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Presidential aspirant Prince Johnson Monday vowed to use the same methods he is accused of using during the war --executions--for corruption, rape, among others, if he is elected president. Speaking at his party's headquarters in Sinkor on Monday upon his return from Nigeria, where he said he met with Former Nigerian President Obasanjo, he admitted executing people, but justified his actions by saying the executed people had no right to rape. "During the war we instituted guidelines, special operational procedures to govern our combatants. And we said no raping. Rape is a capital crime. If you rape, execution. It's not good to execute, but it's not also good to rape somebody's child," he said. "We will fight corruption to the letter. We will make it impossible for you to steal people's money. You may say Sen. Johnson is just talking because he hasn't got the post. The former warlord turned lawmaker told his partisans that if he did all that when he was a warlord in a state of "anarchy," what should one expect when he becomes president in his endeavor to fight "societal ills"? "So if we had this guide lines during the war to protect women and girls against rape, during the war when lives were cheap, when your life depended on the gun-toting men, and we instituted these rules to govern the activities of combats, protecting lives and properties in conflict in a state of anarchy, what do you think when we are there(elected President) what will happen?" he asked. Dressed in a cream-like coat and a gray pair of trousers, Sen. Johnson declared himself 'fit' for the elections and promised more reforms in several sectors, including health and education, where he said the largest budget amounts would be allotted if he is elected president. Senator Johnson (Nimba), former leader of the erstwhile rebel group, the Independent National Patriotic Front of Liberia, a breakaway faction of Mr. Charles Taylor's National Patriotic Front of Liberia, is listed in the Truth and Reconciliation Report as "the most notorious" and recommended, amongst several others, for prosecution for war crimes.

TITLE: Karugarama Shares Nation's Strategy to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS (77%); TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (73%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (70%); INVESTIGATIONS (65%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (57%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Minister of Justice, Tharcisse Karugarama, yesterday, delivered a keynote address at an anti- corruption conference in Maseru, Lesotho, organized by the Government of the Kingdom of Lesotho, the Commonwealth Business Council and the Business Action against Corruption. The theme of the conference was "Business Action against Poverty: Public-Private Strategies to Improve Governance" Karugarama, who represented President Paul Kagame spoke about Rwanda's policy of zero tolerance on corruption and how the vice has been reduced massively. He noted that fighting corruption in Rwanda started in a conventional way, but has since gone on to include the support of the private sector, helping the government to tackle the problem at five levels. "First, was the political level which formed the basis for subsequent actions. There had to be strong political will among leaders in order to influence policy and implementation of strategies," Karugarama said. "Second, at the level of prevention and enforcement, we enacted laws and set up institutions and systems of transparency, accountability and monitoring. Such institutions as the Rwanda Revenue Authority and the Rwanda National Examinations Council ensure transparency," he added. The minister also cited other institutions like the Office of the Ombudsman and the Auditor General which promote and monitor accountability and prevent abuse of office and resources. He said that the creation of special units like the Police, Judiciary and National Public Prosecution Authority to investigate, prosecute and adjudicate corruption cases, have been crucial in fighting the vice. Karugarama said that the government instituted monitoring mechanisms at the technical level, taking advantage of available technology. "The Government of Rwanda made doing business in the country easier by simplifying and reducing licensing and registration procedures, mainly through increased use of ICT," Karugarama said. "This has removed the need for business people wanting to set up business in Rwanda, to cut corners, and has eliminated corrupt officials who would take advantage of lengthy and complex procedures," added the Justice Minister. He noted that the zero-tolerance stance on corruption is accompanied by prosecution of offenders, whether they are from the public or private sector, while the recovery of stolen assets is also ensured, making corruption is a "very risky venture". The Minister emphasised that corruption is very costly to both governments and businesses and, as such, negatively affects development efforts. The main objective of the conference is to assess the impact of public-private partnerships in fighting corruption.

TITLE: "Corruption is Old..."
SUBJECT: GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); AUDITS (89%); AGREEMENTS (76%); EUROPEAN UNION (74%); WAGES & SALARIES (68%); SUITS & CLAIMS (65%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, under pressure to halt the continuing spread of corruption, says it is almost as the country. "As I have always said, corruption is not a new problem in Liberia. It is almost as old as the country itself. Therefore, the fight against it has got to be the responsibility of all Liberians, and it will take time, sacrifices and patience from all of us," the President said in announcing that she will not renew the contract of Mr. John Morlu as Auditor General. The President did not elaborate on what she meant, but she recently said she had underestimated the strength of corruption from the onset, despite her extending experience in government and international service dating from the 1970s. "European Union concluded an agreement with the Auditor-General to pay the salary for the first four years of the contract, with the understanding that the Liberian Government will assume this responsibility thereafter. We want to thank the European Union for ensuring that the Auditor-General's compensation was lucrative and for providing other forms of support to the GAC for the past four years." The President indicated that in conformity with the Act, approved 5 May 2005, which changed the status of the General Auditing Commission, the Deputy Auditor-General will act in the capacity of the Auditor-General until, through a professional recruitment process, a new Auditor-General is nominated. She said she will ask for continued financial and technical support of the European Union to the General Auditing Commission. This, she said, will enable her government to act even more effectively in fighting corruption and in pursuing appropriate legal action against those charged with financial malpractice in the 40-plus audit reports that have been concluded. "Please be assured," she continued, "that the change in the Auditor-General represents a mere change in person. Our commitment to continue the fight against corruption remains inviolate."

TITLE: Naming and Shaming Offending Contractors Will Help Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (76%); BRIBERY (74%); ADMINISTRATIVE LAW (74%); EMBEZZLEMENT (71%); EXTORTION (66%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: Up to 43 companies are currently banned from bidding for public  tenders after they were blacklisted by the Rwanda Public Procurement  Authority (RPPA). The parastatal blacklists, for up to three years,  companies found to have deliberately failed to deliver on their  contractual obligations or flouted the tendering process. Previously, there have been reports of some public officials colluding with contractors to embezzle public funds. However, in most cases, it is the officials who get punished with contractors walking scot-free. In such circumstances, both parties are culpable and deserve to be held accountable, whether through criminal or administrative course of action. With RPPA now boldly taking administrative measures against offending contractors as well, including naming and shaming, the blacklisted companies will think twice before committing the same offences again. The measures will also serve as an example to other companies that may consider doing shoddy work or flouting the tendering process. In fact, once the suspension is lifted, past offenders may end up playing a crucial role in the fight against corruption by exposing officials attempting to extort a bribe from them in exchange for a public tender. The blacklisted companies must be shunned until they have been cleared to run for public tenders.

TITLE: Ecowas Anti-Graft Agencies Rate Anti-Corruption Laws Strongest
COUNTRY: SIERRA LEONE (98%); WESTERN AFRICA (97%); NIGERIA (95%); AFRICA (94%); BENIN (79%); MALI (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (68%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (68%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (68%); LARCENY & THEFT (67%) Sierra Leone; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Sierra Leone's deputy anti-graft commissioner, Morlai Buya Kamara, has profoundly articulated the uniqueness that characterizes the operations of his country's Anti-Corruption Commission at the ECOWAS Commission conference hall in Asokoro, Abuja, Nigeria to the full view of West African anti-corruption chiefs. Mr. Kamara was speaking during a general meeting and formal launch of the Network of National Anti Corruption Institutions in West Africa (NACIWA), where he left participants with no option but to describe Sierra Leone's anti-corruption laws as the strongest not only in West Africa but the continent as a whole. The virtue in Sierra Leone's anti-corruption laws were exhibited when four countries including Mali, Benin, Nigeria and Sierra Leone represented by deputy commissioner Morlai Buya Kamara, were carefully selected to showcase best practice in fighting corruption. Though all of them spoke on investigation and partnership with the media, some spoke on prosecutorial powers: but quite distinctly, Kamara spoke on some traits of the Sierra Leone Anti-Corruption Commission which distinguishes its strength, role and efficacy - to an extent that it got an acknowledgement of its laws being the strongest in Africa. According to Kamara, partnerships with the media and civil society, coupled with a very strong political will demonstrated by the government and its leadership, have immensely contributed to the success of the Sierra Leone Anti-Corruption Commission. "We have unfettered access to any area of the commission's interest; the commission has no evidence what so ever whereby its work suffered impediment due to interference from any arm of government," the deputy ACC commissioner said. He added: "The 2008 amended Anti-Corruption Act gives powers to the commission to prosecute all cases without fiat from the Office of the Attorney General." "We have twenty-nine (29) categories of anti-corruption offences, and the minimum year of conviction is three years imprisonment, and it also makes provision for recovery of stolen assets. More importantly, the Sierra Leone Anti-Corruption Commission Act provides security of tenure for the commissioner and his deputy." Representing Sierra Leone at the meeting were Commissioner Morlai Buya Kamara and one of the commission's directors, Shollay Davies.

TITLE: Corruption Challenge Delay
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (78%); IRRADIATION APPARATUS MFG (77%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); COMPUTER SCANNERS (77%); CRIME PREVENTION (73%); BAIL (72%); COMPANY STRUCTURES & OWNERSHIP (70%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The three people facing fraud, corruption and other charges in connection with a multi-million dollar transaction in which the Ministry of Finance purchased Chinese-made X-ray scanning equipment in 2008 were back in the High Court in Windhoek yesterday, to be told that their case was being postponed to July 14 for another pre-trial appearance. Chinese national Yang Fan , Public Service Commission member Teckla Lameck (centre), and a business partner of Lameck, Kongo Mokaxwa, were told that a constitutional challenge that Lameck and Mokaxwa have launched would first have to be heard and finalised before their criminal trial would be starting. Lameck and Mokaxwa want the High Court to declare key sections of the Anti-Corruption Act and the Prevention of Organised Crime Act unconstitutional. They and Yang are accused of having corruptly obtained payments totalling N$42 million through the transaction in which the Finance Ministry bought security scanning equipment from a Chinese manufacturer, Nuctech Company, at a total cost of US$55,3 million (then about N$477 million). Lameck and Mokaxwa alone are also accused of having defrauded a Swapo-owned company, Namib Contract Haulage, between December 16 2006 and June 10 2009 by getting the company to pay inflated prices for trucks that it was buying in China. The three suspects remain free on bail until their case returns to court.

TITLE: Simeon Freeman Vows to March Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (90%); ARRESTS (78%); TREASON (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); MIDDLE EAST PROTESTS & UPRISINGS (72%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (65%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (64%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Though President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf termed as April fool her threat that presidential aspirant Simeon Freeman risks being arrested for treason if he carried out a planned rally against corruption, the opposition politician has renewed calls for the demonstration. "We will not relent; the planned march against corruption will take place. It will take place simultaneously throughout the country. Jail is not really one of the things I am afraid of," says Mr. Freeman, leader of the Movement for Progressive Change (MPC). "Loosing my life is certainly not one of the things I am afraid of; I am ready to go to jail for the liberation of my people," he said on Monday. Speaking to journalists at his party headquarters in Fiama, Mr. Freeman said that President Sirleaf is an "autocrat who has desecrated her office by being facilitator of corruption in the country". "...Madam Sirleaf, as the facilitator of corruption, is not qualified to enjoy our trust because she is an autocrat who has no democratic credential, no institution of fighting corruption. "Therefore, we must say no to her and never again allow her to fool us. This must stop. And this election, I am going to throw everything I have to democratically oust her," he emphasized. Though he refused to elaborate on the methods of the planned demonstration, Mr. Freeman said civil society organizations and opposition blocs would participate in the demonstration. Mr. Freeman: "We will soon be forwarding a letter to the Ministry of Justice requesting them to permit us to have our peaceful demonstration against corruption in the country. If they refuse to honor our request, there are other means we can deploy. It will be held on the 30th of April 2011." But Zanzan Karwor, head of the National Traditional Council (NTC), has condemned Mr. Freeman's planned march and cautioned him to respect the presidency. "If you want to demonstrate and the president hears it and talks against it, you should not challenge it. I am talking for this country because demonstrations brought problems in Libya," Chief Karwor noted. He urged all Liberians to boycott Mr. Freeman's call for a march against corruption, stressing: "Nobody should get on the streets for corruption. I know corruption in Liberia can't finish. Everybody in Liberia is corrupt."

TITLE: Corruption 'Exacerbated'
COUNTRY: LIBERIA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); JURY TRIALS (89%); BRIBERY (89%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS (78%); APPROPRIATIONS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (76%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (76%); MISAPPROPRIATION (75%); BUDGETS (75%); WAGES & SALARIES (74%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (73%); ACQUITTAL (73%); COUNTIES (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (73%); LAWYERS (72%); TELECOMMUNICATIONS (69%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (68%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (68%); SUPREME COURTS (68%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (68%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (60%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; United States, Canada and Africa
TEXT: The State Department 2010 Human Rights Report on Liberia has repeated findings in the 2009 Report, saying 'corruption is widespread and systematic in the Government. Reacting to the State Department's 2009 Report, the government disagreed, with President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf announcing that she would send a protest letter to US Secretary of State Hilary Clinton. But in its just released 2010 Report, the State Department noted: "The law does not provide criminal penalties for corruption, which remained systemic throughout the government, although criminal penalties do exist for economic sabotage, mismanagement of funds and other corruption-related acts." It added: "Official corruption and the sense of a culture of impunity were exacerbated by low pay levels for the civil service, lack of job training, and a lack of court convictions. The government dismissed officials for alleged corruption and recommended others for prosecution. The Liberian Anti-Corruption Commission (LACC) and the Ministry of Justice are responsible for exposing and combating official corruption. The LACC is empowered to prosecute any case that the Ministry of Justice declines to prosecute; however, the Ministry had not declined to prosecute any such cases during the year. "The LACC, which had a minimal budget and insufficient staff, investigated eight cases and recommended four for prosecution. Included in the recommendations were former Inspector General of Police Beatrice Munah Sieh for irregularities in the appropriation of uniforms and two Ministry of Finance officials for their alleged roles in misappropriating civil service salary checks. The LACC reported 21 additional corruption cases were pending investigation by year's end. "Former Liberia Telecommunications Authority chair Albert Bropleh was acquitted on a technicality for alleged misuse of $71,022; however, the case was under review by the Supreme Court at year's end. "Judges were susceptible to bribes from damages that they awarded in civil cases. Judges sometimes requested bribes to try cases, release detainees from prison, or find defendants not guilty in criminal cases. Defense attorneys and prosecutors sometimes suggested that defendants pay a gratuity to appease judges, prosecutors, jurors, and police officers or to secure favorable rulings from them. Jurors were also susceptible to bribes, and the Ministry of Justice increased its calls to reform the jury system. "Despite her strong emphasis on decentralization, President Sirleaf froze County Development Funds pending ongoing audits due to evidence of frequent misuse; such funding was intended to support local projects to reduce poverty. The move to recentralize administration of local development projects was widely seen as a result of inadequate local management, which often funneled development funds to support political interests of legislators rather than to reduce poverty."

TITLE: No Major Change -Corruption, Police Brutality, Abuse of Power Still Exist
COUNTRY: LIBERIA (94%); UNITED STATES (93%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); HUMAN RIGHTS (91%); CRIMES AGAINST PERSONS (90%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); DUE PROCESS (78%); FREEDOM OF SPEECH (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (78%); DISCRIMINATION (78%); SEX OFFENSES (77%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (77%); ARRESTS (77%); VEHICULAR OFFENSES (77%); INDICTMENTS (76%); ETHNIC CONFLICTS (76%); CHILD TRAFFICKING (76%); DOMESTIC OFFENSES (76%); CHILD ABUSE (76%); DOMESTIC VIOLENCE (74%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (73%); FREEDOM OF PRESS (72%); ACQUITTAL (71%); VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT (71%); WOMEN'S HEALTH (70%); CHILDREN (69%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (69%); CHILD LABOR (69%); ETHNICITY (68%); HUMAN TRAFFICKING (68%) Liberia; United States, Canada and Africa; Human Rights
TEXT: The United States Department of State has released its 2010 Human Rights Reports on Liberia with no considerable progress from its 2009 status. Like the 2009, the 2010 report released on Friday, April 8, 2011 cited corruption with impunity, police excessiveness, corruption in the judiciary and a media that solicit payments to publish stories. "Human rights abuses included one report of mob killing; reports of ritualistic killings; reported incidents of trial by ordeal; police abuse, harassment, and intimidation of detainees and others...." the reported claimed. Harsh prison conditions, arbitrary arrest and detention, judicial inefficiency and corruption, lengthy pretrial detention and denial of due process, official corruption and impunity, violence against women including rape, and widespread domestic violence, are featured in the report. Widely practiced female genital mutilation (FGM), child abuse and sexual violence against children, human trafficking, continued racial and ethnic discrimination, and child labor did not escape the claws of the report. One of the major issues of power abuse highlighted by the report come from the National Legislature with two lawmakers involved. The Report: "In May Representative George W. Blamoh allegedly beat an LNP officer who attempted to impound his vehicle for improper parking and traffic violations. An investigation was completed and submitted to the Ministry of Justice, and Blamoh was awaiting trial at year's end. "On July 10, Deputy Speaker of the House Togbah Mulbah allegedly ordered the beating of LNP officer Lexington Beh for impounding a truck belonging to the lawmaker. The incident became politicized when partisans from the lawmaker's political party, the Congress for Democratic Change, surrounded Mulbah's residence the next day as police attempted to arrest him. Upon further investigation, an 11-count indictment was issued in July, and Mulbah was awaiting trial at year's end." However the Deputy Speaker had been acquitted. The reported that there was freedom of the press, free speech, and free movement and associations, and that there were no politically motivated killings and political prisoners during the period under review. Meanwhile, the Liberian Government has not commented in this years report published on pages 4 and 5 of this paper.

TITLE: Again the U.S. Verdict On Corruption [column]
COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); LIBERIA (94%); AFRICA (92%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); HUMAN RIGHTS (90%); VERDICTS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (89%); LARCENY & THEFT (74%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (74%); AIDS & HIV (66%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; United States, Canada and Africa
TEXT: The 2010 US State Department Human Rights Report on Liberia, capturing human rights and related developments in the country, is out. From it, the verdict of the US State Department is harsher than its verdict in 2009. In its previous report--2009--the US State Department ruled that corruption prevailed at "all levels" of the Government. This meant that there were no exceptions, no saints, all condemned. In its current report, its verdict is extreme. Corruption, it said, has been "exacerbated," and that it prevails, triumphantly, within the entire government with impunity. Excerpts from the report: "The law does not provide criminal penalties for corruption, which remained systemic throughout the government, although criminal penalties do exist for economic sabotage, mismanagement of funds and other corruption-related acts. Official corruption and the sense of a culture of impunity were exacerbated by low pay levels for the civil service, lack of job training, and a lack of court convictions. The government dismissed officials for alleged corruption and recommended others for prosecution. "The Liberian Anti-Corruption Commission (LACC) and the Ministry of Justice are responsible for exposing and combating official corruption. The LACC is empowered to prosecute any case that the Ministry of Justice declines to prosecute; however, the Ministry had not declined to prosecute any such cases during the year." The disturbing conclusion, that the "law does not provide criminal penalties for corruption," is disturbing. If so, then we can now begin to grasp the gravity of the plague that permeates the society at all levels. Because there is no law against those who plunder state resources, talks of fighting the disease is useless. An illness that has no medicine cannot be cured, and those afflicted by it must die. Thus corruption is like AIDS in Liberia. There are no laws against it. It is free for all, a factor that explains the stampede for public office since, once within, nothing can be done to stop one from stealing. It is said that there is an entrenched culture of impunity, meaning fear for theft of public funds is unnecessary since there are only rewards and no punishment. The US conclusion also explains why, despite all the anticorruption public relations, not a single official has been convicted or punished. Those dismissed, in some cases, have been recycled. If Africa's oldest independent republic lacks laws against corruption, the single most powerful factor responsible for the country's immensely shameful underdevelopment, then the national decay that have resulted in wars and anarchies can be easily understood. It is unlikely that the status quo, under the command of individuals benefiting from the virus, particularly within the Legislature responsible for making laws, will change anytime soon. That this legislature is incapable of passing laws to make corruption a criminal offense is unlikely because, according to the US Report, it refused to forward for prosecution several of those that the General Auditing Commission discovered have stolen huge sums of money from the state. We believe that the Government should embrace this report, instead of challenging its findings as it has done with similar reports in the past. Living in denial is a dangerous option. Accepting truth can lead to honest attempt in finding solutions. The first attempt, we believe, is passing laws to make corruption a criminal offense with stiff penalties, including outright confiscation of property. But we are not delusional. This is a challenge that the current legislature maybe unable, unwilling and unready to take up.

TITLE: Big Money for Improved Civil Service, Corruption Fight
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); BUILDING RENOVATION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); BUDGETS (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (90%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (88%); CIVIL SERVICES (79%); APPROVALS (78%); RISK MANAGEMENT (76%); DISASTER RELIEF (74%); ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (71%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: Government plans to fork out a whopping N$154 million for the improvement of the public service cadre. Motivating for the approval of the budget of the Office of the Prime Minister in Parliament yesterday, Nahas Angula, said the amount would go towards the recently launched Namibia Institute of Public Administration (NIPAM) and the performance management system. The public service management and improvement functions are performed by the Public Service Commission. The second largest allocation in the Prime Minister's office, N$40 million goes towards the construction of the NIPAM building, the renovation of the old State House, the construction or renovations of various offices or warehouses of the Disaster and Risk Management Department. The National Emergency and Disaster Fund receives an annual allocation of N$20 million. Angula said a bill to establish a statutory body responsible for disaster reduction and management would be tabled before Parliament in due course. For Cabinet and parliamentary functions, an allocation of N$37 million was made. Approximately N$7.5 million was allotted for special programmes under the Prime Minister's office. These are N$3,9 million for the San social inclusion programme; N$862 000 for the disability advocacy unit; N$700 000 for the development of the economic empowerment framework; N$1 818 000 for the public office bearers remuneration commission; and N$200 000 for the National Alliance for the Improvement Nutrition unit. Angula also motivated for a massive increase in the budget of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) of N$62 540 000, up from N$36 786 000 of the previous financial year. This is for the two main programmes of the ACC, which are the investigation of corruption (N$37 million) and N$25 million to put in place anti-corruption measures. Angula said the ACC needs Government's support to effectively fight the scourge of corruption, arguing that adequate funding is needed to place the ACC in a position to do so. During the last financial year the ACC investigated 294 reports of alleged corruption. The ACC referred 56 cases to the Prosecutor General with a recommendation for prosecution, while numerous others were referred to other relevant authorities. Angula said in virtually all instances, the matters were only referred after preliminary inquiries were conducted. He reported a reduction in the number of non-mandate related complaints, and attributed it to actions taken against offenders and public educational campaigns. The ACC has recruited 10 additional staff members during the last financial year.

TITLE: Freeman's Anti-Corruption March Allowed
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (79%); POLICE FORCES (79%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); JOURNALISM (77%); LAWYERS (75%); VEHICLE TRAFFIC (71%); PRESS CONFERENCES (71%); WRITERS (71%); VANDALISM (68%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Officials at the Justice ministry says presidential aspirant Freeman Simeon of the opposition Movement of Progressive Change (MPC) is at liberty "to go and get his permit" requested for his planned nationwide demonstration against corruption. According to reports, Mr Freeman plans to stage a simultaneous demonstration in Liberia's 15 counties on 30th April against corruption. In reply to a journalist's question during a regular information ministry press briefing Thursday, Solicitor General M. Wilkins Wright said: "Yes, Mr. Freeman will be granted a permit to demonstrate as he has requested to demonstrate throughout the 15 counties, especially the principal cities of the counties." He said, "Mr. Simeon Freeman is free to mobilize, as many (people) as he wants (in order) to carry out the demonstration". But Cllr. Wright added: "The caution there is peaceful", stressing that "nobody is muscling Mr. Freeman, threatening, intimidating and nothing is going to happen to him". However, Cllr. Wright warned that "if Mr. Freeman comes in conflict with the law, he will be held accountable for the consequences of putting people in the streets thus vandalizing cars, damaging stores, and beating on innocent people." "He has taken the first step to comply with the law which is to write and seek a permit...that letter is been responded to. We have granted his permit; he can now go and get it. But he is not going to block traffic," emphasized. Cllr.Wright said the Liberia National Police will work along with Mr. Freeman to map out his routes so as to maintain the free flow of traffic. In reply to the heavy presence of policemen at street corners here, Cllr. Wright said "the month of April has a history in this country, and if police are present at various corners should that be a problem to you? I say no." He continued: "If you were big enough April 14,1979, we all know or should know what happened on April 12, 14 and 6. There are too many instances of April in this country, and so an event taking place in April, the police are to take precaution; but it was not directed to Mr. Freeman.

TITLE: Corruption Remains Systemic - US Report
COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); LIBERIA (94%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); JURY TRIALS (89%); BRIBERY (89%); LAWYERS (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); APPROPRIATIONS (77%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (77%); MISAPPROPRIATION (76%); BUDGETS (76%); EXTORTION (73%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (70%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (70%); WAGES & SALARIES (68%) Liberia; Crime and Corruption; United States, Canada and Africa
TEXT: The US Government 2010 human right report on Liberia stated that corruption remained "systemic" in the country despite efforts by the Ellen Johnson Sirleaf's administration to deal with the deep-seated social problem. "The law does not provide criminal penalties for corruption, which remained systemic throughout the government, although criminal penalties do exist for economic sabotage, mismanagement of funds and other corruption-related acts," Section Four of the report titled 'Official Corruption and Government Transparency', stated. The US Government report released this month was last week corroborated by the Liberian Government when the Ministry of Justice, in its report on corruption, declared that corruption was prevalent at all levels of society including the public and private sectors. President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf who promised to make corruption public enemy number one in her administration in her 6th State of the Nation Address January said despite the many progress pout into place to combat the maniac, corruption remains a formidable force to battle-but progress have been made during the last five years.. The US Government's report particularly pointed at widespread corruption including bribery and extortion in the country's justice system with jurors and police officers at center stage. Solicitor General Wilkins Wrights in his report to the cabinet admitted to the claim by stating that one of the obstacles in fighting corruption is the jury system. Cllr. Wright noted that corruption related acts are committed by citizens...and can b e classified as high or low ranging from economic sabotage to bribery. The Solicitor General called for a total reform of the Jury System. The US report claimed that "Official corruption and the sense of a culture of impunity were exacerbated by low pay levels for the civil service, lack of job training, and a lack of court convictions." "The government dismissed officials for alleged corruption and recommended others for prosecution," stated the report. The Liberian Anti-Corruption Commission (LACC) and the Ministry of Justice are responsible for exposing and combating official corruption. The LACC is empowered to prosecute any case that the Ministry of Justice declines to prosecute; however, the Ministry had not declined to prosecute any such cases during the year. The LACC, the report noted, which had a minimal budget and insufficient staff, investigated eight cases and recommended four for prosecution. Included in the recommendations were former Inspector General of Police Beatrice Munah Sieh (now a representative aspirant in the pending elections) for irregularities in the appropriation of uniforms and two Ministry of Finance officials for their alleged roles in misappropriating civil service salary checks. The LACC reported 21 additional corruption cases were pending investigation by year's end. The report: "Judges were susceptible to bribes from damages that they awarded in civil cases. Judges sometimes requested bribes to try cases, release detainees from prison, or find defendants not guilty in criminal cases. Defense attorneys and prosecutors sometimes suggested that defendants pay a gratuity to appease judges, prosecutors, jurors, and police officers or to secure favorable rulings from them. Jurors were also susceptible to bribes, and the Ministry of Justice increased its calls to reform the jury system." It said despite her strong emphasis on decentralization, President Sirleaf froze County Development Funds pending ongoing audits due to evidence of frequent misuse. The Funds were intended to support local development projects to reduce poverty. The move to recentralize administration of local development projects was widely seen as a result of inadequate local management, which often funneled development funds to support political interests of legislators rather than to reduce poverty. Following is an excerpt of the report: "The government dismissed or suspended a number of officials for corruption stated the report. For example, in April the comptroller for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and a senior financial officer were dismissed for allegedly stealing $4,500 intended for the country's embassy in Nigeria. In May the Bureau of Immigration and Naturalization recommended six officers for prosecution for collusion in the escape of six Bangladeshi detainees. The case was pending investigation at year's end. In June the National Security Agency arrested three Ministry of Finance officials for soliciting bribes of $10,000 each from the Cocopa Rubber Plantation Company. The case was pending investigation at year's end. On September 24, the government dropped the 2007 economic sabotage case against former National Transitional Government of Liberia chair Charles Gyude Bryant due to a lack of evidence. On October 12, President Sirleaf recommended senior officials for dismissal and referred others for further investigation for their involvement in the Carbon Harvesting Corporation deal, a carbon-credit agreement containing irregularities that would have resulted in significant loss of government revenue. The investigation of the former assistant superintendent for development in Grand Cape Mount County was pending at year's end following his October 2009 dismissal for involvement in the disappearance of approximately $90,000 from the Grand Cape Mount County Development Fund. The March 2009 case against the former minister of information Lawrence Bropleh was dismissed with prejudice on December 7. The dismissal cited the prosecution's alleged failure to appear in court; however, the Ministry of Justice contested the judge's claim. A writ of prohibition to undo the judge's decision was before the Supreme Court at year's end. Police corruption was a problem. During the year the LNP investigated reports of police misconduct or corruption, and authorities suspended or dismissed several LNP officers. For example, in August an LNP officer was charged with property theft and was awaiting trial at the end of the year. In June a senior LNP official was accused of assaulting an individual over a personal misunderstanding. The official was suspended and ordered to pay restitution; however, no restitution was made and he remained suspended by the end of the year. On October 9, the LNP director announced the implementation of complaint forms to be submitted by the public to report incidents of bribery or unethical practices. In November an LNP officer was arrested for allegedly permitting his acquaintances to use his police uniform to commit acts of armed robbery. He was released and returned to duty due to a lack of evidence. There were no developments in the September 2009 case of the former Monrovia chief of patrol indicted for looting the house of a private prosecutor. During the year the government continued to take steps to improve transparency. The General Audit Commission continued its ministerial audits and referred findings to the legislature. However, the legislature did not recommend any cases to the Ministry of Justice for prosecution."

TITLE: LCC Plot Scam Exposes PF Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); POLITICS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); MAYORS (89%); CITIES (89%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); CONSTRUCTION (77%); INTERVIEWS (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (74%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (73%); LEGISLATION (66%); ROAD & BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION (50%); HIGHWAYS & STREETS (50%) Zambia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Government has said the high-level corruption exposed at the Lusaka City Council has exposed the Patriotic Front (PF) inherent appetite for corruption and warned Zambians to be wary of the opposition party ahead of the elections this year. In an interview in Lusaka yesterday, Local Government and Housing Minister Brian Chituwo said PF president Michael Sata had been accusing the Government of being corrupt but had not issued a statement to condemn his councillors and MPs. Dr Chituwo said Zambians must judge which of the two parties was corrupt following allegations that MPs who had been named in the PF shadow cabinet were named as beneficiaries of the 102 plots that were irregularly shared. The minister said the on-going investigations at the country's biggest council had revealed deep scandals apart from the Lilayi Housing project. Dr Chituwo said the team had continued receiving submissions from the members of the public on many other irregularities that were unknown, which forced him to extend the suspension from the initial 90 days for another three months. He said the Government had faced a lot of accusations that it was corrupt but the PF had failed to provide evidence for the law-enforcement officers to investigate. Dr Chituwo said the Government had operated in an open and transparent manner, which had helped raise more resources for the construction of roads and hospitals countrywide. He said avoiding corruption at 100 per cent was impossible in any government but its commitment had been shown with the enactment of new laws such as the Whistle Blowers Act and strengthening of the anti-money laundering systems. The minister urged residents to continue providing reports on what they knew about corruption at the LCC in order to improve service provision for the local government to operate efficiently. Dr Chituwo, who is MMD chairperson for local government, said people were quick at condemning the Government on the basis of the Auditor General's reports but never followed up when recoveries were made. He said the Government always ensured that people mentioned refunded the Government and where crime had been detected, such people were handed over to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC). Dr Chituwo said the PF had been malicious against the Government and wondered what answers they had over the high levels of corruption at the council. Lusaka City Council was involved in a land scam in which councillors mayors, MPs, PF officials such as secretary general Wynter Kabimba were given plots that were not advertised in line with the law. Later reports indicated that Lusaka Mayor Daniel Chisenga sold oneplot to a resident of Lusaka. The mayor was allocated 10 plots while his deputy had five and the acting town clerk received five. Meanwhile, Dr Chituwo has said the LCC will remain suspended until the investigations that were currently going on are concluded. Dr Chituwo said some of the offences that were leveled against some officials were serious, hence the need for investigations to be allowedto be concluded. Dr Chituwo, who was speaking when he featured on Radio Phoenix's Let the people talk programe on Tuesday said the Government wanted to set up structures that would protect the council from any future abuse from office-bearers. "How possible is it that one person can get 10 plots? We want to get to the bottom of this for now and for the future," Dr Chituwo said. Dr Chituwo said in the event that the investigations established that criminal activities took place within the council, the inquiry would be handed over to the law-enforcement agents for further cause of action. "I want to tell the nation that the Government is on course but the issues are complex and require time. We have to ensure that the findings are true and fair," Dr Chituwo said.

TITLE: Police Cautions the Public Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (91%); BRIBERY (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (73%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Rwanda National Police would like to caution the public to steer away from corrupt tendencies. The vice is taking a new twist, where on several occasions, perpetrators have attempted to bribe Police officers. In a period of less than one month, police officers have rejected bribes of Frw 200,000; Frw 100,000 and Frw 7,000 respectively, in Rubavu, Gicumbi and Nyabihu. With the country's zero tolerance to corruption, the Rwanda National Police calls on the general public to desist from corruption. In its capacity as the law enforcement institution, RNP is determined to ensure that all those involved in corruption activities are brought to justice. Rwanda National Police takes the opportunity to thank those who have refused to be drawn into corruption. It also expresses its gratitude to whistleblowers for their boldness in reporting corruption instances to law enforcers. It further encourages them to continue giving information related to corruption instances so that it can be combated.

TITLE: Govt, UK Sign MOU on Corruption
COUNTRY: UNITED KINGDOM (98%); SIERRA LEONE (96%); EUROPE (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); AGREEMENTS (90%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (90%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (56%) Sierra Leone; Europe and Africa; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The Sierra Leone Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has signed an anti-corruption Memorandum of Understanding with the government of the United Kingdom. The purpose of the MoU, according to a joint statement released by the two countries, was to provide a framework for ongoing dialogue between the ACC and UK on matters of common interest in Sierra Leone. "It underscores our shared commitment to good governance and transparency and recognises the need to reinforce joint collaboration aimed at reducing poverty in Sierra Leone," the statement said. Building on the Department for International Development's (DFID) support for the ACC, the agreement will provide support to building the capacity of the ACC to undertake preventative programmes and carry out investigations; to detect, freeze and recover assets stolen from Sierra Leone which are held in the UK; to improve cooperation on corruption investigations which have a UK dimension; and where relevant and possible, HMG will assist the ACC in facilitating contacts with third countries where these are required in such investigations. British High Commissioner to Sierra Leone, Ian Hughes, said: "This agreement will put at Sierra Leone's disposal international expertise and anti-corruption networks in the UK and the wider EU. This will extend the ACC's reach beyond Sierra Leone's shores and make it much harder for the corrupt to hide their ill-gotten gains." For his part, ACC Commissioner Joseph F. Kamara said "the agreement will further cement the growing relationship between the UK government and the ACC in the campaign against corruption, and usher in a new dawn of rigorous pursuit of the proceeds of corrupt acts at the international level".

TITLE: N$71 Million Corruption Accused Still in Hospital
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); MAGISTRATES (90%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (89%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); HYPERTENSION (78%); ARRESTS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (76%); UNOFFICIAL ECONOMY (73%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (72%); BAIL (71%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Tomorrow it will be one month since multimillion-dollar corruption accused Esmerelda Majiedt was hospitalised for high blood pressure, an ear infection and for her left leg to be elevated. The 46-year-old woman was admitted to the Windhoek Central Hospital on April 7 - shortly after she had made a second court appearance for allegedly embezzling more than N$71 million from her former employer, AfriSam Cement, since 2007. During her appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court yesterday, Majiedt's lawyer, Bradley Basson, told Magistrate Ruth Herunga that he had no idea how much longer his client would need to stay in hospital. Basson said: "The doctor is unable to discharge her [now] as her blood pressure is still fluctuating." Basson asked Herunga that Majiedt should "not be brought to court for a mere postponement, should she not be discharged before her next court appearance". Public prosecutor Hans Thourob said the State "will not entertain a formal bail application while the accused is still in hospital". Majiedt was arrested on April 4 by officials of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC). She is accused of having masterminded the corruption bonanza by manipulating her former employer's accounting system and using their own money to pay for truckloads of cement. This allegedly enabled her to have the cement released from the company's premises where it was picked up by third parties. Majiedt's alleged accomplices - all still at large - then allegedly sold the cement on the black market after which the money was allegedly shared by them. The alleged fraud was detected when Majiedt wrote off stock worth more than N$13 million earlier this year. As the company is in the process of winding down its Namibian operations, it is suspected that she did the write-off to conceal her alleged corruption. Yesterday Herunga postponed the case to June 1 for further Police investigation.

TITLE: Majiedt 'Corruption' - Trucker's Suicide Link?
SUBJECT: SUICIDE (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); TRUCKING (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (77%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); ARRESTS (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (74%); UNOFFICIAL ECONOMY (72%); SHOOTINGS (69%) Namibia; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: The mysterious suicide two weeks ago of a Windhoek man involved in the trucking industry has raised renewed questions about who shared the N$71 million cake with corruption accused Esmerelda Majiedt. Yesterday an official close to the probe confirmed they received information that Gavin van Wyk, who committed suicide recently, may have been an accomplice of Majiedt's. This could however not be confirmed by Acting Director of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), Erna van der Merwe. Gavin van Wyk, a Windhoek businessman and a shareholder in SBS Trucking, committed suicide on April 16 - just five days after his 37th birthday and less than two weeks after Majiedt was arrested. According to Khomas Regional crime investigation coordinator Deputy Commissioner Silvanus Nghishidimbwa, Van Wyk shot himself at his home in Windhoek at about 22h00 on April 16. Nghishidimbwa said Van Wyk left no suicide note. "What forced him to do that is not known to us." Van Wyk's body was found by relatives and no foul play is suspected, the Police officer said. SBS Trucking's financial manager, Klaus Beukes, yesterday confirmed that they transported "four or five loads" of cement per week for AfriSam from Windhoek to Swakopmund. Beukes also confirmed that they dealt with Majiedt as she was "chief in charge of everything". He, however, maintained that there could not have been any underhand dealings. "I am the financial guy and there is no way that it could have happened. Gavin did not do any invoicing. Our books are open for any investigation." Majiedt is accused of having manipulated the accounting system of her former employer, AfriSam Cement, over a period of four years. This alleged corruption spree enabled her to have truckloads of cement released from the company's premises, picked up by third parties and sold on the black market. After spending 32 nights under Police guard in hospital, Majiedt was discharged yesterday. Majiedt's lawyer, Bradley Basson confirmed her release from the Windhoek Central Hospital yesterday. Van der Merwe, of the ACC yesterday said the ACC did not doubt the seriousness of the illness that kept Majiedt in hospital for longer than a month. Responding to a question by The Namibian about the possibility that the 46-year-old Majiedt was being hospitalised to delay the legal process, Van der Merwe said: "That would be a very dangerous thing to say, because I am not a medical practitioner. Doing that would also cast doubt on the credibility of the doctor. It is not something that we would like to question at this stage." Since her hospitalisation on April 7, Majiedt spent both her birthday and Mother's Day in the Windhoek Central Hospital. She was admitted merely three days after she was nabbed by officials of the anti-graft watchdog. In a medical statement handed in to court recently, it was stated that Majiedt needed to be hospitalised to rest, have her high blood pressure monitored, an ear infection treated and her left leg elevated. She was meant to be returned to the Wanaheda Police station yesterday. Magistrate Ruth Herunga postponed Majiedt's graft case last Thursday to June 1 for further Police investigations to be done. Majiedt, the alleged kingpin in the N$71 million corruption case, is the only one who has been arrested thus far. All van der Merwe was prepared to say yesterday about the progress of the investigation was: "We're making good progress, yes." She maintained that other arrests were "not excluded".

TITLE: ACC Presents 'Corruption Proceeds' to Pres. Koroma
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ANNUAL REPORTS (90%); FINANCIAL RESULTS (89%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (87%); FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE & REPORTS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); ANNUAL FINANCIAL RESULTS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (77%); THIS DAY IN HISTORY (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (70%) Sierra Leone; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Commissioner of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) last Friday presented to President Ernest Bai Koroma the 2010 Anti-Corruption Commission Annual Report at State Lodge in Freetown. Joseph Fitzgerald Kamara also handed over to the president two cheques of six hundred and eleven million, one hundred and forty-one thousand leones (Le611,141,000) and nine thousand four hundred and fifty US dollars ($9,450), being monies recovered from proceeds of corruption. Mr. Kamara informed President Koroma that within the course of the year in review, the ACC had presented to the government a total of one billion, eight hundred million leones (Le1,800,000,000), despite the fact that the commission was not a revenue generating agency. He assured the president that the ACC would continue to complement the work of his government by making sure there were enough recovery proceedings. Kamara also informed the head of state that in the course of the last six months, the commission prosecuted 17 new cases in which there were 8 convictions and 2 acquittals. In his response, President Koroma said he was satisfied with the promptness of the commission. "I am very pleased that the Anti-Corruption Commission has submitted their report which is an indication of the level of efficiency and the speed with which you are doing things within the organization. So let me start by commending you for the timely submission of the report," commented President Koroma. He reaffirmed his government's support to the commission in the fight against corruption, while encouraging them to keep up with the good work. The Annual Report 2010 examines the convictions, cases acquitted and discharged; recovery details; case reports; systems review in ministries, departments and agencies, service charters, development of Codes of Conducts for local councils; community outreach meetings, general challenges, the way forward, and the Financial Report for 2009.

TITLE: 'In a State Where Corruption Abounds, Laws Must Be Very Numerous' - Tacitus [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (76%); POLLS & SURVEYS (66%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (54%) Sierra Leone; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: Sierra Leone has a corruption problem, and Britain is leading efforts to help deal with it. Sometimes I am called a hypocrite for this: how dare Britain criticise corruption here when it exists in Britain too! Not so? Critics who say this misread our motive. Britain does not judge Sierra Leone: corruption is a fact of life everywhere, a crime that stems from human greed just like theft and fraud. As Tacitus told his Roman readers, all countries have to arm themselves with laws to deter, prevent and detect it. All countries need to work together vigorously to keep it in check. Corruption is particularly dangerous for Sierra Leone. It diverts development funds, undermines social programmes and distorts government decisions. Winning the battle against it is essential to address the chronic poverty and deliver prosperity to a nation celebrating its 50th birthday. Sierra Leone has effective anti-corruption legislation and an active Anti Corruption Commission (ACC). I am pleased that the UK is helping by providing encouragement, technical advice and financial support through DFID. But Sierra Leoneans decide priorities, investigate allegations, prosecute the accused and determine their fate: the progress made is entirely theirs. The passionate response to the ACC decision on the NASSIT ferry issue in newspapers, on radio and TV demonstrates that Salones care deeply about that progress. Bravo: in a democracy it is important that government knows that the public is on its side in such a difficult struggle. Yet the public know the struggle is not over. A recent survey commissioned by the ACC shows public perception of continuing corruption in some ministries and in the Sierra Leone Police. While more needs to be done it is an uncomfortable fact that as the ACC gets better, its job gets harder. As it tracks ill-gotten gains through Sierra Leone's banks, corrupt big fish have moved their money off-shore. So last week the Anti Corruption Commissioner and I signed an MOU plugging the ACC into the UK's own system for tracking and combating corruption. This allows it to track ill-gotten gains through banks in the UK and beyond.  It signals Sierra Leone's determination to fight corruption effectively and it demonstrates continued UK support. We are both determined that this MOU will not gather dust on government shelves. Already we are planning how to put it to work.  I'll let you know how we get on.

TITLE: Corruption Fight Effective - Anti Graft Body
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); BRIBERY (92%); ETHICS (78%); POLLS & SURVEYS (77%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (74%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (73%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (50%) Rwanda; Crime and Corruption
TEXT: A new study by Transparency International (T.I) shows that the fight against corruption is paying off. The study dubbed 'Rwanda Bribery Index (RBI) 2010' measures bribery levels in the private and public sectors Speaking at the launch of the index, last week, the chairperson of Transparency Rwanda, Immaculee Ingabire, pointed out that the research shows that the likelihood of encountering a bribe demand is 3.9 percent while the prevalence of bribery is at 2.15 percent. "Bribery levels in our country are so low, and we commend all the institutions that fight corruption on a daily basis," Ingabire said. The research is the first attempt by any organisation to intensely analyse the current state of this specific form of corruption in the country. Respondents in the survey mention the police as the leading institution in fighting corruption. 43.2 percent said they had faith in the police on fighting corruption followed by the Ombudsman at 17.6 percent and the Presidency at 15.5 percent. The survey dwelt on small bribes and petty corruption. Almost 90 percent of the bribes paid were below Rwf50, 000 while 40.5 percent were below Rwf5, 000. According to the research, the Police has the highest prevalence of bribery rated at eight percent, closely followed by civil society at five percent, village conciliators at 4.2 percent and private sector at 3.2 percent. Bosco Binenwa, an ethics and culture professor at Kigali independent University (ULK), reacting to the report, explained that because Police are law enforcers, it makes them susceptible to bribes. "They are exposed to bribery from people who fear being apprehended or fined larger sums of money," Binenwa said. Police spokesperson, Theos Badege, concurred that the nature of their work makes them prone to bribes, but noted that the institution has mechanisms to facilitate the elimination of the vice. "We are fighting corruption in every way possible and that is why the Police has come top on the list of the institutions fighting corruption," Badege said. He added that taking a bribe is outlawed and all officers within the force are aware of the grave consequences should they be found guilty of taking bribes. Speaking at the launch of the report, the Minister of Local Government, James Musoni said: "Though the government has put in place a number of ways to check corruption, it is always important to have an outsider's view." He added that he was confident that such perception surveys would help government to fine-tune zero tolerance strategies to corruption. The Minister urged the civil society and the media to do more in educating the public about corruption.

TITLE: Unmil Official's Honest Observations On the Tenants of Corruption
SUBJECT: ETHICS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); JURY TRIALS (90%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); INTELLIGENCE & COGNITION (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); FOUNDATIONS (76%); EXECUTIVE ORDERS (69%); CONSULTING SERVICES (67%) Liberia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; International Organizations and Africa
TEXT: UNMIL Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary General, Henrietta Mensa-Bonsu, has made some remarkable, but no so strange, suggestions that the government should seriously consider if public confidence in state institutions is to be salvaged. She called for relentless prosecution of corrupt public officials. She said if this is not done, public trust in the government will continue to be eroded. Political institutions are therefore endangered. The official reflected on the oddity within the judicial system, one that allows illiterate men and women to serve on the jury and are expected to render intelligent, fair and acceptable judgments on complicated cases. The UNMIL official further noted that there is a need for a Code of Conduct governing public officials. These are ideas which, if accepted and applied, could mitigate the graft hemorrhage for various reasons. Illiterate jurors, whatever their virtues, cannot understand the complexities of cases for acceptable verdicts. This erodes faith in the judicial system. A Code of Conduct that bars public officials from running NGOs, foundations and other projects or businesses while in office is long over due.
