Within the prevailing political atmosphere that is free for all, conflict of interest is protected because it opens the avenues for siphoning of public funds into private coffers through NGOs, foundations, etc. Dumping public funds on private projects has been a perennial problem now entrenched, and it will require a revolution, not cosmetic reforms, to alter it. Historically, the entire state bureaucracy--ministries and agencies, etc.-- have been run from private buildings owned by political elites or their extensions. This trend has taken a more sophisticated form, leading to the establishment of declared 'private' enterprises such as cronies-run consultancies through which state funds are channeled. By occupying influential public offices and running NGOs, foundations or businesses, the condition for abuse is created. This is one of the reasons why it has been suggested that donors can better channel funds through the state and its official institutions than via private foundations and NGOs beyond the reach of audits and probe. A Code of Conduct for public officials was one of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf's announced priorities. Formulated and adopted, it would have given the public yardstick for measuring performance. But since the pronouncement was made, the idea has simply died. The argument that the Legislature must approve such a Code of Conduct to make it legally binding, however logical, is impractical. This is because this Legislature, unwilling for its members to be audited, is unlikely to subject members to a code of conduct. But what we believe that the President can do is to subject officials within the Executive branch to a Code of Conduct made legal through whatever means, including an Executive Order. It is however never too late. There is a need for a Code of Conduct as the UNMIL official has suggested, with mechanisms to monitor compliance.

TITLE: Court Lays Out Proof Needed for Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); SENTENCING (89%); FINES & PENALTIES (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (77%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: A POLICE officer who was convicted of corruption after he received a payment of N$2 000 from a complainant in a case he was asked to help investigate has been cleared in an appeal judgement handed down in the High Court last week. The judgement, given on Thursday, is an important ruling with regard to the question of what the prosecution would have to prove to show that a public official who has accepted any form of gratification is guilty of a crime in terms of the Anti-Corruption Act of 2003. It would have to be proven not only that the official has received a payment, but also that the official had a "guilty mind" in that the official knew he or she was committing a crime by accepting the payment, is the effect of the judgement by Acting Judge Harald Geier. Judge Naomi Shivute agreed with Acting Judge Geier's ruling. The judgement was given in an appeal that a Police officer, Joel Paulus, lodged after he was convicted in the Otjiwarongo Magistrate's Court on a charge under the Anti-Corruption Act and sentenced to an effective fine of N$5 000 or two years' imprisonment. Paulus was suspended from his work when an Otjiwarongo district farmer, who had asked him to help trace a suspected cattle thief, paid him N$2 000 on October 24 2006. According to the farmer and Paulus the money was to help cover petrol and travelling expenses. The farmer decided to approach Paulus, whom he knew as an effective Police officer, for assistance after he felt frustrated by the inaction of the Police at Otjiwarongo, the trial court was told. By accepting the money, though, Paulus's conduct fell squarely within the ambit of conduct prohibited by the Anti-Corruption Act, Geier found. Geier found that the Anti-Corruption Act does not criminalise conduct on the basis of strict liability, where it would be sufficient for the prosecution to prove only that the law had been transgressed without taking into account what the state of mind of the alleged offender was. To prove the offence that Paulus was accused of, the prosecution would also have to prove that an accused person had a "guilty mind", in that the person knew what he or she was doing was against the law, the court found. The evidence before the magistrate showed that it was not for any dishonest or corrupt motive or purpose that a request for assistance was made and the N$2 000 was offered and accepted, the court further found. Paulus's conviction and sentence were set aside.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Lacks in Key Areas - IPPR
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); LEGISLATION (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (77%); STATE OWNED BUSINESSES (50%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (50%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: DESPITE extensive legislation aimed at fighting corruption, the Namibian anti-corruption laws do not go far enough in regulating against the potential for corrupt behaviour, according to the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR). In the first of the eight research papers to be published under its newly launched anti-corruption research programme this year, the IPPR has reviewed the anti-corruption law and related legislation in Namibia, identified key shortcomings and has made a number of recommendations. Lacking an over-arching national anti-corruption policy or strategy, Namibia has been unable to spell out the linkages between the various laws and agencies to create a united front against corruption. The IPPR have noted that agencies responsible for fighting corruption, such as the ACC, have been operating in "jurisdictional bubbles," with very little cooperation and coordination between them. This lack of coordination and cooperation does not only exist between law enforcement agencies, but "appears to permeate the workings of the entire public sector." Despite the law being clear and far sighted, this indicates a general lack of understanding of the role of the ACC.Inadequate skills capacity and expertise within the public sector has become a serious concern in the fight against corruption and service delivery in general. "The lack of relevant and sufficient skills and resources at every and various junctures in the criminal justice chain charged with combating graft necessarily affects the quality of the state's response to such destructive practices." Furthermore, Namibia's judicial system appears to have become a considerable stumbling block to the effectiveness of anti-corruption efforts, according to the IPPR. Not only has the slow turning of the wheels of justice undermined the integrity of the work of agencies such as the ACC, as well as the applicability of various laws, "but has also had a dampening effect on the public's faith in, support and enthusiasm for the overall anti-corruption fight." Adequate protection of whistle-blowers or informants has also become a serious concern. A further "glaring omission" within anti-corruption legislation is the absence of an access to information policy and law. As a result, the IPPR says Namibia is lacking on the important issues of transparency and accountability, as "a culture of openness has yet to take hold within and between the state and broader society." Amongst others, the IPPR has recommended that each ministry, state agency, regional and local authority, and state-owned enterprise should be required to submit to Parliament an annual anti-corruption plan. IPPR has recommended that the ACC together with the receiver of revenue be empowered to conduct lifestyle audits where it is clear that private persons and public figures are living beyond their reported incomes.

TITLE: Gakenke Lost Rwf 90 Million Through Corruption - District Officials
SUBJECT: EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); BUDGETS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (73%); ARRESTS (72%); BAIL (71%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: Four top officials in Gakenke District are being investigated in connection with the loss of Rwf 90 million. A special session of the District Advisory Council which convened last week sacked the newly elected vice mayor in charge of Economic development, Clemence Ugiribanga and the embattled District Executive Secretary, Richard Mberabagabo, overhauling the entire district team within its third month in office. Mberabagabo was arrested and released on bail last week in connection with the scandal. Others sacked include the district accountant, Jean Claude Surwume, and the district budget officer Peter Kwizera. The district council, held the three liable for the loss of over Rwf 49 million, through cheques and payment orders signed by Mberabagabo and Ugiribanga, when she acted as Director of Administration and Finance. It emerged that more funds were swindled in several Sectors. For instance, in Busengo Sector, a VUP-Umurenge financial officer is said to have disappeared with Rwf 16 million belonging to SACCO, while in Mugunga Sector, over Rwf 2 million was also embezzled. The District Mayor, Deogratius Nzabamwita, disclosed that further investigations were underway to unearth 'the network' of people involved in embezzling over Rwf90m, in the last two years. The district vowed to pursue the culprits and ensure that money is refunded. The president of the District Advisory Council, Patrice Hakizimana, said that money was withdrawn from the district account 7 times, and those charged with financial management failed to do their jobs.

TITLE: Governor Intervenes in Gakenke Corruption Scandal
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); TALKS & MEETINGS (91%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (90%); SCANDALS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (88%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (77%); BUDGETS (76%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (73%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: As Gakenke District grapples with corruption scandals, the Provincial Governor, Aime Bosenibamwe, on Tuesday met with district leaders. The meeting came on the heels of an extraordinary District Advisory Council meeting which interdicted four top officials over allegations of graft. Those fired include the vice Mayor in charge of Economic Development, Clemence Ugiribanga, the District Executive Secretary, Richard Mberabagabo, the Accountant J Claude Serumwe and Budget Officer, Peter Kwizera. District officials say over Rwf 90 million was lost through corruption, especially through breached tendering procedures. "The Public Finance Management team, along with the Police, will carry out a full inquiry to assess how the money was misused and find the network of people involved. All the money must be returned," Bosenibamwe said. The fired leaders are also accused of flaws in implementation of activities of a development partner, the Belgian Technical Cooperation-BTC, especially in the construction of offices and establishment of nursery beds. The officials also allegedly inflated the costs of activities. Police says there was need for technical expertise to investigate whether the costs of the alleged activities by various NGOs were not inflated or whether they were value for money.

TITLE: Conflict of Interest Promotes Corruption
SUBJECT: CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (92%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); POLITICS (78%); ETHICS (77%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (77%); REGULATORY COMPLIANCE (77%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (73%); SERVICE WORKERS (68%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: DISREGARD for asset declaration and the National Assembly Asset Register by senior Namibian political figures reflects a political culture which fails to see accountability as part of legitimacy, says the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR). In the second of eight research papers to be published under its anti-corruption research programme this year, the IPPR reviewed Namibia's approach to conflict of interest in the political, public and private spheres, and has made a number of recommendations. In the political realm, the focus is on Parliament and the Assets Register, which requires Members of Parliament to disclose assets and interests. Asset declaration can help in the fight against corruption by reducing instances of conflict of interest and can be used as a tool to identify cases of illicit enrichment. However, a Register of Member's Interests, the National Assembly Assets Register, has only been published twice since independence, in 2003 and 2009 respectively. The IPPR notes that in both cases, asset disclosure, which is a requirement in the National Assembly and the National Council, by senior political figures was less than satisfactory. The problems surrounding the Register of Member's Interests "run deeper and are reflective of a broader malaise - a general political culture which does not view accountability as a component of legitimacy." This, the IPPR says, is illustrated by the fact that political parties in Namibia are amongst the most unregulated institutions, and do not have to account for or disclose their assets and interests to any agency in Namibia, despite many of them receiving considerable amounts of tax-payer money on an annual basis. In the public sector, the situation is similar to that of political office bearers, as the rules governing the conduct of public sector employees do not go far enough, and are not proactive enough in encouraging ethical conduct in the civil service. This is evident in that the Public Service Act is "decidedly passive" in dealing with the issue of potential conflict of interest, as it relies almost entirely on the integrity and honesty of individual civil servants to declare their outside interests. Furthermore, there is no mechanism to proactively monitor whether public service employees actually comply with the provisions of the Public Service Act. In the private sector, the IPPR identifies "labour representatives - out for self-enrichment - colluding with management rather than representing employees interests," as the "most obvious avenue for conflict of interest in the private sector." An important first step in preventing the damage done by the practice of conflict of interest and its consequences, is a "clear and comprehensive, if not watertight, regulatory environment" for dealing with the practice. The IPPR notes that Namibia appears to be falling short in understanding the nature and scope of conflict of interest, as it relates to corruption, which is reflected in the country's lack of an all-inclusive approach to deal with the issue. In broad terms, the IPPR recommends legislation similar to South Africa's Executive Member's Ethics Act be introduced including codes of ethical conduct for the various levels of the public service. Furthermore, it has called for access to information to be legislated and that a national access to information policy be introduced. A more progressive and proactive regime where ministers and presiding officers publicly and comprehensively list their interests has also been recommended by the IPPR. Such a regime would also require senior officials, such as CEO's and senior management of state-owned enterprises and Permanent Secretaries, to disclose outside business interests on an annual basis.

TITLE: ACC Takes Corruption Fight to PLTC
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (89%); TEACHER EDUCATION (89%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (89%); UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); FINES & PENALTIES (76%); CRIMINAL FINES (76%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: In a bid to address key corruption issues at the Port Loko Teachers College (PLTC), the Anti-Corruption Commission has engaged staff and students of all departments. Officers of the Northern Regional office on Wednesday 1st June 2011 in a sensitization meeting warned all to desist from corrupt practices. Speaking on the offences and penalties as contained in the 2008 Act, Public Education Officer, Al-Hassan Sesay informed staff and students that the commission has the mandate to investigate all forms of corruption, no matter the amount of money or individual involved. Sesay explained various offences which are common in learning institutions and emphasized that the punishment for such offences is a fine of not less than thirty (30) million Leones or imprisoned of not less than three (3) years or both fine and prison term. Sesay highlighted key corrupt practices taking place in colleges which he noted are obstacles for development. He told staff and students that the ACC is not witch-hunting anybody or institution but intervening wherever there are possible loopholes for corruption. He therefore called on them to desist from corrupt practices and change their negative attitudes for the development of Sierra Leone. Explaining the rationale for the meeting, ACC's District Coordinator for Port Loko, Sahid Kamara said the engagement was part of the commission's public education and preventive approach in the fight against corruption. He emphasized that the commission decided to engage them to discuss key corruption issues and solicit their support in addressing them. The District Coordinator added that the meeting was to educate them on the dangers of corruption, work of the commission, how corrupt practices in their operations can hinder the development of education and how they can join the fight against it. Giving an overview of the commission, Public Education Officer Fatmata Finda Bockarie emphasized that the fight against corruption is a national concern, noting that the ACC alone cannot fight graft in the country. She told all staff and students present that the commission is not just bent on arresting and prosecuting corrupt individuals but also changing the corrupt behaviour, opinion, attitude and thoughts of people. The Public Education Officer emphasized the commission's core value of confidentiality and professionalism and stressed that if the fight against corruption is to succeed, they must be ready to resist, reject and report corruption. She explained the various methods of making reports to the commission, protection of informers and the 10% reward. Ms. Bockarie read the free mobile hotlines of the commission and urged staff and students to report any act of corruption. In their welcome address, Principal of Port Loko Teachers College Mr. Ibrahim William Saspo Bangura and President of the Student Union, Hassan Yansaneh expressed appreciation to ACC for bringing the commission closer to them. They admitted that such engagement will go a long way to minimize corruption at the college. They heaped praises on the commission for according them the opportunity to learn more about its activities and what they should not do. They assured the commission that they will abide by the warnings and stand firm against any act of corruption in the college. Questions and answers, suggestions and comments formed part of the meeting.

TITLE: ACC Takes Corruption Fight to Lebanese Community
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (77%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (72%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (71%); INVESTIGATIONS (70%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Asia, Australia, and Africa
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Commission on Saturday 28th May 2011 met with the Lebanese community in Kenema, in a meeting that attracted about nineteen (19) Lebanese businessmen and their business agents at the Lebanese International School hall in Kenema town. Declaring the purpose of the meeting, the Kenema district coordinator of the ACC, Mohamed Sylvanus Blake, said the Lebanese community is strategic to the economy of Sierra Leone as they contribute immensely to the revenue of this nation through taxes and other dues they pay. He emphasized that in the course of running their businesses, they face several challenges, as they come in contact with public officers in government ministries, departments and agencies and interact with people from every facet of life, including the common man. He added that partnership with the ACC will enhance their business and prevent exploitation from public officers. He encouraged them to make adequate use of the presence of the ACC in Kenema, stressing that the commission prefers making converts rather than convicts of corruption. In his overview of the commission, the interim eastern regional manager of the ACC, Peter Baio Kamara explained the three-pronged approach that the commission employs in the fight against corruption, namely Public Education, System and Process Review, and Intelligence, Investigation and Prosecution. Sound and adequate knowledge of the commission and its operations, Mr. Kamara said, will help people identify what makes them culpable by law, desist from corrupt acts and join the fight against the menace. Kamara further spoke about the report centre and its operations and how it receives and processes reports received from the public. He said some reports sent to the ACC are not corruption related but that the commission endeavours to respond appropriately to all reports received so as not to frustrate the efforts of those sending them. He encouraged participants to report corruption and assured them of the commission's protection and confidentiality. Earlier in his opening remarks, the eastern regional public education officer, David Kanekey Conteh alluded to the fact that there are third and fourth generation Lebanese that see Sierra Leone as their home. Therefore, the progress of Sierra Leone is their concern, and whatever befalls this nation affects them also. Even though the Lebanese run private business entities, their interactions with public officers and the public make such a meeting very necessary. Mr. Conteh highlighted some of the offences likely to be committed by private business people, such as offering an advantage, corrupting a public officer, using influence for contract, bid rigging, to name a few. He gave them the hot lines they could use to report corruption. Responding, the chairman of the Lebanese community in Kenema, Alhaji Ali Hassan thanked the ACC for creating such a forum which he referred to as awareness raising and confidence building.  He said poetically that the eye has been watching alone, the ear joined the eye, now he is asking the mouth to join the ear and the eye in the fight against corruption by not keeping silent. Alhaji Ali Hassan lamented over the duplication of the payment of taxes and other licenses to both the central and local governments, the illegal importation of goods to the country through smuggling; acts he said sometimes frustrate them and other issues affecting them. He called on the ACC to bring these issues to the attention of the government, while promising that the Lebanese in Kenema will continue to remain law abiding. He pledged the support and cooperation of the Lebanese to the commission and asked for more of such engagements in future.

TITLE: Nation's Anti-Corruption Pace Outstanding - Governance Council
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); TRENDS (76%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The Executive Secretary of the Rwanda Governance Advisory Council (RGAC), Prof. Anastase Shyaka, has announced that the country has made impressive strides in the fight against graft and is on the right path to become a corruption-free state. According to Shyaka, Rwanda is leading in the fight against corruption in the region. "At this pace, there is no doubt that Rwanda can catch up with Asian tigers in control of corruption . If the trend is maintained, Rwanda can aspire to become a corruption-free society before 2020," he said. Shyaka added that various indexes conclude that Rwanda is making outstanding progress towards a corruption-free society. "This situation results from several measures that have been put in place by the Government, including institutional setup, mindset change and adequate enforcement of rules and regulations that aim at completely eradicating corruption," he added. Rwanda's ranking keeps on rising and has constantly overtaken several countries. Since 2006, the country has made a considerable step, a case in point, from 121 to 66, thus overtaking 55 countries in the world in five years alone.

TITLE: N$71 Million Corruption - Majiedt Still Fighting for Bail
SUBJECT: BAIL (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); WITNESSES (89%); TESTIMONY (89%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (77%); POLICE FORCES (72%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: When the bail hearing of Esmerelda Majiedt resumes on Wednesday, it will be the third week during which the 46-year-old multimillion dollar corruption accused will try to be released from the Wanaheda Police station. On Friday, Advocate Louis Botes, Majiedt's lawyer, grilled the investigating officer, Justine Namukwambi, for allegations she made on Thursday that Majiedt's life would be in danger if freed on bail. All Namukwambi was prepared to say was: "I interviewed many witnesses known to the accused and paid money to her. You can feel ill feelings [towards her], because they paid." Majiedt, who faces a corruption charge totalling more than N$71 million, allegedly disbursed cement valued at N$42 million to Discount Hardware and N$16 million's cement to Cool Properties without AfriSam, her former employer, receiving a single penny despite claims by the Calvyn and Gerhard Bezuidenhoudt of Cool Properties and Daniel de Jesus of Discount Hardware that they paid bags of cash to Majiedt. The difference between this total of N$58 million (N$42 million and N$16 million) comprises N$13 million worth of stock that Majiedt allegedly wrote off. When Botes asked Namukwambi on Friday who the people are who allegedly paid money to Majiedt and who because of that are a threat to her life, she said: "I cannot reveal the names - this is not the time." Botes also wanted to know from her what basis she has for such a serious allegation claiming that Majiedt could be harmed or killed, the investigating officer said: "I will come and answer the question when the need arises." She added that she regards the Police cells - where up to 35 inmates are detained- "as a safe custody for the accused". When Botes asked whether Namukwambi regards the alleged accomplices, the Bezuidenhoudts and De Jesus, as suspects or as State witnesses, Namukwambi maintained that the investigation has not been completed. "After completion [of the probe], we can decide what to do with those people." She denied that she had testified on Thursday that there "is no doubt" that these men were in cahoots with Majiedt. Public Prosecutor Hans Thourob earlier said one of the grounds on which the State objects to bail is that it would not be in the public interest. Botes wanted to know from Namukwambi what this is based on, and whether there has been a public march against Majiedt's possible release. Namukwambi answered that "it's not necessary for people to demonstrate [against Majiedt's release on bail]. The public outcry will be there until the case is finalised, whether they demonstrate or not." When the hearing continues on Wednesday, Thourob is expected to call a former colleague of Majiedts, Zebbie van Zyl, to testify against Majiedt being freed on bail after she had allegedly interfered with the investigation against her. During her testimony last week, Majiedt admitted that she met Van Zyl in the parking lot at the Ministry of Finance where she asked him for a company stamp. The multimillion dollar alleged fraudster, however, denied that she also asked him to supply her with blank invoices. Thourob earlier said the State is in possession of a recording of the conversation between the two. Majiedt was arrested in Windhoek on April 4 this year. Since her arrest, she has spent 32 nights in hospital under Police guard for various ailments. Botes acts on Majiedt's behalf on instruction of Bradley Basson. Magistrate Ruth Herunga is on the bench for the bail hearing.

TITLE: Local Firm in Drive Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (91%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (89%); BANKING & FINANCE (89%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); INTERNET RETAILING (85%); HUMAN RESOURCES (78%); COMPANY PROFITS (78%); CORPORATE WRONGDOING (78%); AGREEMENTS (78%); INTERNAL AUDITS (77%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (76%); BUSINESS OPERATIONS (74%); BANKING & FINANCE SECTOR PERFORMANCE (74%); TECHNICIANS & TECHNOLOGICAL WORKERS (74%); FORENSICS (73%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (73%); CURRENCIES (72%); INTERVIEWS (70%); RISK MANAGEMENT (69%); ELECTRONIC COMMERCE (65%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (61%); SOCIAL MEDIA (60%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: A local firm, Compact Training of Zimbabwe, will soon partner the Anti-Corruption Commission of Zimbabwe in the fight against white-collar crime in both the private and public sectors. Since the switch from the Zimbabwean dollar to the multi-currency system, there has been an unprecedented rise in fraud and corruption in business. Under the envisioned partnership, the two entities will help business organisations and public sector bodies to detect fraudulent and corrupt activities in business. CTZ official Mr Trueman Dehwe said in an interview, there has been a surge in fraud in companies that has prompted many organisations to engage skilled professionals to help detect such activities before they negatively impacted on company operations and profitability. "An agreement (with the Anti-Corruption Commission) is expected to be reached soon as it has only been delayed by the restructuring process currently being undertaken by the commission. We are, however, confident that we will be working together in the near future. "We have been hosting and facilitating a good number of conferences and over the period demand for fraud detection expertise has steadily increased. "It is against this background that we have decided to move a step further by including a Government arm," said Mr Dehwe. He added that white-collar crime is currently pervasive in virtually all the sectors of the economy, but most particularly in the financial services sector. Added Mr Dehwe: "Over the years, there has been increased demand from financial companies for workshops that are targeted at combating fraud and corruption and also help in financial management. "A leading financial institution recently tasked us to draft a financial plan for them and also an insurance company has requested us to facilitate a training programme for them from Kesdee of the United States since we are certified training partners." Due to the proliferation of technology and valued added products from the Information Communication Technology sector, there are programmes that have also been designed to ensure that businesses understand some of the pitfalls on the electronic marketplace, which has occasioned by e-commerce. From Monday next week, CTZ will he holding a three-day workshop in Nyanga that is tailored to train locals about the electronic marketplace, internet, e-commerce and online business. The workshop will highlight the components and functioning of the e-marketplace, identification of the threats in the e-marketplace and the social media threats in the electronic marketplace. The workshops will culminate in a convention dubbed "Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Conference and Workshop" that will be held in Victoria Falls in August. The convention will mainly be targeting bankers, IT personnel, stores managers, purchasing managers, loss control managers, human resources managers, administration managers, internal and forensic auditors. Speakers at the event will include Dr Jar Botha, Professor Barry Splitz, Mr Mashandu Ramano, Mr Peter Peddler and Mr Bart Handerson. Last year CTZ partnered Henderson Solutions of South Africa in order to come up with practical solutions on combating fraud. It also partnered Kesdee of the US and the Euromoney Institute. Delegates who have attended previous workshops include those from the ministries of Economic Planning and Investment Promotion and Home Affairs, Ernst & Young, Zimra, Zesa Holdings, TelOne, Zimnat Life Assurance and financial institutions like TN Bank.

TITLE: Judiciary Sacks 12 Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); MISCONDUCT (90%); DISMISSALS (90%); BRIBERY (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (72%); ARRESTS (61%) Rwanda; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The judiciary has sacked 12 of its employees over serious misconduct, including corruption and desertion, The New Times has established. Five workers who include two Presidents of Primary courts, two registrars and a judge, were sacked on grounds of soliciting bribes and swindling government funds. Judicial Spokesperson, Charles Kaliwabo, confirmed the development in a telephone interview. "They were irrevocably dismissed by the judicial high council which was chaired by the Chief Justice [Aloysie Cyanzayire] after analysing their files," Kaliwabo said. Among those dismissed is the Registrar of Rushashi Primary Court, Modeste Barakengera. Kaliwabo said he was suspended for doctoring a case file. "He (Barakengera) forged a case file," he added, without giving the details on the file case in question. Also fired were Elias Nsengimana and Janvier Muhire of Mugombwa and Kagarama primary courts respectively. Kaliwabo explained that seven others, who include five registrars of the Intermediate Court and one of the High Court of Kigali, were dismissed by the council for desertion. "They had applied for leave-of-absence, but they left before the council decided on their requests as prescribed by the law. The council, therefore, decided to null their applications and dismissed them from the judiciary," he said. Kaliwabo also disclosed that the contracts of three other contractual judges, one attached to Nyarugunga primary court and two others of Nyarugenge Primary court, were revoked on corruption grounds. "We have networks of establishing such corrupt officials. The judiciary does not tolerate any sort of misconduct. Corruption is at zero tolerance and anyone implicated in this act will be pursued accordingly," he noted. Most of the sacked lawyers, Kaliwabo explained were reported by the public following the February-Week of fighting corruption in the judicial sector. "The public should know that they are not supposed to buy their rights. We need their cooperation, especially in fighting corruption," he stated, adding that the judiciary established a hotline (3670) for the public to report any form of corruption. He, however, added that some members of public were also arrested trying to bribe judges. This month alone, he said, two people were arrested in Musanze and Karongi districts for trying to bribe judges.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Engages Nacsa in Kenema [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (89%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (89%); LAWYERS (69%); INVESTIGATIONS (69%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (69%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (69%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (68%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (64%); MISAPPROPRIATION (50%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: As part of the institutional approach to public education and external outreach, the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) on Wednesday 22nd June 2011 met with both district and regional staff of the National Commission for Social Action (NaCSA) at their regional office at Hangah Road, Kenema. The meeting commenced with the ACC's regional public education officer, David Kanekey Conteh explaining the purpose for such engagement with officials of NaCSA. Mr. Conteh said ACC's visit to NaCSA does not necessarily denote any suspicion, neither does it mean that NaCSA was corrupt, but it was part of the efforts of the commission to recruit public officers to the anti-corruption army. As the fight is a national one, he emphasized, the ACC cannot fight alone and that it was enlisting every Sierra Leonean into this formidable force. Mr. Conteh further said that even though ignorance of the law was no excuse, public officers at times contravene the laws out of ignorance and that raising awareness of what constitutes corruption or corrupt practice was the first step in addressing corruption. "Public officers are therefore advised to always work within the provisions of the law as they provide leadership in various capacities," he admonished. In his overview of the commission, ACC's acting regional manager East, Peter Baio Kamara said before the enactment of the AC Act 2008 which gave the commission extensive powers, matters investigated by it were sent to the Attorney General's office for prosecution. The process was very slow and stifled most of the efforts of the commission, he said, adding that the pace at which the commission was now addressing matters was based on the new provisions of the 2008 ACC Act. Mr. Kamara informed his audience that the ACC laid premium on public education "because education brings knowledge and knowledge empowers people". He however said that people often thought that the ACC's success story was based on the number of public officers sent to court and incarcerated. On the contrary, "ACC does not pride itself in having lots of convicts but prefers converts". He observed that since corruption operates in a system, the ACC was also involved in what he referred to as a review of systems and processes in MDAs, which according to him, helped in preventing corrupt practices. Recommendations made during these reviews are monitored to ascertain and assess the level of compliance, he said. ACC's Kenema district coordinating officer, Mohamed Sylvanus Blake, highlighted several offences such as corrupting a public officer, bid rigging, using influence for contract, misappropriation of public funds, influencing a public officer, impeding investment, as part of the corrupt practices in the Anti-Corruption Act 2008. He informed NaCSA officers that involving in any of these practices may attract several related offences which may invoke a fine of not less than thirty million leones or three years imprisonment or both fine and imprisonment, for each offence. He encouraged them to report corruption to the ACC as there is always protection for informants and witnesses. He stressed that nobody will jeopardize his or her job or position for reporting corruption. Mr. Blake added that there is a ten percent reward scheme for anyone who reports corruption and such report leads to recovery of misappropriated funds. Responding, the NaCSA regional coordinator Mahmoud Koroma said NaCSA is involved in community, social action, relief and resettlement programs, among others. He added that NaCSA does not implement projects directly but through the communities or by employing the services of licensed contractors. Mr. Koroma appreciated the ACC for their move in educating them on many issues that they were unfamiliar with and asked that the ACC makes available the 2008 Act to them as they may want to use it as a reference point. Participants asked several questions that were responded to by the team of ACC Officers. David Kanekey Conteh, Public Education Officer

TITLE: Kenema Junior Secndary School Principals Warned By Anti-Corruption Commission [opinion]
SUBJECT: SCHOOL PRINCIPALS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); EDUCATION ADMINISTRATION (91%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (90%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (89%); STUDENT EXPENSES (78%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (78%); BUDGETS (78%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (78%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (77%); PUBLIC POLICY (76%); INVESTIGATIONS (72%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (60%) Sierra Leone; Education; Corruption
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Commission has cautioned Principals of Junior Secondary Schools in Kenema not to levy extra or illegal charges on pupils. This caution was given at an emergency meeting of JSS Principals in Kenema convened by the ACC and the Eastern Regional Chairman of the Conference of Principals, Sandy Moijueh at the Government Secondary School hall in Kenema. In his opening address, the chairman, Sandy Moijueh said he was met by a three man team of ACC officers who raised a number of issues bothering on illegal and extra charges levied on pupils which is why the meeting was convened. He called on all presents to listen attentively to the ACC officers. Explaining the purpose of the meeting, the Acting Regional Manager of the Anti-Corruption Commission Peter Baio Kamara stated that during the usual ACC weekly radio discussion programme, parents and guardians have repeatedly phoned in to complain that school authorities levy extra charges on pupils as a precondition for issuing admission or identification notices especially for the BECE candidates and for report cards, practical work and even for submission of assignments. Such charges, he stated, are illegal if not sanctioned by the Ministry of Education or have not been agreed on unanimously by parents at CTA meetings and minutes of such meetings forwarded to the Ministry of Education for their approval. Mr. Kamara stated they are in constant touch with the Directorate of the Ministry of Education in Kenema to crosscheck and ascertain whether such charges are sanctioned by the ministry. He stated in no uncertain terms that the ACC frowns at such charges and warned all school authorities to work in consonance with existing laws, policies and procedures governing the administration of schools and school charges. Peter Kamara suggested a range of measures school authorities could employ to avoid imposing extra financial burden on parents especially. He said it is very unfair to prevent pupils from taking an examination because of non payment of fees for extra classes especially when composite fees have been paid. Kamara called on all the Principals present to do all within their powers to ensure such practice does not take place in their schools as the Anti-Corruption Commission will leave no stone unturned in its effort to fight corruption through the investigation of such allegations and subsequent prosecution of any school authority found culpable. Responding, Principals present outlined some of the issues that they said were bottle necks in the effective administration of their schools, such as the shifting of the responsibility of Batch Registration Scheme (BRS) from West African Examination Council (WAEC) to respective schools with all its budget obligations, the decision to have extra remedial lessons agreed upon at CTA meetings by parents, and the non-payment of school fees by parents/guardians leaving the school authorities in critical positions and delays in the payment of girl child subsidy by the Ministry of Education  among others. The Principals also noted that pupils in a bid to extort monies from their parents inflate school fees and hide behind extra charges. They expressed satisfaction over the move by the ACC officers to address these issues and registered their preparedness to work within the legal framework and cooperate with the ACC. In his statement, the national president of the Conference of Principals, Michael Samba commended the move by the ACC and maintained that they as administrators are responsible for the implementation of government policies on education in schools for a better Sierra Leone and as such the government should create the enabling environment for them to function effectively and efficiently. He encouraged his colleagues to use the media extensively to educate the public on their constraints as administrators of education as that will help change the perception of the public about them. Mr. Samba maintained that the concerns raised by the ACC are realistic even though they as administrators may not be aware of such activities going on in their schools and asked his colleague Principals to be vigilant in the monitoring of their staff to ensure that they strictly operate within the legal framework prescribed in policies and procedures. He promised that the caution will be taken into consideration and acted upon. Mohamed Sylvanus Blake, District Coordinating Officer-Kenema

TITLE: Chasing the Dots - Poverty a Crime, Corruption is Fine [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%); POLITICS (89%); ETHICS (78%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (78%); ELECTIONS (76%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (69%); EVIDENCE (60%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: THE seemingly sad, recent death of John Nankudhu in conditions of social deprivation or dumping 120 kids by farmers on the Rundu - Grootfontein road without warmth or sustenance shows much about the reality of our society and, especially, our leaders. Such incidents also give insight to the apparent social winds of change permeating many world societies especially in our longitudes. Assuming the accuracy of the press reports, Nankudhu, whatever one's political standpoint, was a hero of Namibia but left to rot. Later damage control by the politicians to correct this image makes no difference to the departed hero! The 120 kids, reportedly moved out because of a GRN survey (?), although probably an "unintended consequence", reflects equally badly. Leaving kids by the road in winter is an unspeakable sin. Thanks goodness the Rundu man took matters in hand; but GRN remains tarnished. National pride is easily dented. It such unpredictable incidents, that while not intentional (I hope), become more likely as our political system and the executive become more and more focussed upon themselves and less upon the people. Jacob Zuma's recent comments that "weakness emerges from strength" as political incumbents with large majorities take decisions in their own interest rather than those that they should in the interests of their communities (Cosatu conference, 26/06/11). The people are patient but ! The poor and exposed eventually have "nothing to lose". Equally international bodies, once of high repute are coming under fire. FIFA's ethics committee has pronounced on the corruption surrounding leadership elections; yes, "bags of cash" (the new model of diplomacy?) were handed out by Warner, appropriately titled Vice President, to buy Caribbean votes. And well done Damaseb (a GRN / Swapo stalwart) as Vice Chair and part of the process; a plus for National Pride. But what happens? Warner, threatening talk on exposure, walks away, blemish free in deafening silence. Back to politics! And the FIFA President was unaware . ? Locally our minds are challenged in similar ways. Despite apparent prima facie evidence published by the GIPF in the press authorities are withholding two reports on these massive losses. Whatever those reports contain it is in the public domain that the Trustees,quite obviously failed in their fiduciary duties and there are clear incidents of conflict of interest. And this is only in the DCP area! There are other areas. It is therefore not unreasonable to suggest due process is being avoided as people in high position are implicated. If not, just release the reports or we have to assume statements about zero tolerance of poor governance and corruption are empty promises. And the RDF? The current Arab disturbances where the elite are protecting their own interests through outrageous violence are well documented by others but are a social reaction of note. A subject on which I have already made my views clear. But the Greek situation, the land where Aristotle, Socrates and Plato (and many others) created the first models of democracy is relevant. The Greeks, over the years have become famous for poor tax collection, overpaid and ineffective government and living beyond their means. They even "lost" debt with US investment bankers hiding the truth. Life was good, problems were solved with more cash and democracy faded to apathy as the population basked in their fools paradise. Politicians who made the best promises were elected. Business and politics merged and the regulatory and control functions of government ceased working. Suddenly the financial world woke up and realised that Greece was totally broke! Now things get interesting and hard, cost cutting and capital generating decisions have to be made. Government is now hated. Whose fault? The Greeks themselves. They failed to listen to and maintain democratic dialogue and now head for anarchy and the drachma! A lesson in what happens when democracy is not constantly tuned up; eventually reality catches up. There are lessons for all of us as "weakness emerges from strength". Peace and progress is easy with large majorities, lots of money and the sun shines! Take this away and the people change. Democracy is the safety valve, protest and dissent defuses and gives time for change. The people want peace and security but not to starve. Thus we should remember that political expression by oppositions may well upset the elite but when an HonMin criticises the APP for "victimisation and intimidation" referring to our democratic right to peaceful protest, like Egypt, he must remember it is our Constitutional right to protest peacefully! And sure political rhetoric does go overboard sometimes but I don't remember the same HonMin complaining when the use of hammers on certain groups was suggested! I object to corruption and poverty is solvable.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Cautions SLRTA in Kenema [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); VEHICLE TRAFFIC (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (76%); THEATER & DRAMA (75%); THEATER COMPANIES (75%); INVESTIGATIONS (72%); IMMUNITY (72%); THEATER (70%); RADIO ADVERTISING (69%); MOTOR VEHICLES (54%); TELEVISION PROGRAMMING (50%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: In the bid to address key corruption issues and to educate every public officer about corruption and its devastating effects, the Anti-Corruption Commission in Kenema engages government ministries, departments and agencies within the Eastern region. As a result, the ACC on Thursday 7th July 2011 met with staff of the Sierra Leone Road Transport Authority (SLRTA) at their Blama Road office in Kenema. Explaining the reasons for such engagement with the authority, ACC's Kenema District Coordinator, Mohamed Sylvanus Blake said that the commission had previously met separately with key players in the traffic sector in Kenema; the traffic division of the Sierra Leone Police, Motor Drivers and General Transport Workers' and the Commercial Motorbike Riders' Unions who voiced dissatisfaction and frustration over undue delay in the issuing of licences by the SLRTA and the unfair manner in which the traffic wardens issue tickets. He said they were meeting with the SLRTA to sensitise them and get their side of the story. He said as a commission they are taking every step necessary to address corruption and that people should remove the phobia or negative impression about the ACC by trying to create a positive one. He added that corruption is enemy to the development of the state and that every well meaning Sierra Leonean should look at it from that perspective. Mr. Blake informed his audience that the fight against corruption is national and that all should join the fight to achieve the common goal, which is to see a corrupt free Sierra Leone. He said after the meeting, the commission will hold another session with all the stakeholders in the traffic sector in Kenema to address key corruption issues. In his presentation, the Acting Regional Manager ACC, Peter Baio Kamara said the first step to the enlisting people into the fight against corruption is to educate them. There is the need for a person to be adequately informed, if that person is to be recruited into the anti-corruption force, he said. Kamara gave a rundown of the main operational wings of the ACC, noting that two of these departments - the Public Education and External Outreach and the Systems and Processes Review Departments - are there to prevent corruption while the Intelligence Investigations and Prosecutions confronts corruption and corrupt public officers. He explained that a public officer is a person working for a public body whether paid or unpaid, and a public body is an institution established by an Act of Parliament, owned by government or where government has a percentage of shares. He added that even NGO workers are not immune from prosecution by the ACC as they too receive monies and properties for or on behalf of the people of Sierra Leone. Mr. Kamara said the commission prioritizes making converts rather than convicts, that is why in its public education drive the ACC uses community theatre, jingles and radio and TV drama spots and engages the print and electronic media extensively, to pass on the anti-corruption message. Explaining the offences and the procedures for reporting corrupt practices to the ACC, Public Education Officer, David Kanekey Conteh mentioned offering, soliciting or accepting advantage; influencing a public officer; corrupt acquisition of wealth; possession of unexplained wealth; and corrupting a public officer as offences punishable under the Anti-Corruption Act 2008. Public officers in the traffic sector who solicit and accept advantage these days go through a middle man to perpetuate such a crime, he observed and therefore warned all to desist from corrupt practices and stressed that the minimum penalty for every corruption offence is a fine not less than thirty million leones or three years imprisonment or both fine and imprisonment. He called on all to resist, reject and report corruption and concluded by encouraging his audience to change their behaviours, opinions, attitude and thoughts about corruption. Responding, the Regional Director of Sierra Leone Road Transport Authority in Kenema, Arthur Brima thanked the ACC for guiding them. He said they have learnt a lot and that the sensitization has made them to be aware of many things they did not know amounted to a corruption offence and promised to pass on what he has learnt to the officers who were absent as a result of postings. Mr. Brima explained the procedures for obtaining various licenses, and the constraint they face in dealing with the public. He appealed to the ACC to make available the Anti-Corruption Act 2008 and other ACC literature to them. Several concerns and questions posed by participant were responded to by the ACC team. David Kanekey Conteh Public Education Officer - Eastern Region
