TITLE: Most Corruption Cases Are Administrative - Ombudsman
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (90%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); WRONGFUL TERMINATION (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); DISMISSALS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (77%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (77%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (76%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (76%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (71%); SUPREME COURTS (69%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (69%); INTERVIEWS (69%); POLICE FORCES (60%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: Mal-administration and administrative corruption such as unfair dismissal of employees, discrimination and unfair promotions at work places are the highest forms of corruption registered, and stand at 82.37 percent, according to the 2009-2010 Ombudsman's report. Augustin Nzindukiyimana, the deputy Ombudsman in charge of Preventing and fighting Corruption yesterday presented the report to delegates from the United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC) and United Nations Office of Drug Crimes (UNODC). The delegates are in the country to assess the implementation of the international anti-corruption instruments as requested by the convention. The same report indicates that 53.24 percent corruption cases were recorded in the local administration while 43.19 percent was registered in the justice sector during the same period. In public procurement, 28.12 percent cases were registered. Nzindukiyimana told the delegates that raising public awareness is one of the major strategies the Ombudsman's Office uses to prevent and fight against corruption and injustice. The UNCAC, the first legally binding international anti-corruption tool adopted by the UN General Assembly Resolution 58/4 of October 2003, obliges member states to implement a wide and detailed range of anti-corruption measures. However, the UN anti corruption body is currently evaluating two of its four major tools in the fight against corruption including criminalisation and international cooperation. Other tools are prevention and asset recovery. In a separate interview, Nzindukiyimana said that most of the tools were achieved in Rwanda. "We did not achieve this to the maximum; there are some laws that need to be introduced," he noted. He outlined laws on international cooperation and investigating corruption as some of the acts that need to be introduced to further enhance the anti corruption campaign in the country. "We cannot define the number of laws that should be introduced now, but after we get their (UNCAC) report, we will work on the required laws to be submitted to parliament for approval," he added. The delegates are also assessing the laws used in the anti corruption campaign. Nzindukiyimana, however, said that the Ombudsman office still face challenges such as limited staff to accomplish its mission coupled with limited powers. The efforts of the corruption watchdog's body are complemented by a national anti-corruption advisory council composed of the Office of the Ombudsman, National Public Prosecution Authority (NPPA), Supreme Court, National Police and the Ministry of Justice among others.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption in Local Gov't is Our Priority - Ombudsman
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (89%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (88%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (87%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); WRONGFUL TERMINATION (75%); INTERVIEWS (72%); DISMISSALS (70%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (64%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (63%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The Deputy Ombudsman, Augustin Nzindukiyimana, said that fighting corruption at the grassroots level is the institution's priority for the next seven years. Nzindukiyimana, who is in charge of preventing and fighting corruption disclosed this yesterday, in an interview. "It is our priority to fight it at the local government level, and it is a priority of the government," Nzindukiyimana noted. He, however, explained that most forms of corruption in local government institutions are 'bureaucratic' related. The 2009-2010 Ombudsman report indicates that 53 percent of the corruption cases were recorded in the local administration. Unfair dismissal of employees, discrimination and unfair promotions at work places were ranked as the highest forms of corruption registered, and stood at 82.37 percent, according to the same report. "Fighting corruption has no end, but we are doing it appropriately because we have the political will, which is lacking in many other countries. Our leaders prioritise, among others, fighting corruption, which is the most important tool in fighting the vice," he added. Increasing public awareness, Nzindukiyimana said, is one of the methods to be employed in the anti corruption drive. "Rwandans should consider three things; to refuse, reject and report corruption. We want people to reject and report any form of corruption. But leaders at the grass-roots should also be active in this campaign," he stated. In a related development, Nzindukiyimana said that the final report on Rwanda's implementation of the United Nations Convention against Corruption (UNCAC) instruments will be produced in a meeting to be held in Vienna, Austria in September. A delegation from UNCAC and United Nations Office of Drug Crimes (UNODC) was in the country, last week, to assess the implementation of the international anti-corruption instruments as requested by the convention such as criminalisation and international cooperation. It was the first time the international anti-corruption body assessed Rwanda's implementation process since it was adopted by the UN General Assembly Resolution 58/4 of October 2003 as the first legally binding international anti-corruption tool.

TITLE: 'Corruption is Responsible for High Unemployment' - Sluyag President
SUBJECT: UNEMPLOYMENT RATES (92%); JOB CREATION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EMPLOYMENT (90%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (90%); EMPLOYMENT GROWTH (89%); LABOR SECTOR PERFORMANCE (78%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (78%); APPRENTICESHIPS & INTERNSHIPS (77%); EMPLOYEE TRAINING (77%); TRENDS (76%); ACADEMIC STANDARDS (75%); SELF EMPLOYMENT (75%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (75%); EMPLOYMENT TRENDS (73%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Labour
TEXT: President of the Sierra Leone Unemployed Youths Advocacy Group (SLUYAG) has stated that corruption and mismanagement were responsible for the high rate of unemployment in the country. Mohamed D. Sesay told participants at a job creation workshop for unemployed graduates organised by his group in collaboration with Africell that despite the effort of government and its partners, unemployment continues to be a great challenge. "Corruption and mismanagement are responsible for the high rate of unemployment. Government should not focus on short-term strategy to address the issue," Sesay said. "Many qualified students are still without jobs. We do not need experts from abroad to foster development in Sierra Leone, what we need is a conducive atmosphere for job creation." He noted that the country's standard of education has fallen considerably as the university was busy producing more generals rather than specialists. He observed that most of the courses being taught at the university "do not match with the modern trend in the job market", while encouraging his colleagues to be pillars of development and not ones of destruction. He recommended that the government establishes a national youth service scheme and a safety net. National youth commissioner, Anthony Koroma noted that the potentials existed for youths to become managers, engineers and doctors, among others. He said youths should have personal ambition if they were serious about making it in life, adding, "Unemployed graduates should reposition themselves and focus on innovative methods that promote self-employment." Africell's corporate affairs officer, Joe Abass Bangura said investment made by the company has succeeded in creating some eight hundred direct and five thousand indirect employments for Sierra Leoneans. He noted that human investment through training of personnel in the practical application of knowledge gained in schools was priceless. "No school can completely and adequately prepare one for the requirements of the workplace," he said. "Africell wishes to announce the launching of its job training scheme for graduates. As a pilot project, we will provide an opportunity for three graduates to benefit from a three-month internship with us." Bangura explained that after the three-month programme, candidates who meet the requirements will have the chance to be offered a full time job in the company.

TITLE: ACC Schools BKPS Staff On Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (88%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (69%); INVESTIGATIONS (66%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (64%); PUBLIC HEALTH ADMINISTRATION (63%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (60%); IMMIGRATION (50%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: The Anti-Corruption Commission on Thursday 14th July 2011 continued their sensitization exercise by engaging workers of the Bo/Kenema Power Services (BKPS) office in Kenema. The meeting, which was chaired by Madam Francess M. Kpaka, Senior Personnel Clerk of the Bo-Kenema Power Services in Kenema, attracted over forty one workers. In her opening and welcome statement, Madam Kpaka said people had different notions about the ACC and that their presence at the BKPS will provide all the opportunity to get a clear understanding about corruption and the operations of the commission and called on all to be attentive so that all will benefit from the sensitization. Establishing the purpose for such engagement with BKPS, Mr. David Kanekey Conteh, Regional Public Education Officer of the ACC, intimated his audience that the BKPS was an essential service provider whose service was strategic to the development of that region. He said the ACC was seeking partnership with BKPS for national development, adding that the vision of the commission was to make Sierra Leone a corrupt free country where the socio-economic needs of its citizens would be met. This could not be achieved by the ACC alone, but by every Sierra Leonean, he said, noting that the ACC was at the BKPS not because they were corrupt but because public officers needed to be educated on corruption and the operations of the commission so that they will see the need to join the fight against corruption by becoming the "eye" of the commission. Giving the overview of the commission, the Kenema District Coordinator Mohamed Sylvanus Blake said at times people castigate the ACC because of the opinions or notions they habour about it and its operations. He categorized the operations of the commission in to two: Prevention and Confrontation. The public education and external outreach and the systems and processes review departments to prevent corruption by educating the public on the bad effects of corruption and the corresponding benefits of a corrupt free society and the examination of existing systems and structures which make room for corrupt practices to thrive and to recommend preventive measures. Blake mentioned that the commission has carried out reviews on the ministries of Health, Education Agriculture and Local Government, the Immigrations Department to name a few. The Intelligence, Investigation and Prosecution come in as the very last resort; to confront public officers who failed to heed the call and take personal interest above national interest. He said this has led to the prosecution and conviction of both high and low profile public servants. Speaking on the offences, the acting Regional Manager, Kenema, Peter Baio Kamara dilated on the limitations in the 2000 Act as having only nine corrupt practices, while the 2008 ACC Act contains twenty seven. He listed several corrupt practices that were punishable under the Anti-Corruption Act 2008 and called on workers of the BKPS to work within the ambit of the law, as it was quite dangerous for someone to circumvent the law. Mr. Kamara further said the penalties in the 2000 Act were such that many public officers treated the commission with levity. But the 2008 Act made the penalties very stiff, with a fine not less than thirty million leones or three years imprisonment or both fine and imprisonment depending on the opinion of the judge. The 2008 Act however makes provision for recoveries of monies misappropriated by public officers which are paid back into the consolidated fund. One such case was when the Commissioner of the ACC Joseph F. Kamara Esq. on the 13th May 2011 handed over a cheque of six hundred and eleven million, one hundred forty-one thousand Leones (Le611,141,000) and nine thousand four hundred and fifty US dollars ($9,450) to President Ernest Bai Koroma. He explained some of the offences in the ACC Act 2008 and the procedure for reporting corruption and how the report centre handles and processes complaints and reports from the public. He called on all to support the commission for the good of the nation. Responding, the Technical Director of BKPS, Munda M. Lewis, appreciated the ACC for putting them on their guard, as they have been educated about corruption, which will help them perform their duties more effectively as public officers. He said that was the most educative session he had ever had from the ACC, especially the area of the offences. He noted that he had been reading both the ACC Acts of 2000 and 2008 but the simple manner in which the offences were explained really opened his eyes to what they really meant. He alluded to the fact that the ordinary masses must not continue to suffer in silence but should be always ready to speak out against corruption, as it was the best service one can offer the nation. He also said that corruption was not only found among senior officers but there were junior personnel that have more access to state resources more than those at management level. He therefore advised every public officer to work carefully within the law so that they do not fall foul of the ACC Act 2008. He however appealed to the ACC to make available the Act and other ACC materials to public officers to serve as reminder. Questions and answers formed part of the programme.

TITLE: ACC Takes Corruption Fight to MAFFs in Bo
SUBJECT: TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (89%); AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENTS (78%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (78%); FOOD SECURITY (77%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (71%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (70%); MISAPPROPRIATION (60%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: As part of its Public Education drive to all Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs), the Anti- Corruption Commission has on Tuesday 19th July 2011 held an institutional sensitization meeting with staff of the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Food Security (MAFFS), Bo District. The meeting which took place at the Ministry's District Head Quarters, China Farm Bo/Kenema Highway in Bo attracted over 300 staff members including, The District Agriculture Officer, Heads of Departments, and Extension Officers from the various duty stations in the District. The Anti-Corruption Commission District Coordinator for Bo District, Mr. Anthony Samu, while explaining the purpose of the meeting, said that the meeting is not for any mishap done by the Ministry, but just one of the periodic and many sensitization meetings organized with Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs). Mr. Samu reiterated that the ACC realizes the fact to come closer to the people in order to allay their fears and misconceptions concerning the ACC. Availability, Accessibility and Affordability of food are key issues the Ministry is taking the lead to address, and that we should all make our own input or contribution towards this drive Samu maintained. He also said that the meeting will give staff of the Ministry the opportunity to advance questions or raise issues and concerns regarding the operations of the Commission. Mr. Samu therefore encouraged the participants to be open and frank in the deliberations. Giving an overview of the Commission and update, Mr. Patrick Sandi the Regional Manager-South, on behalf of the Commissioner of the Anti-Corruption Commission, expressed his gratitude for the strides made by the Ministry to addressing the food self-sufficiency and security issue. He underscored the fact that the MAFFS like the Health and Education Ministries is very strategic to the State in addressing the Millennium Development Goal (MDG) and the Government's "Agenda for Change" programme. He therefore solicited the support and collaboration of all in the Ministry to get onboard and do the right thing since corruption is dynamic and fights back when it is being fought against. Mr. Sandi went ahead to talk about the establishment of the ACC and what the Commission does which he said include, Education, Prevention and Confrontation. He informed the audience that the 2000 Act was reviewed in 2008 which gave the Commission more powers including additional offences above 27 in number. These offences include, 'possession of unexplained wealth", "bid rigging" and "misappropriation of public and donor funds & property" among others, and goes with stiff penalty when convicted.  He also talked about Declaration of Assets and Liabilities, which according to him, demonstrate how accountable and transparent Public Officers are in public life. Declaring your Assets as a Public Officer Mr. Sandi emphasized will protect and guide you in the event of future problems. Provision in the Anti-Corruption Act 2008, regarding a person failing to declare his/her assets and liabilities shall be  on conviction to pay a fine of not less than twenty million leones or one year jail term or both fine and jail term. Mr. Sandi also informed the MAFFS staff that the ACC has signed a Memorandum Of Understanding (MOU) with the UK Government for assistance to be provided to the ACC by the UK Government as and when the Commission needs it and that Sierra Leone has ratified the United Nations Convention Against Corruption (UNCAC) whereby Sierra Leone can solicit other states for assistance. He appealed and encouraged all partners to work together to get things right to move the country forward bearing in mind that the Judiciary is also independent. In his statement on behalf of the MAFFS, Mr. Michael Bockarie of the Private and Rural Sector programme acknowledged that ACC cannot work in isolation and therefore need the support and collaboration of other partners to move the fight forward. He reaffirmed to the Commission that as a Ministry and strategic player to the fight, they are always ready to supply the ACC with all valuable information required. Earlier, the District Agriculture Officer, Bo District, Mr. Mohamed Bah in welcoming the ACC team and his staff registered greetings to the ACC on behalf of the MAFFS. He reiterated that the relationship between the ACC and the Ministry should be cordial as the two institutions are partners in development. Mr. Bah underscored that the ACC is not witch hunting anybody but that wants things to be done right as it is the more reason why the Commission was established. Mr. Bah concluded by saying that we should do things or behave in a way that we feel confident and safe with no fear of falling foul of the ACC Laws. Interactive questions, answers and concerns session formed part of the programme. The vote of thanks was given by a staff of the Ministry, Madam Mary Mammy.

TITLE: ACC, Mest Join Hands in Corruption Fight in Bo
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (89%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (89%); CHILDREN (78%); SOCIAL JUSTICE (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (77%); WAGES & SALARIES (73%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (72%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (70%); IMMIGRATION (50%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: As part of its fight against corruption campaign, the Anti- Corruption Commission (ACC) has met with staff of the Ministry of Education Science and Technology (MEST) in Bo District at its Baiima Road office. The meeting was attended by over 20 staff members including the Deputy Director of Education, Science and Technology, Bo District, Supervisors of schools, Education Officers and the general administrative and support staff in the district. ACC District Coordinator for Bo District, Mr. Anthony Samu informed the Deputy Director of MEST, Bo District and his staff that, in allaying their fears, the ACC is just at the ministry for a face-to-face discussion and interaction, and not for any alleged corruption related activity by the ministry. "We want to come closer to our partners and other stakeholders if we need to succeed in the fight against corruption," Mr. Samu emphasized. The meeting is one of the normal and routine engagements with institutions that the ACC makes through the many public education drive in the fight against corruption. "Education is paramount to the heart of Government and the people of this country and as such, we should all protect and promote the educational pursuit of our children, especially regarding the illegal school charges levied by some schools authorities on parents," Mr. Samu concluded. On the Commission's activities and update, Mr. Patrick Sandi the Regional Manager-South, on behalf of the Commissioner of the ACC informed the ministry staff on the approaches the ACC uses in fighting corruption, which he said, includes education, prevention, prosecution and the National Anti-Corruption Strategy. Mr. Sandi touched on the Act 2008 which replaced the Act 2000 and the related offences with the corresponding penalty for each. Declaration of assets and liabilities, he went on, is obligatory for all public officers as this demonstrate transparency. The ills of corruption are many, but mentioning a few, Mr. Sandi talked about social inequality, poor service delivery system and poor educational system which undermine the achievement of the Millennium Development Goal (MDG), Agenda for Change and the Girl Child Education. Since education is vital, issues that have been raised from the public include; Fee subsidy utilization by school authorities, handling of unclaimed salaries, strict monitoring of schools and the observance of the code of conduct for teachers. As he went on, Mr. Sandi informed the audience that the Commission had made tremendous strides regarding its operations and these include; the conviction of two Government Ministers and others, reviews done in some institutions like, Education, Health, Agriculture and the production of Service Charters for organizations like, Immigration, SLRTA etc. Earlier in welcoming the visiting ACC staff, The Deputy Director of Education, Bo District, Mr. John Amara Swarray who also chaired the meeting said that it was a very good idea to have the ACC for such interactive session. Mr. Swarray reiterated that they as teachers are always ready to learn, and that the meeting is a learning opportunity for not only them in the Ministry but for the ACC as well. Making statement on behalf of the MEST, Mr. Swarray underscored that the success of Sierra Leone lies with the ACC. He further emphasized that the ACC has been established to see that things are done correctly and efficiently. Mr. Swarray however intimated the ACC team that some oversight bodies like journalists are somehow disturbing the education system for they enter into schools without reference to the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology, and not even with proper identification. Issues and concerns were raised by staff at the end of meeting.

TITLE: NFF, ACC Collaborate to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (76%); FINES & PENALTIES (73%); LAWYERS (68%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (65%); MISAPPROPRIATION (60%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (50%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Soccer
TEXT: In a bid to addressing key corruption issues jointly with key stakeholders, the Anti-Corruption Commission has engaged Staff of the National Fire Force (NFF) in the Southern Region at its Damballa Road, Regional Office in Bo. The meeting which was held on Wednesday 27th July 2011 attracted over (20) twenty staff members including; the Deputy Commandant - South, fire fighter operators and other administrative and support staff. When Speaking to the NFF staff members regarding the visit of the ACC, Mr. Anthony Samu, the District Coordinator for the Anti corruption Commission, Bo District, tried to allay the fears of his audience stating that their visit at NFF is routine in meeting with Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs), sensitizing them on the establishment of the Commission, evils of corruption, the corruption offences and penalties as contained in the 2008 Anti-Corruption Act. Mr. Samu also talked about the commitment and public relations aspect required of Fire Force workers. He underscored the fact that the Commission needs to come closer to its partners and the wider community, and that it is even the more reason why the ACC is having the meeting in a bid to have a face-to-face discussion and soliciting the support of the NFF. The engagement Mr. Samu further explained was part of the Commission's public education and preventive approach in the fight against corruption and he therefore encouraged the audience to be frank, open, raise issues, concerns, and ask as many questions as possible during the meeting for this is an opportunity for them in learning more about the Commission and its operations. Addressing the NFF staff, Mr. Patrick Sandi, the ACC Regional Manager - South reiterated that the NFF Deputy Commandant - South, Mr. Albert Parker had long expressed his desire for the Commission to address the NFF staff. Mr. Sandi hastened to say that the ACC is not for witch hunt or used to bring people down. ACC, he continued, is an independent institution established by an Act of Parliament in 2000. The 2008 Act gives more powers and has helped the Commission, as it can now prosecute its own cases without reference to the Attorney General's Office. Sandi informed staff that the Commission has the mandate to investigate all forms of corruption, no matter the amount of money or individual involved in it, and these has been demonstrated in the past as records show. Mr. Sandi also explained the various offences which are common in public institutions like; "possession of unexplained wealth", "misappropriation of public funds, revenue & property", "protection of public revenue, property", etc. and that the area of procurement is a serious avenue for corruption to take place. He emphasized that the punishment for such offences is a fine of not less than thirty (30) million Leones or imprisoned for not less than three (3) years or both fine and prison term. According to Mr. Sandi, the Act 2008 also makes provision for the declaration of assets and liabilities. Asset Declaration he went on is making public officers accountable in public life besides the protection it provides should one face or encounter corruption accusation in the future. Concluding, Mr. Sandi encouraged all to avoid the culture of silence, and therefore report all corruption related activities. He hastened to talk on the low motivation of public officers for their work and services which to some extent undermines the work of the Commission, but that the Commission continues to advocate for better conditions of service for public workers. We should all improve on our moral stature and with the support of all we shall win or succeed in the fight Sandi maintained. Contributing, District Coordinator, Anthony Samu cautioned the NFF staff to be careful regarding their public relations during their outdoor activities. He advised the officers to resist and reject corruption when attempts are made to them by the public. The offence of soliciting and accepting will catch up with them if they are manipulated by the public to doing the wrong things contrary to what is prescribed "not to do" in the Act 2008. He also talked about their commitment to work in nation building. Welcoming the ACC visiting team earlier on, Mr. Alimamy Conteh, NFF Sub Officer - South who also chaired the meeting, underscored that the ACC is not witch hunting anybody or institution, but that the ACC's presence will send the message to all for change of behavior and attitude for the betterment of Sierra Leone. Mr. Conteh emphasized that as public officers, we need to be checked with regards our behavior and attitude especially when we are care takers of fire hazards in the Southern region and the country as a whole. He implored his staff to listen keenly to the message the ACC have for them as such engagement will go a long way to minimize corruption at public institutions. Questions and answers, suggestions and comments formed part of the meeting while Mr. Bockarie Saffa gave the vote of thanks.

TITLE: We Cannot Afford to Relent On Corruption [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (73%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: This week, the National Public Prosecution Authority (NPPA), released  a report on investigations carried out based on the 2007 Auditor  General's (AG) report, which indicated that over Rwf 3.7 billion was  embezzled. Twenty six of the investigated cases, involving the loss of over Rwf125.3m and implicating 66 officials, have been forwarded to court for prosecution. In total, about 223 officials from various levels of government have so far been prosecuted. The Office of the Prosecutor General deserves commendation and support from all stakeholders for the great work it is doing to ensure accountability by government officials. As a country characterized by zero tolerance to corruption, we ought to devise better and permanent mechanisms that will help check graft. However, fighting corruption requires collective effort. All government officials have within their mandate a duty to fight corruption and protect public resources. Several AG's reports have highlighted cases of illegal tendering and embezzlement. Some institutions divert funds for activities that they were not originally budgeted for. While there is general improvement in the management of public funds, some irregularities still persist. Now that prosecution carried out investigations, they should go all the way and bring all the culprits to book. There's no doubt that the remaining irregularities shall be addressed given the existing political will.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission to Sweep Across Nation
COUNTRY: ETHIOPIA (94%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (93%); UNITED STATES (92%); SOMALIA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ETHICS (90%); POLLS & SURVEYS (90%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (89%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (78%); CONSULTING SERVICES (78%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (78%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); ENTREPRENEURSHIP (77%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (76%); PROJECT MANAGEMENT (75%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (74%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); CONTRACT AWARDS (72%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (72%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (62%) Ethiopia; Corruption
TEXT: The Federal Ethics and Anti Corruption Commission (FEAC) is to conduct the second national baseline corruption survey at a cost of 7.9 million Br in this fiscal year. Financed by the World Bank (WB), the survey is to be conducted by a Tanzanian-based American company, called Kilimanjaro International Cooperation. The FEAC had invited prospective local and international consultants to conduct the survey three years ago. "The stringent evaluation process of the commission and WB has taken time," Fanosea Hussein, project manager at the FEAC, told Fortune. Out of 20 international and local companies who submitted their proposal, only five companies passed the technical requirements, and were shortlisted for the financial proposal, including Ernst & Young. The technical evaluation included previous experience of the company, methodology, number and competency of the professionals involved, number of data collectors, and familiarity to African governance, specifically Ethiopia. While the financial evaluation is based on determining which candidate can offer the lowest consulting cost. After three years of evaluation, the FEAC awarded the contract to a Tanzanian based company which was founded and established by Greyson Kiondo in 1997. The company is engaged in sector specific capacity building in policy and regulation. The Institute of Educational Research of Addis Abeba University (AAU) had been contracted to conduct the first national survey in April 2001, commissioned by the ethics sub programme of the Civil Service Reform Programme before the commission was established in May 2001. The project was financed by the Ethiopian government and United Nation Development Programme (UNDP). "The new survey is to investigate how institutions perceive the state of corruption in Ethiopia, and will manifest the situation on the ground," Fanosea anticipated. The survey is to be conducted in households, among businesses, government institutions, government developmental institutions, religious institutions and non-governmental organisations (NGOs), according to FEAC. Around 7,000 individuals are expected to be surveyed from all regions, including Addis Abeba and Dire Dawa. For such purposes, the questionnaires are to be prepared in five different languages including, Amharic, Oromifa, Tigrigna, Afarigna and Somali. The AAU's Institute of Educational Research (IER), in the previous survey, had surveyed public officials, household heads, and business entrepreneurs as sources of data in all nine regions. "The survey is very important in gauging the current level of corruption, in order for the commission to react accordingly, and will be an input for policy making," according to a project manager. In the past 10 years, the country has gone through different changes and we need to know the status of the country, he added. The IER survey noted that the country has demonstrated not only the prevalence of corruption, but also the severity. The most intensive corruption rate is observed in places where financial transactions are carried out in the allocation of scarce resources, such as land, and where contracts are enforced, particularly in courts of law, according to the first survey. Employment in government offices is also dependent on political affiliation, or loyalty, rather than skill and merit. Accordingly, institutions that are singled out to be highly corrupt and inefficient by households and business entrepreneurs included the then Customs Authority, the Inland Authority Administration, and the police, including traffic police and all utility service institutions. On the other hand, the former Security, Immigration and Refugee Affairs Authority was given low corruption ratings. Ethiopia is ranked 116 out of 176 countries with the index of 2.7 out of 10 in 2010 (meaning that 60 countries are struggling with more serious corruption issues), according to Transparency International. Transparency International is a non-governmental organisation that monitors and publicises corporate and political corruption in international development. It publishes annual Corruption Perceptions Indices, a comparative listing of corruption worldwide.

TITLE: Corruption Cases Reduce - ACC
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); INTERVIEWS (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); CUSTOMER SERVICE (70%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (67%); IMMIGRATION (55%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has said corruption cases have reduced due to the introduction of internal mechanisms in organisations that prevent corruption. Chief communication education officer, Festus Chipungu said in an interview at the on-going Agriculture and Commercial Show that the integrity committee had been introduced in Government organisations, agencies and private companies to monitor operations. This year's Agriculture and Commercial Show is carried under the theme, 'Shaping tomorrow's world.' Mr Chipungu said reforms such as customer service had also been set up in some organisations and had worked very well in fighting corruption in the immigration department, Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) and the Ministry of Lands. He said reforms had worked in the fight against corruption because they prevented individuals from having too much power over the clients and improved accountability and transparency. "We have set up about 15 integrity committees in more than 15 organisations such as the Government, agencies and private companies," he said. He said the introduction of the Whistle-blowers Act under the Public Interest Disclosure number four of 2010 would encourage more people to report corrupt cases to the ACC. He said efforts had also been made to widely publicise the existence of the law through the electronic adverts, information materials and lectures. "The integrity committee that started two years ago has proved to be a success in the fight against corruption in organisations," he said. Mr Chipungu further said ACC had engaged civil society organisations to supplement its efforts in fighting corruption through educating the public.He called on the public to take the fight against corruption seriously and treat those corrupt as thieves because the act took away resources, which was tantamount to stealing. He urged the public to take advantage of different materials published in all the seven major local languages on corruption so that they could fully understand its dangers to the economy. "People do not fully understand the effects of corruption. It results in lack of proper housing, no enough education and diverting of resources meant for development to private purposes. About 140 corrupt cases were reported to the ACC last year and were mostly from individuals.

TITLE: Roads Authority, ACC Sign Agreement to Fight Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); AGREEMENTS (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (89%); EXECUTIVES (76%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (74%); PUBLIC POLICY (64%); DRIVERS LICENSES (53%) Namibia; Corruption; Transport and Shipping
TEXT: THE Roads Authority (RA) has stepped up its efforts in the fight against corruption by signing a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) allowing it unrestricted access to the RA's systems and information database. Speaking at the signing ceremony, ACC director Paulus Noa said the MoU marks a "remarkable milestone in our quest to cement an already existing good working relationship between the two institutions". Noa said the agreement would facilitate cooperation between the RA and the ACC and would ensure that the two institutions would render more assistance to each other in investigations into corruption and fraud. Noa added the agreement would facilitate easy access for the ACC to the data kept within various departments at the RA, and "it would certainly help the commission to expedite the investigation when allegations of corrupt practices in either the registration of vehicles or the issuance of driver's licences are reported to the commission. According to the ACC Director, the memorandum would also help the RA in carrying out its own investigations, as it would also make it easier for the RA to obtain information from the ACC. "All institutions need to strengthen their integrity systems and this would lead to a decline in corruption and fraud in Namibia," Noa said. Also present at the signing ceremony was RA Acting Chief Executive Officer Conrad Lutombi, who said that due to the nature of its work, the RA has dealt with a number of corruption related cases in the past. To address the situation, the RA strengthened its internal policies and launched an independent anti-corruption hotline in November 2008. Lutombi said the signing of the MoU represents a "bold initiative" in the fight against corruption, fraud and workplace dishonesty. The RA acting CEO said that the MoU "confirms the relationship between the RA and ACC in terms of mutual cooperation, support and rendering assistance, it also serves to strengthen and formalise a good working relationship between the RA and ACC." Lutombi added that improvements in service delivery can be expected through the initiative. He added that while there was no national policy on whistle-blowing as yet, the RA had drafted a whistle-blowing policy as part of its fight against corruption. When asked whether the RA and ACC would be working together to strengthen internal policies to close loopholes which allow for corruption, Lutombi said that the RA would be working with the ACC to root out corruption.

TITLE: TR to Launch Gender Based Corruption Report
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); GENDER & SEX DISCRIMINATION IN EMPLOYMENT (90%); GENDER EQUALITY (90%); WOMEN (90%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (77%); POLLS & SURVEYS (72%); HUMAN RESOURCES (67%) Rwanda; Women and Gender; Corruption; Human Rights
TEXT: Transparency Rwanda (TR) will next week launch a report on Gender Based corruption at work places in the country. Speaking to The New Times yesterday, Marie Immaculee Ingabire, the Chairperson TR, said that her organisation would present its latest findings in a survey conducted in both private and public institutions. TR is a non-governmental non-profit organisation whose objective is to fight against corruption and related offences. "The report which covered the whole country and used both quantitative and qualitative methods unveils the prevalence of this form of corruption, the sectors where it is most relevant and the categories of citizens most at risk," she stated. Ingabire said that, the study explored the performance and usage of the strategies and mechanisms designed to report and prevent cases of gender-based corruption cases at work places. She stated that the launch would be an opportunity for key institutions engaged in the fight against corruption and promotion of gender equality to explore potential synergies and reflect on how to deepen their actions. The report also highlights causes and consequences of this form of corruption as well as aspects of human resources management most exposed to abuse. The study, which is the first of its kind in Rwanda, highlights concerns on corruption despite government's efforts to fight against graft and the promotion of gender equality.

TITLE: Hunted By Past Deeds -Edith Gongloe Weh in Corruption Web
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (76%); TEXT MESSAGING (70%); WRITERS (69%) Liberia; Corruption
TEXT: Nimba County former Superintended and senatorial aspirant Edith Gongloe Weh is being hunted by her past deeds of reportedly chopping monies intended for the people of Kwedin Township in the county. Reports gathered by this paper revealed that the former superintendent failed to deliver an amount of over US$2,500 donated by the office of President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf for the people of the township, but the amount never reach its destination. Meanwhile the Nimba County junior senatorial aspirant has failed to respond to the allegation after several calls and text messages, though the Office of the President has confirmed the saga. The information reached The Informer a week after this paper carried a front headline story captioned: 'Protest Vote Plotted against Ellen in Nimba", in which the citizens of Kwedin Township said they have planned not to vote for President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf for the second time because according to them she has failed to fulfill campaign promises made to them. Some citizens of the area informed this paper that President Sirleaf, through the office of the Assistant Minister of State for Logistic, Varney Sirleaf, made available over US$2,500 to the former Nimba Superintendent as "initial contribution" to the construction of the Kwedin Guest House project, but the citizens claimed that said amount was never delivered to them by Madam Weh. According the citizens' spokesman Roger Matadi, during an honoring program they organized for President Sirleaf early this year, at which the Liberian leader was represented by Madam Weh, they received from Madam Weh US$280. Of the amount, Madam Weh gave US$200 on behalf of the President and Varney Sirleaf and US$80 on behalf of herself, he alleged. He explained that they got to know that the President sent more than the amount that reached them when a representative group of the citizens later came to Monrovia to officially gown President Sirleaf and Varney Sirleaf. During the program, he narrated, they thanked the Office of the President for the US$200 sent to them earlier through Superintendent Weh. He said this commendation brought about shock and surprise to Varney who had reportedly given over US$2,500 and two set of jersey to madam Weh. Since last Thursday, this paper has made several efforts in getting Madam Weh's side of the story, but she has failed to comment, despite making promises to call back. When called for the first time on Thursday morning, Madam Weh said, "...I am in meeting, please called me at 2:30." Called at 2:30, as she requested, her phone was switched off. Called, again, on Friday morning, after this writer had sent her two text messages about the citizens' claim, Madam Weh, again, responded that "I am in a meeting, but I will call you back when finish." She failed to call or respond up to press time. However, when contacted, the Assistant Minister of State for Logistic, Varney Sirleaf, confirmed the citizens' allegation but said it had since been laid to rest. Mr. Sirleaf, who also rejected being interview on the matter, said he does not want to be seen as the one causing hindrance to anyone's political ambition. According to him, the leaders of the Kwedin citizens raised the issue and it was settled. "I even gave them (leaders) US$500 at the time they visited me in my office," Mr. Sirleaf added. He wondered why the problem that was dealt with ever since has to surface at this time. "May be it is the same leaders that are bringing this thing out," Sirleaf noted. President Sirleaf last month relieved Madam Gongloe-Weh of her post as superintendent of Nimba "to enable her to pursue her political objectives." The President's decision is in keeping with her decision that all political appointees vying for electoral office must step down," Presidential Press Secretary Cyrus Wleh Badio stated.

TITLE: PF Adoption Marred By Corruption -- Lifwekelo
SUBJECT: EXECUTIVES (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (79%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICS (78%); DISORDERLY CONDUCT (77%); MENTAL ILLNESS (72%); INTELLIGENCE & COGNITION (67%); HOTELS & MOTELS (50%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: FORUM for Leadership Search executive director Edwin Lifwekelo has said it is obvious that the adoption of candidates by the Patriotic Front (PF) is embroiled in corruption by the party leadership. Mr Lifwekelo said there were allegations that Copperbelt and Lusaka parliamentary seats were fetching as much as K100 million, adding that it was a clear indication that democracy in PF had been subverte and mutilated by Mr Sata. And Mr Lifwekelo has disclosed that his organisation has information that a meeting took lace at the Finnish Embassy where donors expressed disgust at the PF/Post alliance. He alleged that at the meeting, Post editor Fred M'membe failed to justify his alliance with the PF and the same was described by the donors as unprofessional. Mr Lifwekelo said the donors further expressed unhappiness with M'membe's willingness to turn the newspaper into a PF propaganda machinery. Meanwhile, Committee of Citizens executive director Gregory Chifire has called on relevant authorities to establish a commission of inquiry to ascertain Mr Sata's full mental capacity. Mr Chifire said it was in the interest of the nation and that of Mr Sata that an inquiry be stablished going by a number of things that Mr Sata had been doing which were not in onformity with the behaviour of a would-be republican president. He said this at a Press briefing held at Courtyard Hotel in Lusaka yesterday. Mr Chifire said his organisation had been compelled to furnish information in accordance with the provisions of the Mental Disorder Act Chapter 305 of the Laws of Zambia to relevant authorities for the possible establishment of an inquiry into the irregular conduct which was akin to mental disorderly conduct. He alleged that Mr Sata's conduct had not only been highly disorderly, irregular and sad but it seemed to suggest that his mental comprehension was not as it should be. Mr Chifire said Mr Sata's conduct could seriously be classified under the provisions and ambit of the law, in particular the Mental Disorder Act, adding that his organisation had found it fit to classify Mr Sata as an individual well within the provisions of Section 5 of the said Act, in particular Class I and II under the Act. He said although he was not an expert in the medical profession but merely a law-abiding citizen who believed in the laws the of Zambia, he had an obligation to point out matters of nation interest such as Mr Sata's conduct that Zambians had since sadly become ccustomed to through Mr Sata's conduct. Mr Chifire said the Act clearly gives members of the public the liberty to enforce what could be termed in lay mans language as a 'citizen arrest' for purposes of ensuring that mental isorderly conduct was gagged. He said establishing of an inquiry was a safer and more dignified route that his organisation was seeking because Mr Sata had constantly displayed conduct to the general public. Mr Chifire said his organisation would rely on well-documented conduct exhibited by Mr Sata on different occasions such as the November 1, 2008 issue where Mr Sata astonished the whole nation when he allegedly went on rampage hurling insults towards international and locally accredited journalists having lost the 2008 presidential elections. Mr Chifire said the other incident was Mr Sata's alleged unwavering support for gay rights in Zambia and his unpalatable verbal rampage on August 3 this year at a meeting called by the ECZ for presidential aspirants and also the calling of a freelance journalist, Chanda Chimba II as a hyena when he was a human being. He said that the information provided in this regard was not with malice or prejudice but was advanced purely in national interest and especially to safe guard Mr Sata's personal interest and of those around him. Mr Chifire said his organisation would soon be filing an affidavit before the courts on the request for the establishment of an inquiry. But PF vice-president Guy Scott has challenged Mr Chifire to have his mental status examined before he called on Mr Sata's mental status to be examined. Mr Scott said in an interview in Lusaka yesterday that Mr Chifire should ascertain his mental ability first and see whether he was mentally fit. "That is nonsense! He should first have his mental status examined before he requests for Mr Sata's mental status to be examined. Let him do it first and show us how it can be done," Dr Scott said.

TITLE: ACC Takes Corruption Fight to Nurses
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); NURSES & NURSING (94%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); MEDICAL EDUCATION (90%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); GRADUATE & PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS (78%); MIDWIVES (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (74%); PRISONS (69%); CRIMINAL FINES (69%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Health and Medicine
TEXT: The Northern Regional office of Anti-Corruption Commission has taken the educational approach in the fight against corruption to student nurses in Makeni. This was in the form of a sensitization meeting with staff and students of the National School of Nursing and School of Midwifery at the Masuba campus in Makeni on Friday 5th August 2011. Explaining the rationale for the meeting, the ACC District Coordinator, Bombali district Raymond Alieu Kamara said it was meant to encourage them to partner with the Commission in the fight against corruption. He said the meeting was also aimed at educating the nurses on the dangers of corruption, operations of the Commission and how corrupt practices can hinder the improvement of health delivery system in Sierra Leone. He stressed that the fight against corruption was a fight for all and should not just be left in the hands of the Commission alone. Kamara therefore entreated all present to see the fight against corruption as a collective responsibility which requires coalition building and partnership. Giving an overview of the Commission, Public Education Officer, Al-Hassan Sesay explained the three approaches used by the ACC in the fight against corruption, which are public education, prevention and confrontation. He explained the prosecutorial powers and mandate of the Commission as enshrined in the 2008 Anti-Corruption Act. Mr. Sesay made it clear to staff and students of the Nursing School and School of Midwifery that the Commission was not witch-hunting anybody and not just there to arrest and convict corrupt individuals, but also sensitizing the public on the dangers of corruption. Explaining the offences, Public Education Officer, Mrs. Fatmata Finda Bangura stressed that the Commission has the mandate to investigate all forms of corruption and corrupt practices. She highlighted some of the offences in the 2008 Act and disclosed that the punishment for any of the offences was a fine of not less than thirty (30) million Leones or imprisonment for not less than three (3) years or both fine and prison term. She used the opportunity to warn all staff and students to stop receiving gifts for corrupt purposes. She emphasized that Section 47 of the Anti-Corruption Act 2008 clearly makes it an offence for any public officer who solicits or accepts gifts as an inducement in the performance of his/her official duties. Mrs. Bangura explained the various methods of making reports to the Commission and entreated the student to resist, reject and report corruption. She reminded them of their civic responsibility to report corrupt practices going on in their respective institutions. She emphasized the Commission's core values of confidentiality and fullest protection for informants. Mrs. Bangura read the free ACC mobile hotlines and explained to them the benefits of making report and the 10% reward to informers for reporting corruption acts to the Commission. She however warned them against making false report which she said was an offence. Delivering the vote of thanks on behalf of staff and students, one of the midwifery students, Mrs. Marie Theresa Sheriff thanked the ACC for enlightening them on the offences and what they should not do. She assured the Commission that they would abide by the warnings and appealed to the Commission to address their numerous concerns and take the message to the government. Questions, answers, comments and concerns formed part of the meeting.

TITLE: 'Anti-Corruption Commission Won't Probe ECZ'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ELECTIONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); PRINTING INDUSTRY (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (78%); BALLOTS (78%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (77%); POLITICAL PARTIES (73%); POLITICS (73%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has said it is not carrying out any investigations into alleged corrupt practices by the Electoral Commission of Zambia (ECZ) over a printing company it engaged to print ballot papers for the 2011 general elections. In a statement released in Lusaka yesterday, ACC director-general Godfrey Kayukwa said there were no investigations concerning ECZ or any of its suppliers, including Universal Printing Group of South Africa. "Recently, there have been statements and reports in the media in relation to generalised allegations of corruption at the ECZ in the public interest and as director of ACC I have decided to provide some clarity on this matter. "The ACC wishes to state that there is no investigation concerning the ECZ or any of its suppliers," he said. Mr Kayukwa, however, said the institution was investigating an allegation of corruption against a former ECZ employee, Mpundu Mfula on a matter unrelated to the printing of ballot papers. He said the allegations against Mr Mfula were made in 2007 by an individual. "It was, however, not possible to progress the investigations into this allegation due to the fact that Mr Mfula left the country and his whereabouts are not known since April this year. "The commission recorded a warn-and-caution statement from him in April itself. As this is an on-going investigation, the commission is constrained from releasing any details at this stage as this would prejudice the investigation and the rights of Mr Mfula," Mr Kayukwa said. Meanwhile, ECZ said it was dismayed by the manner in which Patriotic Front member Given Lubinda delivered a letter to the office of the chairperson of the commission. ECZ public relations manager Cris Akufuna said in a statement last evening that Mr Lubinda was in the company of other people and a cameraman who, without permission, took pictures in the chairperson's office and the reception. "The commission would like to warn political parties and their members that the commission will not entertain such behaviour and will not hesitate to take drastic action against any individual who deliberately puts to risk the security of the commission. "The mandate of the commission is to conduct elections and it will not be distracted by any intimidatory and cowardly acts from any individual or party," Mr Akufuna said.

TITLE: No Immunity On Corruption- ERSG Schulenburg
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); DIPLOMATIC IMMUNITY (90%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (90%); HUMAN RIGHTS (90%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (90%); PEACE PROCESS (90%); IMMUNITY (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATIONS (78%); INTERNATIONAL LAW (78%); RULE OF LAW (77%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (75%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (72%); CIVIL SERVICES (70%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (65%); ILLEGAL DRUGS (64%); DRUG TRAFFICKING (50%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: The Executive Representative of the Secretary General (ERSG) in Sierra Leone has said that being head of the United Nations Peace-building Office in Sierra Leone (UNIPSIL) and having diplomatic immunity does not mean he was above the laws of the country and therefore could not be prosecuted for corruption. Michael von der Schulenburg said he was ready to comply with the rules and regulations governing the fight against corruption in the country. He was speaking last Friday during a one-day seminar organized by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) to review the United Nations Convention Against Corruption in the country. He disclosed that he had admonished all staff of UNIPSIL to abide by the laws of the country, noting that being a diplomat does not mean one should violate the laws of the land. The ERSG commended officials of the ACC and the Human Rights Commission of Sierra Leone for their efforts in promoting good governance and human rights issues in the country. "I do not have any immunity against corruption," ERSG Schulenberg told his audience. "It is significant that this country is included in international conventions because it shows that there is normalization. The Human Rights Commission has been recognized in Geneva where they now have the right to speak in front of others on the human rights situation in Sierra Leone." Mr. Schulenburg has accumulated a wide range of professional experience covering virtually all aspects of United Nations activities, from development assistance to humanitarian aid and managerial reforms; and from combating illicit drug trafficking to conflict resolution and political affairs. Over the years, the UN envoy has made important contributions to internal strategy discussions of the United Nations and has written a number of analytical and policy papers on Sierra Leone and the world over. Commissioner of the ACC, Joseph Fitzgerald Kamara said the review mechanism was significant to the fight against corruption in the country, adding that fighting graft has gone beyond national borders. The ACC boss informed the session that there was an increase in the compliance rate of government officers and civil servants in declaring their assets for transparency and accountability. "The United Nations Convention Against Corruption requires state parties to effect policies in the fight against corruption," Kamara noted. "We are working towards that, and as the commission now has prosecutorial powers, it is important to note that we are an efficient body. We are not just focusing on those in higher places in the implementation of the rule of law but every Sierra Leonean."

TITLE: Police Officers Kill Corruption Case
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ARRESTS (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); SEARCH WARRANTS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); SEARCH & SEIZURE (89%); BAIL (72%); ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS (50%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: DUE to the illegal involvement of the Police in a 2009 graft case under the Anti-Corruption Act, all charges were dropped against a cleaner at the Ministry of Works and Transport, Dorothea Ngozu (47), by Swakopmund Magistrate Bernhard Tjatjara on Monday. Ngozu was arrested in December 2009 after she was accused of subletting her Government home in Swakopmund to more than 20 people, which is a contravention under the Anti-Corruption Act. Under the act, it was charged that Ngozu (a public officer), allegedly used her position to obtain gratification from members of the public by renting the rooms between 2005 and 2009 of a Government house allocated to her. After an investigation followed by an arrest by the local Police, it came to light that Ngozu had rented out the four bedrooms, the living room, the garage and an outside room for N$400 per month per room. Entire families were apparently living in some rooms. Up to 23 people were living there. She was granted bail of N$2 000 then, and the occupants of the house were ordered to vacate the home immediately and find other accommodation. Lana Fouche, who represented Ngozu, argued that the Police were not authorised to conduct and execute search warrants in terms of the Anti Corruption Act, and that the whole search at the house and the arrests were outside the scope of the Police as they were not appointed as investigators under the Act and that they were not part of ACC. In the matter with Ngozu, the Police obtained a search warrant under the Criminal Procedure Act, to search for illegal immigrants, but ended up with a graft investigation. In terms of the Anti-Corruption Act, it is only authorised officer (under specific definitions) who can arrest, investigate and execute search warrants for graft related charges. In his verdict, Tjatjara stated that it was clear that the Police had to be authorised by the ACC, and that the Namibian Police are not recognised as investigative officers or special investigating officers under the corruption law, as they are not appointed by the ACC Director. He also stated that the Police "do not blend in" as investigative officers or authorised officers for graft charges. "It follows that the whole investigation and search related to the case for which the accused was charged under the Act was not within the powers of the Namibian Police, thus ultra vires and illegal," the Magistrate said.

TITLE: Magistrate Charged With Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); MAGISTRATES (92%); BRIBERY (90%); EXTORTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (88%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (88%); BAIL (88%); ARRESTS (88%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A young Oshakati-based Magistrate, Melaney Theron, was arrested on Monday on charges of corruption, extortion and bribery. Magistrate Theron appeared in Oshakati Magistrate's Court yesterday and was granted N$7 000 bail. Her case has been postponed to September 27 for further Police investigation. Oshana Regional Crime Investigation Co-ordinator Sydney Philander confirmed Theron's appearance in court at 14h00 yesterday. Philander also confirmed that the charges are related to allegations of fixing traffic tickets where Theron would allegedly pocket traffic fines and throw out traffic transgression cases. "All we can confirm is that from our side we have three charges. One count of corruption, one of extortion and one count of bribery. We cannot go into technical details of alternative charges because the prosecution would be in a better position to do that," Philander said. The Anti-Corruption Commission's head, Paulus Noa, himself a former Magistrate, said the matter is not an ACC case. "Otherwise our officials in Oshakati would have briefed us," Noa said.

TITLE: Ombudsman Launches Anti-Corruption Week
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%) Rwanda; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: The Ombudsman, Tito Rutaremara, says Rwandans should be aware of their rights as well as respect others' as a way of eliminating injustice. He made the remarks during the launch of the anti- corruption week in Rubavu District. "Rwanda strives for dignity and we can't claim pride with injustice and corruption still in our society," Rutaremara said. The five-day campaign, will see staff of the office visit all the sectors in the district to receive complaints from residents. The exercise that was launched in Rubavu will also take place in other districts. Venancia Twagirayezu, the Minister in the President's Office, commended the Ombudsman and his team for a good job in the fight against graft. The Ombudsman's office visits every district once a month to solve corruption-related issues and injustice cases. Plans are underway for more frequent visits. "The Ombudsman has done a great job in trying to ensure that all Rwandans receive justice and fight corruption and that's why we have received international recognition," Twagirayezu said. She encouraged Rubavu leaders to be role models in implementing strategies put in place to fight the vice. "During this week, corruption cases should be assessed carefully and solved and this exercise taken to the grassroots as well," she added. Stephen Nsengiyumva, a resident in Rubavu, welcomed the campaign, saying it was timely in stemming corruption and injustice that is rampant in the district. "Residents are not that enthusiastic about their rights because they lack awareness, so the government should step up the sensitisation campaign," he urged.

TITLE: Provide Proof On UPG Corruption, Lusaka Lawyer Challenges Nchito
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ELECTIONS (90%); LAWYERS (90%); EVIDENCE (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (74%); NATIONAL SECURITY (69%); BALLOTS (67%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: LUSAKA lawyer Hobbday Kabwe has challenged Mutembo Nchito to provide documented corruption allegations against Universal Print Group (UPG). Mr Kabwe said it was sad that Mr Nchito could now turn against the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), a client he represented in the past and pretend not to be aware that allegations such as those against UPG should only be proved with evidence. "This is a very slippery ground for Mr Nchito who formerly represented the ACC to now accuse it of not doing anything. "Allegations such as the ones targeted against UPG should only be proved with evidence and I am challenging Mr Nchito to tell the nation whether such corruption allegations are documented anywhere in the courts of law," he said. He said what Mr Nchito, Post Newspaper managing editor Fred M'membe and former Patriotic Front Kabwata Member of Parliament Given Lubinda had raised now that the country was headed for elections should not be acceptable. He said there was need for people to always remain principled, especially on matters bordering on national security. Mr Kabwe said it was not the first time UPG was printing ballot papers for Zambia and that it was surprising that Mr Nchito and Mr Lubinda could not raise such allegations during the 2006 and 2008 elections. "These people are raising these allegations now just because they have realised that their preferred candidate is losing the September 20 elections," Mr Kabwe said. Mr Nchito, Mr Lubinda and Mr M'membe have come under fire for failing to provide evidence of their allegations against UPG when they were summoned by the ACC on Thursday last week.

TITLE: Corruption Crusade Reaches Burma III
SUBJECT: TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (73%); WITNESSES (60%) Sierra Leone; Corruption
TEXT: The robust and sustained public education crusade by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) in the eastern province of the country has been ongoing in pursuit of one of its mandates of employing all necessary measures to curb corruption, through public education and outreach sessions which has seen the commission meeting with various MDAs and communities in and around Kenema aimed at raising their awareness on corruption and the operations of the ACC. Burma III community, in Nongowa Chiefdom, Kenema district was on Friday 19 August, 2011 the latest community to be targeted. Anthony S. Kamara, in welcoming the ACC officials, expressed satisfaction over the visit as the people of Burma needed a lot of education on corruption and the operations of the commission. Chief A.J. Lamin, who chaired the meeting, expressed delight over the move by the ACC to engage and educate them on corruption, which he termed as enemy to the development of this war ravaged nation. He maintained that the commission alone cannot successfully curb corruption except with the support of all and sundry. He encouraged all to be attentive and seek clarifications to confusing concepts about the ACC and its operations. The District Coordinator of the ACC Kenema, Mohamed S. Blake, in declaring the purpose of such an engagement was quick to point out that the presence of the ACC in Burma was just one of their regular public education campaigns aimed at taking the commission to the people. He referred to the ACC as the lead agency in the fight against corruption in the country and thus seeks to recruit the public into the fight and as such was educating them on the operations of the commission, what constitutes corruption, how to report corruption and the benefits of a corrupt free nation. This is all aimed at better preparing them to join the national crusade against graft. He stated that corruption was one of the principal causes of the unrest that this country went through and called on all to stand firm against corruption and educate others to resist, reject and report instances of corruption to the ACC. Giving a brief overview and operations of the ACC, the Public Education Officer East, David K. Conteh spoke on the establishment of the commission by an Act of Parliament in 2000 as result of recommendations of the TRC. He added that the Anti-Corruption Act of 2008 has 27 corrupt practices and gives the commission prosecutorial powers. He spoke on the three operational wings of the ACC: education, prevention and prosecution. He stated that the ACC puts much premium on preventing corruption rather than prosecuting offenders. He encouraged people to abide by the laid down rules, regulations and policies. Acting Regional Manager East, Peter B. Kamara briefly spoke on the reporting procedures, the informant and witness protection and the 10% reward scheme, and encouraged his audience to break the culture of silence and report corruption. He highlighted some corrupt practices in the Anti-Corruption Act of 2008 and their respective penalties and encouraged all to serve as ACC ambassadors by educating other members of the community. He urged them to support the work of the commission by giving timely and credible information. He gave the ACC hotlines and encouraged the community people to utilize the opportunity by reporting corruption related issues to the commission. In his closing statement, Chief Bockarie Samai of Burma III community appreciated the ACC for the sensitization and called on all to be committed to the fight against graft. He registered his community's preparedness to support the commission in the interest of national development. Chief Mary Salamy, the women's leader moved the vote of thanks. By Mohamed Sylvanus Blake District Coordinating Officer - Kenema

TITLE: Local Traders Decry Corruption At Mombasa Port
COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); RWANDA (94%); SUDAN (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); ETHIOPIA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); PARKING SPACES & FACILITIES (90%); PORT AUTHORITIES (90%); BORDER CONTROL (78%); BRIBERY (78%); TRUCK DRIVERS (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); POLICE FORCES (77%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (74%); TALKS & MEETINGS (72%); EXECUTIVES (72%); COASTAL AREAS (69%); RECESSION (68%); ECONOMIC NEWS (68%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (65%); CITY GOVERNMENT (56%) Rwanda; Kenya; Corruption
TEXT: Traders from Rwanda who use the Kenyan port of Mombasa have expressed their displeasure with the port's inadequate parking lot amid allegations of corruption that they claim is adversely affecting their business. The Secretary General of the Rwanda Long Distance Truck Drivers Union, Theodore Murenzi, said that port clerks, police and crane drivers, collude and demand for bribes from drivers to clear their goods. "We are forced to park along the road where we get into trouble with the Mombasa Municipal Council authorities who fine us Kshs 4,000," he said during a meeting organised by the Kenya Ports Authority (KPA) to share views with the port's customers in Kigali yesterday. The Mombasa Port situated along the coast of Indian Ocean, is an entry point for goods destined for the East African region, Democratic Republic of Congo, Southern Sudan and Ethiopia. "It has been happening whenever cranes have broken down," Eng. Joseph Atonga, the Chief Operations Manager, Kenya Ports Authority said, adding they are committed to bringing to an end such criminal activities. Atonga added that KPA is converting part of the land it owns into a parking yard for foreign trucks. Traders have also reported that highway robberies and police roadblocks on Kenya highways target them and strip them of their cargo and money. However, the Senior Deputy Commissioner and Director of Operations in the Kenyan Police, Julius Ndegwa, reassured traders that police now provide special escorts for cargo in transit from the port up to Malaba border post in Western Kenya. "We have formed a highway patrol unit to protect goods in transit. They will be assisted by the Special Crime Protection Unit created recently," he said. The Managing Director of KPA, Gichiri Ndua, said despite the global economic recession, the port saw an increase of 5.1 percent in exports from the region with a growth in traffic of 5.4 metric tonnes from 5.1 metric tons, with Rwanda accounting for 5.4 percent transit traffic registered a growth of 33.5 percent. "Currently, there is increasing usage of the port by the region, a sign of the improved region's economic performance," he said.

TITLE: Skills, Corruption and Theft Biggest Business Enemies
SUBJECT: LABOR FORCE (90%); ETHICS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); TAXES & TAXATION (86%); INFLATION (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); TAX LAW (74%); CURRENCIES (54%); LABOR & EMPLOYMENT LAW (52%) Namibia; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: CORRUPTION, crime, theft and poor work ethics are increasingly taking their toll on business in Namibia, a new survey by the World Economic Forum has shown. The poor work ethic in the national labour force is now the second biggest stumbling block for doing business in the country, according to the 2011-12 Global Competitiveness Report, released yesterday. Last year, ethics was rated as the fifth biggest problem out of 15. Corruption has jumped from the sixth to the fourth biggest concern, while crime and theft moved from the ninth to the seventh position this year. Like last year, the inadequately educated workforce still gives business its biggest headache. Also up on the latest constraints ladder, are foreign currency regulations (from 13th to tenth place), and poor public health (from 12th to 11th place) Inefficient red tape remained as the third highest hurdle. Other hampering factors are restrictive labour regulations (fifth), access to financing (sixth), inadequate supply of infrastructure (eighth), tax rates (ninth), inflation (12th), tax regulations (13th), political instability (14th) and government instability or coups (15th). Rating the problems, Namibia's unskilled workforce scored 16,9 points, while political instability and government instability or coups got 1,3 and 0,5 points respectively.

TITLE: KCM Employee Jailed for Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); MAGISTRATES (92%); JAIL SENTENCING (91%); SENTENCING (90%); COPPER MINING (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); AGREEMENTS (77%); ARREST WARRANTS (72%); ARRESTS (72%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A Chingola magistrate's court has sentenced a Konkola Copper Mines (KCM) employee to nine months imprisonment with hard labour for engaging in corrupt practices. According to a statement released by Anti Corruption Commission (ACC) Public Relations Manager Timothy Moono, Chingola resident magistrate Vincent Siloka on September 1 convicted Jackson Mutawa, 34, of flat number 11B ZISC complex, President Avenue in Chingola for corrupt practices by a private officer contrary to section 31(1) and 41 of the Anti-Corruption commission Act no.42of 1996. Mr Moono said that particulars of the matter were that on dates unknown but between March 1 and 31 2010, in Chingola, Mutawa, being a private officer working as divisional secretary with KCM plc in Chingola corruptly solicited for and received K500,000 cash gratification from Kelvin Katongo as a reward or inducement for himself to extend a tenancy agreement between KCM and Kelvin's canteens a matter which concerned KCM as a private body. Mutawa, was arrested by the ACC on July 22, 2010, after working closely with the KCM security department. In another development, Chief resident magistrate of the Kitwe subordinate court has sentenced a Chililabombwe resident to one year imprisonment with hard labour for also engaging in corrupt practices. Magistrate Mercy Makubalo convicted Steven Mutale of house number T306, Chililabombwe of corrupt practices by a public officer. Particulars of the offence were that, on dates unknown but between February 20 and March 3, 2010, in Kitwe, Mutale being a public officer, working as acting interpreter with the judiciary department in Chililabombwe corruptly solicited for for K3, 000,000 and received K350, 000.00 cash gratification as a reward or inducement for himself not to execute a bench warrant issued against Jones Mwale, Sydney Makumba and Cheelo Mudenda for contempt of court, a matter of transaction which concerned the judiciary department, a public body. Mutale was arrested by the ACC on July 13, 2010.
