TITLE: Corporate Governance - An Antidote to Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: EMERGING MARKETS (90%); ECONOMIC POLICY (90%); ECONOMIC NEWS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (89%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (89%); ETHICS (78%); ECONOMIC CRISIS (78%); ENTREPRENEURSHIP (77%); INDUSTRY SECTOR PERFORMANCE (75%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (74%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (69%); HOUSEHOLD NUMBERS (69%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (69%); SHAREHOLDERS (60%) Zimbabwe; Governance; Corruption; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: It has rendered to naught brilliant economic reforms. Most people hate it. A few benefit from it. Yet corruption is strong enough to have replaced traditional economic ethos of capital and production. No wonder the economic crises. Like economics there is a supply-side and demand-side for corruption. The supply-side or the giver resides in businesses. Businesses pay the bribes. The demand side or taker is predominantly government officials. Government officials demand bribes. In most discussions corruption is often blamed on government officials and seldom on the private sector. This is not to say that the private sector is the sole supplier. Literature is revealing that non governmental organisations are steady suppliers of corruption in developing countries. The centre piece of supply and demand for corruption in Africa and many advancing nations has been the many market oriented economic reform, such as privatisation. Public sector procurement for a long time now has attracted corrupt activities. In trying to find a cure for corruption it is important to consider both the supply and demand sides of corruption. Much has been said about the demand side and seldom on the role of the private sector as a supplier of corruption. The private sector is more cash liquid than the public sector, performance driven, profit motivated and always short of time. No cost no gain is an established rule of the profit game. Risk taking gives the game adrenalin. Entrepreneurs outperform one another in pursuit of profits. This desperation, risk inclination and willingness to pay whatever it takes render the private sector most gullible to demanders of bribes. In a survey carried out by the African Capital Markets Forum in Ghana during the year 2000, it was reported that 86 percent of households saw corruption as a major problem in the public sector, whereas 59 percent of households saw corruption as a major problem in the private sector. It was also found that many firms in Ghana made unofficial payments (44 percent) to public officials with over a quarter (27 percent) frequently or always making such payments. Unofficial payments constituted a regular feature of transactions between business firms and public service agencies. 56 percent of firms reported that service was frequently delivered once they made an unofficial payment. Although there is not much statistics on the level of private sector involvement in corruption in Zimbabwe, it is common knowledge that there is an increase in the supply of bribes in the country. How does good corporate governance reign in this corporate behaviour? Corporate governance spells out the rules and procedures for making decisions on corporate affairs. It also specifies the distribution of rights and responsibilities among different participants in companies such as the board, managers, shareholders, and other stakeholders. In addition corporate governance reminds businesses that while profits are important, businesses need ethics, customers and other stakeholders. Through corporate governance, corporations are warned of the dangers of putting profits first. Company leadership is also cautioned that when numbers become all-important, almost any behaviour is justifiable as long as money is made. Sound corporate governance standards reduce supply-side corruption by removing systemic opportunities that breed corruption. Principles of accountability, transparency, fairness and rule compliance help a good corporate governance system spell out the procedures for carrying out activities and responsibilities in an organisation. The system does not leave room for uncertainty of roles and power. An example of a good corporate governance mechanism is the transparency in the provision of accounting information. It helps reduce the level of corruption by increasing the probability of detecting bribery acts. Better accounting practices make it difficulty for directors to hide bribe payments. However, if the shareholder encourages bribery then accounting information might not be as effective in curbing corruption. Why then do corporations with good corporate governance systems pay bribes? First there has to be a conducive atmosphere for the supply and demand of bribery. This can take place in broad ranges of business activities over which some government officials hold discretionary powers. Common among these are; where firms bribe public officials to avoid or reduce tax, to secure public procurement contracts, to bypass laws and regulations, or to block the entry of potential competitors. On the surface bribery seems to be cost-effective for businesses because bribe payment is often a fraction of the monetary value of the services rendered by the corrupt officials. The reason to bribe becomes even more compelling when public officials hold the power to punish the firms for not paying the bribe, such as revoking business licenses. Corporates are often duped to believe that the only cost of bribery is paying the government officials. However, global research is showing that there are hidden costs to bribery, some of which can be fatal. Xun Wu in "Corporate Governance and Corruption: A Cross-Country Analysis" states that bribery exposes firms to substantial legal and financial risks in the future. Governments may decide to nullify contracts that have been initiated or influenced by bribery, or to blacklist the firms for future government projects. In the past the government of Singapore banned five multinational companies (Siemens, Pirelli, BICC, Marubeni, and Tomen), from bidding on any government projects for five years after their consultant was convicted of paying bribes for utilities construction contracts. Perhaps the most vicious is that, when companies open their doors to corruption, they may find it difficult to resist demands for bribery payments in the future. Research is also finding that companies with a reputation for bribing their way out are more likely to receive demands for higher bribe payment by corrupt officials, sometimes for services that are normally free of bribery for other companies. Bribe payment from firms with such a reputation may be perceived to be "safe" from the perspective of the potentially corrupt officials, and these corrupt officials may increase the level of bureaucratic interference in order to secure bribe payments from these firms. These companies become "ka mugodhi" or a private small mine for the officials. Xun Wu goes on to explain that, as a result firms that hope to circumvent government regulations may actually face an increased level of bureaucratic interference. Companies that pay more bribes face more, not less, effective red tape because corrupt officials can often customise the nature and amount of harassment on firms in order to maximise bribe collection. Bribery undermines the companies' drive in developing long-term competitive advantages. If managers realise that they can win business through bribery rather than through providing better products or services, they will be busy courting government officials rather than concentrating on developing the competitiveness of their firms through innovation and better investment decisions. This is detrimental to developing economies. Corporate governance is not only about dealing with the internal governance of a company but also with its relations to its suppliers, to its consumers, to its business partners, and to the government. Integrity and accountability are the values that guide the relationship between owners, managers, employees, and other stakeholders. Thus if the relations of the company, its suppliers and regulators are premised on bribery and corruption, as stated above, it will be difficult for the company to resist future demands for bribes. A strong board of directors that prioritises the interests of shareholders can prevent companies from giving bribes to public officials. Directors and managers determine the corporate culture. Yet, they often sign shady contracts, ignoring the negative implications. Non executive directors are systematically appointed in relation to their ability to influence outcomes with government relations. Such directors, instead of protecting the resources of the company, become conduits for bribe payments. While corruption offers companies short-term relief, good governance provides a longer-term, victory. Victors are those who protect their reputation and their shareholders. Prudent investors need assurances that their investments will not be channelled into unproductive activities. Entrepreneurs look for ways to attract investors to finance their visions. The aim is to make profits and maximise the value of the company. To achieve this, more and more corporations are coming up with corporate governance reforms. Investors are looking for businesses that uphold values of good corporate governance. Weak governance systems provide a good environment for corruption to thrive. Shareholders and investors in countries that are experiencing a high level of corruption may receive double dividends from the improvement in corporate governance. Companies with better corporate governance have better prospects of growth and command higher valuation in the market. A McKinsey study showed that global investors are willing to pay more for better-governed companies. It is said that inorder to kill off a bad habit, starve it. Private sector has the muscle to starve off corruption - stop supplying. Anti-corruption activists encourage private sector to adopt good corporate governance. The writer is a researcher and governance consultant.

TITLE: Katima Mayor Faces Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); MAGISTRATES (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); MAYORS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); ACCOUNTING STANDARDS (86%); MISCONDUCT (78%); CITIES (78%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (78%); BAIL (73%); SPECIAL ECONOMIC ZONES (73%); EXECUTIVES (72%); WAGES & SALARIES (70%); MAINTENANCE & REPAIR (69%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: KATIMA Mulilo mayor John Likando has made a first court appearance on charges relating to fraud and corruption. Likando appeared in the Caprivi Regional Court in Katima Mulilo last week before Magistrate William Kastomo. The case was postponed to October 3 and his bail was extended. Likando's case was set for plea and trial last week, but the trial could not start as Likando's lawyer, Matildah Shakwa of Sisa Namandje Legal Practitioners, was absent due to personal reasons. The charges against Likando date back to between May 2005 and February 2008 when he was employed by the Offshore Development Company at Katima Mulilo. He faces four charges of contravening the Anti-Corruption Act. It is alleged that he corruptly used his office and position for personal gratification after he allegedly rented company stall units in the Economic Processing Zone (EPZ) for personal enrichment at the company's expense. In an unrelated development, the Katima Mulilo Town Council is still awaiting the outcome of last month's disciplinary hearing involving its chief executive officer, Vincent Sazita, and finance chief Charles Nawa. Sazita and Nawa have been suspended from duty since April 20 this year. Charles Matengu, chairperson of the Katima Mulilo Town Council's management committee, said yesterday that the council was still awaiting the verdict of the disciplinary committee. Both Sazita and Nawa have been charged with misconduct in the performance of their duties. Sazita's charges include "failure to ensure that all policies and decisions of the council and management committee are executed effectively and efficiently". Sazita has also been charged with failure to provide guidance, advice and leadership to the council, as well as a failure to assume accountability for all financial dealings undertaken by the council, and a failure to maintain effective communication with all stakeholders. Nawa, the chief financial officer, is accused of "irregular salary increments during the period 2007-2010", failure to be responsible for revenue assurance, failure to establish and maintain internal control procedures and to assure the management and council that accounting procedures are maintained. Nawa is also charged with failure to comply with accounting legislation, accounting standards and good practice as well as failure to maintain and collect council revenue. Both Sazita and Nawa have alleged that proper procedures relating to their suspension were not followed, but these claims were dismissed by Matengu.

TITLE: Journalists Form Alliance Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (98%); JOURNALISM (91%); WRITERS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); NEWS REPORTING (79%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (72%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (71%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Press and Media
TEXT: Media practitioners across Sierra Leone have formed a strong alliance to help the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) in its quest to curtail corruption in the country. The group, Media Alliance Against Corruption (MAAC), was established at the end of a 3-day national training for journalists organised by the ACC and the Sierra Leone Association of Journalists (SLAJ) at the J&E Resort in Bo on the theme: "Good Governance and Investigative Journalism: The Role of the Media in Corruption Control". With the setting up of the group, journalists would work closely with the country's anti-graft agency in the fight against corruption. MAAC is charged with the responsibility of raising public awareness on corruption, its causes and consequences and report cases of corruption for the commission's attention. Acting ACC Commissioner, Morlai Buya Kamara, expressed the commission's delight at the establishment of MAAC, saying the ACC will support the group all through to ensure its success in its objectives. "We are very much encouraged as a commission by the setting up of such a group," Mr. Kamara said. "We will be pleased to work with MAAC to report corrupt issues and stop this menace in our nation. We will give them all the support they need to succeed." To demonstrate his commission's readiness to work with MAAC, Mr. Kamara presented the sum of Le1 million to the group to kick-start their campaign. While imploring journalists to have a vision and passion for their work, the acting ACC boss pointed out that the commission will welcome objective comments and criticisms from the media. "I advise you to do more investigations and follow-ups in your reporting. I am aware that your task is challenging but not insurmountable," he noted. MAAC's acting National Coordinator Melvin Rogers thanked the ACC boss for his personal donation and assured him of the group's determination to ensure that the fight against corruption is won. Rogers promised to seek SLAJ's recognition of the group and put modalities in place to hold a convention to elect its national executive. After the launch of the group by Mr. Kamara, the training came to an end with the distribution of certificates to participants.

TITLE: Let's Gang-Fight Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICS (89%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (89%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); ETHICS (77%); BRIBERY (77%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (71%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Rabid critics of the Zimbabwean Government, chief among them, Transparency International have been parroting a white lie incessantly that "there is no political will in the country to fight corruption". This is so because the country's leadership has used every opportunity to castigate and speak against corruption in the different sectors of the economy. Only recently at the burial of Retired General Solomon Mujuru, President Mugabe said "corruption is there in the country among us and only a thief gets rich overnight. We have laws and we don't want a country of thieves, but we want a country with people with discipline" This statement was followed last week by the swearing in of a nine-member Anti-Corruption Commission by President Mugabe marking the beginning of concerted efforts by the inclusive Government to curb the vice. The vice has condemned the country to number 134 out of 178 nations ranking by the Transparency International (2010), Corruption Perceptions Index. Recognition of corruption as a problem in the country and subsequent action taken by President Mugabe is tangible evidence that there is political will to tackle the problem. But the truth be told, the buck does not stop with the Head of State to curb this vice which cuts across political, social and economic divide and has deadly effects on politics, economy, administration and national institutions, posing a serious threat to development. We all envision a corruption-free society where its citizens are guarded by national interest, professionalism, integrity and ubuntu for the development of the nation. Thus, every Zimbabwean has a role to play if we are going to win the war against such degeneracy. One would like to believe the first Anti-Corruption Commission sworn in on September 8, 2005 was not successful because Zimbabweans disassociated themselves from the problem but expected miracles to happen. The country had witnessed unprecedented corruption fuelled by the crippling effects of the illegal sanctions, which had strangled the macro-economic environment. As one writer once alluded, "the country has been reduced to a nation of dealers out to make a quick buck from the corridors of power, street alleys to flea markets". It had become the norm that if one wants to get service in government departments one had to be prepared to part with one's hard-earned cash. The private sector has not been spared as well, as corruption increases the cost of business through the price of illicit payments, bribes and kickbacks. There is no place for blame games in fighting corruption. PM Morgan Tsvangirai once said, "the (Prime Minister) needs the support of ethical and professional leaders in Government who stand ready to fight corruption. I don't see this in the crop of public bureaucrats we have, especially from the Zanu-PF party." PM Tsvangirai's naive statement was before the rot in his own party, especially in the councils was exposed. The MDC, embarrassed at the scale of the corruption of its own officials led shame-faced Tsvangirai to say "we have cases of people who were push-cart operators before they became councillors but now have 10 cars each. Many others were simple market traders are now in big business because of corruption". The Prime Minister was made to eat his words as he acknowledged "we admit that our basket has bad apples, but we cannot throw away the whole basket, unfortunately others are now falling for this culture of corruption". "A lot of our councillors have breached the citizen's charter and flouted tender procedures. Our councillors have been emulating and imitating the Zanu-PF model of a councillor." The undeniable truth is, corruption cuts across the social, economic and political divide, so it needs the concerted efforts of every Zimbabwe. Thus, fighting corruption is not a one-man fight. According to a United Nations (UN) paper entitled Corruption & Anti-corruption in Southern Africa, the media has a role to play in "responsibly investigating, reporting and exposing corruption without undermining the credibility of anti-corruption efforts". While civil society organisations have a role to play in monitoring, raising public awareness, research and prevention" "Corruption is as much structurally conditioned as it is a personal-choice driven behaviour". Thus, in corruption vulnerable areas (customs, police, procurement, licences and permits, education, employment, immigration and border controls, revenue collection, judiciary) anti-corruption strategies and polices ought to seek to reduce structural opportunities for corruption as well as motivational factors to corrupt and or to be corrupted", the paper rightly pointed out. While at the same time, Zimbabweans will be complementing the functions of the Anti-Corruption Commission, which among other things is to 1) investigate cases of corruption in the public and private sectors 2) combat corruption and abuse of power 3) promote honesty, financial discipline and transparency in the public and private sectors 4) secure the prosecution of persons involved in corrupt activities. Political will to fight corruption and support anti-corruption efforts is imperative if the country is to succeed in combating this deadly vice. Susan Chipanga is a political commentator based in Harare.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Conference Set for Windhoek
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); CONSULTING SERVICES (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); RISK MANAGEMENT (90%); ETHICS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); MANAGEMENT CONSULTING (78%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (75%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (73%); WIRE FRAUD (73%); CYBERCRIME (73%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (70%); FORENSICS (66%); HOTELS & MOTELS (64%); PRIME MINISTERS (55%); BUSINESS ETHICS (52%); AUDITS (52%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: AN INTERNATIONAL fraud and corruption conference is set for Windhoek next week. The gathering organised by Gahel Investment & Consultancy will be known as 'All Africa Fraud &Corruption Conference' and will start on Saturday and end on October 28. The conference will bring together all relevant stakeholders that are already involved in the fight against corruption and fraud to map out the best ways to fight these scourges. The organisers of the conference told The Namibian that Prime Minister Nahas Angula, Minister of Health and Social Services, Richard Kamwi and deputy health minister Petrina Haingura have already confirmed their attendance and participation in the conference. The five day conference will be addressed by legal practitioners and risk management consultants from South Africa, apart from Angula, Kamwi and Haingura who are also listed on the programme as speakers. Among the topics to be addressed are security and audit controls, cyber fraud, money laundering, fraud and forensic investigations, business ethics, legislation governing corruption and fraud and risk management. The fifth and final day of the conference will be devoted to active discussion and information sharing on how organisations can adopt action plans for their anti-fraud and corruption programmes. The conference will be held at the Hilton Hotel in Windhoek.

TITLE: Students Join Anti-Corruption Drive
SUBJECT: STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (66%) Rwanda; Corruption; Education
TEXT: Secondary school students in Karongi and Rutsiro districts have formed anti-corruption clubs. Yesterday, Bernadette Kanzayire, the Deputy Ombudsman in charge of preventing and fighting injustice, commissioned the clubs in various secondary schools in the area. She challenged the students to play a leading role in fighting the vice as youths, as they are the country's future generation. "You are the leaders of tomorrow and the struggle against corruption begins with you. Avoid any involvement as you condemn the vice," Kanzayire advised. She also called for joint efforts in the promotion of justice and equality among Rwandans. Meanwhile, university students across the country hailing from Karongi, organised a re-union this week in which they pledged their full commitment towards developing their area. "We intend to hold more of such meetings because they help us to devise means of exploiting the resources back home. The local leaders are very supportice," Gaspard Hirwa, a third year student at KIST said. He noted that development programs to raise individual economic welfare can be achieved through the formation of associations and cooperatives. During the get together, Karongi District Mayor, Bernard Kayumba, re-affirmed the district's commitment to enable the youth to transform their social and economic status.

TITLE: Former Karas Governor's Corruption Trial Resumes
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); WITNESSES (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (89%); LAWYERS (78%); BRIBERY (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); HOUSING ASSISTANCE (76%); INVESTIGATIONS (72%); WAGES & SALARIES (69%); GOVERNMENT GRANTS & SUBSIDIES (56%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE corruption trial of former Karas governor Dawid Boois resumed yesterday in the Keetmanshoop Regional Court with former Karas chief regional officer (CRO) Salmaan Jacobs in the witness stand. Boois had pleaded not guilty to 24 counts of corruption at the start of his trial in August. It is alleged that Boois had used his position as governor for gratification by pocketing a monthly housing subsidy of N$7 500 for two years while he was living in a government house. Boois admitted that he had received a subsidy while living in a government house, but denied he had used his position for gratification as charged. Jacobs yesterday told the court that Boois was verbally encouraged and advised to voluntarily ask to have his housing subsidy payment stopped because he had forfeited it after moving into a government house in May 2005. Boois did not follow this advice, Jacobs testified. Asked why the administration had allowed the subsidy payment to continue while Boois was occupying a government house, Jacobs said his consent was needed. Because of Boois's silence on the matter, Jacobs added, the administration was forced to write to him on September 4 2007 with a proposal to enter into negotiations for an amicable way to solve the matter. Jacobs said only when the regional council started the process to recover the subsidy payments of close to N$180 000 and to stop payments, Boois responded through his legal representative on September 18 2007. The lawyer demanded that the administration repay Boois the N$7 500 it had deducted from his salary and to desist from making further deductions, according to Jacobs. He added the lawyer also threatened with a "mandatory interdict" should the administration ignore his demands. Jacobs added that the recovery process was initiated on the advice by Regional and Local Government Ministry permanent secretary Erastus Negonga. The process to rectify the illegal payments had taken almost two years because of protracted negotiations between the council administration and Boois, Jacobs replied when asked why the administration had not implemented a Cabinet resolution stipulating that political office bearers should forfeit the subsidy when occupying a government house. Boois vacated the house two months after the debt recovery had been implemented, said Jacobs. Grilled by defence counsel Sisa Namandje whether Boois had used his position as governor to have the house allocated to him, or had influenced the council not to stop his illegal subsidy payments, Jacobs replied: "Charges were put by someone else, and someone else must answer it". State Prosecutor Pieter Smit requested a postponement to summons an Anti-Corruption Commission investigator to testify. Despite Namandje's objections, Regional Magistrate Sunsley Zisengwe granted the postponement. The trial will continue on May 2 and 3 next year.

TITLE: President Sata Renews Hope in Corruption Fight
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENTS (77%); RULE OF LAW (77%); INTERVIEWS (77%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (72%); LAWYERS (71%); SUPREME COURTS (70%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (70%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (69%); NARCOTICS ENFORCEMENT (60%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (60%); POLICE FORCES (50%) Zambia; Governance; Corruption
TEXT: IT is a fact that corruption has been and still remains a serious cancer that has eaten into the vital fiber of the Zambian society. While efforts have been made by successive governments, especially under late President Levy Mwanawasa's government, corruption has remained a great challenge to the country's economic development. Worse still corruption affects the poor of the poor. The effect of corruption, as observed by many, has many dimensions related to political, economic, social and environmental effects. It is therefore refreshing that newly elected President Michael Sata has prioritised the fight against corruption. In his inaugural speech at the Supreme Court on Friday September 24, President Sata pledged that his administration would have zero tolerance for corruption. He said his administration shall ensure full accountability of national resources. "It is not the wish nor intention of the incoming government to victimise anyone but as indicated during our campaigns, we shall have zero tolerance for corruption. "As President I give my solemn promise to the citizenry of this country as well as to our partners who entrust us with their money that this government will steadily tackle this scourge with the vigour it deserves," he said President Sata said corruption is morally unacceptable and that those charged with the responsibility of looking after the country's resource should guard them jealously. Because of corruption, resources meant for service provision in the health, education and other sectors are diverted to benefit individuals. And as many stakeholders have observed, the stance by President Sata would greatly benefit Zambia. Transparency International Zambia president Reuben Lifuka says President Sata's prioritising of the corruption fight is a sure way of propelling Zambia to economic success. "It is a significant point and we welcome the pronouncements, we hope to see transformation from words to action. We want to see an action plan that will help the country to fight corruption," he said. Mr Lifuka said in a recent interview that however the new government would also need to strengthen relevant institutions such as the Anti Corruption Commission (ACC) and the police service. He said the new government should ensure that relevant institutions, including the Drug Enforcement Commission (DEC) as well as the Auditor General's office are strengthened to remain relevant. Former Task Force chairperson Maxwell Nkole said President Sata needs the support of all Zambians in the fight against corruption. "We hope to see that the instruments of justice are restored back to original credibility. There should be no interference of the judiciary but ensuring that there is rule of law," he said. Mr Nkole said Zambians were anxious to see a vigorous campaign against corruption which had reduced during the MMD tenure. Former Attorney General Mumba Malila is hopeful that the PF under the leadership of President Sata will ensure all corrupt leaders should not be spared. "I hope the fight against corruption will go back to Levy's (Mwanawasa) time because recently we saw a reduction and reversal of the fight against corruption, such as the removal of the abuse of office clause from the constitution," he said. Mr Malila said there is need for the new government to put in place an appropriate legal framework. "The first thing should be to put in place the appropriate legal framework. Then the international conventions that we have signed such as the AU (African Union) convention and the UN (United Nations) convention against corruption should be domesticated," he said. In the political sphere, corruption impedes democracy and the rule of law. In a democratic system, public institutions and offices may lose their legitimacy when they misuse their power for private interest. Corruption may also result in negative consequences such as encoring cynicism and reducing interest of political participation, political instability, and reducing political competition, reducing the transparency of political decision making, distorting political development and sustaining political activity based on patronage, clientelism and money. The economic effects of corruption can be categorised as minor and major. However, both in one way or the other have serious impact on the individual community and country. First and foremost, corruption leads to the depletion of national wealth. "It is often responsible for increased costs of goods and services, the funnelling of scarce public resources to uneconomic high profile projects at the expense of the much needed projects such as schools, hospitals and roads, or the supply of potable water, diversion and misallocation of resources, conversion of public wealth to private and personal property, inflation, imbalanced economic development, weakling work ethics and professionalism, hindrance of the development of fair in market structures and unhealthy competition there by deterring competition. Large scale corruption hurts the economy and impoverishes entire population," reads a recent report on corruption. President Sata's prioritising of the fight against corruption therefore is a step in the right direction.

TITLE: Yaregal Aysheshum, Family Assets Frozen Over Allegation of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); ARRESTS (89%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); ETHICS (77%); AGREEMENTS (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTING (76%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (76%); CHILDREN (75%); BOARDING SCHOOLS (74%); EMBEZZLEMENT (72%); VOCATIONAL & TECHNICAL TRAINING (71%); RESTAURANTS (66%); TEACHER EDUCATION (64%) Ethiopia; Corruption
TEXT: Assets of Yaregar Aysehshume, MP and director general of the Federal Cooperative Agency, have been frozen by the Federal High Court on October 20, 2011 following a request from prosecutors of the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC). The assets were frozen on the same day as Yaregal was arrested on suspicion of corruption in the bidding procedures of the construction of three educational institutions which cost 83 million Br during his tenure as president of the Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State. Assets registered under Yaregal's wife, Tigist Bekal and his two children, who are minors, have also been frozen on the request of Beryehune Asegdom, public prosecuter of the Anti-Corruption Commission. The former Director General's house, built on 1,204sqm of land in Assosa, 675km from the capital, a 1,000sqm plot, both in Benishangul Region, and a 500sqm plot in Bole district, registered under his name have been frozen. A total of 4,132sqm plot in the region, a one storey house resting on 500sqm in Oromia Regional State, a 500sqm plot in Bole district and a condominium house, and restaurant all registered under his wife's name were also frozen. The court has additionally frozen a 1,490sqm plot in the region registered under one of Yaregal's child's names. Also under arrest for involvement in the corruption is Gezahgne Hadge, manager of Gad Construction and Habtamu Hica, former head of the region's Education Bureau and speaker of the house for the region's Parliament. Gezahgne was arrested only two days after Yaregal while Habtamu was arrested a while back. All of the men are suspected of corrupt involvement in the construction of Tana Beles, a boarding school for women; Gilgel Beles Teachers Training Collage as well Technical and Vocational Training centres that were planned to be constructed in five zones of the regional state six years ago. Investigators of the FEACC are claiming that proper bidding and procurement procedures were not followed. As a result, the project, which was supposed to have been finished in 13 months, is not yet completed. The Commission claims that this has resulted in a loss of seven million Birr in payments outside of the contract agreement. Gad Construction, established in 1993, was one of the contractors that allegedly awarded the project through an improper bidding process. Although the Commission received tips about the alleged embezzlement at the end of 2009, the investigation and evidence gathering took time, according to the Commission. The arrest of Yaregal and Habtamu was held back until Parliament had resumed session. Yaregal's immunity was revoked by the house on October 18, 2011, a week after Parliament was back in session. The investigation has yet to uncover the exact amount paid by contractors to Yaregal and Habtamu for their alleged undue advantage, according to the Commission.

TITLE: Corruption Trial of Health Permanent Secretary Underway
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); MAGISTRATES (90%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (88%); AIRPORTS (51%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: KAHIJORO Kahuure, the Permanent Secretary (PS) in the Ministry of Health and Social Services, maintains that he had authorisation to use the Government car over which he now faces graft charges. Kahuure's corruption trial in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court will continue on October 24. He made a first appearance on September 2 2009. Kahuure is charged with corruptly using his office or position for gratification. The alternative charge is that he used a vehicle without its owner's consent. According to the charge sheet, the alleged corruption took place between November 12 and 15 2008 on the road to the Hosea Kutako International Airport. Public Prosecutor Arrie Husselmann represented the State during the trial before Magistrate Helvi Shilemba.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Not Peddling 'Selective Justice' - Noa
SUBJECT: RELIGION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CORRUPTION (92%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); PROTESTANTS & PROTESTANTISM (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (66%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Religion
TEXT: ANTI-Corruption Commission (ACC) director Paulus Noa took issue with an allegation that the crime-fighting organisation is doing so selectively. Evangelical Lutheran Church in the Republic of Namibia (ELCRN) member Gerson Doseb said the ACC has opened a case against Pastor Japhet Sem and Eunice Nakapunda of the ELCRIN Macedonian parish, while it failed to investigate suspected fraud or theft at a number of church institutions which he, Doseb, had reported to the ACC and the Ombudsman's office in 2008. The ACC at the time responded that after a preliminary investigation, there was no evidence that constitutes an act of corruption in terms of the ACC Act. It said the matter does not fall under its mandate of investigation, and referred_ Doseb's allegations to the Namibian Police. Doseb claimed that some of the money implicated in the suspected fraud and theft he reported, was Government funding that went towards schools run by ELCRN, thus that there was sufficient reason why the ACC and the Office of the Ombudsman should do an investigation. "Why this selective justice?" questioned Doseb yesterday. He charged that two members of the Macedonia parish where Sem and Nakapunda were investigated for fraud and theft, are working at the ACC, and were responsible for the charges made against Sem and Nakapunda. "They abused their influence at the ACC," charged Doseb. "The ACC abused its position and State machinery to meddle in something that is not under their jurisdiction," said Do"seb, referring to the Sem and Nakapunda case now before the High Court. "If money is stolen from the church, it must go the same way as Pastor Sem," suggested Doseb. Noa said the cases cannot be compared because the alleged transactions are entirely different. In the case of Pastor Sem, he said, money was siphoned off from one account into another account, and some funds reportedly even went out of the country. Noa said Doseb had merely made an allegation of fraud and theft without any evidence, which the ACC referred to the police for investigation. "It does not mean that if money is stolen the ACC should investigate it," said Noa. "One must look at the circumstances of the allegations."

TITLE: Ex-Air Nam Employees Charged With Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); HOLDING COMPANIES (90%); AIR CHARTER SERVICES (90%); AIRLINES (90%); MAGISTRATES (89%); TRAVEL TICKETS (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (75%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (75%); LAWYERS (73%); BAIL (72%); ARRESTS (72%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (71%); PUBLIC RELATIONS (71%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Company News
TEXT: THREE and a half years after his sudden resignation from a senior post at Air Namibia, the national airline's former spokesperson, Ellison Hijarunguru, has now been charged with twenty counts of corruption. Hijarunguru and a former colleague, Anthony Alberts Rickerts, made a first appearance in the Windhoek Magistrate's Court on twenty charges under the Anti-Corruption Act on Friday. Hijarunguru (52) was Air Namibia's Public Relations and Corporate Communications Manager until his resignation in March 2008. He resigned a few days after he had been suspended from his post in the wake of allegations about irregularities with the use of flight tickets which the airline was supposedly exchanging for other services under barter agreements. Rickerts (42) worked as a sales representative at the airline. According to the Anti-Corruption Commission, which investigated the allegations that led to the court appearance of the two men, Hijarunguru and Rickerts are accused of having used their positions to obtain a gratification for their own benefit or that of another person. A barter agreement between Air Namibia and media group Democratic Media Holdings (DMH) is at the centre of the charges against the two men. At the time of Hijarunguru's resignation it was reported that allegations had surfaced about the abuse of barter agreements in terms of which the airline exchanged air tickets for free newspapers and advertisements. In a statement released on Friday, the ACC claimed the two men have been implicated in regard to allegations that they placed people who were not employees of DMH, which had a barter agreement with Air Namibia, or who were not affiliated with the company, on the barter agreement, while these people were not entitled to such a benefit. In the process, it is claimed, the two men pocketed a total of N$206 077 for themselves. Hijarunguru and Rickerts were arrested on Thursday last week after the Prosecutor General decided to charge them with 20 counts under the Anti-Corruption Act. With their appearance before Magistrate Ingrid Unengu on Friday, they were granted bail of N$10 000 each. Their case was transferred to the Windhoek Regional Court, where they have to appear on November 11. They have not yet been asked to plead to the charges. Hijarunguru and Rickerts were represented by defence lawyer Ray Rukoro, while Public Prosecutor Samantha Diergaardt appeared for the State, on Friday.

TITLE: Zuma's Anti-Corruption Blitz Gets Thumbs Up
CITY: CAPE TOWN, SOUTH AFRICA (92%); PRETORIA, SOUTH AFRICA (90%)
SUBJECT: POLITICAL PARTIES (90%); POLITICS (90%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CORRUPTION (86%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (78%); APPELLATE DECISIONS (78%); SUPREME COURTS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); POLICE FORCES (77%); CIVIL RIGHTS (74%); MISDEMEANORS (74%); HUMAN RIGHTS ORGANIZATIONS (73%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (72%); LEASE AGREEMENTS (69%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (66%); JUDGES (66%); LABOR UNIONS (60%); INFRASTRUCTURE (57%); APPEALS COURTS (51%) South Africa; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: CAPE TOWN - Political parties have welcomed President Jacob Zuma's decision to axe Cabinet members Gwen Mahlangu-Nkabinde and Sicelo Shiceka. Democratic Alliance leader Helen Zille also applauded Zuma's announcement that national police commissioner General Bheki Cele was suspended with immediate effect. "This announcement is better late than never," she said in a statement. Zuma announced earlier in Pretoria that Mahlangu-Nkabinde would be replaced as public works minister, and Shiceka as co-operative governance and traditional affairs minister. Zille said Zuma's government had been beset by controversy for several months. Public Protector Thuli Madonsela urged Zuma to take strong action against those involved in the SA Police Service lease deals, as well as Shiceka for his abuse of public money. Zille lauded Zuma "for reaffirming his government's commitment to the role of the public protector and other Chapter Nine institutions". The ANC said the Cabinet reshuffle would contribute significantly to strengthening government performance and capacity. "In this regard, the ANC would [like] to praise and equally endorse the president's action and decisiveness," spokesperson Jackson Mthembu said in a statement. The ANC also welcomed Zuma's announcement that Supreme Court of Appeal Judge Willie Seriti would head the new commission of inquiry into the arms deal. African Christian Democratic Party leader Kenneth Meshoe said action against the two ministers was long overdue. "What we still want to see happen is Mr Shiceka paying back the taxpayers' money he wasted on his alleged visit to his imprisoned girlfriend in Switzerland," he said. Freedom Front Plus spokesperson Pieter Groenewald also welcomed Zuma's announcements, as did the Council for the Advancement of the South African Constitution (Casac). "We believe that the president has acted appropriately in responding to the reports of the public protector regarding the misdemeanours by these two former ministers," Casac said in a statement. Casac welcomed Cele's immediate suspension and the appointment of a board of inquiry to investigate his role in the SAPS leases. The Congress of SA Trade Unions said it hoped the announcement marked a turning point in the fight against maladministration and corruption. "From now on there must be a policy of zero-tolerance to the looting of public resources by anyone, in the public or private sector, no matter how senior their position," the trade union federation said in a statement. Civil rights group AfriForum said Zuma's decision sent a strong and essential message regarding the accountability and responsibility of people in positions of power. - Nampa-Sapa

TITLE: Police to Stamp Out Corruption [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLICE FORCES (91%); FINES & PENALTIES (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (89%); BRIBERY (78%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (78%); EXTORTION (73%); WAGES & SALARIES (71%); APPROVALS (68%) Zambia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: THE police command deserves commendation for acting swiftly to stamp out corruption in the traffic section of the Zambia Police Service by banning on-the-spot fines imposed on erring motorists at police roadblocks. Many of the sordid cases of corruption that have sullied the image of the whole police service emanate from this wing because the bulk of traffic officers are now associated with numerous cases of impropriety. It would be an under-statement to state that traffic officers had become shameless extortionists. Many have been caught red-handed soliciting for bribes and harassing their victims at every opportunity, and all this happened under the noses of senior police officers who elected to do nothing to stop the rot. The net import of this inaction is that the vice spread quickly within the service, and an impression was created that corruption among police officers, particularly those in the traffic wing, had the tacit approval of the police command. Police Inspector-General Martin Malama has sent the right message by taking timely action, soon after assumption of office, by banning on-spot fines by traffic officers who will now be required to issue tickets to offending motorists so that they could make payments at police stations. It is indisputable that the bulk of the cash collected by police in fines was never properly accounted for but ended up in the pockets of corrupt officers. There are no more grounds now for police officers to bemoan low salaries and lack of motivation as the reasons for engaging in corrupt practices. To begin with, there is no justification anywhere and at any time, for any person to commit an offence. But more importantly is the fact that under the new government, the police service has everything to look forward to. President Sata has already demonstrated his commitment to improve conditions in the police service through rationalisation of salaries. He has further motivated the service by widening the ranking structure in the service with the creation of eleven positions for commissioners of police from two positions and six of the new police commissioners are female. These changes have opened up avenues for every serving officer both male and female to aspire to senior positions in the service. This will in turn open up the subsidiary ranks so that those in the lower ranks of the service also move up to fill senior ranks as they are promoted. This is the motivation that should spur the police service to even greater efforts to attain higher heights in the fight against corruption and criminal activity where ever it is found in Zambia.

TITLE: Lebanon Backs Govt's Corruption Fight Stance
COUNTRY: ZAMBIA (95%); LEBANON (94%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); POLICE FORCES (71%); COPPER INDUSTRY (69%); ARRESTS (69%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: HONORARY counsellor of Lebanon in Zambia, Hussein Safieddine has said his government supports President Michael Sata's stance on fighting corruption and that Lebanese in the country engaging in corrupt practices would not have his support. Mr Safieddine said corruption should be discouraged and fought vigorously because it encouraged poverty. "As a community of Lebanese nationals settled in Zambia, we wish to come up in full support of the Government's fight against corruption, which is an unacceptable vice retrogressive to the economic development of a country," he said. Police in Ndola on Wednesday recovered 28 tonnes of copper cathodes worth K1.1 billion stolen from a truck which was in transit from the Democratic Republic of Congo to Tanzania and 14 people, among them four Lebanese, were arrested in connection with the theft. He said his office would not condone any Lebanese national involved in criminal or illegal activities in Zambia. Mr Safieddine said such people were ungrateful to the hospitality shown by the Zambian people and that the law should deal with them. He, however, said the majority of the Lebanese community consisted of law-abiding citizens and would support the Government to ensure prosperity for all.

TITLE: Corruption Claims Surface At Polytechnic
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (89%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (89%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (75%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: THE Polytechnic of Namibia on Friday had to put out fires after a 'suspended' employee implicated senior staff in allegations of corruption and unethical behaviour. Joseph Madhimba, head of department (HOD) for business management, accused the institution's registrar, Corneels Jafta, of, amongst others, "very poor communication skills and is arrogant, foul-mouthed and provocative". Furthermore, Madhimba charged, Jafta "has no respect for other academics and does not listen to others". In a letter of complaint to the Deputy Minister of Education, David Namwandi, Madhimba charged that after 19 of 33 students did not qualify for the International Marketing examination, he was summoned to Jafta's office to explain. A copy of the letter is in the possession of The Namibian. During this meeting with Jafta, Madhimba alleges, the registrar wanted to know why two students, Linda Antonio and Ester Kakonge, had not made the cut. "I told him [they did not qualify] because they performed poorly. I also asked him whether these two were supposed to pass even if they failed." According to Madhimba, "a heated argument then followed in which the registrar insulted me using some language which is better not put down on paper. I recorded what he was saying on my portable tape recorder. I said to him he should not insult me. He said: 'Of course, I am insulting you and what can you do to me?'." Madhimba says this is "intimidation as if he was daring me to a physical fight". The now 'suspended' HOD claims Jafta "ordered me to change the marks so that more students could qualify, including Antonio and Kakonge" - something which he says he refused to do. "I told Mr Jafta that I don't want to be involved in corruption and so I refused to change the marks, because this would be unfair to the other students, who, through their own efforts, had qualified for the examination." As a result of the drama surrounding the subject, Jafta subsequently postponed the examination to November 18. This reportedly has some students fuming. Another reason why he refused to adjust marks, Madhimba says, was because "I think we should not lower standards and compromise quality by changing marks given by a lecturer simply because some students perceive others were favoured". Madhimba has also accused his dean, Kofi Boamah, of being in cahoots with Jafta. Another allegation which Madhimba has levelled against Jafta is that the registrar allegedly instructed him to allow "into a degree programme, the son of his friend who did not have the prerequisite diploma". Because he allegedly did not comply with the entry requirements, "the student is now struggling", Madhimba charges. "The problem with Mr Jafta is that he claims to be professional, but then he breaks the Poly regulations and policies when it suits him. That is a recipe for disaster in this institution of higher learning." He asked Namwandi "to intervene to stop the rot at the Poly, especially intimidation, interference with lecturers' marks and other forms of corruption". Last year, Jafta also came under fire for allegedly helping his daughter get into a course for which she was not qualified. In a written response to the newspaper's questions, Polytechnic spokesperson Donovan Weimers on Friday said that Madhimba's "allegations come in the wake of his suspension and the filing of disciplinary charges against him on Thursday, November 3 2011". Weimers said that in terms of the institution's communication policy, "disciplinary procedures instituted against, or grievances lodged by, individual staff members are sub judice. We are therefore not at liberty to comment on Mr Madhimba's allegations regarding the reasons for his suspension". Unless The Namibian clarifies its sources about the corruption and intimidation claims, "it is not the Polytechnic's policy to respond to hearsay and thus we have no comment on these allegations", Weimers said.

TITLE: Region Protocol Against Corruption Idles
COUNTRY: NAMIBIA (94%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (94%); AFRICA (94%); MALAWI (92%) Southern Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INTERNATIONAL LAW (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (75%); RULE OF LAW (74%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (73%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (73%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (60%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: The ninth Southern African Forum Against Corruption (Safac) Annual General Meeting (AGM) which started in Windhoek yesterday made an urgent call on SADC members to implement the SADC Protocol Against Corruption. Safac chair Dr Edward Hoseah blamed the non-functioning SADC Committee on Corruption (SACC) for the delay in the implementation of the protocol at the opening of the event. "The Southern African Development Community (SADC) Protocol Against Corruption and its implementation is our litmus test for effective measures in our region. The willingness of our political masters to heighten and fast-track the implementation of the SADC Protocol is extremely fundamental to manage our citizens' expectations," he stressed. The Heads of State and Government signed the protocol in Blantyre, Malawi in the year 2001. However, Hoseah expressed his concern about the protocol, which was adopted before the African Union (AU) Convention on Preventing and Combating of Corruption, as well as the United Nations' Convention Against Corruption in 2003, respectively. According to him, the fundamental question that each SADC member has to answer is to what extent have they ratified and put in place not only the legal framework for its implementation, but also the strategic interventions that address the daunting challenges that corruption imposes on the economic, political and social realities. Hoseah emphasised that political will is the ability of the executive arm of a government to confront corruption without compromises. "It is the commitment of the entire leadership to restore integrity and promote transparency and accountability, where democratic principles and rule of law are respected and given prominence in the day-to-day functioning of the government," he added. Meanwhile, Namibia's Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) Director Paulus Noa said that SADC needs to accelerate the implementation of developmental programmes, noting that this is only guaranteed when oversight institutions are well co-ordinated, strengthened and adequately funded. With the advent of regional, continental and international legal instruments on the prevention and fight against corruption, the question is no longer merely about investigation and prosecution of the culprits. Noa said it is also more about regional and international co-operation, aimed at mutual legal assistance for purposes of confiscation and recovery of stolen assets or proceeds of crime, wherever they are found.

TITLE: Report Corruption Cases, Watchdog Urges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); INTERVIEWS (90%); POLLS & SURVEYS (76%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (75%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (70%); POLICE FORCES (68%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (66%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (64%) Rwanda; Corruption; NGOs and Civil Society
TEXT: The Executive Secretary of Transparency Rwanda (TR), Apollinaire Mupiganyi, has called for a change in mindset in the fight against all forms of corruption in the country. In an interview with The New Times yesterday, Mupiganyi said that Rwanda is generally on the right track in the fight against the vice. He however noted that people's mindsets are still bent on keeping cases of corruption under wrap which remains a stumbling block. "Our survey established full political will from all government institutions; however, we realised that over 50 percent of the population don't report cases of corruption and this is a serious issue which needs an urgent solution," Mupiganyi. He said that mindsets can be changed through public awareness campaigns, encouraging them to always report such cases to concerned authorities. Rwanda was recently ranked the fourth least corrupt African country by the World Bank Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project. The country scored 70.8 percent, the fourth highest score, behind Mauritius with 73.2 percent, Cape Verde with 74.6 percent and Botswana, the least corrupt with 79.9 percent. Mupiganyi noted that if all Rwandans take part in reporting cases of graft, the dream of achieving zero corruption, would be achieved, which he said, would translate into rapid development. The TR survey indicated that corruption was most prevalent in local government authorities and other institutions like the National Police, especially the traffic department. Speaking to The New Times, the acting Ombudsman, Augustin Nzindukiyimana, said that his office had set up anti-corruption committees at the district and other local levels, to fight the vice. He however said that there was need for civil society organisations to actively participate in fighting against corruption. "The war against corruption is cross-cutting and a continuous process, which needs every citizen's participation," he observed.

TITLE: Stop ZRA Corruption, Ex- State House Aide Urges Govt
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (88%); TAXES & TAXATION (87%); INVESTIGATIONS (72%); TAX EXEMPTIONS (70%); TAX LAW (70%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: FORMER State House economic adviser Donald Chanda has said the Government should ensure that it gets rid of the perceived corruption at Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) for the institution to deliver to the expectations of the country. Appearing before the Kingsley Chanda-led commission of inquiry on ZRA, Dr Chanda said it was important for the Government to work with ZRA to stop any corrupt practices and instill confidence in tax payers. Dr Chanda also urged Government not to concession borders but instead work with ZRA to make some borders multi-facility economic zones. He said the Government should also avoid some tax exemptions as they might be injurious to ZRA. Dr Chanda, who is a University of Zambia lecturer in development studies, said the Government should broaden the tax base to collect more revenue. "There is need to continue building capacity for ZRA to collect more revenue," he said. He said there should be no delays in revenue collection and that the public should be educated on the role of ZRA and the tax they pay. Dr Chanda said Zambians wanted to see how their money was being used and urged the Government to assist them in that area. He said the Government should also improve conditions of service for ZRA officers.

TITLE: Tikonko Community Embraces Anti-Corruption Commission's Fight Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (90%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (89%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (86%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (72%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (70%); INDICTMENTS (69%); RURAL DEVELOPMENT (67%); STRATEGIC PLANNING (63%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (60%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Governance
TEXT: The Southern Regional Office of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) has on Wednesday 26th October 2011 admonished all stakeholders including school going children in the Tikonko community to desist from corrupt practices and promote good governance. Welcoming the team from the ACC and giving an overview of what he views about the work of the Anti-Corruption Commission, the Chiefdom Speaker Mr. George S. Murray pledged support to the course of fighting graft in his community and implored everyone in their midst to join the fight. Mr. Murray gave some scenarios of existence of corruption and corrupt practices and stressed the need for community stakeholders to be accountable in their service delivery activities for the general good of the nation. Giving an overview of the meeting and also updating his audience on the current activities undertaken by the commission, the Public Education Officer South, Mr. Wilfred Bangura, said that the Anti-Corruption Commission was at Tikonko village because they alone cannot fight corruption in the country. He called on all present to partner with the Commission as that will demonstrate a mark of patriotism. Mr. Bangura explained the three-pronged approach used by the Commission in the fight against graft. According to him, this exercise presents the friendly face of the commission. The ACC also prides itself in fixing institutions where loop holes are bound to occur in service delivery. If both prevention and public education interventions fail, then the last resort will be confrontation which means individuals who perpetrate corrupt practices will be investigated, prosecuted and convicted in a competent court of law. Mr. Bangura further told participants about the Commission's strategic plan (2011-2013) recently presented by the Commissioner of the ACC, Mr. Joseph Fitzgerald Kamara to H.E the President, Dr Ernest Bai Koroma. He also briefed participants of the commission's recent indictments and pointed out clearly that the Commission is not just there to arrest and convict corrupt individuals but also to sensitise the public on the ills of corruption. Participants were then informed about the various ways of making reports to the ACC and assured them of the commission's fullest protection of informers. Dilating on the causes and effects of corruption particularly in rural communities, the Regional manager south, Mr. Mohamed Dumbuya, underscored that corruption is prevalent in rural communities_ because of greed and selfishness. He opined that poverty is one of the root causes of   corruption. Manager Dumbuya made mention of the negative effects of corruption which he said undermines the development of Sierra Leone, affects human rights, hurts the poor,  brings about war and diseases to name but a few. He encouraged the people of Tikonko to be very mindful of development initiatives carried out in their chiefdom and informed participants that rural development is not an exclusive favour from Non Governmental Organisations (NGOs) or kind gesture delivered to beneficiaries in communities but a complementary role of government through funds received on their behalf by development partners locally and internationally. Speaking on the theme 'Community Mobilization in the Fight against Corruption', the ACC Bo District Coordinator, Mr. Anthony B. Samu said Tikonko Chiefdom should by all means humanly possible join the ACC in the fight against graft. Mr. Samu reiterated the fact that, Local and International NGOs source funding in the name of communities for their development projects; so it should be the business of communities to watch closely how these projects are implemented by these NGOs. He encouraged participants to be proactive in asking salient questions regarding the implementation of programmes and should be involved in the monitoring and evaluation process to enhance quality standards. He told participants that the doors of the commission are always open for such complaints and that there are no sacred cows in the fight against corruption. Highlighting the major offences in the Anti-Corruption Act 2008, Mr. Thomas T. Rogers of the Intelligence, Investigation and Prosecution Department (IIP), explained in precise terms the core offences in the Act that touch individuals in public life on daily basis. Mr. Rogers took a clinical look at these offences and admonished all participants to be mindful of the corresponding penalties associated with them. A minimum of Thirty million Leones or three years imprisonment or both fines and imprisonment will be levied in court against corruption offenders for each of those counts. He therefore implored the people of Tikonko to be free from corruption and should report acts of corruption to the ACC. Questions and answers, distribution of IEC materials and a vote of thanks given by Mary Mattia climaxed the meeting.

TITLE: Culprits of Corruption Will Face Law - Lubinda
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); APPOINTMENTS (89%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (78%); GOVERNMENT TOURIST OFFICES (78%); EXECUTIVES (77%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: INFORMATION, Broadcasting and Tourism Minister Given Lubinda has said people who will be found wanting on corruption in the ongoing investigations would face the wrath of law. And Mr Lubinda has said the appointment of the late former President Frederick Chiluba's spokesperson Emmanuel Mwamba demonstrates that President Michael Sata had embraced even people he considered as foes. Speaking on the Radio Phoenix Friday edition of the programme 'Let the people talk', Mr Lubinda said the Patriotic Front (PF) Government would review the current corruption laws to ensure that they are strengthened. Mr Lubinda said the Government would also soon be reviewing the decision by the previous MMD government to remove section 37 from the Anti Corruption Act. He said the PF Government would lead by example by ensuring that leaders live above board and remain transparent and accountable to the Zambian people. Mr Lubinda who is also chief Government spokesperson said all the Cabinet ministers had made declarations of what they owned. "Everyone has made declarations, we were given 30 days from the day of appointment to make the declarations," he said. Mr Lubinda, however, said there was need to strengthen the laws on declarations so that they are not just fictitious. He said the PF Government was determined to make governance transparent. The minister said there was need to ensure that procurement decisions in Government departments were not made by individuals but groups of people to ensure checks and balances. He said those that would find themselves on the other side of the law in the ongoing investigations would be prosecuted. The minister also said that the media should play a critical role in the fight against corruption by ensuring that they ask critical questions and not just be "vuvuzelas" to sing praises for the Government. He said society should also shame people who are corrupt. "Do not hero worship corrupt individuals, it is not like we do not know the people who are corrupt," he said. And during the same programme Mr Lubinda said the appointment of Mr Mwamba as permanent secretary for the Northern Province demonstrates that he could appoint even people who condemned and worked against the PF. Mr Lubinda also refutes insinuations that President Sata had only appointed people from one region. Transparency International Zambia (TIZ) president Reuben Lifuka, however, was against the appointment of Mr Mwamba as Northern Province Permanent Secretary. SACCORD executive director Lee Habasonda said the President should avoid making appointments that sent wrong signals.vMeanwhile Mr Lubinda has said the media should proceed and launch the Zambia Independent Media Council (ZAMEC) so that they can regulate themselves.

TITLE: ACC Presents New National Anti- Corruption Strategy (2011-2013)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (71%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Governance
TEXT: The Anti- Corruption Commission (ACC) yesterday presented the Revised National Anti- Corruption Strategy for 2011-2013 before a cross section of government functionaries at the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MoFED) main conference hall in Freetown. Chairperson of the programme, Lavina Banduah, said it is the duty of all Sierra Leoneans to fight against corruption, describing corruption as a menace to the progress of development adding that: "We want to see that the society is free from all forms of corruption as the public is doing all what it takes to fight against corruption." Commissioner of the Anti- Corruption Commission Joseph Fitzgerald Kamara said the purpose of the revised strategy was to determine a midterm review of the fight against corruption. He noted that the commission was set up in 2000 to address cases of corrupt practices and most cases that were filed in court but not well adhered to. He said the commission is grateful to the president and the parliament for their support in helping to prosecute cases of corruption. The commission has engaged in meetings with NGOs and young people in schools to be effective and engage clean hard work, he said. We need to create a national task force against corruption that will also help man affairs against corruption though we have engaged more than a thousand community based organizations. "The commission is grateful to the UNDP for their tireless assistance and we want to extend our gratitude for the good work they have been doing," he said. Director of NACS, Nabilahi Kamara, who did the presentation, said the NCSA is Sierra Leone's roadmap in the fight against corruption and its approach to building strong public and private sector.

TITLE: Corruption Fight - Just How Much Political Commitment Is Required?
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); POLITICS (78%); POOR POPULATION (77%); WEALTH MANAGEMENT (77%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (67%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (60%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (57%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: CORRUPTION should be fought because it frustrates every genuine effort and robs the nationals of their privileges. Does every politician agree that the fight against corruption should be non-selective and ruthless especially in a county like Zambia where poverty levels remain high? There are many ways of getting wealth in this world but certainly not through dubious means. Many Zambians today have fought hard to acquire their wealth through hard work and endurance to invest prudently. This is a means that should be admired and adored. The other means of getting wealth can be through inheritance of family estates. Although this could be deemed a benefit from a misfortune, there is morally nothing wrong with it as long as one manages to run the fortune prudently. Such is life as death is inevitable. Sadly some people are thriving on corruption to enrich themselves. These are people that feel that it's not necessary to work hard. Corruption is a menace and should never be tolerated. Be it at among politicians, faith leaders and civil society organisations, the vice is totally wrong and detrimental to society. Zambia is a victim of this corruption in so many ways. It is the hope of all well meaning individuals that this vice should always be fought. But is the nation seeing this willingness from everyone? This fight should not be for those in government alone. It should not be looked at as a fight between President Michael Sata and others or maybe the Transparency International Zambia (TIZ) versus others. It should be a natural responsibility that each Zambian volunteers to carry and show the rest of the world that wealth creation comes through hard work and not disadvantaging other natives through corruption. President Michael Sata has launched a gruesome anti corruption crusade. There are several people in Zambia that benefited either directly or indirectly from corrupt activities. These people may not be happy with maneuvers by the President to sweep the country clean of corruption. They will protest in so many ways. Their protests may take days, months or years but every Zambian's prayer is that such protests should not succeed. What is required is to ensure that the fight against corruption is amplified by all. The zeal from the civil society should be massive and clear. Leaving this fight to law enforcement agencies can not be enough. It is indeed a complex fight that should be tackled ruthlessly but lawfully to the conclusive end. Just like the late President Levy Mwanawasa lost friends, relatives and indeed political allies over his corruption fight, Mr Sata should equally not relent. Criminals are tactful and deceitful. They may befriend authorities just to blind them. This is the time to look out for such wrong people who would always want to claim innocence when actually their rightful tag is criminal. Just upon being sworn-in as Zambia's 5th republican President Mr Sata made a commitment to the world that he would fight corruption as a means of ensuring lives of Zambians are promoted and secured from poverty. He declared that 'I'm allergic to corruption' and that he would not sit idle and watch such vices go on. The phenomenon of being allergic to corruption should not only be with the President but in all Zambians. The poverty Zambia faces today is to a larger extent because of corruption. As an immediate measure to curb this vice, Mr Sata said he would strengthen anti-corruption laws by putting back on the books the offence of abuse of office, which the previous government had removed. "We will investigate acts of corruption by the previous government. Our country needs a new beginning. "If found wanting, you will be prosecuted regardless of your status. I want to sound a timely warning that this government has taken a zero stance to corruption," he said. It still remains unclear as to why the abuse of office clause was scrapped by the previous government So far Mr Sata has won support of various international and local stakeholders over his stance on corruption. He has said what people want to hear and he so far seems committed to it. Even bilateral partners such as Britain, Germany, China and many more openly came out in support of his stance. This is a key step in the governance system of the country and it is only the political will that can get the other sectors of the economy to respond to such a well intended crusade. British High Commissioner to Zambia Tom Carter believes that Britain has always been willing to render assistance to Zambian in the fight against corruption and improvement of the governance system. Even with the PF government, the British Government has committed itself to assist in curbing corruption. According to Mr Carter corruption derails national development and that meaningful sustainable development can be achieved if it is wiped out. Not long ago, some European Community members including Britain backed the fight against corruption during the late Dr Mwanawasa's reign. This even saw the formation of the Task Force against Corruption whose headquarters was in Lusaka. The taskforce composed of skilled men and women from the Drug Enforcement Commission, the Anti Corruption Commission, and the Zambia Police Service. Others were lawyers like Mutembo Nchito and Nchima Nchito who were equally engaged to ensure that the crusade bore fruits. Sadly, and regrettably this effort didn't yield much as the task force was disbanded shortly after the death of Dr Mwanawasa in 2008. But are Zambians going to see a similar splendid fight against corruption this time around? This is everyone's wish. The reinvigorated fight against corruption under the PF government will capitalise on the past experiences. Fortunately people like former Task Force chairperson Maxwell Nkole are still around and now holding senior government positions as Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Home Affairs. Definitely, the latest teams of investigators into allegations of corruption know where the previous crop went strong. They will now have the capacity to compare and improve upon such ineptitude. The investigators will also take advantage of the reports to come from the many commissions of inquiry set by the President Sata. Mr Sata has appointed a commission to investigate operations at the Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA), Zamtel, and another commission to investigate transactions at the Zambia National Building Society (ZNBS). The president has also request for a report on the reversed sale of Finance Bank to foreign bank where he suspected fraud and corruption to have marred the whole transaction. So far, just from the few directives that Mr Sata has made the work of the investigators would be made easier. Naturally, the fight against corruption has received mass criticism from some sectors of society The Alliance for Development and Democracy (ADD) has supported Mr Michael Sata's commitment to fighting corruption saying it will help improve the living standards of Zambians. The ADD president Charles Milupi said his party campaigned on the basis of eradicating corruption in Zambia and would still support any such efforts even if it is not in government.
