What is puzzling is the amount of criticism coming from some opposition political parties over the corruption crusade but without offering tangible, substantiated or corresponding counter claims to their positions. Realistically it should not matter who or which party is in government for a country to effectively curb corruption. The spirit should be that of unity of purpose, aimed at attaining one simple goal of improving Zambia's governance system through prudent means of acquiring opportunities for all deserving citizens. If there are critical issues that the other stakeholders have against the PF government, there is still room to open dialogue and just present such concerns formally. Mr Sata appears willing to listen to advice that is well meaning. Criticism is important in a democracy and should be encouraged. However constructive criticism is most preferred and people should not be scared to criticise or air their views on issues they are not happy with. For now its time to build consensus in this corruption fight.

TITLE: 'Corruption Making Business Costly'
SUBJECT: MINES & MINING (91%); CORRUPTION (89%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (89%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); COPPER MINING (78%); TRADE DEVELOPMENT (77%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (76%); LIVING STANDARDS (75%); CHAMBERS OF COMMERCE (73%); HOTELS & MOTELS (56%) Zambia; Corruption; Mining
TEXT: THE government will not tolerate corruption in the mining and other business sectors because the vice is making the cost of doing business high in the country. Commerce, Trade and Industry Bob Sichinga said there was need to stamp out corruption in the mining industry if the country was to develop on a sustainable basis. The minister was speaking when he addressed the Copperbelt business community at Moba Hotel in Kitwe yesterday. "We will not entertain corruption in the mining industry, especially that mining is the mainstay of the country's economy. Corruption in the mining industry is further adding to the cost of doing business," Mr Sichinga said. The Minister said the Government recently engaged Mopani Copper Mines (MCM) officials who complained that a number of suppliers were conniving with its employees to over-invoice goods or services. He said the mine had argued that local suppliers were not adding value to their products. He therefore challenged the Mine Suppliers and contractors Association (MSCAZ) to ensure that corruption was eliminated among its membership. And Mr Sichinga was saddened that the 7.6 Growth Domestic Product (GDP) was not flowing to the Zambian citizens. He said benefits must flow not only to the top mining companies but to ordinary Zambians. Mr Sichinga said the Government was working hard to ensure that the cost of doing business was reduced and standards of living improved. He said the Government was seeking partnership with Austrian Investors who had put together a total of 1.5 billion Austrian dollars which would be committed to various infrastructure among them the road network. Speaking earlier Kitwe District Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KDCCI) chairperson Raj Karamuchand said the business sector was adversely affected by corruption, which he said was contributing to increased costs of doing business. He urged the Government to strengthen the institutions fighting corruption on its behalf. "A businessman's cost are increased by having to pay corruption officials in order to survive," Mr Karamuchand said.

TITLE: Local Court Magistrate Denies Corruption Charge
SUBJECT: MAGISTRATES (97%); CORRUPTION (92%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (90%); CRIMINAL LAW (78%); SENTENCING (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); ARRESTS (78%); JAIL SENTENCING (73%); LARCENY & THEFT (72%) Zambia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A SENIOR Local Court magistrate yesterday pleaded not guilty to allegations of corrupt practices in a Kitwe magistrate's court. Joyce Chikolwa, 38, of 109 Kantanta Street, Nkana East, is charged with one count of corrupt practices by a public officer contrary to sections 19(1) and 40 of the Anti-Corruption Act number 38 of 2010. Particulars of the offence are that on October 4 this year, Chikolwa, being a Local Court magistrate, did corruptly solicit for and received K1, 500,000 cash from Alice Chisembele. It was alleged that Chikolwa received the money as an inducement or reward to review the judgment in a Local Court case between John Chisembele and Catherine Nakamba, a matter of transaction that concerned the Local Court, a public body. Chikolwa denied the charge before Principal Resident Magistrate Penjani Lamba where she took a fresh plea. She earlier appeared before Magistrate Densen Muchamba who, however, recused himself from handling the matter. The matter comes up on December 20 and January 16 for mention while trial has been set for February 6 next year. Meanwhile, a Mansa-based Zambia Postal Services (Zampost) employee has been jailed for three years with hard labour after being convicted of theft by public servant, reports ZANIS. Magistrate Patson Chiluba sentenced Davison Mwange, 44, of house number 48 area 16 in Spark Compound in Mansa Magistrate Court yesterday. Mwange, who worked as area cashier for Zampost, was between January 26 and March 31 this year involved in stealing company money amounting to more than K132 million, property of Zampost. According to the judgment, the act was contrary to Section 277 of the penal code chapter 87 of the laws of Zambia. Mwange was arrested on April 4, 2011 and judgement was delivered yesterday.

TITLE: Corruption Conviction Rate Disappointing
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (88%); PUBLIC POLICY (77%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (69%); WRITERS (68%); PUBLIC SCHOOLS (64%); ACQUITTAL (62%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) says it is faced with a lack of funds to execute its mandate of fighting corruption effectively. ACC director Paulus Noa said this yesterday when speaking at the launch of the Institute of Policy Research (IPPR) anti-corruption research programme title 'The ACC in Action: What Does The Track Record Say?' The research reviewed the work of the graft fighting body over the past five years since its establishment. IPPR urged the ACC do more to fulfil its mandate in terms of preventing corruption and educating the public on corruption according to the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR). Noa said investigating corruption as a crime is very different from murder or rape, as corruption leaves very little evidence, if any, behind for investigators. He also said that individuals cannot be convicted just on the basis of newspaper reports, adding that corruption cases are often the most difficult to investigate. In terms of the ACC's record, from 2006/2007 to 2008/2009 the ACC received 2 514 reports of alleged corrupt practices of which 268 were pursuable according to the IPPR. This means that approximately 10 per cent of total reports received were pursuable. Ellison Tjirera, one of the authors of the latest IPPR report, said that this was an indication that a large portion of the public was not educated on what constitutes corrupt practices, and as a result bring frivolous reports to the ACC. To this end the IPPR have recommended that the ACC expand its public education efforts country wide to improve public knowledge on what constitutes corrupt practices. From 2006 to 2010, the ACC submitted 262 cases to the Prosecutor General for prosecution, however only 38 have resulted in successful convictions. Over the same period of time there have been 15 acquittals, and the Prosecutor General has declined to prosecute in 36 cases. More than half (151) of the cases submitted to the Prosecutor General are in court awaiting trial, and the IPPR regards this as evidence of an inefficient court system in Namibia. IPPR director Graham Hopwood said that data and indicators on the fight against corruption have been reviewed in the research paper and that the IPPR had also made some recommendations to the ACC to enhance its credibility and gain public support. Hopwood said that early impressions and beliefs were that the ACC would be effective in fighting corruption, noting that many similar institutions enjoy a "honeymoon period" in terms of public perception but that there was a tendency for this to fall away over time. The IPPR recommended that the ACC fast tracks the setting up of its directorate of Corruption Prevention "which would be dedicated to researching systems practices and procedures that will best enable Namibia to reduce corruption". It is also recommended that the ACC 'name and shame' those prosecuted and convicted of corrupt practices.

TITLE: Shun Corruption, Dr Sezibera Urges
COUNTRY: RWANDA (94%); EASTERN AFRICA (94%); BURUNDI (93%); UGANDA (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); KENYA (92%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (89%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); BRIBERY (73%); TARIFFS & DUTIES (69%); RANKINGS (69%); NONTARIFF BARRIERS (53%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The East African Community (EAC) Secretary General, Dr Richard Sezibera, has cautioned regional member states over persistent corruption cases, saying that unless much effort is exerted in purging the vice, the region will remain underdeveloped. In interview with reporters from the region held yesterday in Bujumbura, Burundi, Sezibera said fighting corruption should not be left to government officials only but citizens should also play a part. "Corruption is a problem. Fighting corruption is much more than laws and all these agencies and institutions. It should be a culture people must say no to," he said. The latest East African Bribery Index 2011 ranked Burundi as the most corrupt nation with a score 37.9 percent, both Uganda and Tanzania stood at 33.9 percent, and Kenya recorded a slight improvement at 28.8 percent, down from 31.9 percent in 2010. while Rwanda scored 5.1 percent, down from 6.6 percent last year. Rwandan traders recently complained of rampant corruption and non tariff barriers in other EAC member states, which they believe, has not only affected their businesses, but also dogged regional integration. In 2007, the East Africa Association of the Anti corruption Authority (EAAACA) was formed to promote the spirit of zero tolerance on corruption and encourage regional cooperation in preventing and combating the vice, but its efforts are yet to bear fruit. According to traders, due to graft, larger competitors from Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania are able to sell their products in Rwanda at lower prices, despite associated transport costs as they enjoy the benefits of economies of scale on top of incurring lower production costs. "You cannot develop a country with corruption...it's something we need to fight as regional citizens for the benefit of our community," Sezibera noted. He further tipped regional media practitioners on the essence of collaboration with civil societies and other stakeholders to highlight the most corrupt officials as a means of fighting graft.

TITLE: Corruption Laws Under Attack
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (91%); CRIME PREVENTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); LAWYERS (78%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Act, the Prevention of Organised Crime Act, and the dual appointment of Pendukeni Iivula-Ithana as Justice Minister and Attorney General in 2005 all came under attack in the High Court in Windhoek yesterday. In a case heard by a full bench of the High Court, fraud and money-laundering suspects Teckla Lameck and Kongo Mokaxwa want the court to declare Iivula-Ithana's dual appointment as contrary to the Constitution, to declare that the Prevention of Organised Crime Act did not legally come into operation on May 5 2009, and to declare key sections of that law and the Anti-Corruption Act unconstitutional. If Lameck and Mokaxwa succeed with the case, it will have a far-reaching effect on two of the main legal weapons in Namibia's arsenal for the fight against corruption and organised crime. Judges Elton Hoff and Dave Smuts and Acting Judge Kobus Miller, who heard the case, reserved judgement after hearing arguments from senior counsel Jeremy Gauntlett, representing Lameck and Mokaxwa, and Wim Trengove, the senior counsel representing the President, the Minister of Justice, the Attorney General, the Prosecutor General and the Director of the Anti-Corruption Commission. Gauntlett argued that the Constitution, which provides for the appointment of an Attorney General whose functions include being the principal legal advisor to the President and Government, expressly contemplates a dedicated government legal advisor. The appointment of the same person as both Attorney General and Justice Minister weakens the separate offices and the capacity to perform the offices' different roles under the Constitution, he argued. Because - according to this argument - Iivula-Ithana cannot hold both posts in terms of the Constitution, she could also not have issued the Government Notice in which May 5 2009 was set as the date on which POCA came into operation, Gauntlett argued. If that is accepted, POCA has never legally come into operation. Trengove argued that there is nothing in the Constitution to indicate that it is not permissible for the Attorney General to also be a member of the Cabinet, or that a person cannot at the same time serve as Attorney General and as a minister holding another portfolio. There is no reason to suggest that the Minister of Justice was wrongly appointed when President Hifikepunye Pohamba announced Iivula-Ithana's appointment in that post in March 2005, he argued. One of the main challenges to the constitutionality of POCA is directed at that law's provision that it also covers "unlawful activities" that took place before the Act came into operation. Such a provision that makes the Act operate retroactively "is patently unconstitutional", Lameck claims in an affidavit filed with the court. She states: "(T)he retrospective effect of the definitions 'unlawful activity' and 'proceeds of unlawful activities' has the potential of criminalising activity which was not an offence at the time it was committed, and make property which was previously legally obtained (...) subject to confiscation." Trengove's response to this was to argue that with a proper interpretation of POCA it is apparent that crimes committed before the law came into operation would not trigger the asset confiscation and forfeiture mechanisms which the Act created. The entire purpose of POCA is not to punish people for their crimes, but rather to strip criminals of the benefits derived from crime, he said. Lameck and Mokaxwa are also attacking the Anti-Corruption Act's definition of the term "corruptly" as being unreasonable, vague and too wide. The Act defines "corruptly" as meaning "in contravention of or against the spirit of any law, provision, rule, procedure, process, system, policy, practice, directive, order or any other term or condition pertaining to any employment relationship; any agreement; or the performance of any function in whatever capacity". Trengove told the judges that he agreed that broad terms were used in the definition of "corruptly". However, he said, the definition was an attempt to capture a concept which in the first place is an elusive one. Lameck, Mokaxwa and Chinese national Yang Fan are facing charges over an alleged corrupt deal in which Chinese-made security scanning equipment was bought by the Ministry of Finance in 2008. It is alleged that the price of the equipment was inflated to enable the manufacturer of the equipment, Nuctech, represented by Yang, to pay a "commission" of at least US$12,828 million to Teko Trading, a close corporation of Lameck and Mokaxwa.

TITLE: State Struggles to Shed Corruption Label
COUNTRY: NAMIBIA (94%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (79%); FINLAND (66%); DENMARK (52%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); RANKINGS (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (73%); TRENDS (70%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: NAMIBIA is regarded as the second least corrupt country in the region, Transparency International's latest Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI) showed yesterday. However, it has been unable to shed its reputation as highly corrupt in the eyes of the world, retaining its 2010 score of 4,4 out of ten. Any country scoring less than five points is perceived as "highly corrupt" by the global watchdog for domestic and public sector graft. Namibia's latest score is a slight drop from the 4,5 it achieved in the 2008 and 2009 surveys. Transparency International (TI) ranked Namibia 57th out of 183 economies this year. Last year, Namibia held the 56th spot out of 178 countries, while in 2009, it was 56th out of 180 economies. In 2008 it held the 61st position, compared to the 57th spot in 2007. The recent trend is a far cry from the period of 1998 to 2002, when Namibia was continuously ranked amongst the top 30 least corrupt countries in the world. Although Namibia's 2011 score is better than its all-time low of 4,1 points from 2004 to 2006, it is a drastic drop from its record-high of 5,7 points in 2002. New Zealand, with a score of 9,5, came out tops in this year's ranking. It was followed by Denmark and Finland, both with 9,4. Globally, war-torn Somalia and North Korea were joint bottom of the list, perceived to be the world's most corrupt countries, with a score of 1,0. Compiling its yearly CPI, TI uses data from 17 surveys that look at factors such as enforcement of anti-corruption laws, access to information and conflicts of interest.

TITLE: 60 Riders Sign-Up for Anti-Corruption Race
SUBJECT: SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CYCLING (90%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: OVER 60 riders from nine clubs are expected to take part in the inaugural Anti-Corruption cycling competition this Sunday. According to the president of the national cycling federation (Ferwacy), Aimable Bayingana, the 80km race, sponsored by the Ombudsman's office, is a prelude to the Anti-corruption week from December 5-11. "This is a great start to our goal of having monthly competitions," Bayingana said. The winner of the one-day event will pocket Rwf0.3m while Rwf0.2m and Rwf0.1m has been staked for the first and second runner-up.

TITLE: Let's Stay the Course in Fighting Corruption
COUNTRY: AFRICA (92%); RWANDA (90%); BOTSWANA (89%); CAPE VERDE (88%); MAURITIUS (88%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (66%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: Botswana, Cape Verde, Mauritius and Rwanda make up the prestigious club of near corruption-free nations on a continent that has suffered so much at the hands of corrupt systems. Placing fourth least corrupt in Africa and 49th worldwide, with a score of 5.0 out of 10, is no mean feat for a country that languished in 111th position out of 178 countries, with a paltry score of 2.8, as recently as 2007. It is an achievement built upon years of solid work and consistency, through the application of appropriate legal framework and procedures, as well as establishment and empowerment of institutions designed to fight graft. Many bold decisions were taken to ensure a paradigm shift in matters of public accountability and ownership. From Rwanda's experience, it is clear that one of the main deterrence is punishing the corrupt, regardless of their position and status, as this sends out a strong message to the rest of the public. It may be difficult to totally rid society of any corrupt tendencies, but keeping the momentum against the vice should remain a top priority. The annual Auditor General's reports, easily demonstrate why the anti-corruption crusade must not lose steam. Taxpayers need value for every single penny that leaves the public coffers. They have seen the benefits of fiscal transparency and public accountability and will not tire in demanding more vigilance to ensure that government remains as clean and open as possible. While we must appreciate the commendable progress we have made as a nation, we must not be complacent, let's stay the course.

TITLE: Corruption Bigger Than Crime, Fraud
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (92%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (90%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (89%); PRIVATIZATION (79%); PUBLIC FINANCE (79%); EMBEZZLEMENT (78%); BANKING & FINANCE (78%); MONEY LAUNDERING (78%); PENSION FUNDS (77%); LUXURY GOODS (77%); RESEARCH REPORTS (76%); LOBBYING (74%); SOCIAL SECURITY (72%); US SOCIAL SECURITY (72%); RANKINGS (69%); ENTOMOLOGY (68%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: GOVERNMENT corruption is a bigger problem than any other form of organised crime and fraud in Namibia, the World Bank has said. At least "tens of millions of dollars", pocketed through dubious tendering, illegal issuing of licences, bribery, kickbacks and investment schemes, finance lifestyles and pay for luxury items such as cars and apartments in Swakopmund or Cape Town, it said. The report echoes the findings of the latest Corruption Perceptions Index (CPI), which showed that Namibia remains "highly corrupt" in the eyes of the world. Transparency International's 2011 CPI placed Namibia 57th out of 183 economies, a far cry from the period of 1998 to 2002, when the country was continuously ranked among the top 30 least corrupt countries. A lack of hard data makes it hard to put a price tag on corruption, the World Bank said. However, the "embezzlement of government funds and fraud with public money has increased dramatically in recent years". The findings are contained in a new study, 'Ill-gotten Money and the Economy: Experiences from Malawi and Namibia'. The World Bank sent a research team to Namibia last November and this February to interview Government, the private sector, academics and civil society on the matter. The report was compiled in collaboration with the Financial Intelligence Centre (FIC) at the Bank of Namibia (BoN). The World Bank concluded: "High-end corruption in Namibia involves tens of millions of dollars at a minimum." The World Bank said corruption and alleged corruption cases vary from a few million to N$30 million through the Social Security Commission/Avid scandal, N$100 million via the Offshore Development Corporation (ODC) and about N$1,8 billion through the Government Institutions Pension Fund's (GIPF) Development Capital Portfolio (DCP). "Many observers consider the influential role of one party to be one of the root causes of present-day concerns of corruption in Namibia," the study said. According to the World Bank, privatisation has strengthened the relationship between the business class and the political elite. "Many black economic empowerment managers have become business tycoons, and are influencing parliamentary decisions and lobbying for legislation that will ultimately secure their wealth," the study said. BEE remains a "highly debated" topic in Namibia and is perceived as "creating economic distortions", it said. Although Namibia's legal and institutional framework for curbing corruption generally received the thumbs-up, there are insufficient controls and loopholes, especially in the tendering process, the World Bank said. The report also addresses money laundering within and across the territorial borders of Namibia. "Namibia is considered to be highly vulnerable to the inflow of proceeds of crime and corruption from other jurisdictions [countries]," the report warns. The World Bank in particular mentions Namibia being a neighbour to South Africa and Angola, countries regarded to have "large and thriving criminal" classes. Angolans, the report continues, spend large amounts of money in the Namibian economy "doing business, driving up real estate prices, outbidding Namibian entrepreneurs". Angolans and other nationals are known to be buying luxury and middle-income houses for cash and have been accused of driving up property prices. Namibians interviewed by the World Bank for the report observed that many well-to-do Angolans coming with cash to Namibia have benefitted directly and indirectly from the Angolan oil boom and very fast economic growth over the past decade.

TITLE: Hategeka Wins Anti-Corruption Cycling Tourney
SUBJECT: CYCLING (91%); SPORTS & RECREATION EVENTS (90%); TOURNAMENTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%) Rwanda; Sport
TEXT: GASORE Hategeka showed incredible power ad determination after winning the Anti-corruption cycling tour on Sunday afternoon. The 24-year-old rider, who rides for Benediction cycling club, used 3 hours, 12 minutes and 45 seconds. Veteran Innocent Uwamungu a.k.a Rocky came in second place, 50 seconds behind Hategeka, while Nicodem Habiyambere claimed the final podium slot. In the ladies' fray, Angelique Munkandezi, Jeanette Uwimana and Diane Uwineza finished first, second and third in that order. Over 60 riders took part in the 80km race that was a prelude to the Anti-corruption week which ends this week. The one day tournament was sponsored by the Ombudsman's office.

TITLE: Govt to Recover Rwf2.8 Billion Lost Through Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); EMBEZZLEMENT (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); AUDITS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (78%); MISAPPROPRIATION (74%); SUPREME COURTS (73%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); FERTILIZERS (72%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (50%); IMMIGRATION (50%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The Ministry of Justice hopes to recover Rwf 2.8 bn following the successful prosecution of 145 individuals by the National Public Prosecution Authority (NPPA) on charges of corruption. The prosecutions were based on the Auditor Generals (AG) reports from 2007 to 2009. The jail terms incurred by the individuals ranged from one to ten years imprisonment. This was disclosed in a report released by the NPPA, containing the names of individuals who had lost corruption cases. The report reveals that the Prosecution forwarded, to the Justice Ministry, a list of 63 dossiers worth over Rwf 2.7 billion, 660,000 Euros and US $5,855 as well as other non-financial assets to be recovered. "We have been following up on the Auditor General's report since 2007," Prosecutor General Martin Ngoga said. The majority of the individuals on the list are government officials as well as financial controllers who embezzled, failed to account or misappropriated funds, flouted tender and procurement procedures or failed to deliver good account books. "We have been investigating and systematically following up these cases so that we don't miss out anything the Auditor General pointed out", Ngoga said. Prominent among the cases cited by the NPPA are instances of government officials diverting public funds for personal reasons as well as officials stealing materials for the implementation of government programmes such as iron sheets, fertilisers and cement. The Prosecutor General commended the NPPA's Economic Crimes Department for following up on the cases despite the challenges it faced. He, however, expressed concern that the department, which was established in 2007 and currently has 21 prosecutors, did not have enough capacity to follow up all the cases highlighted in the AG's report. He stated that the prosecutors have to follow up cases in and outside the country including in all embassies and he cited the biggest challenge being government employees getting transferred to other institutions or even quitting, making it difficult to locate them. The Coordinator of the Economic Crimes Department, Jules Marius Ntete, told The New Times that the NPPA will embark on the 2010 Auditors General Report by February 2012 because it is still handling a backlog of cases. The AG's most recent report highlighted some Rwf 9.7bn that has not been properly accounted for. The NPPA has opened 265 cases between 2007 to 2010 based on the findings of the Auditor General's report. Reacting recently on the recovery process, the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Justice, Pascal Bizimana Rugemitwari, said that they were undertaking a recovery process in collaboration with the Prosecution, the Supreme Court and the Ombudsman's office. He said they will send a list of names of the wanted individuals to the Department of Immigration, banks and other service points to ensure that the culprits don't evade justice.

TITLE: Corruption Watchdog Warns Local Leaders Against Graft
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (90%); CORRUPTION (90%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The chairperson of Transparency Rwanda, Immaculee Ingabire, has cautioned local leaders in Gicumbi District against soliciting bribes from residents seeking services. Ingabire, who was meeting district leaders, criticised public officials who demand bribes before offering services. The meeting aimed at training local leaders how to render better services. "There are instances where local leaders demand bribes from residents before handing over documents they are entitled to," she said, adding that such leaders should be exposed. The meeting called for more awareness campaigns to sensitise residents about their rights. Some residents, who spoke to The New Times, argued that although there had been remarkable success in the fight against graft, there were some corrupt local leaders who still deliberately delay to endorse documents. "I fell victim one time when it took me three months to get documents to put up a commercial house on my plot of land," one resident who preferred anonymity said.

TITLE: Corruption - a Major Challenge to National, Regional Aspirations - ACC Boss
COUNTRY: SIERRA LEONE (94%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); AFRICA (92%); UNITED STATES (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); BEST PRACTICES (75%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (71%); TAXES & TAXATION (70%); TAX LAW (68%); TAX FRAUD (53%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Corruption is one of the greatest challenges affecting the realization of our national and regional development goals and aspirations, says Commissioner of Sierra Leone's Anti-Corruption Commission ACC, Joseph Fitzgerald Kamara at the opening of the first ever conference of Heads of Anti-Corruption Agencies in West Africa. Kamara told the audience that the adoption of a regional approach in preventing and combating corruption is a commendable effort and a great step towards addressing such challenge. "A gathering such as this offers the unique opportunities to share experiences and best practices in preventing and combating corruption and economic crime in the region. Those of us with responsibility to prevent and combat such crimes must adopt appropriate strategies to deal effectively with the perpetrators and proceeds of corruption," he said. Mr. Kamara noted that the complex nature and new level of sophistication of corrupt crimes, such as illicit flows of financing and tax evasion requires the effective use of the platform provided by the conference, to strengthen collaboration and partnerships in the war against corruption. The anti-graft boss maintained that the 5-day conference will discuss corruption, methods of revealing it, reports about countries' commitments to fight corruption and the chances of enhancing integrity and honesty in the fight. "At the conference, we shall aspire to urge participating countries to undertake consistent and complex reforms in their institutional and legislative framework, aiming to decrease the level of corruption and to ensure the efficiency of their policies," he noted. In his brief statement, United States Ambassador in Sierra Leone, Michael S. Owen said: "The fact that we are hosting such a conference is a testimony of the government of Sierra Leone's commitment to the fight against corruption." While commending the government and parliament for allowing the commission to do its work freely without any political interference, the envoy pointed out that the ACC has had great success in preventing and combating corruption.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Probes Immigration Official in Illegal Arrest
SUBJECT: IMMIGRATION (94%); ARRESTS (92%); CORRUPTION (91%); MISCONDUCT (90%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY SCHOOL TEACHERS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (90%); IMMIGRATION LAW (90%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION EMPLOYEES (90%); ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS (89%); POLICE FORCES (73%); COSTS & ATTORNEY FEES (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (71%); LICENSES & PERMITS (69%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (57%) Namibia; Zimbabwe; Migration; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) will investigate the conduct of an immigration official who orchestrated the arrest of a Zimbabwean school teacher as an alleged illegal immigrant last month. ACC director Paulus Noa confirmed on Friday that they had received a copy of the case record containing an affidavit by Zimbabwean national Goodhope Chibika, and are investigating the conduct of senior immigration official Claudia Shilunga. Chibika, a teacher at Windhoek's Jakob Marengo Secondary School, was arrested in the early hours of November 10 and driven to Seeis Police Station east of Windhoek. According to Chibika, Shilunga had threatened to have him arrested and prosecuted for allegedly working in Namibia without a work permit. Chibika claimed Shilunga started threatening him after she had her car repaired at his garage and its immobiliser was lost in the workshop. Chibika says he agreed to pay Shilunga N$12 250 to have the immobiliser replaced, but she was not satisfied with his payments and visited the school where he teaches to warn the principal that Chibika would be arrested for working in Namibia illegally. Chibika obtained an urgent release order from the Windhoek High Court on the day of his arrest, with Acting Judge Andrew Corbett ruling that Shilunga should pay Chibika's legal costs. Chibika's lawyer, Norman Tjombe, told the court that the manner in which his client was arrested was an example of "blatant corruption" and an "abuse of statutory powers for personal gain." The matter was heard by Acting Judge Corbett for a second time on November 29, when he ordered that the Registrar of the High Court should provide a copy of the case record to the ACC for the matter to be investigated. Noa said ACC investigation would aim to determine whether Chibika's had been arrested because he is an illegal immigrant or due to bad blood between himself and Shilunga. Chibika married a Namibian citizen in 2004, and argues that he has been legally domiciled in Namibia since then, although his wife has since died. In terms of the Immigration Control Act, being domiciled in Namibia means that does not require a work or residence permit to legally live and work in the country, Chibika says.

TITLE: Corruption, a setback for Implementing Country's MDG's - Permanent Secretary
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (97%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (73%); DEVELOPING COUNTRIES (68%) Zambia; Corruption; Sustainable Development; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: LUPAULA Province Permanent Secretary Gabriel Kaunda has said the  effects of corruption are jeopardising Zambia's chances of attaining the  Millennium Development Goals (MDGs). And the Anti-Corruption Commission in Luapula Province has started  partnering with the grassroots by forming anti corruption village wings. In a speech read for him by Luapula Province Deputy Permanent  Secretary Alfred Sakala during the International Anti-Corruption Day at  the weekend, Mr Kaunda said the effects of corruption were known to all  Zambians hence the need to fight it with concerted effort. "The much needed resources for education, health, infrastructure and  any other basic services could be siphoned for personal use by the  corrupt. Similarly, the attainment of good governance, especially in  developing countries and young democracies can remain a pipe dream," he  said. And Anti-Corruption Commission regional manager Victor Musungwa said  the formation of village wings of the ACC which operated like clubs in  Nchelenge, Mwense and Mansa had taken the fight against corruption to  the people. "With continued support from Government, cooperating partners and all anti-corruption stakeholders, the fight against corruption will be  enhanced at all levels of society which will lead to good governance  through accountability and transparency," Mr Musungwa said.

TITLE: Yaluma Admits Corruption At Lands
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (89%); ENERGY & UTILITY TRADE (89%); ENERGY & UTILITY REGULATION & POLICY (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (74%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (73%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (72%); INVESTIGATIONS (62%); ECONOMIC NEWS (60%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: LANDS, Energy, and Water Development Minister, Christopher Yaluma, has admitted that acts of corruption at his ministry are still rife but stressed that steps are being taken to curb the vice. Concluding his policy statement on estimates for his ministry in Parliament yesterday, Mr Yaluma regretted that corruption was rife especially in the issuance of title deeds and allocation of plots. "My ministry is perceived to be corrupt and I agree with this perception but we have got to eliminate corruption. I have tried to prove a point by having a title deed processed within two weeks and yet the same process in many other cases takes two years. "We therefore need to have a value chain process so that we can monitor the title deed issuance and track down corrupt elements in the process and deal with them," he said. The minister said he was frustrated that the process of title deeds issuance took unnecessarily long because of corrupt officers at his ministry. He noted that it was frustrating for people to travel long distances to Lusaka to process their title deeds. "As a ministry, we are seriously considering decentralising the process so it can be done at provincial level. "You can imagine that I have got pending applications for titles deeds of 2001 in my office, which is unacceptable. Let us, therefore, work together and expose issues of bribes so that we can decisively deal with culprits," he said. Mr Yaluma during the same debate reiterated the PF Government's commitment to boosting the energy sector in Zambia started by the defeated MMD regime. Earlier, Chongwe Member of Parliament (MP) Sylvia Masebo (PF) said corruption at the Ministry of Lands was rampant, that was why at some point late president Levy Mwanawasa closed it to pave way for investigations. "Some amount of change was seen as a result of this action by Dr Mwanawasa and I am, therefore, urging the minister to clean up this ministry. In the last three years we saw a total diversion from good governance," she said. Choma MP, Cornelius Mweetwa (UPND) urged the minister to decentralise the issuance of title deeds to provincial centres. Mr Mweetwa called on the Government to increase staff levels so that service delivery could be enhanced at the Ministry of Lands. Namwala MP, Lubezhi Moono (UPND) said the high prices of fuel obtaining in Zambia negated efforts of growing the economy. Chavuma MP, Kenneth Konga (MMD) in his debate stressed that the energy sector was a critical component to the social and economic development of Zambia. Mr Konga noted that aspects of mining, agriculture and industries all hinged on the availability of energy and he was impressed that the PF Government had increased allocations to the sector. Justice Minister Sebastian Zulu told Parliament that the Government would ensure that corruption was eradicated. In presenting estimates for the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), Mr Zulu said the Government was serious about fighting corruption and that was why it would re-introduce Article 37 which was struck out from the ACC Act by the MMD regime. "The PF campaigned on the platform of fighting corruption and in view of this we shall reinstate the repealed Section 37 of the ACC Act in its totality. The fight against corruption requires vibrancy and concerted efforts by all institutions and citizens," he said. Mr Zulu who was also acting leader of Government business in the House said the Government would support ACC through the national Anti-Corruption Policy. The K60 billion allocated to the commission was approved.

TITLE: MDC-T Admits Corruption Amongst Councillors
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (88%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (87%); TALKS & MEETINGS (72%); PRIME MINISTERS (70%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Urban Issues and Habitation
TEXT: MDC-T has admitted that most of its councillors are corrupt and has since set up a committee to investigate the various allegations levelled against them. The party resolved to suspend the corrupt councillors at its national council meeting held last Saturday. Most MDC-T run local authorities have been accused of corruption, a development that saw government suspending some of the councillors. The party said they would set up committees to investigate and audit each of the councillors and councils to consider issues of good governance, accountability and policy consistency. "The party observes with concern the corruption, lack of service delivery and chaos resulting from ministerial interference in some of these councils and local authorities," MDC-T said. Last month, Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai warned corrupt councillors against engaging in shady deals, saying the party would not hesitate to dismiss them. MDC-T fired all its Chitungwiza councillors after investigations unearthed massive corruption within the council.

TITLE: Stay Away From Corruption, President Sata Urges Defence Wings
COUNTRY: ZAMBIA (95%); RWANDA (79%); MOZAMBIQUE (79%); NAMIBIA (79%); MALAWI (79%); BOTSWANA (79%); UGANDA (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%); ZIMBABWE (79%); KENYA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ARMIES (90%); ARMED FORCES (90%); AIR FORCES (89%); NATIONAL SECURITY (78%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (78%); POLICE FORCES (76%); EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION GRADUATION (75%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (73%); RIVERS (69%); NARCOTICS ENFORCEMENT (66%) Zambia; Arms and Military Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: PRESIDENT Michael Sata has implored the defence forces and other security wings to be vigilant and desist from engaging in any acts of corruption. Mr Sata has since assured the defence forces that the Government would equip them with skills to enhance their capacities so that they continue contributing to national development. President Sata, who is commander-in-chief of the armed forces, said the defence forces and all security wings should be part of solutions to the problem of corruption in the country. He said this in a speech read for him by Defence Minister, Geoffrey Mwamba during the graduation ceremony of the 14th command and staff course of 55 defence officers who graduated after undergoing 11 months of intensive training at Defence Services Command and Staff College in Lusaka. The officers graduated with a University of Zambia (UNZA) diploma in defence and security studies. "We believe that unless the fight against corruption is won, all our efforts will be in vain. You should be vigilant and see yourselves as part of the solution to this problem," President Sata said. The graduands were drawn from Zambia Army, Zambia Air Force, Zambia Police Service and Zambia National Service. They included foreign defence force officers from Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, Namibia, Mozambique, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zimbabwe. During their training, the officers interacted with several institutions such as Anti-Corruption Commission, the Drug Enforcement Commission, and Zambezi River Authority. And speaking earlier, Defence Services Command and Staff College Commandant Henry Nyundu said the course the officers undertook included theory of war, command leadership, army and air force studies, international and national affairs that affected Zambia. Brigadier general Nyundu said the officers also conducted various local and foreign visits aimed at giving student officers a broader view of Zambia's economic and social development. He said a site for a new staff college was secured and was hopeful the Government would source funds to construct a new staff college with appropriate infrastructure and adequate facilities.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption in the Country - Is Govt Telling the Truth? [analysis]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ELECTIONS (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (90%); HEADS OF GOVERNMENT ELECTIONS (90%); POLITICAL PARTIES (89%); SCANDALS (89%); CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (87%); DRUG TRAFFICKING (85%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (78%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); WRITERS (72%); DOCUMENTARY FILMS (62%); FORESTRY & LOGGING TRADE (61%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (60%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: As we approach the New Year 2012 when the decisive 2012 presidential and parliamentary elections will be held for a five-year presidential and parliamentary mandate, it is apparent that one of the most crucial issues that will determine which political party Sierra Leonean electorates will vote for in the majority during the campaign season will be corruption. Indeed, upon his accession to power, President Ernest Bai Koroma assured the people of this country that his government will vigorously pursue the fight against corruption noting that in the regime's drive against corruption and to achieve zero tolerance to corruption there will be no 'sacred-cows', not even members of his own family. Controversy is brewing in many quarters about the seriousness that the All People's Congress (APC) party government had committed to the anti-corruption objective given that statistics show that despite the president's determination to minimize corruption, the pandemic remains endemic in every fabric of the Sierra Leonean society. A long pro-APC regime article written by Kabs-Kanu in the USA published in the 14th December 2011 edition of the Independent Observer put to rest government's unrelenting determination by creating the impression that President Koroma is very serious about his determination to eradicate corruption in Sierra Leone. This is a far cry from what a letter that the flag-bearer of the opposition Sierra Leone People's Party (SLPP) Julius Maada Bio tried to portray in the widely read London-based Guardian newspaper recently. In the letter, the retired brigadier hinted that corruption is still rampant in almost every segment of the society especially in the area of education, the economy and democratic reforms. The SLPP presidential candidate also cited the timbergate corruption scandal involving the Vice President Alhaji Sahr Sam-Sumana recently exposed in a documentary of the Aljazeera international television as an example. The timbergate scandal or the logging trade monopoly is today a serious embarrassment to the APC government. The scale of humiliation is probably on the same magnitude with the drug trafficking scandal few years ago, in which the first minister of transport and aviation of the President Koroma-led APC regime, Hon. Kemoh Sesay, was implicated. In the case of the drug trafficking scandal, the government tried by every means to claim its direct involvement by ensuring that justice takes its course through the law court with the involvement of international agencies that monitor drug trafficking in the world such as the International Police (INTERPOL). At the end of the trial, government's show of cooperation with the prosecution and other signs became quite evident that the APC regime was innocent except that corrupt individuals working for the government had hidden-hands in the drug trade. What is certain today is that the APC government appears to be divided over whether to cover the reputation of the hardworking Vice President. The issue was at first bitterly criticized by certain pro-APC newspapers and propagandists some of which established the impression that the Aljazeera story is a set-up meant to tarnish the good image of the APC government thereby reduce their chances for re-election in the coming 2012 elections. Some government officials even toyed around with the idea of taking international legal actions against Aljazeera's documentary while labelling journalist Sorious Samura who presented the documentary as a paid-up traitor on the payroll of the detractors of the Vice President. Today, after giving a second thought to the entire affair, government's official spokesman, the Minister of Information and Communication I.B. Kargbo is even mumbling about the possibility of the VP being asked to relinquish his function for the sake of the good governance initiative. The agitations for the VPs resignation appear to have gained added dimensions as a group of American congressmen presented a position statement cautioning the resignation of the Vice President. The SLPP presidential candidate came out plain in that letter by urging those "holding influence with the current administration such as ex-British Prime Minister Tony Blair to caution the APC government to reverse their actions by repudiating all anti-democratic measures and by being honest about the Koroma regime's record in government. The UK which supplies 60% of the Sierra Leonean government's budget through aid must demand change," Maada Bio wrote. What is logical about the SLPP leader's letter is that it did not fail to mention that there are serious challenges ahead. There are many who feel that education in Sierra Leone has seriously declined in standards that tempted it to be labelled as 'The Athens of West Africa' because many issues have been compromised. There are fears in the horizon that very soon, commercial banks may start rationing payment of customer's deposits. Strike action looms over the educational system for salary arrears in the primary, secondary and tertiary institutions of the educational system while threats of the exchange rate to foreign currencies especially the British pound and the U.S dollar as well as monetary inflation is pushing shockwaves into the economic sector. One point hammered out in Maada Bio's letter is that efforts must be made to ensure that there is a transparent political process although there are pessimistic signs that the ghosts of the past election may return to manipulate the fair elections that Sierra Leoneans deserve as a basic human right while expressing the hope that all parties should work together to ensure that the transfer of power is peaceful. "It is something that the British government bravely advocated in the year 2000 and over a decade later we must not let that intervention be in vain." What Maada Bio appears to be stating is that it should be the unwavering determination of every stakeholder in the electoral process to ensure an honest, transparent and accountable process and one reason that may ignite rays of hope is that over five years at the helm of the National Electoral Commission (NEC), Dr Christiana Thorpe may have by now learnt enough lessons and experience that may enable her not to repeat the errors of the past. In the coming 2012 presidential and parliamentary elections, draconian measures should be taken to ensure that polling stations in the country and the NEC election supervisors and monitors do not possess ballots in excess of the number of registered voters in a given constituency. In the words of the SLPP leader, the danger that a free and fair election may not materialize in Sierra Leone this time around is a tragedy not only for the country but also for Britain that has invested so much in aid and support to the country in the past 11 years and it will be an uncomfortable development for Blair who ordered the original military intervention. So far, it seems that the APC government is on the track of holding an unprecedented transparent elections as consultative meetings and seminars have begun in earnest to forge understanding with key stakeholders such as the NEC, participating political parties, the Political Parties Registration Commission PPRC), the Sierra Leone Police etc to sensitize them on their roles and responsibilities in ensuring transparent elections. Essentially, it will be an underestimation to conclude that President Koroma is not at all serious about fighting corruption in the country. This can be viewed in the large number of the close allies of the government that have been prosecuted without any signs of favouritism. In the government's determination to fight corruption, one must take into account the ceremonious departure of Mrs AfsatuKabbah, who served as Minister of Energy and Power where she was accused of the dubious 'Income-Electrix' contract for the supply of electrical power generators before she was transferred to be Minister of Fisheries and Marine Resources where contracts awarded were not equally free from corrupt practices. The long list should also include the Commissioner of the National Revenue Authority (NRA) Alieu B. Sesay, the Maritime Administrator Philip Dukuly and the circumstances of cabinet reshuffles that sent Dr. Joseph Koroma from State House to China as ambassador as well as the dismissal of the Minister of Health and Sanitation, Dr Sheku Koroma. In the opinion of the hardworking Anti-Corruption Commission's (ACC) Commissioner Joseph Fitzgerald Kamara on the role of the ACC recently, he said the ACC is an established pillar of support to good governance, pursuing integrity in public life; confronting corruption through exposure system review, investigation and prosecution. He added that the new ACC Act 2008 now covers wide ranging issues including conflict of interest, unexplained and illegal acquisition of wealth, corruption in procurement, abuse of position and office to name a few.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Rapped
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); CORPORATE COUNSEL (72%); EXECUTIVES (69%); SHAREHOLDERS (56%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission was yesterday accused of abusing its office by arresting FCA Motors and Western Union franchise owner, Frederick Mtandah, who is facing over US$25 million fraud charges. Mtandah's lawyer, Mr Jonathan Samukange, made the accusation during the State's application to have the businessman surrender his passport, which was temporarily released. Mtandah, who is also a major shareholder of CAPS Holdings, is appearing before Harare magistrate Mr Kudakwashe Jarabini. To buttress its case, the State yesterday called the chief legal officer of the Anti-Corruption Commission Ms Monica Chizunza to furnish the court with the reasons why Mtandah should surrender his passport. In her evidence in chief, Ms Chizunza said the State erred in consenting to the temporary release of the passport, hence the need to rectify the issue. Ms Chizunza also argued that there were changed circumstances warranting the return of Mtandah's passport. "I am here to tell the court that the release of the passport was erroneous whether it was by consent or not, that is why I am here so the issue can be rectified," Ms Chizunza said.

TITLE: Tax Collectors Lose Contracts Due to Corruption
SUBJECT: PUBLIC FINANCE (91%); TAX AUTHORITIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); TAXES & TAXATION (90%); CONTRACT AWARDS (89%); INFLATION (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (78%); CITY GOVERNMENT (78%); MAYORS (76%) Rwanda; Corruption; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: The controversy surrounding the award of a tax collection tender to private individuals in Rubavu District, has taken a new twist, with the District Advisory Council saying private individuals should not have been given the tender. Rubavu district advertised five different types of tenders in tax and revenue collection. It included collection of taxes from Gisenyi town, Sebeya sand quarry, taxes from all sectors in the district, taxes from butcheries and all animal markets and taxes from motorists and cyclists. In July last year, there was a standoff between the district tender committee and the bidders who even petitioned the office of the Ombudsman, accusing the district top leadership of manipulating the tender procedures to award their cronies contracts. Now, barely three months after the tender was controversially awarded, reports say the District Advisory Council is cancelling the tenders, citing corruption and inflation of the standard tax tariff on the part of the contractors. Efforts to get a comment from Nelson Mbarushimana, the Executive Secretary of Rubavu, were futile as he didn't pick our several calls. But Mayor, Sheikh Hassan Bahame, confirmed the development, saying tax receipts that were being given to business people are not exactly what are presented to the district authorities. "We have evidence that they charge high taxes which is against the stipulated charge. hence extorting residents," said Sheikh Bahame. "Inflating taxes for unsuspecting citizens is theft which should not be tolerated, and as leaders, we must protect citizens." However, Mustapha Majyambere, one of the contractors, told our reporter they had not received any official communication terminating their services. "We are still working and the district has not written to us to stop us from working, and I can't make any more comments beyond this," said Majyambere. While Amin Francoise, who has the biggest contract to collect taxes in Gisenyi town declined to talk to the media when we called him. "I don't discuss work related issues with the media on phone," said Amin before hanging up the phone. It emerged fingers are being pointed at some district leaders whom, it is alleged, are behind the extortion of the taxes since contracts were won by their relatives. "We know some of the money stolen is deposited on an account belonging to the wife and brother of a top leader in the district," said a businessman who preferred not to be identified.

TITLE: Local Watchdog Challenges Judiciary Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); VERDICTS (90%); TRIAL & PROCEDURE (90%); BRIBERY (89%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (78%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (73%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); TALKS & MEETINGS (69%); AGREEMENTS (64%); RANKINGS (61%) Rwanda; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Transparency Rwanda, has accused the judiciary of not eliminating legal procedures that may lead to corruption. Among those include sudden resumption of closed court cases. According to Chairperson of Transparency Rwanda, Marie Immacule Ingabire, her office has continuously complained about revisions of the court verdicts with an executory formula. An executory formula is an enforcement seal stamped on a court ruling that allows the implementation of the verdict. "There are cases where a ruling is passed, the 30 days of appeal also expire but suddenly the defendant files an appeal under unclear circumstances. There is no way someone can convince us that there is no element of corruption in such arrangements," said Ingabire. She added that Transparency Rwanda has continuously raised the concerns with the Judiciary in vein. Reacting to the accusations, however, the spokesman of Courts, Charles Kaliwabo, refuted the claims, saying that lifting of executory formula seal cannot, in any way, encourage corruption. "There are situations where a defendant fails to appeal within the required 30 days due to some valid reasons - maybe he or she was sick - in that case an executory formula seal is stamped on the court verdict and a court order is implemented. "However, anytime the defendant shows up and proves beyond doubt that they were unable to appeal within the stipulated timeframe due to unavoidable reasons, the seal is lifted and the case is revised. This is the misunderstanding we have with Transparency Rwanda," said Kaliwabo. He added that the judiciary has held several meetings with Transparency over the same issue, but the parties have since failed to reach an agreement. "We have requested Transperacy Rwanda to give us lists of the cases they claim were revised under unclear situations, but they have not given us that list," said Kaliwabo. Transparency Rwanda argues that, under no circumstances should a sealed case be resumed, and that the resumption of an already sealed case may be a result of a bribe. Meanwhile Rwanda Bribery Index 2011, released last month, indicates that the average size of bribes reduced from Rwf 27,000 in 2010 to Rwf 19,000 in 2011. Although the index does not capture high-profile corruption cases, it indicates that the most common form of corruption witnessed in Rwanda is bribery for purposes of securing a service. A statement from Transparency Rwanda published Thursday indicates reads in part: "the likelihood of encountering bribe demand has reduced from 3.9 percent in 2010 to 1.19 percent in 2011. The institution with the highest likelihood of encountering a bribe demand situation is the police (5.83 percent) followed by mediators (4.62 percent) and the Civil Society (2.88 percent) takes the 3rd position, whereas it was ranked first in 2010." It adds that in 2010 survey, the police was ranked 3rd. On a positive, however, the likelihood decreased from 6.1 percent in 2010 indicating an overall reduction in bribery demand cases. "Village and Justice Institutions come right after the top three while health centres are still the best performers," reads the statement. The survey revealed 45 percent of those who engage in corruption do so to obtain services which they are entitled to and should get for free. This represents an increase from 30.7 percent in 2010, indicating an increasing burden on service seekers.

TITLE: Don't Punish Corruption, Prevent It [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (89%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (89%); CIVIL SERVICES (78%); PREVENTION & WELLNESS (75%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (74%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (71%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (65%); LICENSES & PERMITS (65%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: TODAY everyone is talking about punishing the massive corruption which took place under the MMD government. Fine, let's do that. Corruption does great harm to the country, and all honest Zambians want to see it punished. We all cheer when a big fish is caught and put behind bars. We want the Attorney General's Office strengthened and offenders prosecuted, and we want to bring back the law that treated as evidence of corruption the failure by government officials to account for unexplained wealth. But successful prosecution, when achieved, is less than half the battle. Prevention is far better than punishment. It is less exciting, but more effective, just as preventing disease is better than curing it. And with corruption, which is a social disease, prevention is also better than treatment. How can we prevent corruption? By removing, or greatly reducing the opportunities for it. It is, of course, not possible to remove ALL such opportunities. But there is great scope for removing, or at least reducing, most of them. I refer to the countless instances where civil servants in government offices, and in governmental institutions like NAPSA and the ZRA, are responsible for providing services to members of the general public. What kind of services? Almost anything you can think of: issuing national registration cards or passports, issuing any kind of license or permit, paying out any benefit to which a person is entitled, admitting students to institutions of learning, etc., etc. For there are countless requirements which ordinary people need to obtain from 'the powers that be' in order to make progress. The official approached for the document may not have the power to refuse to issue it, but he or she can usually find a way to delay issuing it, and delay can cause the applicant great inconvenience, as well as serious loss or expense. That gives the official concerned an opportunity to extract 'speed money'. If the official approached lacks the power to issue the document applied for, he can delay in recommending its issue to a senior who has the necessary authority. The point here is that civil servants at various levels can so manipulate a situation as to frustrate an applicant in order to extract money for performing an official duty in a timely manner. They may well not make any demand for payment. It is enough to delay and delay, until the applicant becomes so desperate that he or she resorts to offering payment for a service to which they are legally entitled. An alternative route for people who do not know how to apply, or who fear to get involved in corruption, is to pay a hefty sum to an 'agent' or a 'facilitator' to act on their behalf. The fact is that delays create desperation, which often leads to corruption. Indeed delays can virtually compel honest people to be corrupt in order to obtain a benefit to which they are legally entitled. So how can this kind of corruption be prevented? Many countries succeed in preventing it by getting public institutions to publish customer service charters or citizens' charters. Each charter commits the issuing institution to perform within a stipulated period each of the specific services which it offers. The charter is put on display at the institution's offices for members of the public to read. Then, if stated performance times are not met, applicants have the knowledge and the justification to appeal to senior staff. Charters of this kind are used in many countries. In Ghana every government institution has one, and they are very effective. There is even a ministry for government reform! In our own country the Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) issued its Taxpayer Charter in February 2008. And in June that year the Ministry of Labour and the Immigration Department both published charters. Since then there has been talk of other ministries and government institutions issuing charters, but these have yet to be published. It is, of course, one thing to issue a charter, and another to make it effective. That is far more difficult. But it can be done, if there is determination, such as has been shown by the ZRA. The Authority invited the Zambia Institute for Public Policy Analysis (ZIPPA) to monitor the performance of the Taxpayer Charter, and to comment in the press on the ZRA's quarterly publication of results. Early last year the ZRA asked ZIPPA to carry out a detailed study of its Taxpayer Charter, and the Authority is now undertaking improvements recommended in the consultant's report. Apart from the three charters introduced in 2008, no other ministry or governmental institution has yet introduced a charter. But several are said to be planning to do so. Charter introduction is one good initiative started during the last government, although it was not persevered with. Let us hope that the Patriotic Front (PF) Government, with its strongly declared opposition to corruption, will recognise that customer service charters are powerful weapons in the war against corruption, and will embrace them with determination. It is good to look back and punish past corruption. But it is far more important to look ahead and do everything possible to prevent corruption in the future.

TITLE: Chief Mpezeni Blames Poverty On Corruption in MMD
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); POOR POPULATION (90%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (90%); POVERTY RATES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (77%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: PARAMOUNT Chief Mpezeni of the Ngoni people in Eastern Province has said the growing poverty levels in Zambia are as a resulted of gross corruption that took place during former president, Rupiah Banda's reign. Meanwhile, the traditional leader has rubbished accusations that the fight against corruption was targeted at people from certain tribes. Chief Mpezeni reiterated his calls that Mr Banda's immunity should be lifted to give him an opportunity to clear himself of corruption allegations. Speaking to the media after he paid a courtesy call on the President Michael Sata at State House in Lusaka yesterday, the traditional ruler said there was nothing special about Mr Banda and that he should be ready to face the courts just as some chiefs had been arraigned in courts. "Se tamamfumu tuyenda ku court, lomba a Banda angalekelenji kuyenda ku court" (We the chiefs have appeared in courts, what is so difficult about Mr Banda appearing in court?), he asked in his Ngoni language. He said the Patriotic Front (PF) Government had so far performed well since it assumed power and should be supported in all its causes. "Boma iyi yatsopani chioneka kuti yugwira nchito. Vintu vambiri vinasokonezeka. (The new Government is performing well considering that so many things had gone wrong." The paramount chief said it was important that the immunity be lifted because it was only the courts that could clear the allegations of corruption. Chief Mpezeni also said Zamtel did not belong to one individual but was for all the Zambians and that the sale should be reversed. He said it would be wrong to resist the people's popular demand for the Government to get back the 75 per cent shares in Zamtel. Chief Mpezeni said complaints that arrests and investigations were selective were incorrect because the police could only arrest people suspected to have stolen. The police would do so regardless of the people's status, political affiliation and tribe. He said people facing accusations should be bold enough and appear in the courts so that they could clear their names instead of resorting to counter accusations. The paramount chief said the investigations and arrests could not be targeted at people from the Eastern Province, citing former minister of Labour, Austin Liato who hails from Western Province and was already appearing in court.

TITLE: The Role of the Dpp - a Critical Anti-Corruption Assignment
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LAWYERS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (77%); LITIGATION (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (76%); SUITS & CLAIMS (69%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (68%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: To prosecute or not to prosecute this is the daunting task which is bestowed on the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) whenever he is required to issue a consent. The DPP has to determine whether there is enough ground for any criminal agency to prosecute any case and advise accordingly. His advice will assist Government prevent wastage of time on non-issues and expedite the probe on clearly suspected cases. The fight against corruption in Zambia is an old one. It has been there before and has now been revamped with renewed vigour by the Patriotic Front (PF) Government. The approach is totally different and involves a new set of suspects. To start this crusade, a government has to be prepared to lose popularity especially among those that would be pursued by various investigative wings. This is normal and totally inevitable. However, Zambians should know that no criminal investigation goes to court without the consent of one key office-the DPP. Renowned lawyer in criminology and prosecution Mutembo Nchito is there to offer such vital guidance in this whole fight against corruption. He is now the DPP and all matters await his functionary duties. A man with an ease stature and a highly patriotic character to national issues, Mr Nchito bears the blessings of the head of State Michael Sata to get rid of all corruption and sort out all the past and present wrong doings in Zambia. This is indeed a great task. With a passion for his profession, Mr Nchito has spent more time in the courts of law in trying to pursue justice on behalf of the general public than just shifting in his posh office. He has all it takes for one to be called a comfortable person in society but he still feels the concerns of the majority Zambians on the high levels of corruption could be addressed using his skills as a lawyer. Previously Mr Nchito pursued corruption cases as a private lawyer hired by the then Task Force on Corruption, but this time he is a fully employed public servant occupying the DPP's office and determining which cases would be worthy pursuing. According to Mr Nchito, his appointment as DPP is purely owed to President Sata who identified his determination and prowess to rid Zambia of corruption. He is focused and will remain so as he executes his duties. Those with a criminal mind and have been thriving on corruption proceeds have all the reason to be scared with the appointment of Mr Nchito. Mr Nchito's role will include assisting the judiciary in determining where there is a case and where there is none at all. "We will expect you to assist the Judiciary by preparing your cases; don't blame the Judiciary that they are acquitting people if you don't prepare your cases properly," President Sata said shortly after swearing-in Mr Nchito at State House. Mr Sata said third president of the Repulic of Zambia Levy Mwanawasa worked well and created the task force on corruption but his successor Rupiah Banda and his colleagues abandoned it. The Zambian laws should not segregate. Upon assuming his new role as DPP, Mr Nchito realises the need for all people to be equal before the law regardless of their status in society. According to Mr Nchito his appointment to the office of DPP is an opportunity to contribute to the rule of law. He believes that all Zambians must be accountable and held to the standard of the law. "If we are all equal before the law, I believe that this country will develop. We can't have different laws for different people. We need one law for all of us," Mr Nchito said. He said he will sit down with his staff in the office (DPP) and look at the cases they are working on. "I will ensure that I pick up from where my predecessor left. I am not going to try and do everything myself, I will sit down with my colleagues so that we can move the office forward together," he said. Mr Nchito said his office would not rush cases to court but ensure that good ground work is established before taking them to the courts of law. "My team will take good cases before the courts of law. If some people are innocent, they are innocent. If they have an issue to answer, they have to be given a chance to be heard before the courts of law," Mr Nchito said. He said he would review all the high-profile cases, adding that all must be prepared to be answerable for previous conduct. Mr Nchito said when allegations were raised against someone, society must be patient enough to allow law enforcement agencies to investigate matters and bring them to finality. He promised to ensure that everyone was treated the same way and those that were accused were treated fairly. President Sata, who has publicly stated that he is allergic to corruption, said he wants to fight the vice to create new jobs and reduce high poverty levels at more than 65 per cent. Already Mr Nchito is showing his commitment to team work. The fight against corruption cannot be won by a single person. The appointment of Mr Nchito as DPP does not signify victory in corruption fight at all but just a start of the whole episode. He needs support and the other stakeholders equally need the support of his experience. So are other stakeholders aware of the task ahead and the need for team work? There are several cases before the DPP's office that really need to be addressed just like the ACC the DEC and the police are equally keeping a back-log of cases. The work load has to be offloaded fast to achieve the desired results. Corruption offences are being committed every day and hence the need for the fight to equally be doubled. Laxity in dealing with the scourge may result in a nullity of the entire efforts. According to Mr Sata, there is a lethal team put up to fight corruption at the moment. The combination of Mr Nchito, the solicitor General Musa Mwenye and the Attorney General Mumba Malila is just a complete armory required to defeat corruption in Zambia. The fight against corruption in Zambia could have been won by now had the spirit ignited by Dr Mwanawasa had been upheld by the successive leadership. The questions still lingering in most Zambians' minds is why the MMD under Mr Rupiah Banda as head of State abandoned the anti-corruption crusade which was driven by Dr Mwanawasa. Although an opportunity was lost, there is the renewed hope now that the Government has re-launched a much 'vicious' campaign to rid the nation of corruption. According to Mr Sata, there is need to: "clean both visible and invisible cobwebs of corruption in Zambia." The MMD did not only abolish the task force on corruption but removed the Abuse of Authority clause from the penal code. Some anti-corruption advocates had argued that the removal of the clause was a recipe for more corruption especially in the civil service where people were acquiring questionable assets not commensurate with their earnings. The PF is now contemplating reintroducing the abuse of office clause as one of the special, tools to fighting corruption. This intention has received overwhelming public support. Politicians, the church, the civil society and all others stakeholders should support calls for a revived corruption fight by the PF if equality before the law and the spirit of genuine hard work could be retained in Zambia. Corruption defeats the spirit of hard work as people tend to enjoy undue benefits and riches. With determination and zeal, this fight will be won.

TITLE: Local Leader Suspended Over Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); SCANDALS (78%); LAND USE PLANNING (70%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: A local leader in Ngarama Sector, Gatsibo District, was relieved of his duties, after he was allegedly involved in a corruption scandal. According to the District Mayor, Ambrose Ruboneza, Gilbert Niyonshuti, yje former Executive Secretary of Kigasha Cell in Ngarama Sector, was suspended after residents pinned him of involvement in corruption malpractices. "We received several complaints from residents accusing the local leader of being corrupt, especially in the land registration exercises. We suspended him from his duties to warn others that we have a government that does not tolerate the culture of impunity," he said. According to residents, Esdras Sibomana acquired his land title but later Niyonshuti forcefully retained it using his powers as a leader. "He took it back and gave it to another resident. We realized that he was given some cash," complained one of the residents. Others accused the local leader of having conned them while seeking several services from him. A big percentage of disputes registered in Gatsibo District are commonly land-related and authorities have been called on to step up measures against the vice. The district leadership vowed to facilitate residents from engaging in land disputes but instead adopt justice and peaceful mediation. However, residents said local leaders, especially at the grassroots level, were behind such conflicts.

TITLE: Trail of Corruption Haunts Rupiah Banda, Allies [editorial]
