SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); TRANSPORTATION SECTOR PERFORMANCE (78%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (78%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (76%); TAXES & TAXATION (76%); US PRESIDENTS (76%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (73%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (72%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (71%); LINES OF CREDIT (62%); IRRIGATION (60%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: The detailed report on the operations of the Zambia Revenue Authority (ZRA) made public yesterday has opened a pandora's box and exposed a trail of corruption, plunder and, in some cases, brazen theft perpetrated by high ranking officials in the Rupiah Banda administration. A total of 14 senior officials, including the former Republican president Mr Rupiah Banda and several former cabinet ministers, have been cited in the commission's report for various forms of suspected impropriety during MMD's reign. The commission, chaired by Mr Kingsley Chanda, former ZRA commissioner in charge of direct taxes, has recommended that "appropriate action/investigations" be instituted against the named officials. Among those named are former Finance and National Planning minister, Dr Situmbeko Musokotwane, former Works and Supply minister, Mike Mulongoti, former Transport and Communications minister, Prof Geoffrey Lungwangwa and former Local Government and Housing minister, Dr Eustarckio Kazonga. Two former ZRA commissioner generals, Mr Criticles Mwansa and Mr Wisdom Nhekairo have both been cited in the report. Mr Nhekairo is named in connection with the award of the controversial Bradwell contract, which was skewed in favour of the company engaged to operate ZRA border scanners, as well as justifying single-sourcing of the equipment on "flimsy grounds", and payments to Cargo Scan Limited with no regard to service delivery and contract terms. Mr Mwansa has similarly been cited for justifying direct bidding of Nuctech company and Cargo Scan Limited and justifying the procurement of four additional scanners and reduction of the floatation period. The report paints a picture of unprecedented levels of impunity in the manner in which key Government functionaries circumvented laid down procedures aimed at ensuring transparency and accountability in the procurement process. Failure to adhere to prescribed procedures will impact adversely on the Zambian tax payers who will foot the bill from the US$125 million loan contracted from the Chinese Government. The genesis of the deal dates back to 2007 when the then president Levy Mwanawasa visited China and negotiated for a credit line of US$100 million for storage sheds for Food Reserve Agency ($11million), Government complex ($25 million), earth moving equipment $39 (million), irrigation ($12.5 million), and water and sanitation ($12.5 million). The coordination of the use of the loan, including the purchase of four scanners, was delegated to then vice-president Banda. When Mr Banda ascended to the presidency in 2008, part of the loan ($50 million) which was reserved for irrigation, water and sanitation was diverted, on the advice of Chinese officials, to the procurement of four additional scanners, bringing the total to eight. The total loan contracted was also increased from $100 million to $125 million to cover the cost of four scanners. Then Finance minister Ng'andu Magande opposed the variation of funds to favour procurement of scanners, while then secretary to the treasury Evans Chibiliti cautioned Government to take into account the views of the technocrats who had advised against procurement of more scanners. Dr Musokotwane also excpressed misgivings about the additional equipment, but the advice was ignored as Government proceeded to buy the eight scanners from Nuctech, and all of them were single sourced, a decision which the commission has criticised. Although the speedy procurement was purported to be based on urgent need to enhance revenue collection at the borders, the equipment has been lying idle since its importation, save for one installed at Chirundu. The commission is appalled, and understandably so, at the callousness and impunity of the individuals involved. The decision to circumvent the open tender process is indefensible and single-sourcing has cast serious doubts on the whole procurement process, and the motives by the key figures who sanctioned the illegal purchase. We hope the investigations will leave no stone unturned in order to ensure that all those linked to the scanners purchase, the Bradwell contract and related matters are brought to book.

TITLE: Corruption Could Undermine Nation's Develoment Goals - Sebhat Nega
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); PUBLIC FINANCE (89%); POLLS & SURVEYS (88%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (88%); ETHICS (77%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (77%); INFLATION (75%); ECONOMIC NEWS (75%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (74%); TAX AUTHORITIES (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (72%); PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION (69%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (69%); COST OF LIVING (67%); FOOD SECURITY (67%); WATER CRISES & SHORTAGES (62%); HOTELS & MOTELS (55%); FOOD CRISES & SHORTAGES (50%) Ethiopia; Corruption
TEXT: Sebhat Nega, one of the founders of the TPLF and a veteran fighter during the armed struggle, made a statement last week that raised eyebrows around town. If left unchecked, corruption could undermine the nation's development efforts, although it might not have reached that capability yet, Sebhat warned, serving as a director general for the Ethiopian International Institute for Peace & Development (EIIPD). Speaking to the media at a conference that his Institute, a federal think-tank on foreign policy issues, organised at the Ghion Hotel, on Wednesday, February 22, 2012, Sebhat also criticised the government for doing little in practical terms to fight corruption, while there are widespread rumours among members of the public about government officials and federal agencies suspected of being corrupt. Federal agencies, such as the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA) are rife with what the public perception that Sebhat alluded to accuses them of, a new study has confirmed. Conducted for the second time in a decade, after securing a close to eight million Birr, fund from the World Bank, the corruption perception survey was released a day before Sebhat's statement at the Ghion. Close to 17pc of business enterprises that responded to questionnaires had been asked to pay gratification in return for services at public institutions over the past 12 months, they said, according to the second nationwide corruption survey, which was commissioned by the Federal Ethics & Anticorruption Commission (FEAC) and conducted by a Tanzanian-based US company, Kilimanjaro International Corporation (KIC), after beating 19 bidders. The survey measures views, perceptions, and experience of respondents from the pubic on corruption and its perception. Nonetheless, corruption is rated as the seventh-most serious socioeconomic problem experienced by citizens in the country, preceded by a lack of access to safe drinking water, food shortages, lack of quality roads and networks, poor public transportation, unemployment, and high cost of living and inflation, in that order. A considerable amount of the public has to "catalyse" the efficiency of the services they seek from public institutions through extra payments, in the forms of gratification, the survey finds. The survey identified the judiciary, law enforcement community, municipalities, and the ERCA as places that most people perceived as being prone to corruption and inefficient public service delivery. The ERCA was singled out 10 years ago during the first survey, although it was then divided into three federal agencies: the Ministry of Revenues, the Ethiopian Customs Authority (ECA), and the Federal Inland Revenues Authority (FIRA). It was believed that forming a single large and powerful federal Agency could provide a base for a modern and equitable tax and customs administration regime, effective resource utilisation and fast service delivery. However, despite the relentless efforts made so far towards combating corruption and providing effective public service, specially, in the areas of custom clearance, as well as tax and revenue collection, it has remained a challenge both to the service provider and the service seeker, according to the new survey. A study by the World Bank and International Finance Corporation (IFC) also corroborate the findings in this survey. "A standard export shipment of goods from Ethiopia requires seven documents and takes an average of 42 days at a cost of 1,760 dollars per container whereas a standard import shipment of goods requires nine documents and takes an average of 44 days at a cost of 2,660 dollars per container," according to the World Bank. The same message was also echoed by the business community, during the second Public Private Consultative Forum (PPCF) held at Sheraton Addis, two weeks ago. The ERCA suffers from about eight shortcomings, including a lack of clarity on procedures as well as an absence of coordination among federal agencies that make decisions at various stages of importing. Though corruption remains a problem in the country, as strongly emphasised by Sebhat, the two topmost problems faced by citizens - inflation and unemployment - have perceivably created a conducive environment and breeding ground for corruption. The complexity of the government procurement procedures and the requirement to pay gratification to public officials were among the major obstacles that the business community faces in doing business with the government, the survey also revealed. "Managing inflation should constitute an important element in the fight against corruption," the report recommends. However, rumours of corruption by agencies and senior government officials should be urgently investigated to determine whether they have any merit, Sebhat suggested.

TITLE: Aupindi Denies Swimming Pool Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); WITNESSES (90%); TESTIMONY (90%); MAGISTRATES (78%); EVIDENCE (78%); CROSS EXAMINATIONS (78%); BUILDING RENOVATION (69%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: STATE witnesses battled to keep their heads above water yesterday on the first day of the corruption trial of former Namibia Wildlife Resorts (NWR) MD Tobie Aupindi. Aupindi and Antonio di Savino, his co-accused, pleaded not guilty to a charge of corruption and an alternative charge of attempting to defeat or obstruct the course of justice. The State alleges that Di Savino paid for a swimming pool for Aupindi in 2006. Di Savino allegedly forked out N$50 000 for the pool at Aupindi's Hochland Park residence, Herman Kuhn testified yesterday. Kuhn works for LIC Pool Centre. He claimed that Di Savino approached him to buy a pool in December 2006. Although he initially told Di Savino that he would not be able to install the swimming pool because of a tight December schedule, he later agreed to do so. This was allegedly done at an additional cost of N$12 000. During cross-examination by Aupindi's lawyer Richard Metcalfe, Kuhn was less sure of his version. He agreed that documentation on which he based his side of the story was prepared by someone else at LIC Pool Centre. Moreover, he could not explain two payments of N$25 000 to their business. This, Metcalfe argued, was money that Aupindi paid himself and that Di Savino in fact did not pay for Aupindi's swimming pool. Kuhn went as far as admitting that he manipulated and changed documents but "only when asked". Guiseppe Ditrapani, who was allegedly first approached by Di Savino to install a pool at Aupindi's house, battled to remember the dates on which what happened. What was not disputed was that he received N$38 000 from Di Savino but was later told to vacate Aupindi's premises - seemingly after he took too long to install the pool. Of the N$38 000, Ditrapani later returned N$33 000 to Di Savino. The trial before Magistrate Helvi Shilemba is scheduled to continue today. Aupindi appeared confident throughout yesterday's proceedings. Before the start of the trial, he told The Namibian that he was "excited and fired-up inside. It's good that there is a legislative framework to fight corruption. But it's up to them to prove their case." In May last year, an anti-graft website Corruption Watch Namibia reported that documents in its possession show that Di Savino had forked out N$50 000 for the state-of-the-art pool installed at Aupindi's house. Di Savino allegedly paid for the pool with a cheque on December 12 2006. It is alleged that this 'gift' came at a price - tenders to refurbish the beleaguered parastatal's run-down resorts. The NWR, during Aupindi's tenure, came under fire for not employing professional engineers to manage the multimillion-dollar renovation projects. One such company which NWR also appointed was Tane Mahuta - a company which evaded tax. In April 2010, The Namibian reported that Tane Mahuta failed to pay a single cent in income tax despite cashing in at least N$40 million from NWR. This was for work done at Ai-Ais - approximately N$37 million, and at the Sesriem Campsite - around N$5 million. It was reported that Aupindi instructed an employee to pay the amounts to Tane Mahuta while a substantial part of the upgrading work had not yet been done. Furthermore, the budget for Ai-Ais alone had been overspent by at least N$10 million. In February 2010, it was reported that Aupindi had been pocketing hefty sums in board fees. The Namibian then reported that he had raked in close to N$80 000 between 2007 and 2008.

TITLE: ACC Rejects Mariental Corruption Claims
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (92%); CORRUPTION (92%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); CITIES (88%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (87%); MISAPPROPRIATION (72%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (70%); EXECUTIVES (53%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: THE Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) will not investigate allegations of corruption made by residents against the Mariental municipality. In a petition recently handed over to the town council, the residents accused it of misappropriating money earmarked for structural development. They said N$10 million Government had allocated through its Targeted Intervention Programme for Employment and Economic Growth (Tipeeg) for the construction of toilets had gone missing. Calling on the ACC to investigate their claims of mismanagement, the residents maintained the council had spent the money on paying its water and electricity bill. The council's chief executive officer, Paul Nghiwilepo, forwarded the petition to the ACC. However, the ACC said in a letter dated February 3: "The unsubstantiated general allegations contained in the petition do not constitute sufficient grounds for investigation by ACC. "In order for ACC to consider whether there are reasonable grounds for investigation, those making allegations can lodge formal complaints which must be supported by potential proof what they are alleging."

TITLE: Over 48 Percent Corruption Cases Completed
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); SUPREME COURTS (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (79%); JUDGES (79%); BRIBERY (78%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (75%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: Courts cleared 48.5 percent of cases related to corruption this week, the Spokesperson of the Judiciary, Charles Kaliwabo, confirmed yesterday Of the 66 corruption-related cases that are before courts, Kaliwabo said that 34 were closed during the just-concluded week that was dedicated to fighting against corruption within the judiciary. The move to clear corruption cases was part of the Supreme Courts campaign against corruption, which started Monday this week and ended yesterday. Kaliwabo revealed this while speaking to journalists, shortly before a procession of all employees in the justice sector, which marked the end of this year's Supreme Court campaign against the vice. "We had planned to clear all the cases by the end of this week, but today's report is yet to be released," he said. "The campaign has yielded positive results since it started, but there is need for more efforts to effectively fight this vice," he said. Last year's campaign saw eight judicial employees - including six judges - suspended on corruption-related cases. Between 2009 and 2011, 14 people were also arrested for attempting to bribe judges. This year's campaign was taken to villages, the lowest governance level, where the public were sensitised how to partner with the judiciary in the fight against the vice. "We want the public to know that we are ready to work with them to end corruption. Those who say that the justice sector is built on corruption are just tarnishing our image," he observed. Chief Justice Sam Rugege led a procession that brought together employees from all justice institutions, including the Ombudsman office, prosecution and the Ministry of Justice. Others included police, judges and lawyers Rugege was accompanied by his predecessor, Aloysie Cyanzayire, the President of the High Court, Johnston Busingye, and Augustin Nzindukiyimana, the acting Ombudsman.

TITLE: Sharing Best Practices Will Help Curb Corruption in EAC [editorial]
COUNTRY: EASTERN AFRICA (94%); AFRICA (93%); RWANDA (90%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (90%) East Africa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); BEST PRACTICES (74%); NONTARIFF BARRIERS (66%); WHISTLEBLOWER PROTECTION (56%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: Members of the East African Community (EAC) Sectoral Committee on Combating Corruption met in Tanzania last week, to review the progress made in the region's quest to eradicate corruption. Among other things, participants urged partner states to provide more funding towards anti-graft programmes and mechanisms, and to do more to protect whistle blowers. While it was noted that partner states had taken positive steps to address corruption, various weaknesses were identified including the fact that, in some countries, anti-corruption watchdogs were themselves corrupt. The meeting came at a time when some EAC states ranked so poorly on the Transparency International's global corruption index, with only Rwanda belonging to what is known as 'Africa's clean states'. However, with concerted efforts, experience sharing and close follow-up on the agreed measures, the EAC can go a long way in addressing one of the main threats to business and service delivery in the region. East Africans, particularly traders, have repeatedly cited corruption among the main Non-Tariff Barriers (NTBs), which increase the cost of doing business with the final consumer bearing the ultimate burden. It is important that EAC member states learn from each other's experiences so that successful measures in one country are replicated in the others to ensure better results.

TITLE: Khorixas Residents to March Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); CITY GOVERNMENT (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CITIES (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (90%); CONSTRUCTION (88%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (87%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (86%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (73%); EXECUTIVES (72%); CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTING (71%); ARRESTS (70%) Namibia; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Khorixas residents will take to the streets today to demand the axing of town council employees implicated in the disappearance of about N$400 000 at the council. The town's chief executive officer, Nicodemus Gaeseb, housing department head Daniel Geiseb, Eben Xoagub, Swapo councillor Jeremias Kheimseb, Sipho Ganeb, a local preacher, Barry Goamub and Xoagub's wife were arrested in October last year by the Anti-Corruption Commission in connection with a fictitious construction tender. The demonstrators will also call on local councillors, of the United Democratic Front and Swapo alike, to resign because they are allegedly condoning corrupt practices by council officials. Sakarias Dawids, who is organising the demonstration, says the mayor, Andries !Aebeb has the power to suspend corrupt officials but has failed to do so. New allegations of financial irregularities have been made against the council. Xoagub, who is an accused in the N$400 000 fraud, and who heads the finance department, has confirmed that there are "irregularities" but would not reveal the amount involved.

TITLE: Khorixas Residents Rally Against Corruption
SUBJECT: EXECUTIVES (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CITIES (90%); PROTESTS & DEMONSTRATIONS (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); MAYORS (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); PETITIONS (89%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (78%); COMMUNITY ACTIVISM (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (71%); SOCCER (57%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: ABOUT 500 Khorixas residents yesterday demonstrated against corruption at the local council, calling for the removal of the chief executive officer. The demonstrators in no uncertain terms called for the current CEO Nicodemus Gaeseb to be replaced with a new chief executive. The unhappy residents met at Eddie Bowe soccer field early in the morning before marching through the informal settlement of Donkerhoek to the Khorixas Town Council under the leadership of community activist Romeo Nauseb. "Money given by the central government is sent back to Windhoek, while no development takes place at Khorixas," Nauseb told The Namibian. \Nauseb also alleged that "most of the tenders given through the Khorixas Town Council mainly benefit family members and friends of those on the council". He further said although millions of dollars had been budgeted for a prepaid water system in 2008, nothing has been done. The demonstrators also questioned the suspension three weeks ago of the head of finance, Gerhard Amingo /Honneb, and the resignation of Pasquela Ouses, a revenue collection clerk. /Honneb's suspension comes amidst calls for the axing of three officials of the council who have been charged by the Anti-Corruption Commission with the disappearance of about N$400 000 at the council. The three officials allegedly have become untouchables at the council, with the town councillors allegedly refusing to take action against them. "Those who talk the truth like /Honneb are suspended," one of the demonstrators shouted. When the demonstrators arrived at the Khorixas Town Council building, the situation was tense, as they refused to hand over their petition to CEO Gaeseb. "We want the mayor, Andries !Aebeb, or the deputy mayor, Moloto, to take the petition," they chanted, closely monitored by armed Police. Some protesters threw stones at the council offices before the Police intervened. After much argument between the CEO and the demonstrators and with the intervention of the Police the petition was later handed to the CEO, who promised to forward it to the Minister of Regional, Local Government and Housing, Jerry Ekandjo, to whom it is addressed. At one stage Gaeseb requested the Police to remove the demonstrators, since they had not notified the council of their demonstration and the handing over of a petition. Accepting the petition, Gaeseb said: "Thank you Khorixas residents who are concerned about the town. Your problems are our problems. I will take it up to the highest office; give us time to go through it." Asked about the allegations in the petition, Gaeseb said: "I cannot talk about them now, but someone else will investigate me and reveal them." The petitioners also called on an investigation into Aqua Expresso, which was given the contract for the prepaid water system. The Build Together Programme was also on the petition, as the residents are angry over the way it has been handled.

TITLE: Country Ready for Oil Riches Amid Corruption Fears
COUNTRY: UGANDA (95%); AFRICA (94%); ANGOLA (92%); EQUATORIAL GUINEA (92%); NIGERIA (92%); CHINA (79%); NAMIBIA (79%); FRANCE (72%)
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); AGREEMENTS (90%); CRUDE OIL & NATURAL GAS EXTRACTION (89%); OIL EXPLORATION (89%); OIL EXTRACTION (89%); OIL & GAS EXTRACTION (89%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (89%); OIL & GAS EXPLORATION (78%); PETITIONS (78%); COMMUNITY ACTIVISM (77%); ALTERNATIVE DISPUTE RESOLUTION (75%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (74%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (73%); POLLUTION & ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS (72%); LEGISLATION (71%); EXECUTIVES (70%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (67%) Uganda; Namibia; Corruption; Petroleum; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Environment
TEXT: Uganda's government has signed long-delayed licenses that would make it Africa's newest oil-producing nation defying court cases, legislators and growing concerns that the new riches will bring more corruption and pollution. The deal with Anglo-Irish company Tullow Oil lacks transparency, contend critics who do not want to see Uganda go the way of other African countries like Nigeria, Equatorial Guinea and Angola, where a small elite became fabulously wealthy off petroleum while most citizens remained deeply impoverished Dickens Kamugisha, CEO of the Uganda-based Africa Institute for Energy Governance, complained that the agreements between the government and the oil companies are secret, and so are environmental and feasibility studies. Uganda's High Court is to hear a petition March 5, filed by Kampala lawyer Hamada Mulumba as a concerned citizen in December, asking the court to temporarily halt the government from signing any oil deals. But earlier this month, after more than a year of acrimonious negotiations, the government signed two licenses with London-based Tullow Oil. The agreements, worth US$2,9 billion, allow Tullow to sell two-thirds of its Uganda interests to China's CNOOC Ltd and France's Total. Tullow agreed the oil would be refined in Uganda and not exported as crude. Ugandan legislators resolved three months ago that all oil contracts should be suspended until Parliament puts in place laws and institutions to ensure transparency in the industry. Still, the deal with Tullow Oil was inked. Government spokesman Fred Opolot said the government "is not bound by parliamentary resolutions, which are advisory". A spokeswoman for Tullow Oil, Kate Lehane, said the government of Uganda decided the timing of the deal. "Tullow is dealing with the government of Uganda and the executive," she said. "Tullow remain very keen to talk to Parliament." Kamugisha said civil society organizations are threatening to work with international partners to blacklist Tullow as they threaten to challenge the legality of the agreements at the Constitutional Court. Oil Network Uganda, an activist civil group, is mobilising communities to oppose the construction of any refinery or pipelines until a new law is enacted to provide proper compensation, resettlement and conflict resolution to those affected or displaced by the project, said Henry Mugisha, chairman of the group. Eleven residents who say they have lost grazing grounds and harvests during drilling for oil exploration are threatening to sue Tullow. The company says it has paid about 38 000 claims for structures and crops damaged during its exploration for oil but farmers complain it took months to get paid and that the rates were too low at just over US$1 for each square meter of a cassava plantation. Orchards of mangoes and oranges also have been lost. Tullow declined to say how much it had paid in total compensation. Community activist Isaac Nkuba of the Buliisa NGO forum said the damage occurred in January 2011 and people were only paid last November and December. Francis Beeta, a farmer who was paid nearly US$340 for his destroyed cassava plantation said: "We are angry because we feel like we have been cheated." Uganda issued its first oil exploration license in 1902 when it was a British colony, according to Fred Guweddeko, a Makerere University research fellow. The poor quality of the waxy and sulfur-laden oil kept companies from pumping it out until new technology and high oil prices made it viable. Now drilling rigs for test holes have been sprouting on Uganda's landscape. Conservative estimates suggest Uganda could earn around US$2 billion a year for the next 30 to 35 years from the deposits, which lie below forests and lakes along a border with conflict-torn eastern Congo. Despite the efforts at gaining transparency, skepticism is running high that the Uganda's oil will better the lives of its regular citizens. Uganda's government has made huge stride fighting poverty, with about 25 per cent of the population living below the poverty line in 2010, according to the World Bank, but the country is struggling with a growing gap between rich and poor. "All signs are that Uganda will be the latest nation to fall victim to the 'oil curse' - cheated of its financial benefits by a corrupt government and left with extensive environmental damage," said Uganda's Association of Professional Environmentalists. Critics are already complaining that more than US$300 000 paid in signature bonuses on oil contracts already have gone missing. Legislators have accused the prime minister and two Cabinet ministers of taking millions of dollars in bribes from Tullow - charges Tullow denies. Two long-serving Cabinet ministers and stalwarts of President Yoweri Museveni resigned this week over graft allegations unrelated to oil. Three other ministers were forced to resign last year because of corruption allegations. Museveni has been in power since 1986. The Constitutional Court has barred legislators from investigating their charges while it rules on a motion that the parliamentarians' investigation is improper and out of order. Tullow spokesman George Casanove said documents presented to Parliament are "forgeries, unquestionably and irrefutably". He said the company is looking forward to demonstrating that publicly when it is summoned to appear before the parliamentary committee. He said the company does not know who made the forgeries, or what the motivation was. Still, legislators and activists also are angry with Tullow, and the issue has divided legislators from the president's party. Ugandan newspapers report that some have had a change of heart though because of a new US$40 000 allowance to buy cars. "The culpability of government is obvious but so is the role of Tullow," said Ssekikubo, a legislator from Museveni's party. "If you promote the breakdown of the rule and law in the country of your interest, how will you ensure that your interests are covered?"

TITLE: Ruling Delivers Blow to Corruption Act
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (90%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (90%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (78%); LITIGATION (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%); CRIME PREVENTION (71%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: A KEY part of Namibia's Anti-Corruption Act is unconstitutional, it was ruled in the High Court in Windhoek yesterday. The definition of "corruptly" in the Anti-Corruption Act is unconstitutional because it is "unduly vague", Judges Dave Smuts and Elton Hoff and Acting Judge Kobus Miller ruled in a case in which the constitutionality of sections of the Anti-Corruption Act and the Prevention of Organised Crime Act (POCA) was under attack. At the same time, the constitutionality of the dual appointment of Cabinet member Pendukeni Iivula-Ithana as Justice Minister and Attorney General in 2005 was also being questioned. While the three judges struck down the definition of "corruptly" as unconstitutional, they dismissed the attacks on the constitutionality of other sections of the Anti-Corruption Act and POCA, and ruled that the appointment of Iivula-Ithana as both Attorney General and Minister of Justice was not unconstitutional. Although the court's ruling is a blow to the Anti-Corruption Act, it is not a fatal one. The remainder of the Anti-Corruption Act remains intact, and it would be up to courts to interpret what is meant by the word "corruptly" where it is used in other parts of that law, it is indicated in the court's judgement, which was written by Judge Smuts. "In doing so, the courts would have regard as to how the term is understood including its dictionary definition, its definitions in international instruments and how it has been interpreted by this or other courts in giving content to that concept," the judge said. The judgement was delivered in an application which fraud and money laundering suspects Teckla Lameck and Kongo Mokaxwa filed with the High Court in March last year. Lameck and Mokaxwa attacked the Anti-Corruption Act's definition of the term "corruptly" as being unreasonable, vague and too wide. The Act defines "corruptly" as meaning "in contravention of or against the spirit of any law, provision, rule, procedure, process, system, policy, practice, directive, order or any other term or condition pertaining to any employment relationship; any agreement; or the performance of any function in whatever capacity". Senior counsel Jeremy Gauntlett, representing Lameck and Mokaxwa, argued during the hearing of the application at the end of November last year that policies are not binding legal instruments, that it is difficult to establish what practices are, and that the vagueness of the definition was compounded by the use of the term "against the spirit of", Judge Smuts recounted in the judgement. Gauntlett further argued that the Anti-Corruption Act's definition of "gratification", which was also attacked, was limitless and was unreasonably and impermissibly wide, the judge also recounted. He remarked that he agreed with senior counsel Wim Trengove, representing the President, the Minister of Justice, the Attorney-General, the Prosecutor General and the Director of the Anti-Corruption Commission, that the concept of corruption is something which does not lend itself to neat and precise formulation and delineation. However, the definition of "corruptly", Judge Smuts said, "would seem to me to be unduly vague and (does) not meet the test of indicating with reasonable certainty what is hit by it to those who are bound by it". "The same cannot be said for the definition of gratification," he further stated. "Although wide, it is not in my view unduly vague." The Act's definition of "gratification" is a lengthy one, and includes "money or any gift, loan, fee, reward, commission, valuable security or property or interest in property of any description, whether movable or immovable", "any office, dignity, employment, contract of employment or services and any agreement to give employment or render services in any capacity", "any valuable consideration or benefit of any kind, any discount, commission, rebate, bonus, deduction or percentage", "any right or privilege", and so forth. The attack on Iivula-Ithana's appointment as both Attorney General and Minister of Justice was aimed at the Justice Minister's fixing of May 5 2009 as the date when POCA came into operation. Gauntlett's argument was that because she could not hold both those posts at the same time, she could not validly put the law into operation, and thus it is not legally in force yet. His argument was rejected. The Attorney General is - like any member of the Cabinet - a political appointee who holds office at the President's pleasure, Judge Smuts found. The Attorney General's powers and functions would not be incompatible with membership of the Cabinet, and given the wide powers of appointment vested in the President it would not be in conflict with the Constitution for the President to appoint a minister as Attorney General or appoint the Attorney General as a member of the Cabinet, if he or she is a member of the National Assembly as required, the judge said. The constitutional challenge to POCA was based mainly on an argument that the law was retrospectively criminalising and imposing penalties for conduct which had been lawful when it was committed. What POCA actually does, Judge Smuts found, is to criminalise the current possession, use or acquisition of the proceeds of unlawful activities, and not the original conduct which rendered those proceeds as unlawful. In the context of the whole application Lameck and Mokaxwa did not achieve substantial success, Judge Smuts commented. As a result, he ordered that they should bear 80 per cent of their opponents' legal costs in the matter, while the respondents should pay 20 per cent of Lameck and Mokaxwa's legal costs. Lameck, Mokaxwa and Chinese national Yang Fan are facing charges over an alleged corrupt deal in which Chinese-made security scanning equipment was bought by the Ministry of Finance in 2008. It is alleged that the price of the equipment was inflated to enable the manufacturer of the equipment, Nuctech, which was being represented by Yang, to pay a "commission" of at least US$12,828 million to Teko Trading, a close corporation of Lameck and Mokaxwa.

TITLE: African Countries Urged to Emulate Country's Anti-Corruption Drive
COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); RWANDA (94%); MAURITIUS (79%); CAPE VERDE (79%); BOTSWANA (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (77%); ECONOMIC NEWS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (77%); SCANDALS (73%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (73%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (72%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (70%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: A regional meeting bringing together experts to explore the best possible ways to combat corruption on the African continent, have hailed Rwanda's policies against graft. Prof. Said Adejumobi, Officer in Charge Public Administration Division GPAD at the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA), urged African countries still engaging in corruption scandals to emulate Rwanda's anti-graft efforts. "Rwanda serves as the best example due the country's interlinked good governance policies and strong anti-graft strategies," he added. The two-day forum, in Kigali, says all stakeholders need to be strategically drafted in intervention programmes. Dr. Edward G. Hoseah, the Director General, Tanzania Prevention and Combating Corruption Bureau, said that graft in Africa remains a threat to good governance and development. "Africa loses more than US$148 billion annually, or 25 percent of its GDP, as a result of corruption. The unrelenting spread of corruption has not helped our continent's image and growth perspectives," he asserted. Hoseah stated that strong partnership is highly needed between the African Union (AU) and the continent's anti-graft institutions to reduce or eradicate loopholes of corruption in Africa. He pointed out that 31 out of 54 countries in Africa have ratified the AU convention to combat corruption in Africa. "We call upon those nations who have not ratified the convention to do it urgently. If we rally behind the principle and strengthen our cooperation, we can eliminate the vice," he noted. The meeting was organised by UNECA, through the Governance and Public Administration Division (GPAD), in collaboration with the Africa Union Advisory Board on Corruption (AUABC). The forum will be followed by an expert meeting on illicit financial outflows for Africa from 23 to 24 February. Rwanda's Augustine Nzindukiyimana, the acting Ombudsman, observed that it was high time African governments found a lasting solution to corruption which has crippled development in the continent. "Rwanda is committed to eradicating corruption. We have consistently dealt with graft cases," he noted. Rwanda was ranked fourth least corrupt African country by the World Bank Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI) project according to the report released late last year. The country scored 70.8 percent, the fourth highest score, behind Mauritius with 73.2 percent, Cape Verde with 74.6 percent and Botswana which is the least corrupt African country with a score of 79.9percent.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission to Release VP Sumana/Aljazeera Findings
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (93%); CORRUPTION (90%); JOURNALISM (90%); NEWS REPORTING (87%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); WRITERS (72%); DOCUMENTARY FILMS (68%); FORESTRY & LOGGING TRADE (67%); EXPORT TRADE (50%) Sierra Leone; Governance; Press and Media; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Labour
TEXT: Commissioner of the Anti-Corruption Commission, ACC has disclosed that after a rigorous investigation process, the commission has collected enough evidence on the Aljazeera TV allegations on some senior government officials in the country for presentation to the public soon. Making the revelation yesterday at the ACC headquarters in Freetown, Joseph F. Kamara said great effort was made to ensure that a credible report was made available to the public. "Some time ago, the government asked the ACC and the Sierra Leone police to investigate the Aljazeera saga," the ACC boss briefed newsmen, stressing that his commission will ensure appropriate actions are instituted against those found wanting. "This is a matter we have been working on over the past months and the commission has travelled even out of the country to investigate and very soon our investigation will be made public." It would be recalled that late last year, Aljazeera news network screened a documentary revealing a timber deal that allegedly transpired between undercover journalists and two men, Alex Mansaray and Momoh Konte, who were linked to the VP's office. The journalists visited Vice President Sam-Sumana's office posing as businessmen; they met with the VP and the two men who claimed to be official advisors to the vice president. Later the two men sought and accepted cash payments from the 'businessmen', which they claimed would help secure the VP's support for a timber export business that the undercover reporters wished to establish.

TITLE: ZRP Stresses Zero-Tolerance to Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); ETHICS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (68%); ELECTIONS (67%); REFERENDUMS (67%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Zimbabwe Republic Police will not hesitate to crack the whip on its members found engaging in corrupt activities. Deputy Commissioner-General Levie Sibanda on Tuesday urged all police spokespersons countrywide to take a leading role in the fight against corruption. He was speaking at the official opening of the 2012 Press and Public Relations workshop in Harare. "I would like to urge you to take a leading role in the fight against corruption, hence collective effort is required to rid the police of all members who engage in corrupt activities," Deputy Comm-Gen Sibanda said. He said officers should always remember that discipline and moral uprightness were pivotal to all their policing endeavours. Deputy Comm-Gen Sibanda said the workshop afforded them a vital platform to enhance effective and efficient interface between the ZRP and the public. He said the workshop came at a time when the nation was preparing for a referendum and general elections. "Honestly, the success of these important processes is hinged on your professional application of public relations ethics, morals and norms, which foster constructive interaction between the organisation and its stakeholders," he said. He applauded the press and public relations section for defying all odds and remaining resolute in portraying the positive image of the force.

TITLE: Health for All Opens its Books to Anti-Corruption Commission
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); AGREEMENTS (91%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (78%); HEALTH CARE POLICY (78%); ALLIANCES & PARTNERSHIPS (77%); STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS (77%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (76%); EXECUTIVES (73%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Health and Medicine
TEXT: Leading civil society advocate for President Koroma's free health care scheme, Health For All Coalition, HFAC on Friday signed a memorandum of understanding with the Anti-Corruption Commission, ACC to form a strategic partnership in the monitoring and implementation of the free health care initiative nationwide. The agreement is to establish a broader framework and principles of close collaboration on issues of mutual interest between the two leading organizations. HFAC executive director, Charles Mambu, said his organization had earlier requested ACC officials to conduct a system review of his institution so as to guide its projects implementation processes, noting that the partnership would ensure that the free health care plan becomes more effective and in the interest of Sierra Leoneans. "Health For All and the ACC are two separate institutions with programme objectives rooted in support for accountability, transparency and empowerment to enhance service delivery," Mambu said, citing that his institution has received enormous support from UNFPA, DfID and the government of Sierra Leone through the ministry of health and sanitation for the past years. "The two institutions will therefore make critical impact by cooperating in all areas of joint focus interest. It is against this backdrop that we have freely entered into this agreement," he said. While signing the agreement, ACC Commissioner, Joseph F. Kamara said fighting corruption should be a collective responsibility and that his institution is ready to enter into an agreement based on its credibility so that corruption will be minimized in the society. "Today is an important day for all of us because this is one of the many ways we can tackle corruption in the country," he said. "Health For All has been working with us over the years and it is our fervent hope that this partnership will help us in minimizing corruption in Sierra Leone."

TITLE: Tobie Must Explain 'Pool Corruption'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); EVIDENCE (78%); TESTIMONY (78%); BRIBERY (78%); TRIAL & PROCEDURE (75%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (75%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (74%); FREELANCE EMPLOYMENT (68%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: FORMER Namibia Wildlife Resorts (NWR) boss Tobie Aupindi on Friday heard that he and co-accused Antonio di Savino need to defend the allegations of corruption against them. Magistrate Helvi Shilemba dismissed the men's application for a discharge "and the accused are placed on their defence to explain". At the close of the State's case, Richard Metcalfe for Aupindi and Louis du Pisani for Di Savino asked for the discharge of their clients. In terms of the Criminal Procedure Act, an accused should be discharged at the end of the State's case if there is no evidence before the court that the accused committed the offences they are charged with. The application came after Metcalfe earlier argued that Aupindi's prosecution stems from a personal vendetta by freelance journalist John Grobler. Metcalfe told the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) investigating officer, William Lloyd, that it appears as if a website article written by Grobler was based on Lloyd's docket. "It seems as if this man [Grobler] has intimate knowledge of the ACC and it looks like he had a copy of the docket." This article appeared before the Prosecutor General had decided to charge Aupindi and co-accused Antonio di Savino, Metcalfe charged. Lloyd maintained that he "never made contact with this guy [Grobler] in my life". He conceded that, based on articles that Metcalfe read out in court, it appears that Grobler "is angry with Mr Aupindi". Metcalfe told the investigating officer that Grobler "seems to have gone on a mission to crucify Aupindi". Metcalfe further grilled Lloyd for never taking a statement from Michael Kuhn, owner of LIC Pool Centre CC. Lloyd only took a statement from Herman Kuhn, Michael's brother, in which it was alleged that Di Savino had paid N$50 000 for installing the pool at Aupindi's Hochland Park house. Michael Kuhn, on the other hand, said Aupindi had paid cash for the pool. Aupindi and Di Savino went on trial for allegedly lying to Lloyd about who footed the pool bill. Lloyd claims that information given to the ACC suggested that Di Savino bought Aupindi the swimming pool as a gift in exchange for NWR tenders. As part of the investigation, Lloyd also had to follow up information from a media source provided to the ACC Director, Paulus Noa, the investigation officer said. Because he did not deal with this source directly, he could not say whether it was Grobler. Lloyd, during his testimony, also claimed that Aupindi and Di Savino had made "confusing statements" to him. In the end, it was decided not to pursue the claims of kickbacks as the ACC could not obtain sufficient documentation to corroborate the allegations, Lloyd said. Both Aupindi and Di Savino pleaded not guilty to a charge of corruption as well as an alternative charge of attempting to defeat or obstruct the course of justice at the start of the trial. Public Prosecutor Arrie Husselmann acts on behalf of the State. On Friday, Shilemba postponed the case until March 19 for the continuation of the trial.

TITLE: Former Regional President to See Regular Trial Over Alleged Corruption
SUBJECT: MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (90%); EVIDENCE (90%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); LITIGATION (90%); APPEALS (90%); BRIBERY (89%); TRIAL & PROCEDURE (79%); JUDGES (79%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); CRIMINAL DEFENSES (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (76%); LAWYERS (75%); BOARDING SCHOOLS (75%); PRIVATE SCHOOLS (74%); CONSULTING SERVICES (73%); VOCATIONAL & TECHNICAL TRAINING (69%); CONSTRUCTION DELAYS & STOPPAGES (69%); TEACHER EDUCATION (69%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Judges at the Federal High Court ruled last week in the case of Yaregal Aysehshume, former president of Benishangul Gumuz Regional State, who was also an MP and director general of the Federal Cooperative Agency, and six other defendants charged for alleged corruption, for them to go through normal trial procedures. The case has been under summery charge ever since law enforcement agencies arrested Yaregal and his co-defendants in October 2010, accused of abuse of office, concealment of unearned assets, and corruption. The Court has been conducting the case in a preliminary inquiry since then, in which public prosecutors presented 27 pages of charges, with material and testimonial evidence. The defendants, including Habtamu Hika, former chief of the Region's Education Bureau; Gezahegn Adegeh, general manager of Gad Construction; Gedion Demeke, general manager of Gedion Demeke Consultancy; Mekbib Moges, general manager of Colon Construction; Assefa Gebeyehu; and Hailegebriel Hika, a younger brother of Habtamu, also presented their statement of defence. Requesting that both parties present their evidence, Presiding Judge Abohoy Guade, adjourned the case to June 12, 2012, despite appeals from the defence lawyers for the time to be shorter. Family members of the defendants who crowded almost half of the spacious Federal High Court 15th Criminal Bench hall, on Chad Street, were not pleased. Yaregal's wife, Tigist Bekele, was among the family members seen crying in the courtroom. Defendants were charged for allegedly tampering with the bid process for the construction of three educational institutions, whose costs were funded from the federal subsidiary budget given to the Regional State in 2006. This resulted in the delay of construction, which was supposed to be completed within a year. Tana Beles, a boarding school for women, Gilgel Beles Teachers Training College; and Assosa Technical & Vocational Education & Training (TVET) Centre were the institutions planned to be constructed in the five zones of the Regional State during the presidency of Yaregal. Yaregal and Habtamu had allegedly handed over the design and supervision work of the three projects to Gedion Demeke Consultancy, without a competitive public bid, while Gezahegn is charged for allegedly receiving construction work for Gilgel Beles upon paying three million Birr to Yaregal and Habtamu, in kickbacks. Mekbib Moges is also charged for receiving the construction work of Assosa TVET, paying 700,000 Br to Yaregal in bribes.

TITLE: Jacobs's Corruption Case Postponed
SUBJECT: DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (91%); MAGISTRATES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (53%); CATERING SERVICES (51%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: KEETMANSHOOP Regional Court Magistrate Sunsley Zisengwe yesterday granted another postponement at the request of former Karas chief regional officer Salmaan Jacobs, who faces five counts of corruption. It was Jacobs's second appearance in court this week. Zisengwe on Monday ordered Jacobs to obtain legal representation within 24 hours. Jacobs told the court that his previous lawyer, Lot Haifidi, had withdrawn from the case because of "miscommunications" over his fees. Zisengwe yesterday granted a final postponement until July 30 following a written request by Haifidi to postpone the case to allow Jacobs to raise the money he owed him [Haifidi] for three months of legal representation. Haifidi said he could not proceed with the trial this week because he is busy with High Court cases. State Prosecutor Veiko Alexander did not oppose the postponement although he indicated that the State was ready to proceed. Jacobs, who now holds a senior position in the Foreign Affairs Ministry, allegedly defrauded the Karas Regional Council of close to N$32 000 after he had claimed N$49 020 for attending a month-long, all-expenses-paid workshop in Germany. Two other counts originated from a catering contract Jacobs had awarded as the council's tender board chairman to Sadadi Enterprise, a company he had an interest in, in October and November 2006. The remaining count stems from a payment made from the Karas Regional Council's account to Sadadi Enterprise on the pretext that the money was meant for a community garden at Berseba.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Probes Sorensen, Amunyela Land Deal
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); INVESTIGATIONS (91%); EXTORTION (90%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (87%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LAWYERS (77%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (75%); EXECUTIVES (73%); RACISM & XENOPHOBIA (72%); RESTAURANTS (72%); RURAL COMMUNITIES (59%) Namibia; Land and Rural Issues; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: PAULUS Noa, the director of the Anti-Corruption Commission, yesterday confirmed that the ACC is investigating a land deal between businessmen Vincent Sorensen and Desmond Amunyela. Noa said the aim is to get to the bottom of allegations made in extortion claims against Amunyela. "We want to establish whether proper procedures were followed," he said. In an affidavit, property bigwig Sorensen claims that Amunyela wanted to extort money from him. He wants the Police to investigate this alleged extortion and corruption. Amunyela denied the allegations. Late last year, Amunyela dragged AroVin to court for N$1,4 million, which Amunyela claims is owed to him in compensation for a property deal in 2007. Amunyela, an executive director at Paragon Investment Holdings, said he facilitated a deal for a Kleine Kuppe property in 2007 for AroVin - an outfit jointly owned by Sorensen and Aaron Mushimba. Sorensen paid N$700 000 to Amunyela in March last year after the two met following an allegedly racist incident in a local restaurant. Sorensen stated in court documents last year that he made the payment after Amunyela had promised to withdraw criminal charges against him. Sorensen further claimed that Amunyela undertook to use "his newspaper", the Windhoek Observer, to try and restore Sorensen's name. But, according to Sorensen's latest affidavit, it appears that Amunyela had no such plans and in fact allegedly wanted to extort more money from him. In October last year in the High Court, Sisa Namandje, Amunyela's lawyer, said claims that Sorensen made the N$700 000 payment under duress should be ignored, as there was no actual violence or reasonable fear. Moreover, relying on Amunyela withdrawing criminal charges against Sorensen for an alleged racist incident would "amount to a crime of compounding in our law" as the Prosecutor General has the final authority on case withdrawals in Namibia, Namandje told Acting Judge Andrew Corbett. In February last year, Sorensen drove past Paragon Investment Holdings "and noticed a massive depiction of erstwhile President Sam Nujoma displayed on the face of the building with the words 'let the revolution continue' displayed above it". He says he "was irked by the display, as it is [his] belief that Mr Amunyela's ill-placed public purported devotion to the founding father of Namibia is aimed at furthering his own considerable political and financial ambitions". Later that evening, Sorensen was dining at O'Portuga restaurant when he noticed that Amunyela was also there. He sent Amunyela a handwritten note which stated: "Desmond, the effigy of our founding president is impressive. Unfortunately, the fact that your head is not visibly sticking out of his ass is unrealistic." The result of this incident was a public debacle during which Joel Kaapanda, the Minister of Information and Communication Technology, also lashed out at Sorensen. Amunyela's lawyer earlier said the N$700 000 payment was the first instalment of the N$2,1 million commission owed to Amunyela for his role in the tender process of the erf for AroVin. According to Noa, it is this deal that they are probing. He could not say how long the investigation would take. The judgment in the civil matter has not been delivered yet.

TITLE: Corruption in Country 'Chronic'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ELECTIONS (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (75%); VOTERS & VOTING (71%); REFUGEES (69%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: THE Namibian Government pays mere lip service to the fight against corruption and graft has become "chronic", Jesaya Nyamu, Rally for Democracy and Progress (RDP) secretary general, said this week. According to him, corruption "is affecting the society from top to bottom". Nyamu called on the country's young voters to confront Government about corruption and not to vote for Swapo during the next elections. Also, the opposition leader said, Namibians need "to stand up and join us in the relentless fight against corruption". Apart from graft, Namibians also battle to cope with "rampant unemployment and poverty". Nyamu further urged Government "to show compassion and leniency" and ensure that Namibian refugees are repatriated. The RDP praised Namibians for having maintained peace and stability over the past 22 years. Challenges which the country faces are of such a nature that they "puts brakes on our development", Congress of Democrats (COD) secretary general Tsudao Gurirab says. "Chief among these challenges are those of uniting all our people around the values of our unitary state committed to treating all its citizens equitably and fairly, as dedicated by our Constitution." Gurirab also lashed out at the "growing scourge of unemployment". "Many in our country are afflicted by the vicissitudes of poverty which is a result of growing unemployment as many drop out of school with no qualifications and thus no prospect of earning a decent living," he said. He urged Government to extend a hand to Zimbabwe "to ensure that our region becomes one of political freedom and economic prosperity".

TITLE: Police Officer Guilty of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); SENTENCING (90%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (90%); CRIMINAL FINES (90%); LITIGATION (90%); JAIL SENTENCING (78%); VERDICTS (78%); MAGISTRATES (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); LARCENY & THEFT (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); ARRESTS (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: A KARIBIB Police officer was sentenced on Tuesday to pay a fine of N$20 000 or spend five years behind bars on a charge of corruption. It all happened in March 2010 when Sergeant Dawid Maronda (42) learned of a pending theft case against a German citizen, Martina Marbach, who was staying in Karibib at the time. Pretending to be the investigating officer in the matter, Maronda telephoned Marbach, informing her that she would not be able to return to her homeland with the pending theft case unless she paid him N$2 000. If she paid him, he would close the case against her. If she did not want to play along, he threatened to arrest her. She gave in to the threat, and the two agreed to meet in Omaruru at the Spar Supermarket, where she would pay him in cash. But she paid him only N$1 000, and promised to pay the rest at a later stage. Maronda met her dressed in full police uniform when he took the money. After the meeting, Marbach informed the local police and Maronda was arrested and charged under the Anti-Corruption Act. He was found guilty on Tuesday in the Omaruru Magistrate's Court.

TITLE: Help Us Stamp Out Corruption - Chikwanda
SUBJECT: AUDITS (93%); ACCOUNTING (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); BOARDS OF DIRECTORS (90%); INTERNAL AUDITS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (70%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (51%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: FINANCE and National Planning Minister, Alexander Chikwanda has called on auditors and the general accounting staff in the Government to help stop corruption and theft of public resources by using stringent control measures. Mr Chikwanda has also called for implementation of recommendations of audit reports from the Office of the Auditor General. The minister said it was not enough for internal auditors to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of operations in institutions without follow-up actions. He said some controlling officers did not appreciate the role of audit committees in the Government and that there was need for a change in attitude and work culture. The minister was speaking at an internal audit forum in Lusaka called to look at effective internal controls and public audit committees. Mr Chikwanda said managements in Government institutions were expected to demonstrate a high level of accountability and transparency in the use of public resources. There would be no accountability, he said, without a strong relationship between the Government and external accountability bodies such as the office of the Auditor General, Parliament, audit committees, civil society organisations and the media. Mr Chikwanda said it was against this background that the Government had facilitated the inclusion of the controller of audits as a permanent witness at the public accounts committee (PAC) to strengthen good corporate governance practices and promote accountability in the use of public resources. "We need to know whether internal accountability is an underestimated issue in Zambia's Government institutions. This will also help inform the public about internal accountability and create awareness on the role of internal audits," Mr Chikwanda said. The gathering was attended by staff from the office of the Auditor General and several internal auditors from the Government and private sector.

TITLE: Maximum Jail Term for Corruption Upped
COUNTRY: ZAMBIA (94%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (92%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (79%); AFRICA (73%)
SUBJECT: LEGISLATION (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (89%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (86%); EDUCATION DEPARTMENTS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (72%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (72%); INVESTIGATIONS (71%); BONE FRACTURES (67%); NEGLIGENCE (67%); MEDICAL MALPRACTICE (65%); HEAD INJURIES (62%); ARRESTS (62%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (54%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (50%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: GOVERNMENT has increased the maximum jail term for corruption convicts from 10 to 14 years with hard labour in an effort to curb the vice. This came to light yesterday when Justice Minister, Sebastian Zulu, presented the revised Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) Bill of 2012 in Parliament. Possession of wealth that was not commensurate with one's earnings has been criminalised under the new proposed law in an effort to promote transparency. He said the 10 years maximum jail term did not work as a deterrent enough and urged parliamentarians to support the Bill which went through second reading. Mr Zulu said corruption distorted the economy by increasing the levels of poverty not only in Zambia but all-over the world.Article 35 of the ACC Act was removed by the MMD government, a move Mr Zulu said was against the aspirations of the Zambian people. He said Parliament should help send a message that corruption would not be tolerated in line with the Southern African Development Community (SADC) Protocol on corruption. Mr Zulu said the new Act also guaranteed the security of tenure for the director general of the ACC and provided steps for the removal of the office holder to avoid abuse. Bweengwa MP Highvie Hamududu told the House that United Party for National Development MPs had resolved to support the Bill because the party held that position even before the elections last year. Legal Affairs Parliamentary Committee chairperson, Jack Mwiimbu, who is Monze Central MP, said stakeholders had made it clear during sittings that they wanted section 35 of the Act reinstated to stiffen the fight against corruption. Meanwhile, Education Minister, John Phiri told Parliament in a ministerial statement that the three Zambian students who were beaten up in Russia during a drinking spree were in serious condition and that one of them had his skull broken. Dr Phiri said four suspects had been arrested by Russian police but court proceedings could not commence because of the condition of the three students. Dr Phiri said Christopher Bwanga sustained a broken skull while Crispin Bwanga had his jaw broken. Leonard Kawanga sustained a deep cut on the head and they were all admitted to a hospital within St Petersburg city. The incident happened on March 18, 2012 when the three went to a bar where a fracas ensued with some ladies and others joined in. Three other Zambians escaped unhurt. And Government is considering the possibility of taking punitive action against management at Chizongwe High Technical School for acting negligently when the pupils mobilised themselves and walked eight kilometers to Chipata town to damage property at Anoya Zulu Secondary School. Dr Phiri said the matter would be investigated to establish whether or not there was negligence on the part of management because it was unlikely that the pupils could evade detection during their plans. Mr Phiri said all the pupils involved in the destruction would be surcharged and that management would determine the modalities. Both Chizongwe and Chiwala Secondary Schools would re-open three weeks earlier than other schools. And Deputy Minister in the Office of the Vice-President, Edgar Lungu, said the eight former district commissioners in Eastern Province had not been fired but removed pending redeployment. This was in response to a question by Malambo MP Maxwell Mwale who had asked the Vice-President's office how many district commissioners had been fired and for what reasons. Home Affairs Minister Kennedy Sakeni told the House that two inmates from Lusaka Central Prison died at the University Teaching Hospital early this month due to cerebra edema and intracerebral haedoorage. He was responding to a question by Kasenegwa MP Victoria Kalima who wanted to know whether the ministry was aware that four inmates died of poisoning at Mukobeko maximum prison.

TITLE: Corruption Corrodes Judiciary
SUBJECT: ETHICS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); JUDICIAL ETHICS (78%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (78%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (77%); VERDICTS (77%); FINES & PENALTIES (71%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: ZIMBABWE'S judiciary is terribly under-funded, fuelling corruption in the justice delivery system, Chief Justice Godfrey Chidyausiku has said. Addressing delegates at the official launch of the code of ethics for judges and the JSC's strategic plan in Harare, Chief Justice Chidyausiku said under-funding also hindered the judiciary's capacity to deliver. "The judiciary is terribly under-funded. This has seriously impaired the capacity of the judiciary to deliver justice. "The under-funding has also contributed in a large measure to corruption in the judiciary, especially at the lower levels of the judiciary. "Regrettably, the Judicial Service Commission has had to accept that the judiciary will never be adequately funded. JSC has no choice but to learn to live with under-funding." "I am extremely concerned at the reports of corruption in the judiciary. These reports, in the main, relate to the lower levels of the judiciary," he said. The Chief Justice proposed improvement of the working conditions for judicial officers and support staff as one of the ways of reducing corruption. "Put differently, the Judicial Service Commission believes that corruption can be rooted out by a policy of 'carrot and stick'. "Wielding the stick alone without the carrot is unlikely to achieve the desired result." The Chief Justice suggested the imposition of severe penalties for those found guilty of corruption as another measure to stem the rot. Justice and Legal Affairs Minister Patrick Chinamasa said corruption was rife in the judiciary and JSC should work towards curbing it. "It cannot be denied that corruption is a cancerous cell eating away the fabric of our justice delivery system. The JSC must initiate strategies to fight it, to eliminate it. 'Judiciary requires adequate funding' "There should be zero tolerance to corruption. I always put it this way: While I can live with the outcome of a court judgment that is bad in law and with a factual basis which has been erroneously arrived at due to incompetence of a judicial officer, I cannot live with an outcome of judgment that has been bought," said Minister Chinamasa. He said he had received reports and complaints from the public accusing the judiciary and other court officials of corruption. "I receive complaints almost daily from members of the public about the shortcomings of our justice delivery system. "I routinely pass these (complaints) to the Acting Secretary of JSC Mrs Rita Makarau. "Members of the public complain about inordinate delays in finalising court matters. They complain of delays in handing down judgments. Allegations have been made that some judgments have taken up to six years to hand down. "I have received complaints galore about court records that develop legs and surreptitiously walk away," said Minister Chinamasa. He said there were reports of important documents that were plucked away from court records. "More seriously, members of the public allege rampant corruption in the courts involving all key players in the justice delivery system. (They include) judicial officers and support staff, clerks, interpreters and the lot of police investigating officers, prosecutors, lawyers in the private sector not to mention touts who impersonate lawyers, prison officers whether in civil and criminal matters," said the minister. The code of ethics, according to the minister, is set to address corruption and other concerns. "The judicial code of ethics half addresses my concerns. "I say 'half addresses' because this is just a small albeit significant step towards eliminating corruption or the perception of corruption in the justice system," said Minister Chinamasa. He urged the commission to methodically and systematically implement the strategic plan and the code of ethics for the betterment of the justice delivery system.

TITLE: Corruption Perceived as Very High
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (78%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); POLLS & SURVEYS (78%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (77%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (77%); POLITICS (76%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (76%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (70%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (68%); SOCIAL SECURITY (66%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (61%); US SOCIAL SECURITY (56%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: MORE than half of Namibians think corruption in the country is very high, while 64 per cent feel that it is not acceptable for a leader to acquire wealth through corruption. This is according to the latest urban corruption perception report compiled by the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) after a survey carried out in all 13 political regions during March last year. The Ministry of Finance was perceived as the most corrupt (11,6 per cent), followed by Home Affairs (9,9%), Safety and Security (9,6 per cent), Education (8,2 per cent), Defence (8 per cent), and Works and Transport (5,7 per cent). Perceived to be least corrupt are the Office of the Auditor General and the Namibia Central Intelligence Service (both at 0,1 per cent), the Office of the President (0,3 per cent), Office of the Prime Minister and the ACC both at 0,4 per cent, and Parliament at 0,5 per cent. Respondents felt that the Government Institutions Pension Fund (GIPF) is the most corrupt institution in Namibia (at 37,7 per cent), followed by the Social Security Commission (9,4 per cent) and the Namibia Traffic Information System (Natis) at 8,1 per cent. Those institutions considered least corrupt are the local authority councils and the Ministry of Defence (both at 4,8 per cent). Corruption at State schools is perceived to have dropped, but more than 40 per cent of the respondents felt that teachers are involved in corruption, followed by nurses (35,8 per cent), and Police officers (34,7 per cent). Those professions viewed as least corrupt are parliamentarians (3,2 per cent), lawyers (3,6 per cent), and business people (3,8 per cent). Respondents felt that greed is at the core of corruption, but that poverty and poor pay also contribute. Most felt that the corruption-busting initiatives of the ACC are effective, with 24,8 per cent believing that the level of corruption has decreased. More than 30 per cent based their responses on corruption on media reports, 22 per cent on personal experience, 9,5 per cent on discussions with friends, 7,8 per cent on information emanating from the ACC, and 1,3 per cent on information from politicians. The ACC reported that it effectively investigated 297 reports of alleged corrupt practices during the 2011/12 financial year. During that period, it referred 55 cases to the office of the Prosecutor General with recommendations for prosecution. For the 2012/13 financial year, the ACC has requested N$700 000 for investigating allegations of corruption, and a further N$750 000 to establish and implement measures to prevent corruption. The bulk of its budgetary request for the new financial year - N$48,9 million - is for its coordination and support programme. This covers the management and deployment of human and other resources, training within the ACC, and the provision of suitable working environments for its staff.

TITLE: No Corruption in Willowvale Flats Allocation, Says Mutsekwa
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); AGREEMENTS (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); PUBLIC HOUSING (89%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (78%); DEVELOPMENT BANKS (78%); BRIBERY (77%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (75%); REAL ESTATE DEVELOPMENT (75%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (73%); INFRASTRUCTURE (72%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: HOUSING and Social Amenities Minister Giles Mutsekwa says he will deal with any irregular allocation of houses under the Willowvale Flats Phase Two Housing Projects. The minister denied allegations of corruption in selecting beneficiaries. He was responding to the first report of the Portfolio Committee on Public Works and National Housing on Phase 11 Willowvale Housing Projects. Minister Mutsekwa denied assertions by the committee that the project was meant for the poor. He said the project was implemented on a commercial basis as contained in the agreement between Government and the Infrastructure Development Bank of Zimbabwe. "The vetting of candidates is an on-going process and not an event considering that we need to approach the respective local authority and the Deeds Office. In the event that we subsequently discover that some beneficiaries did not meet the requirements we can still deal with them as per clause 14.1," he said. The clause states that false declaration by an individual that they do not own any other property would result in cancellation of the agreement of sale. He cited a case in which some agreements had been cancelled because the persons had made false declarations while in some the beneficiaries were minors. On allegations of corruption, Minister Mutsekwa said there was no evidence to substantiate these claims. "I am disturbed by the use of the word corruption in the report, which according to my definition means an act or practice of giving or accepting a bribe or moral pervasion of integrity. "There is no substantial information to back up this allegation," he said. The minister said the programme was established in 2010 with Government setting aside US$25 million to create the National Housing Development Loan Facility drawn from the International Monetary Fund Special Drawing Rights to Zimbabwe. He said the money was set aside as a Revolving Fund targeting people who could afford. The ministry, IBDZ, local authorities and other private players would then identify suitable land for development and provide on-site infrastructure. Minister Mutsekwa said some of the projects identified included Willowvale Phase 11, Mbizo 22 in Kwekwe, Chikanga in Mutare, Lower Paradise in Marondera, Parklands in Bulawayo while four other projects in Chiredzi, Masvingo, Gwanda and Makonde had been identified for possible development. He said the disparities in deposit paid were a result of affordability. "Some of the civil servants who were nominated by their ministries could and afford were given first preference to pay the commercial deposit of US$10 000. This explains why we have civil servants who paid different deposits of US$3 600 and US$10 000," he said. In its report the committee urged Government to reverse the allocation of the flats saying the criteria excluded the intended beneficiaries, the poor and civil servants. The committee also questioned the existence of children some of them as young as 10 years on the beneficiaries' list.

TITLE: Corruption At GMB
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); AGRICULTURAL MARKETING (88%); IRRIGATION (73%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (53%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: THE Zanu-PF Mashonaland Central provincial leadership has urged Agriculture, Mechanisation and Irrigation Development Minister Joseph Made to launch investigations into the operations of the Grain Marketing Board in the province. Provincial chairperson, Cde Dickson Mafios, told President Mugabe during the launch of the First Choice Wholesale concept in Mt Darwin last week that there was rampant corruption at GMB depots. "There is corruption and we want the minister to investigate this," said Cde Mafios. He was addressing hundreds of people who converged at Mt Darwin Secondary School to witness the launch of the First Choice Wholesale scheme. Cde Mafios said there was need for constant monitoring of GMB operations in the province as grain and inputs meant for the poor were being diverted and benefiting a few senior officials.
