Mashonaland Central provincial Governor Advocate Martin Dinha raised similar complaints last month during a tour of the province by Vice President Joice Mujuru.

TITLE: Dawid Boois' Corruption Trial Postponed
SUBJECT: DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); LAWYERS (87%) Namibia; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Keetmanshoop Regional Court yesterday postponed until June 22 the continuation of the trial of former Karas governor, Dawid Boois due to availability of the presiding Divisional Magistrate, Sunsley Zisengwe. Boois, who faces 24 counts of corruption, is accused of allegedly using his position as Governor for gratification by allegedly pocketing a monthly housing subsidy of N$7 500 over a 24-month period while living in a Government house. At the start of the trial, Boois pleaded not guilty to charges of corruption but admitted that he received the housing subsidy while he stayed in a Government house. He however claimed that the residence was not an official Governor's house. Boois, who is represented by lawyer Sisa Namandje, remains free on warning.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Probes R_ssing
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); DISMISSALS (90%); EXECUTIVES (89%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); EMPLOYEE DEMOTIONS (89%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); MISCONDUCT (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); EXECUTIVE MOVES (76%); RESIGNATIONS (75%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (69%); APPEALS (50%) Namibia; Company News; Corruption
TEXT: PAULUS Noa, the director of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), yesterday confirmed that the anti-graft watchdog was busy probing R_ssing Uranium Limited. This revelation comes in the wake of persistent claims of irregularities at the uranium giant. One of the latest casualties of allegations of misconduct is Jan Groenewaldt. Although the company has drawn a veil of secrecy around his dismissal, this superintendent of contractor management, was fired recently. Noa could however not say if the ACC probe had anything to do with Groenewaldt, as he was not in office. When approached for comment about Groenewaldt more than a week ago, the mine's spokesperson, Jerome Mutumba, denied that he had been sacked. "As far as I am concerned, he is still an employee of the company. What I can tell you at this stage is that all employee issues are internal matters." "But should, at any given stage, an employee cease to be an employee, then I can confirm that he is no longer an employee." Last week, Mutumba said he was on leave and referred all further queries to Chris Salisbury, the managing director. Salisbury was equally evasive. All he was prepared to say was: "I have the policy of not commenting on specific employee matters." Groenewaldt, on his part, fumed that his employment situation had nothing to do with anybody. "What does it have to do with anyone? So what? I don't need to respond to your questions." The Namibian was reliably informed that he was given the boot after being found guilty on two charges - conflict of interest as well as receiving a gift from a contractor "which is tantamount to corruption". Details about the charges remain sketchy. Groenewaldt, it is understood, maintains that he is innocent and has lodged an appeal against his dismissal. Mutumba earlier this year also vehemently denied media reports that there was a large-scale fraud investigation underway at the mine. This seems to be in contradiction to Noa's confirmation yesterday. In December, The Namibian reported that R_ssing's former financial heavyweight, Peter Carlson, also resigned under a cloud. His resignation came amid claims that he was demoted in the wake of alleged irregularities found during an audit. Carlson had served the uranium giant as chief financial officer (CFO) since 2006. Late in 2011, he was moved to the position of chief control officer (CCO). This was seen as a demotion, as he had to report to the CFO. The company is still trying to fill the CFO position. Richard Niddrie has been acting as CFO. On November 25 last year, Salisbury informed its employees that Carlson had resigned. "Peter Carlson has decided to leave R_ssing to pursue other interests. I wish him every success for the future." Carlson "will report to me until further notice", Salisbury's note read. At the time both Mutumba, and Carlson were tight-lipped about the reason for Carlson's resignation. All Mutumba had to say was: "I confirm Mr Carlson tendered his resignation from the company on a voluntary basis. The company wishes him all the best in his future endeavours." The Namibian wanted to know specifically from Mutumba whether he could confirm that Carlson's resignation followed after a demotion based on alleged irregularities including authorising "enormous bonuses" during 2010. Carlson said that he was "not in a position to talk about that right now". The position of CCO also still remains vacant following Carlson's resignation.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Mum On R_ssing Probe
SUBJECT: INVESTIGATIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); EMPLOYEE DEMOTIONS (89%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); AGENCY RULEMAKING (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); DISMISSALS (76%); RESIGNATIONS (76%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (74%); MINES & MINING (72%); BANKING & FINANCE (69%); TAX LAW (68%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (63%); INCOME TAX (54%); APPEALS (50%) Namibia; Company News; Corruption
TEXT: THE director of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), Paulus Noa, yesterday said he cannot reveal more details about their investigation at R_ssing Uranium Limited. This comes despite an undertaking by Noa on Sunday that he would shed more light on the ACC's probe at the mine. Yesterday, Noa said: "I'm not in a position where we can share even an iota of information with you. We are busy with the investigation." R_ssing had been facing the heat on various fronts lately, including reports of the demotion of a senior official after alleged irregularities were found during an audit. Also questions have been raised about an alleged attempt by the company to benefit from its employees pension fund surplus, which according to experts is against the Income Tax Act. R_ssing Uranium Limited spokesperson Jerome Mutumba yesterday said they were unaware of any ACC investigation. "The company is not formally aware of any ongoing or pending ACC investigation as reported in the media today (yesterday). However, should it be the case, it will fully cooperate and support any formal investigation by any relevant authority." According to Mutumba, they are "quite confident in our internal governance systems that are regularly audited". Asked specifically whether the company is reviewing its tender policies because of allegations that there is a lack of transparency, Mutumba did not respond. One source said: "We are busy checking our tender processes also. It is not that transparent for a corporate company." Yesterday, it was reported that the company recently sacked its contractor management superintendent, Jan Groenewaldt. The Namibian was reliably informed that he was given the boot after being found guilty on two charges - conflict of interest as well as receiving a gift from a contractor "which is tantamount to corruption". Groenewaldt, it is understood, maintains that he is innocent and has lodged an appeal against his dismissal. Mutumba earlier this year also vehemently denied media reports that there was a large-scale fraud investigation underway at the mine. This seems to contradict Noa's confirmation yesterday and on Sunday. In December, The Namibian reported that R_ssing's former financial heavyweight, Peter Carlson, also resigned under a cloud of speculation. His resignation came amidst claims that he was demoted in the wake of alleged irregularities found during an audit. Last week it was reported that R_ssing, one of the mainstays of Namibia's mining sector, that it wants to dip into its employee pension fund. A proposed rule change to the R_ssing's Pension Fund has been described by some in the financial industry as a smokescreen to allow the company to access at least one third of the fund's surplus, which stood at N$412,5 million in March last year. Allowing the company to lay its hands on the surplus, some pension fund experts say, would contravene the Income Tax Act of 1981, which stipulates that the employer should be precluded from controlling the management of assets of a pension fund from "deriving any monetary advantage from moneys paid into or out of the fund, except where the employer is a partnership". Over the past two years there had been negotiations between R_ssing, the Mineworkers Union of Namibia and the trustees of the fund over the surplus and a decision had been taken on how it should be distributed. It is now up to the trustees to effect the rule change, which must be endorsed by the company, as it "underwrites the costs and benefits promised by the fund and has to agree any benefit improvement", principal officer of the fund, Erich Beukes told The Namibian last week. R_ssing and its employees have been on a pension contribution holiday since 1992, because of a healthy surplus in the fund. Also, it was reported recently that a cloud of uncertainty hangs over the heads of R_ssing Foundation employees. At least eight foundation employees are expected to be laid off. R_ssing had not contributed any funds to the foundation since 2009.

TITLE: Paltry Salaries Threaten Anti-Corruption War - Commission
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (78%); WAGES & SALARIES (74%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (63%); IMMIGRATION (50%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE independence and effectiveness of the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission is under threat as officials earning US$250 per month are tasked to investigate cases involving millions of dollars, an official said on Monday. Commission chairperson Mr Denford Chirindo said there was need to introduce an anti-corruption risk allowance for his officers to "insulate" them from the temptation. Mr Chirindo was giving oral evidence before the Parliamentary Portfolio Committee on Defence and Home Affairs. The parliamentary committee chaired by Mount Darwin East MP Cde Dickson Mafios (Zanu-PF) wanted to be updated on the commission's operations and challenges. "Our staff earn an average of US$250 a month," said Mr Chirindo. "We believe this does not insulate them against corruption. They are vulnerable to bribes given that they are supposed to pursue cases involving millions of dollars." Mr Chirindo said there was need for additional funding to improve conditions of service for staff in the commission. Secretary for Home Affairs Mr Melusi Matshiya said he will make presentations to Treasury to allow the commission to retain a portion of the money recovered in their investigations. "It's a formula we have used in my department. We have done that with the Registrar-General's office and they are doing well, the same with Immigration and they have bought uniforms. "We have also done that with the police and if the Anti-Corruption Commission is allowed to retain, say, US$100 000 of a million they recover, you are then achieving their independence," he said. On the independence of the commission, Mr Chirindo said while the Constitution provides that they should be independent, the fact that they report to Parliament through a line ministry created problems. He said the Prevention of Corruption Act, which was being administered by the Ministry of Home Affairs, saw a department being created to administer and implement the Act, but in their view it is now running parallel to their commission.

TITLE: Stop Politicising Corruption [opinion]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); BUDGETS (77%); BRIBERY (73%); TEMPORARY EMPLOYMENT (71%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (60%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (60%); INTERNATIONAL TOURISM (55%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: I AM seriously depressed. The alarming rate of corruption in Namibia is getting to me. Almost on a daily basis the media report about one or other corruption case. The only difference is that it started with hundreds being stolen, but now it is no longer hundreds or even thousands. Millions disappear overnight and some people become rich just as quickly. When you see your neighbour suddenly (whether a casual worker or clergyman) giving a huge facelift to his house, buying a top of the range vehicle or taking the family on a foreign trip, you immediately suspect that they must have laid their hands on millions. And it is not a jackpot they have won! It has become a tough task looking for people who systematically work their way up to riches in Namibia. Many opt for the quick fix including stealing, bribery and other forms of corruption. Worse still, many of us admire those who become rich overnight without even questioning how they achieved it. For many young people, they become their role models. Of late it has become a norm for people in key positions at Government ministries, parastatals or even in the private sector to scheme about how they can enrich themselves instead of ensuring efficient service delivery. Networks are formed and millions move between accounts while some turn a blind eye. In fact, I can safely say that some of these syndicates own our leaders! As soon as the leaders smell the rat, they are made to benefit (in most cases indirectly) even if it is just the crumbs falling from the tables. In the most recent instances tenders are not only given fraudulently but the work is either not started or is incomplete despite payments having been made. Worst is that procedures are not followed to first inspect the work or that payments are signed off by those connected to the tenderers. Surely they must be getting something in return. We have had reports of money being transferred between accounts and as it is moved, the amount gets less because people take their share of the cake. Such corruption delays service delivery and promotes poverty in a country which is a signatory to the United Nations Convention on Corruption; where our leaders have declared zero tolerance on corruption; and where we have established an organisation governed by the laws to fight corruption. One gets the impression that ours is just a token commitment. In the early 1990s over-expenditure was first regarded as going over budget, but now it should constitute corruption because, for instance, accounting officers and others in key decision-making positions deliberately go for more expensive tenders so that they can benefit in the process. The corrupt tenderers will not pay from their own money. Will they? They will always recover it through inflated prices. Therefore, even if we have the Anti-Corruption Commission or the President shouting loudly about zero tolerance, it does not automatically translate into good action or minimise the problem. In fact, some of those who shout the loudest are among the main culprits. It's time to let them know that they have gone too far.

TITLE: Call for Private Sector-Led Effort to Stem Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); EXECUTIVES (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (77%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (73%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (72%); PRIME MINISTERS (72%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (71%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (50%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The Private Sector recognises the importance of a corrupt-free society, and will do whatever it can to fight graft, Hannington Namara, the CEO of the Private Sector Federation (PSF) said, yesterday, in response to recommendations from a lawmakers' meeting on corruption. The one-day meeting at parliament aimed at bringing together legislators and their different partners from all arms of government and the private sector, to devise means of stem out all forms of graft in the country. "When it comes to fighting corruption, there is a need to put things in context. One good way is putting in place a stringent legal framework and, the private sector would be very happy to oblige because we are the ones who suffer most. At the end of the day, he said, the private sector is actually all of us in Rwanda. "We are willing to back the efforts that the legislative body is putting in place so as to have what I would call a seamless arrangement." The meeting at parliament was organised by the African Parliamentarians' Network against Corruption (APNAC), the continent's leading network of parliamentarians against corruption. It also called for more collaboration with the judiciary in combating the vice, as well as in sharing information on related crimes. Other suggestions include: perfecting the role and collaboration between government, the civil society and nongovernmental organisations; urging relevant authorities not to accept any forms of corruption usually falsely linked to the culture of showing appreciation through 'gifts'; and sensitising all administrative entities to provide good services. Opening the meeting, the Prime Minister, Dr Pierre Damien Habumuremyi, noted that despite the country's unrelenting war on corruption, new strategies were required to eliminate the remaining traces. Rwanda is ranked fourth least corrupt African country by, the World Bank, and the least corrupt country in the East African Community bloc. The country has achieved significant progress over the past years in terms of government effectiveness and transparency of the regulatory framework including putting a number of measures and institutions in place such as the Rwanda Public Procurement Authority, the Office of the Auditor General (OAG) and the Ombudsman's Office.

TITLE: Step Up Fight Against Corruption - Sata
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (79%); EMERGING MARKETS (78%); LEGISLATION (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (65%); INDUSTRY SECTOR PERFORMANCE (63%); HOTELS & MOTELS (56%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: PRESIDENT Michael Sata has urged African countries to urgently enact stiffer anti-corruption laws that will deter would-be law breakers. Mr Sata said such laws should not be driven by selfish interests but by patriotism and professionalism. He said heads of State in Africa should step up the fight against corruption and help their anti-corruption agencies develop standard innovations in corruption prevention and investigation. Mr Sata said this at Zambezi Sun Hotel in Livingstone yesterday in a speech read for him by Home Affairs Minister, Kennedy Sakeni. This was during the official opening of the second Commonwealth Regional Conference for heads of anti-corruption agencies in Africa. The conference, held under the theme 'Critical role of innovations in fighting corruption in public administration in Africa', has attracted more than 60 delegates from several African countries. The President said corruption had remained a huge challenge to African countries and the world at large. "The whole world is constantly checking on Africa to see if there is anything being done to redeem itself, and it is, therefore, time for Africa to develop individual citizens and empower them with adequate and correct information on corruption for them to make informed decisions. "It is time for Africa to rise above official corruption where people are paid for no work done," Mr Sata said. He said there was need to empower staff in the public service with adequate information on corruption and acceptable values for them to manage public resources with accountability which would be accepted by citizens. "In this regard, I am proud to inform you that a new law called the Anti-Corruption Act Number 3 of 2012 has since been enacted by the Zambian Parliament, repealing the old Act, Number 38 of 2010 which had removed the abuse of the authority clause. "More importantly, the re-introduction of the Abuse of Authority of Office Clause in the Anti-Corruption Act will deter public officials from mismanaging and stealing public resources," he said. Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) Director General, Rosewin Wandi said the theme for the conference was timely in that it had come at a time when the world was undergoing fast transformation into a global village. Ms Wandi said that the world was dynamic as corrupt people were also becoming more sophisticated in their attempt to perpetuate corruption and other vices. She said corruption in the public sector weakened democratic institutions, encouraged organised crime and undermined as well as compromised public service delivery. Commonwealth Secretariat governance adviser, Rodger Koranteng said corruption had remained a huge barrier to economic growth. Dr Koranteng said the widespread perception in many nations indicated that the public sector had lost direction as a lot of people were corrupt.

TITLE: End Corruption in Councils - Sata
SUBJECT: REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); LAND USE PLANNING (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (79%); INTERVIEWS (79%); GRANTS & GIFTS (78%); HOUSING AUTHORITIES (73%); CULTURE DEPARTMENTS (73%); CITIES (70%); CHILDREN (52%) Zambia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: PRESIDENT Michael Sata has directed the newly-appointed Local Government Service Commission (LGSC) to address problems in land allocation which he said were responsible for the rampant corruption in councils. Mr Sata said local government had been ineffective for many years and that it was now the mandate of the new commission to make it effective. Mr Sata was speaking in Lusaka yesterday at State House when he swore-in chairperson of the commission, Steven Mushinge and his deputy, Charles Mwandila, who is former Mufulira Municipal Council town clerk. Mr Sata said councils countrywide were faced with numerous challenges such as corruption and other malpractices and that the commission needed to immediately address them. He said the commission should deal with land allocation which had become one area of concern and mired in corrupt practices. The members of the commission are Maggie Kapiya, Daubt Phiri and Bernard Simpokolwe, while Chipili Katunasa-Magayane is the commission secretary. Mr Simpokolwe is former permanent secretary in the Ministry of Sport, Youth and Child Development in the Frederick Chiluba administration. The President has also urged the commission to explore ways of making councils self-sustaining instead of depending on Government grants for operations. "There is so much corruption in the councils particularly in the allocation of land. You don't have houses. Mr Chiluba sold all the houses. When there were houses, councils survived on those houses but now you don't have them. "Find means and ways of making councils survive on their own instead of relying on grants from the Government," Mr Sata said. The President warned that he would dissolve the newly-appointed commission the moment it failed to perform. He said the commission should not limit its operations to Lusaka Province only but expected the members to vigorously tour all councils to establish councils' operational challenges. "I will not hesitate to dissolve you. With the minister, I have no problems because I can change her any time but for you, I am going to waste time to swear you in again. "Tour the whole country, move to rural councils, district councils, city councils and municipal councils and once they see you that's how they are going to function," Mr Sata said. "The Superannuation Fund belongs to all workers. Don't just sit in your offices in Lusaka or Ndola. Use the money to tour the whole country and see for yourselves what's happening in the councils. "Don't just make transfers from your offices because today we can't see the impact of the local government. The local government today is dead," Mr Sata said. Speaking in an interview with journalists shortly after she witnessed the swearing-in of the commission, Local Government and Housing Minister, Nkandu Luo said she was happy that her Ministry now had a commission. Professor Luo said the commission had a huge task of addressing challenges in areas of human resource capacity and fostering workers' positive attitude. "People report late for duty and these are some areas the commission should immediately address including human resource capacity in the ministry," she said.

TITLE: PSUN Congress Wants Action On Corruption
SUBJECT: LABOR UNIONS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CIVIL SERVICES (89%); AGREEMENTS (89%); SERVICE WORKERS (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); FOREIGN INVESTMENT (69%); FISHING TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (67%); MULTINATIONAL CORPORATIONS (60%); FORENSICS (54%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: THE congress of the Public Service Union of Namibia (PSUN) held at Outjo last weekend decided that the union's new leadership should engage with Government to stamp out corruption, poverty and exclusivity. The leaders elected - or re-elected in many instances - are /Awebahe //Hoseb (president), Richard !Kharuxab (first vice president), Ralph Makgone (second vice president), Ignasia Neis (treasurer), and additional members Leonard Penda Hawanga, Bertha Tjitundje, and Elifas //Khoaseb. The union resolved to fight corruption and mismanagement, and to demand from Government that the culprits in the Government Institutions Pension Fund (GIPF) Development Capital Portfolio (DCP) scandal be brought to book. It wants all reports of forensic and presidential commissions of inquiry made public, and while the fight on corruption should intensify in all seriousness, it demands that national resources be equally distributed to all Namibians as far as mining and fishing rights, bursaries and board positions are concerned. Similarly, the PSUN wants Government to abolish 'camping allowances' for public servants to ensure that Regional Emergency Management Unit (REMU) employees have job security. Currently these REMU workers are being re-commissioned every year but they do not have any benefits or job security, said PSUN senior organiser Ujama Kahongoro. The PSUN, which estimates its membership at about 16 000, does not have a recognition agreement with Government, but demands to represent its members in disciplinary hearings, which is not allowed under the public service staff rules. According to these staff rules, said Kahongoro, unions are only allowed to sit in as observers at disciplinary hearings. Kahongoro claimed that the Namibia Public Workers Union (Napwu), which has a recognition agreement with Government, agreed on the staff rules "in cahoots" with Prime Minister Nahas Angula. "We think Napwu is selling out the workers. There is no way that you can engage in an agreement that will affect workers," Kahongoro said. "We will get our house in order and challenge Government to get a recognition agreement with us. We feel Napwu's recognition status has expired because its membership has reduced." The union wants decent work to be a prerequisite for foreign direct investments in order to protect Namibian workers against exploitation by multinational companies.

TITLE: By-Elections Product of Electoral Fraud, Corruption
SUBJECT: ELECTIONS (94%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (93%); ELECTION FRAUD (91%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PETITIONS (90%); BYELECTIONS (90%); ETHICS (89%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); ELECTION AUTHORITIES (89%); VOTERS & VOTING (89%); POLITICS (89%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); ELECTION LAW (89%); POLITICAL PARTIES (78%); POLITICAL CANDIDATES (78%); POLLS & SURVEYS (77%); POLITICAL ORGANIZATIONS (71%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (71%); HEALTH DEPARTMENTS (70%); RANKINGS (70%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (50%) Zambia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: ZAMBIA has witnessed unprecedented levels of electoral fraud and corruption since the re-introduction of multi-party democracy in 1991, and this ugly syndrome continues to plague the electoral system in spite of determined attempts to eliminate the scourge. If any sordid evidence was needed about the prevalence of this scourge, the number of parliamentary election petitions filed by losing candidates, and the resultant nullification of results by the courts in the aftermath of last year's polls, is irrefutable proof that most elections were marred by rampant fraud and corruption. There were in excess of 50 election petitions filed in the High Court by aggrieved individuals who contested and 'lost' parliamentary polls but are challenging the results, and in a bulk of these cases, corruption is the predominant feature cited by the petitioners. This situation does not augur well for our nascent democracy, for it clearly shows that the will of the people continues to be subverted by some individuals who employ all sorts of crude and unethical practices during election campaigns. So far, a total of nine parliamentary election results have been nullified by the courts, triggering numerous by-elections that will gobble a colossal amount of public funds -- which should be channeled into various development programmes to ameliorate suffering being endured by those living in abject poverty. We concur with the Electoral Commission of Zambia which oversees elections that political parties, as the key stakeholders, should do more to ensure that contestants abide by the Electoral Code of Conduct Act and strive, as much as possible, to avoid blatant breaches of the law which lead to election petitions. Violence, intimidation, vote buying, use of public resources, which include the use of Government transport or vehicles belonging to parastatal firms to ferry voters to polling stations, are all prohibited under the Electoral Act. Sadly, breaches were routinely recorded in nearly every election that took place in the past when the then ruling MMD abused its incumbency through the use of public funds and Government vehicles--including Ministry of Health vehicles--which were used to transport their spin-doctors hired from abroad at exorbitant fees. It is not in dispute that violent conduct by some low-ranking political cadres is often perpetrated at the behest of senior party leaders who appear to give tacit approval to such uncouth methods of coercing the electorate to vote in a particular way. The Electoral Act also expressly forbids making 'false, defamatory or inflammatory allegations concerning any person or party in connection with an election." Candidates are expected to dwell on substantive issues instead of engaging in character assassination. Contrary to the letter and spirit of the Act, the former ruling party concocted crude and vile propaganda against the then leading opposition candidate, who eventually triumphed in the presidential polls. Viewed from a different perspective, MMD's propaganda back-fired on the party as most people were able to see through the blatant lies spread by the then ruling elite hell- bent on winning votes by hook or crook. The level of impunity exhibited in the past, particularly by those who were privileged to occupy positions of power and influence, compromised the efficacy of election results and undermined the country's democracy. The subsequent nullification of some election results by courts of law should be viewed as a case of chickens coming home to roost. Some of the breaches committed by poll contestants and their agents were too serious to go unpunished. We hope what transpired in the past will provide valuable lessons to other aspiring candidates in the forth-coming by-elections and future polls. The will of the people should always prevail, but that can only happen in a free and fair contest.

TITLE: SPB Admits to Corruption in Tender Awards
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CONTRACT AWARDS (90%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: State Procurement Board chairman, Mr Charles Kuwaza, yesterday admitted that some of his officers corruptly awarded tenders to bidders. Appearing before the portfolio committee on Budget, Finance and Investment Promotion Mr Kuwaza said the SPB did not have enough staff to investigate if parastatals and ministries were following the law in procurement. The committee wanted the SPB chairman to clarify reports that some of his officers were corruptly awarding tenders. "The possibility of corruption could be there at the evaluation stage where some people may see that a certain bidder has met all the specifications. They then phone that bidder asking for a payment to facilitate that they win the tender when the bidder was still going to win it because they have met all the requirements," Mr Kuwaza said. "I can't say there is no corruption but what we want is that our officers should not abuse their positions. As a board our attitude is zero tolerance to corruption and our officers know that if they do it they will go to jail," he said. Legislators also asked Mr Kuwaza why his board ignored recommendations from ministries and parastatals on preferred bidders. Goromonzi North legislator Cde Paddy Zhanda (Zanu-PF) chairs the committee. " . . . we have heard that some of your officers were taken to court over corruption," Cde Zhanda said. "We heard that before results are opened, some people will already be knowing them." Bulawayo South MP, Mr Eddie Cross (MDC-T), said the fact that the SPB did not take recommendations resulted in them awarding tenders to companies without capacity. He asked who was to blame if the SPB awarded tenders to under performing companies that will not deliver. Mr Kuwaza said they only awarded tenders on the basis of the criteria set out in the tender documents as long as the companies would have been pre-certified by their mother organisations. He said if the winning bidder failed to do the job, blame was supposed to be directed at the ministry or parastatal that draws contracts. Tsholotsho South legislator, Mr Maxwell Dube (MDC), asked Mr Kuwaza, if his board had been involved in the tendering process for the construction of the National Defence College along Mazowe Road. "In the Act there is a provision on a general policy, which we receive from the President. You should ask the President's Office regarding that policy. As you may be aware Cabinet adopted the Look East policy and we are guided by that," Mr Kuwaza said. He said the board had not yet done due diligence on the project adding that he will raise it with the board. Legislators alleged that the contractor at the defence College imported all the equipment from China including labour. The MPs said there was need for a law spelling out that if a foreigner won a tender they were not supposed to bring some of the equipment that can be found locally. Mr Kuwaza said there was no industry to talk about because it had been affected by hyper-inflation. He said his board will not use the indigenisation and economic empowerment law to give tenders to local companies that did not have capacity.

TITLE: Fighting Corruption War
COUNTRY: LIBERIA (96%); UNITED STATES (94%); AFRICA (93%); CANADA (79%); NORTH AMERICA (79%)
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); CORRUPTION (91%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); APPROPRIATIONS (78%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (76%); INTERGOVERNMENTAL TALKS (74%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (72%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (71%); HYDROELECTRIC POWER GENERATION (69%); HYDROELECTRIC POWER (67%); POWER PLANTS (67%); NATURAL RESOURCES (66%); EMBARGOES & SANCTIONS (65%); IMMIGRATION (62%) Liberia; Corruption; International Organizations and Africa; United States, Canada and Africa
TEXT: There is need for both the Executive and Legislative Branches of the Liberian government to collaborate in fighting the corruption virus that is gnawing the fabric of the nation's coffers, U.S. Vice President Joe Biden has stressed during an address to legislators accompanying President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf in America. He emphasized that it was necessary for the both branches to work together for "transparency, and in the fight against corruption and institution building." Senators Isaac Nyenebo and Geraldine Doe-Sheriff, as well as Reps George Mulbah and Wesseh Blamo are among the President's entourage. Also present during the meeting the Administrator of USAID, Mr. Rajiv Shah, who assured President Sirleaf that his Agency would operate differently in ensuring that projects are country-led. A meeting between President Sirleaf and Secretary of State Hilary Clinton at the State Department underscored similar issues as discussed with Vice President Biden, in which she also spoke of her second-term priorities, especially making the Mount Coffee hydro plant operational. Their discussions focused on Liberia's new three-year, medium-term budget, the proper use of Liberia's natural resources for the benefit of all Liberians, and the need to review the UN sanctions regime on Liberia regarding frozen assets and travel ban, among a wide range of topics. Earlier at their meeting, President Sirleaf assert that Liberia's laws are clear on the protection of the rights and choices of all citizens, and that those laws must be respected and implemented. During President Sirleaf's meeting with Vice President Biden at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, they discussed how to strengthen U.S.-Liberia bilateral relations through the establishment of a Bi-National Commission; the drawdown of UNMIL and the corresponding need to build up Liberia's security forces, particularly the Police and Immigration. According a dispatch from the presidential press secretary, both leader also discussed Liberia's successes and challenges, amongst the latter being the need for infrastructure, especially electricity, promotion of national development, and how to address youth unemployment. The President also underscored the need to restore the U.S. Administration's proposed 15 percent cut in its appropriations to Liberia, U.S. support for Liberia in its effort to achieve Compact status under the Millennium Challenge Corporation Initiative, Liberia's solidarity with other African nations fighting to preserve the third party fabric clause in the AGOA legislation.

TITLE: 'End Corruption in Procurement System'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (74%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (73%); EXECUTIVES (71%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: GOVERNMENT will ensure that corruption in the procurement system is stamped out, Works, Supply, Transport and Communications Minister, Yamfwa Mukanga, has said. Mr Mukanga said the Government would ensure that transparency and accountability were restored. The minister said this in Lusaka yesterday during the launch of the Zambian Public Procurement Monitoring Coalition (ZPPMC) watch group. He said efficient and effective procurement of public goods, works and services was crucial for ensuring good economic management. Mr Mukanga said the Government acknowledged the fact that public procurement played a critical role in developmental programmes and service delivery of the country. "Our country needs a procurement system which is effective and efficient based on transparency, accountability and fairness in order to obtain value for money. "Transparency and accountability is a sure way of lessening opportunity for corrupt practices in the procurement system," he said. He said the Government valued initiatives of ZPPMC whose mandate was to advocate and promote transparency and accountability in the procurement system. The Government, Mr Mukanga said, was committed to ensuring improved access to information on procurement of works and services. Transparency International Zambia executive director Goodwell Lungu, who is the coalition chairperson, said the group engaged in public contract monitoring because the country had lost colossal sums of public funds resulting from flouting of tender procedures by public officers over the years. He said the Auditor-General's report of 2010 indicated that failure to follow tender procedures resulted in many financial irregularities.

TITLE: Massive Corruption Rocks Fuel Industry
COUNTRY: ZIMBABWE (98%); UNITED STATES (93%); MOZAMBIQUE (92%); ZAMBIA (79%); MALAWI (79%)
SUBJECT: ENERGY & UTILITY LAW (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); MARINE TANKERS (89%); OIL & GAS MARINE TANKERS (89%); OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (78%); UTILITIES INDUSTRY (77%); ENERGY & UTILITY REGULATION & POLICY (76%); ENERGY REGULATION (76%); ENERGY DEPARTMENTS (76%); PETROLEUM PRODUCTS (76%); ENERGY & UTILITY POLICY (76%); SPECIAL FREIGHT TRUCKING (75%); ELECTRIC POWER PLANTS (74%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (69%); TRUCK DRIVERS (67%); QUALITY CONTROL (60%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Petroleum
TEXT: Zimbabwe's fuel industry, which is backed by a readily available cash-market, has become the latest target of a heavily pirated market with corrupt activities prejudicing the State of millions of US dollars. Investigations by The Herald have unearthed a cartel of fuel barons whose network involves fuel suppliers, transporters and local dealers. According to sources, the "pirates" are not only on the high seas of the Indian Ocean, but include players from the oil wells, the ships, the Port of Beira in Mozambique, transport companies and their representatives and shadow companies that market the product in Zimbabwe. Government and its regulatory authorities have, however, expressed ignorance to these activities. Energy and Power Development Minister Elton Mangoma yesterday said Government would be eager to investigate the activities. The Zimbabwe Energy Regulatory Authority also expressed interest in taking up the issue. Zera commercial director Mr Eddie Mazambani said the authority would look into the allegations. The fuel industry acknowledged the proliferation of unregistered fuel dealers but blamed it on truck drivers who siphon fuel from tankers. The industry, which does not have representation after the collapse of its association, however questions dealers' preference of road transport to the cheaper Feruka Pipeline. Sources in the industry said unscrupulous elements have taken over the fuel industry taking advantage of the prevailing cash economy. "There is nowhere else in the world where the United States dollar can exchange hands easily and the fuel barons have descended on Zimbabwe for their activities," a source said. He said Zimbabwe, as a transit route to markets in Zambia, DRC and Malawi, has been severely affected. "There are pirates everywhere and they have found a home in Zimbabwe. One wonders why there has been a serious investment in the transport sector to service road (fuel) transportation when Government invested in the cheaper pipeline between Beira and Msasa, Harare. "Dirty money is exchanging hands from dealers in oil producing countries, Beira, Harare and finally the shadowy retailers sprouting all over the country." He said the deals also involve some Government officials who have jumped onto the bandwagon. There are allegations the people involved continue to shun the Feruka Pipeline for the lucrative road transport using their tankers. "There has been an increase in road transport with tankers criss-crossing the Eastern parts of Zimbabwe to Mozambique for the ready cash," the source said. There is also a deliberate move, according to sources, to avoid the Feruka Pipeline as it is controlled especially for quality control measures. "There are serious concerns that the dealers have opted for road transport because of the loopholes in quality control checks. The pipeline is strictly monitored and Zimbabwe could be receiving contaminated fuel," a source said. The sources said unregistered operators are also involved in a scam where fuel enters Zimbabwe disguised as being in transit. "Government does not collect duty for fuel in transit but the bulk of this fuel has found its way onto the local market especially the unmarked service stations in Harare. "There are fears that some of those trucks coming into Zimbabwe could have been improperly cleared at the border as carrying fuel for the Zambian or DRC market but most of it ends up in Harare because there are no clear mechanisms to track the vehicles to their final destinations." There has also been a stampede to invest in the transport sector as businesspeople discovered the loopholes. "Business including people in Government has joined the fray using their trucks and companies to supply the readily available market. "There are people earning between US4c to US8c per a litre of fuel coming into Zimbabwe through the underhand dealings and that should explain reluctance to enforce regulations in the market." Minister Mangoma said: "I have not heard of it. If you have information to that effect give us registration numbers of those fuel tankers for us to take action." He, however, confirmed that ZERA had no role to play on fuel in transit. Mr Mazambani could neither deny nor confirm the allegations saying the issue required wider stakeholder consultations. "We will be attending to the issues you raised. There is need for wide stakeholder verification of the information you require, we will endeavour to get back to you by Monday afternoon (today)," he said. Petro Trade chief executive officer Mr Griffin Revanewako said most of the fuel that used road transport was mainly paraffin and Jet A1. He said the quantity of such fuel was low such that it could not use the pipeline. "You should have checked the type of the fuel in those tankers because it might have been paraffin or Jet A1," he said. Mr Revanewako said the use of the pipeline required huge volumes. A leading fuel supplier also acknowledged the advantages of the Feruka Pipeline. Besides being cost effective, the pipeline improved the turnaround time, ensured quality controls at Beira, Feruka and Msasa in Harare, he said. He however said the parallel market was being supplied by fuel stolen from the tankers. While confirming that information on the abuse of fuel in transit was not available, the supplier expressed confidence on Government's regulation on importation and marketing of fuel in Zimbabwe calling it "adequate". Zimbabwe imports around 110 million litres of fuel monthly.

TITLE: Prosecute Corruption Suspects - Donors
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); CONSTITUTIONAL LAW (89%); TRANSPORTATION INFRASTRUCTURE (78%); TREASURY DEPARTMENTS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); BUDGETS (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (77%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (72%); FREEDOM OF INFORMATION (71%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (66%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (57%); INFRASTRUCTURE (50%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Aid and Assistance
TEXT: ZAMBIA'S cooperating partners have urged Government to expedite the process of prosecuting all those charged with corruption. The donors have also welcomed Government's commitment to reforms in various sectors including the Judiciary. Poverty Reduction Budget Support (PRBS) Chairperson, Mike Hammond said in Lusaka yesterday that cooperating partners were impressed with Government's commitment in the areas of Constitution drafting process, judicial reforms and the pursuit to introduce the Freedom of Information (FoI) law. Mr Hammond, who is Department for International Development (DfID) head in Zambia, said the country had continued to be recognised in the region for sustaining peace and respecting democratic principles. He called on Government to sustain its momentum created in the fight against corruption and hasten the process of putting people charged with offences on trial before the courts. "The Government's commitment to good governance, including the fight against corruption, are particularly high. "It is vitally important to sustain the momentum created to date and to hasten the process of bringing those charged with offences before the courts," he said. He was speaking at Mulungushi International Conference Centre during the high level first joint PRBS review meeting for 2012 attended by Secretary to the Treasury, Fredson Yamba and various diplomats from countries that give support to Zambia. Speaking on behalf of the others, Mr Hammond said cooperating partners welcomed Government's plans for judicial reforms. He said the judicial reforms would be important to balance the need to resolve institutional weaknesses with safeguarding the independence of the judiciary. He cooperating partners had welcomed the current constitutional reform process and were pleased to see comprehensive consultations with the people of Zambia. "We would urge the Government to continue promoting the constitutional reform process without delay," Mr Hammond said. The meeting which drew participants from various Government spending agencies was aimed at dialoguing on key aspects of underlying principles and to assess the 2011 Performance Assessment Framework (PAF). The partners also welcomed the Government's plans to progress the decentralisation process and looked forward to presentation of a roadmap for devolving functions to provincial and district levels. On the economy, Mr Hammond said Zambia had continued to show strong economic performance. He said cooperating partners would continue to offer support to enhance Zambia's capacity to critically appraise infrastructure projects in the road sector. Mr Hammond said the cooperating partners would want to hear where the Government stood on the development of a new International Monetary Fund (IMF) programme. "Real commitment must be demonstrated by actions, concrete plans, resource allocation and ultimately by the progress made in achieving results," he said. He said there were many aspects of underlying principles and more information was needed before donors could reach an agreed conclusion on how the Government's commitment could be assessed. Mr Hammond, however, said the current uncertainty over the Government's intentions with respect to maize purchases in 2012 was of particular concern to budget support to cooperating partners. "Our 2012 PRBS commitments were pledged based on the budget presented in parliament in November which included the decision to limit the budget allocation for the Food Reserve Agency (FRA) to K300 billion and the intention to return the FRA to its intended mandate," he said. He said a third successive supplementary budget. He, however, said the US$900 million made as commitment by the previous regime was crowding out vital spending for social services such as health and education. Mr Hammond said the cooperating partners would want to know the vision of the Patriotic Front (PF) Government for the road sector investments beyond 2012.

TITLE: Corruption At Local Level Worrying
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); PUBLIC POLICY (90%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (88%); ETHICS (79%); POLLS & SURVEYS (78%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (78%); TRENDS (78%); RESEARCH INSTITUTES (77%); LEGISLATION (75%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (65%) Namibia; Corruption
TEXT: Corruption at local and regional level is not tackled with the same importance given to cases at national level. This is according to the latest paper released by the Institute for Public Policy Research (IPPR) titled 'Risking Corruption: Regional and Local Governance in Namibia'. The paper is part of the IPPR's anti-corruption series. "Many corruption cases affecting local and regional authorities occur beneath the radar and if they do reach the national spotlight, they are often only referred to in passing with few follow-up media reports appearing," reads the paper. The paper, authored by IPPR's Ellison Tjirera, Malakia Haimbondi and Graham Hopwood, states that anti-corruption legislation, regulations and initiatives at local or regional level are often not developed and promoted with the same vigour as national responses to corruption. "With little attention being paid to the activities of many local and regional authorities, inadequate regulations in place, and council staff teams sometimes short of key personnel and lacking specific skills, the scene is set for corruption to take place," reads the report. Corruption is reported to be a worrying factor at local and regional level, with at least 18 local authorities having featured in articles about governance problems, some multiple times for different cases over the last seven years. Trends in these cases include the manipulation of the public procurement systems to divert tenders to companies linked to officials or elected politicians. "In several cases, officials appear to see nothing wrong with allocating tenders to their associates and even family members. Undoubtedly the area of public contracting is the most vulnerable to corruption," reads the paper. In late 2011, the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) published its Namibia National Urban Corruption Perception Survey Report based on a nationwide survey of 1 200 people. The most corrupt institution was perceived to be the Government Institutions Pension Fund (GIPF) with 37 per cent perception. Local authorities came in tenth place. The IPPR indicates that clearly there is a lack of ethical conduct, but also a lack of oversight, "loopholes in laws" and a failure to enforce the relevant laws that do exist. "Law enforcement agencies, including the ACC should also be active in all regions so that the reporting of suspected corruption is a straightforward process," recommends the IPPR. In addition, the IPPR suggest that the office of the Ombudsman could also have an official presence in the regions to enable citizens to report matters that might not be corruption per se but fall under the Ombudsman's mandate.

TITLE: Verdict in Boois Corruption Case On July Two
SUBJECT: VERDICTS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (89%); ACQUITTAL (78%); WITNESSES (78%); TESTIMONY (78%); LAWYERS (75%) Namibia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: THE Keetmanshoop Regional Court on Friday set July 2 as the day for the judgement in the trial of former Karas governor and Berseba Constituency regional councillor Dawid Boois, who is charged with 24 counts of corruption. Boois is accused of using his position as governor for gratification by allegedly pocketing a monthly housing subsidy of N$7 500 over a 24-month period between 2005 and 2007 while living in a government house. At the start of the trial, Boois pleaded not guilty to charges of corruption but admitted that he received the housing subsidy while he was living in a government house. He however claimed that the residence was not an official governor's house. When the State closed its case on Friday, defence counsel Sisa Namandje requested that his client be discharged, claiming that the State had failed to prove his guilt. "While asking for my client's acquittal, I just want to note in passing that it's shocking how people are arrested and brought to court without any legal foundation," said Namandje. Namandje argued that the State had failed to prove that his client directly or indirectly had corruptly used the position of his office for gratification. Namandje added that none of the State witnesses suggested during their testimony that Boois had used his powers as governor for gratification. "There was no allegation that the office was used. It disturbs me to note the mixed-up use of contraventions to constitute corruption," said Namandje. Namandje described the illegal housing subsidy as just an "administrative hiccup" which does not constitute corruption. "It's a disagreement. Council knew they voluntarily paid him [Boois]. My client did not demand the payment or used his position, Namandje said." State prosecutor, Pieter Smit contended that Boois knew long before he had moved into the government house that it was illegal to receive a housing subsidy while living in a government house. This, Smit contended, demonstrated intention on the part of Boois to commit an offence. Saying there is a wider interpretation of the phrase, "use of office for gratification", Smit said corruption was indeed proved against Boois because he used his high position to refuse to correct what was wrong when the illegal housing subsidy payment was brought to his attention by junior staff. "He committed the act by refusing to correct what was wrong," said Smit.

TITLE: Corruption Blamed On Poor Remuneration
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); CIVIL SERVICES (90%); WAGES & SALARIES (90%); STRATEGIC PLANNING (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (79%); LEGAL AID (79%); BRIBERY (78%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (78%); LITIGATION (77%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (74%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; NGOs and Civil Society; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Justice and Legal Affairs Deputy Minister Obert Gutu has blamed the rampant corruption particularly in the public sector to poor remuneration. He challenged Government to urgently address the issue of civil servants' salaries to arrest the scourge. Dep Min Gutu said this while addressing an Anti-Corruption Committee strategic planning workshop in Harare last week. He said corruption in the justice sector had reached unprecedented levels and efforts to curb it through media campaigns were not bearing fruit. "There is dire need for quick intervention to restore sanity. Let me hasten to say that this intervention must include addressing the problem of poor remuneration, especially in the public service if at all we are serious about kicking corruption to the curb. This should discourage petty stealing as well as large-scale bribery in the public sector," he said. Deputy Minister Gutu said the courts were not in a position to deal effectively with corruption because they are not adequately equipped. "The judiciary has time and again stated that it is willing to address corruption but willingness alone will not solve the problem. Our courts are generally poorly equipped and trials take a long time making it possible for the police, prosecutors, magistrates and other court officials to manipulate the process," he said. The deputy minister said corruption was also rampant at the deeds and companies offices. "This is exacerbated by bogus estate agents, the manufacturing of fake court orders and fake identity cards. Some shameful individuals have also abused our Legal Aid Directorate which is meant to assist the underprivileged and ensure access to justice for all," he said. Deputy Minister Gutu said concerted efforts by the ACC to arrest graft have not yielded much as corruption continues to spread its wings to the private and even civil society. The creation of the ACC was promoted by high levels of corruption in the judiciary sector. This prompted the Ministry to establish a committee to deal with corruption issues. The strategic plan was aimed at helping stimulate co-operative, integrated and enthusiastic approach to tackling the scourge. Deputy Minister Gutu said the absence of a strategic plan had greatly affected the work of the committee. "For quite some time the Anti-Corruption Committee has been groping in the dark and going round in circles like a ship without a radar owing to the fact that the committee did not have a strategic plan," he said. The committee comprises senior officials from the Ministry of Justice and Legal Affairs' 13 departments.

TITLE: Auditor General, Anti-Corruption Act Seal Deal to Speed Up Investigations
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (90%); AUDITS (90%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (89%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (75%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (73%); MONEY LAUNDERING (73%) Zambia; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: "SECTION 6 1(e) of the Anti-Corruption Act Number 3 of 2012 requires the Commission to co-ordinate with other institutions involved in the prevention and combating of corrupt practices so as to implement an integrated approach to the eradication of corruption." Those are the words of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) Director-General Rosewin Wandi during the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between her institution and the Office of the Auditor-General (OAG) led by Anna Chifungula. Before June 14, 2012, law enforcement agencies such as ACC were not privy to the OAG's findings of financial mismanagement or irregularities in public offices. Therefore, ACC would be left in the dark about the audit findings until the OAG produces its report. In other words, investigations into corruption cases emanating from audit reports were mainly commenced after the reports were availed to the Commission. It is worth noting also that after the culprits are known through the report and subsequently appear before the Parliamentary Accounts Committee (PAC) to exculpate themselves, the prosecution process takes a long time and at times does not even occur at all. With effect from June 14, 2012, financial irregularities findings will not be kept under wraps by the OAG only to be made known to the public through its report. This follows an MoU signed between the two institutions on June 14, this year. The MoU came into effect from the date of execution by both parties and would remain in force until it is terminated by either party giving to the other three months notice by assigning reasons therefore. The Commission is mandated by the Republican Constitution to spearhead the fight against corruption in Zambia through prevention of the vice, community education, investigation and prosecution of offenders. The OAG, on the other hand, has constitutional powers to conduct audits in all institutions where the Government has interest. According to the MoU, the two parties are aware that corruption is a predicate offence to other criminal activities such as fraud and money laundering, among other vices, and the ACC and OAG are committed to dealing with corruption through audits and investigations. It further states that the two institutions are committed to greater coordination and collaboration among State organs in the prevention and combating of corruption to enhance good governance through implementation of the National Anti-Corruption Policy. The parties have agreed to collaborate and support each other in pursuing investigations relating to their mandate both through their headquarters and in their regional offices around Zambia. The parties have recognised the need for expedience and collaboration in order to facilitate investigations. "Where appropriate, information and findings from the audits being undertaken by the Office of the Auditor-General would be shared with the Commission; where necessary, the Commission may in the course of investigations procure from the Office, officers' expertise, information and documents relevant to the conduct of an investigation as may, from time to time, be agreed by the Commission and the Office, for analysis aimed at facilitating an investigation," the MoU reads in part. In terms of joint operations, it adds, each party would bear its own costs. The purpose of the MoU is to provide a framework through which information and findings would be shared between the two parties so as to speedily exchange information, and avoid unnecessary delays and bottlenecks in an investigation. It also aims at calling on each other's expertise and provide a channel for information sharing between the two institutions to facilitate investigations. On issues of obligations and confidentiality, the MoU states that each party would do everything possible for the time being in their power to ensure that relevant and appropriate information is passed between them freely and without hindrance to avoid unnecessary delays in the course of an investigation or audit. All information shared, obtained and exchanged through the MoU is deemed confidential. Each party would at all times maintain the confidentiality and is expected not to disclose any information or subject matter or implementation to any other person or authority. However, the aforementioned empowers either party to go against only if it is required by the law to do so. It was previously agreed by both parties in the terms and form and in the confidence of their professional advisers. Speaking shortly before signing the MoU, Ms Wandi said the development was a timely one and that it had come at a time when efforts to combat corruption were being intensified, adding that it also complemented the strong political will the Patriotic Front (PF) Government had exhibited to stamp out the vice in the country by declaring "war"and taking a zero-tolerance stance on graft. "The event we are witnessing today is a great achievement in our efforts as a country to eradicate corruption which has become a major impediment to economic and social development. I am, therefore, delighted that the signing of this MoU is happening at a time when the people of Zambia need it the most. "The Anti-Corruption Commission has taken advantage of the prevailing political will to strengthen and step up its efforts in the fight against corruption in Zambia," she said. Ms Wandi said the political will was being exemplified through, among other milestones, increased funding to the Commission and oversight institutions as well as the enactment of the Anti-Corruption Act Number 3 of 2012, Section 6 1(e) which promotes co-ordination. President Michael Sata recently assented to the Bill. The Commission, she added, strongly believed that the OAG was an invaluable partner in the fight against corruption because of its pivotal role in providing information from audits, whose revelations called for positive response from law enforcement agencies. "The signing of this MoU will allow the Anti-Corruption Commission to have access to information relating to corruption arising from audits undertaken by the Office of the Auditor-General before the Auditor-General's Report is released," she said. Ms Wandi observed that the country had been experiencing severe looting of the hard-earned public resources by a "few selfish" individuals at the expense of national development, a thing she said should not be allowed to continue. Ms Chifungula said the MoU-signing signified the opening of a new chapter in Zambia's fight against the corruption scourge and echoed Ms Wandi's remarks on Government's stance against the vice. "As you may be aware, corruption if left unchecked can erode wealth, increase poverty and cripple Government structures and systems. "It can also lead to failure to deliver services and in its extreme, cause strife among the citizenry who may feel dissatisfied with the service delivery. "Corruption in most cases causes the cost of doing business to be extremely expensive," she said. Ms Chifungula explained that the MoU sought to improve collaboration between the two institutions through timely information sharing and expertise which would in turn positively contribute to Government's efforts of stamping out corruption. "All cases of suspected fraud and corruption, once discovered in the course of audit, will be communicated in real time to ensure their timely prosecution," she said. She, however, said there was need for the institutions to guard against any possible complacency in collaborations in the fight against corruption and mismanagement of public resources, but that they should instead endeavour to ensure that the MoU signing contributes to the evolution of a much stronger working relationship between them to the detriment of those that engage in such vices. Drug Enforcement Commission (DEC) Commissioner Alita Mbahwe, in congratulating the two institutions, said the MoU was an important initiative as it would help DEC in combating money laundering cases. Ms Mbahwe hoped the MoU was the beginning of more such agreements with other law enforcement agencies. PAC chairperson Vincent Mwale said the committee and Parliament as a whole were delighted at the development spearheaded by the "powerful women" as such initiatives to promote timely and quick action against those that flout financial regulations had been long overdue. Mr Mwale said delays or no action being taken against culprits discouraged the efforts of the OAG and PAC after making recommendations and hoped the MoU would help in safeguarding the much-needed resources to develop the country. "We need these resources to develop our country," he said. Zambia Police Service commissioner in charge of administration, Antoneill Mutentwa said the service would play its role to lighten the job of the two institutions as they did for the police by pledging to strengthen the Stella Libongani-led service's commitment to the fight against corruption and other related vices. "Indeed, as police, we will do our role to make your job much, much more lighter because what you do also makes our job much, much lighter. "So as police, we do also here cement our commitment to the fight against corruption," Mr Mutentwa said. The deal has been sealed and words have been spoken. It is now incumbent upon the two institutions, in collaboration with other relevant law enforcement agencies and the general public, to put the MoU into action. It should not end at that. Ms Chifungula sums up everything by saying: "Our institutions must endeavour to ensure that this MoU's success does not end with the pomp and spledour of the signing ceremony, but that it contributes to the evolution of a much stronger working relationship between ourselves to the detrimentof those who choose the path of corruption and similar vices."

TITLE: We Will End Corruption in Mining Sector - Yaluma
CITY: LONDON, ENGLAND (79%); LUSAKA, ZAMBIA (72%); JOHANNESBURG, SOUTH AFRICA (50%)
SUBJECT: MINES & MINING (94%); CORRUPTION (90%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (89%); PRIVATIZATION (79%); WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT (79%); BUSINESS OPERATIONS (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (78%); MINE PLANNING & MANAGEMENT (78%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (73%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (67%) Zambia; Mining; Corruption
TEXT: GOVERNMENT will ensure that all transactions in the mining sector are conducted in a transparent manner so as to end corruption, Energy, Mines and Water Development Minister Christopher Yaluma has said. Mr Yaluma said the Government would ensure that dealings in the operations of the mining sector were above board. The minister was speaking during a meeting with his Ethiopian counterpart, Ato Tolessa Shagi in Lusaka yesterday, "We are very much trying to ensure that we do the business in the most transparent way so that corruption doesn't encroach into our business operations," he said. He said Government was trying to maximise the proceeds from the mining firms through employing monitoring mechanisms. The Government was closely working with players in the industry to harmonise mining operations among the mining companies, the State and members of the community. Mr Yaluma said despite the country being in the mining business for a long time, it still needed more knowledge and technical know-how, especially that mining was dynamic. He said Zambia still faced challenges in the issuance of licences and that some of the hitches needed to be resolved using different approaches. He said it was imperative that the Zambian and Ethiopian governments exchanged ideas relating to the mining sector. The minister tasked his deputy, Richard Musukwa to come up with a workable roadmap highlighting how the two countries could share ideas on mining before the Ethiopian delegation leaves the country on Sunday. Mr Shagi said his delegation was in Zambia to learn how the country was implementing the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI). The delegation also wants to acquire knowledge on the sector from the country's vast experience as the Ethiopian ministry of mines did not have as much experience as Zambia did. Zambia EITI secretariat head, Siforiano Banda said Zambia felt privileged to be used as a showcase in the EITI implementation. Zambia joined EITI in July 2008 owing to perceived lack of transparency following the privatisation of the mining sector. It became a candidate country in May 2009. The EITI was first announced at the World Summit for Sustainable Development (the Earth Summit) in Johannesburg, South Africa, in 2002 and officially launched in London the following year.

TITLE: City Riddled With Corruption, Mismanagement - Councillors
SUBJECT: CITIES (91%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (91%); CITY GOVERNMENT (91%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); MAYORS (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); TALKS & MEETINGS (89%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (78%); CIVIL SERVICES (73%); RESIDENTIAL COOPERATIVES (71%); APPROVALS (68%); INVESTIGATIONS (65%); LABOR UNIONS (60%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Harare City Council is riddled with corruption, mismanagement and lack of leadership, vices that have negatively affected service delivery. Briefing Local Government, Rural and Urban Development Minister Ignatius Chombo on developments in Harare yesterday, the city's special interest councillors took turns to blast Mayor Muchadeyi Masunda, town clerk Dr Tendai Mahachi and directors. "We lack resolute and determined leadership. "The mayor and town clerk have no capacity to push directors on the ground. The mayor and town clerk speak lofty plans but there is no action on the ground," Clr Thembinkosi Magwaliba said. The Harare lawyer said the "two eloquent speakers" have let the city down by projecting an image of the city that is divorced from the reality. He said there was clear and palpable corruption of councillors especially when it comes to awarding tenders and approval of deals. Clr Magwaliba said there was concerted effort to push donor-funded projects to the detriment of the internally funded programmes. He accused "individuals" within council trying to impress donors by accounting for the funds. Most housing co-operatives in Harare, he said, were fronted by councilors. Clr Lisbon Marufu said most of the co-operatives that were being given land were illegally connecting municipal water causing shortages to residents who pay for the service. There was also a complaint that only co-operatives aligned to the MDC-T were getting land. The co-operatives aligned to the MDC-T and companies that have official representation in council were also getting land at very cheap prices. Clr Magwaliba said the present council was being populist in parceling out land. "We are parceling land like we are the last residents of Harare," he said. Minister Chombo agreed with the sentiments expressed by Clr Magwaliba. Clr Sasha Jogi said council was divided accusing senior officials of stripping the city of its assets. "The camps are quietly and expeditiously getting rid of city assets. Nobody is in control of the functionaries. There is no pro-active leadership at Town House," he said. He asked Minister Chombo to institute an investigation into the city operations. Clr Angus Martens said the city was trying to destroy the Harare Municipal workers Union to put into office a subservient union that turns a blind eye to wrongs committed. Clr Moosa Allana complained that council surrendered the title deeds of Trafalgar Court to a local bank for over a US$5 million overdraft yet the property was worth far more than that. Mayor Muchadeyi Masunda once accused special interest councillors as non-performers. Minister Chombo promised to convene a meeting with council tomorrow (Friday) to discuss some of the issues raised. He said he would get the elected councillors to enumerate on issues affecting service delivery despite the city having grand service delivery plans. Mr Masunda and committee chairpersons are expected to attend the meeting.

TITLE: Former ACC Boss Talks About His Experience in Sierra Leone at UN Corruption Debate
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (77%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (76%); LAWYERS (74%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (74%); LEGISLATION (69%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (69%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (50%) Sierra Leone; International Organizations and Africa; Corruption
TEXT: Many anti-corruption commissions have been "set up to fail, however they could succeed if they were given the right mandate and the right powers. In many cases those elements were lacking," former Anti-Corruption Commissioner ACC boss, Mr. Abdul Tejan-Cole said during his address as a panelist at the recently concluded two-day United Nations Economic and Social Council ECOSOC 2012 high-level panel discussion held to highlight the costs of corruption on societies. The two day high-level corruption discussion from July 9 to 10 held at the UN headquarters in New York, offered two interactive dialogues under the overall theme of "Accountability, transparency and sustainable development: turning challenges into opportunities". The first panel was focused on "Creating inclusive and cohesive societies: a multidisciplinary approach to combating corruption for development" and the second on "Shared roles and responsibilities: developing innovative partnerships for comprehensive action against corruption". Sharing some of the lessons from his experience in Sierra Leone during the first interactive panel on Monday July 9th, Mr. Tejan-Cole, who is currently the Regional Director for Africa at the Open Society Foundation based in New York, told the panel that the most important challenge in his country's context was that "the anti-corruption commission had a very weak legal framework and a very weak law. When the commission itself was setup in 2000, it was largely set up not as a result of the desire of the government of Sierra Leone to implement a genuine anti-corruption reform, but largely because of the pressure it was receiving from the donors and so a weak law was put in place that had only nine offenses." He also emphasized that during his tenure as ACC head between 2008 and 2010, a new anti-corruption act was put in place in Sierra Leone which instituted several new provisions. A major change in the law includes a key provision in the new act which took away prosecutorial powers from the attorney general and minister of justice and handed it over to the anti-corruption commissioner. Also introduced in the new law were steeper legal penalties, whistleblower provisions and strengthening the hand of the ACC to be able to engage in cooperation with other states and other agencies. Mr. Tejan-Cole said prior to 2008, only about 30 corruption cases had been prosecuted in Sierra Leone and the quality of those prosecutions were left to be desired. But between 2008 and 2010, the number doubled and the quality of those prosecutions improved. More than 500 delegates, including government ministers and heads of civil society groups, international institutions and the private sector, attended the ECOSOC's high-level segment which focused on boosting productive capacity, strengthening development cooperation and creating decent and sustainable work. In his opening remarks for the discussion, Under-Secretary-General and Executive Director of the United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime UNODC, Mr. Yury Fedotov, said that an estimated $40 billion is stolen from developing countries annually meaning that each country loses up to $258 million per year or $700,000 per day. He added that the high cost of the abuse is being paid by ordinary citizens who could not access basic services and urged every sector of society to see combating corruption as a shared responsibility as governments cannot win the fight alone.
