"We want it to be as participatory as possible. So we invited the PUL, civil society organizations, representatives of institutions of integrity, as well as people in government cycle," she said. After the questionnaires are returned to UNCAC, she said Benin and South Africa, who are also state parties to the anti-corruption convention, would peer review Liberia while Liberia and Timor-Leste will review Angola. She said the exercise is also intended to "know whether bribery is a crime under the local laws of countries being reviewed or whether or not they have a dedicated body to fight corruption." The United Nations Convention against Corruption is a legally binding international anti-corruption instrument on signatory state parties, providing a unique opportunity to mount a global response to a global problem, she asserted. Adopted in October 2003 by the UN General Assembly, UNCAC is the first global framework to harmonize anti-corruption efforts worldwide. The 165 countries bound by UNCAC which came into force in December 2005, offers a global chance for change since it is widely recognized as the most promising initiative to curb the corruption worldwide. Meanwhile, she said the fight against corruption here was progressing with assets verification gradually taking root.

TITLE: ZAOU Don Counsels Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (90%); TEACHING & TEACHERS (90%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (90%); COLLEGE & UNIVERSITY PROFESSORS (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (67%); BANKING & FINANCE (66%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: ZAMBIA Open University (ZAOU) Chancellor Francis Yamba has urged graduates to guard against involving themselves in corrupt activities when they join industry. Professor Yamba said corruption should be fought in the quest to have a better country that was free of the vice. He was speaking in Lusaka yesterday when he awarded various degrees to 757 graduating students from a total of 885 qualified students. He called on the graduands to loathe and fight corruption when they were given opportunities to serve the country in whatever capacity whether public or private. Prof Yamba said with patriotism the country could defeat the scourge of corruption and change for the better. "It is my sincere gratitude that the graduands we are producing today should be of nothing short of integrity so that they do not fall for anything especially the dirty scourge of corruption which retards national development," he said. Vice Chancellor Dickson Mwansa appealed to the graduands to be patriotic citizens that would serve with dignity, corrupt free morals and ensure that justice in all its forms flowed like a river that never ran dry. "We look to you to work with humility wherever you find yourself be it in the media, legal practice, law enforcement, financial services, research institutions, universities and the public service at large," he said. Prof Mwansa said the university would focus on infrastructure development in order to empower the people with knowledge whilst enhancing the value of education to its finest level. He said the university had constructed four classrooms and would soon put up hostels in Lusaka that would accommodate more than 2,000 bed spaces.

TITLE: Put an End to Legalised Corruption [editorial]
SUBJECT: CURRENCIES (90%); US DOLLAR (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); CONTRACTS & BIDS (89%); PRIME MINISTERS (89%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (89%); DEFENSE DEPARTMENTS (89%); BUDGETS (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (77%); MINERAL LEASES (77%); ETHICS (76%); COMMERCE DEPARTMENTS (74%); EXCHANGE RATES (73%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (72%); MINING REGULATION & POLICY (72%); MINING & EXTRACTION RIGHTS & ROYALTIES (72%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (69%); MINES & MINING (67%) Namibia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: THIS headline is not a mere play with oxymorons and semantics. It's about the multi-billion dollar [you pick whether Namibian or US dollar] handling of Namibia's national incomes. Mind you, government contracts through the Tender Board alone amounted to N$14 billion last year, which was 37% of the national budget. The worrying issue is that abuse and misuse of state processes and resources for private gain is often 'legal' [well, what else can we say?]. Examples abound. Among recent cases at an institutional level is the military's food contract of between N$3 billion to N$5 billion over 10 years that former Prime Minister and now Minister of Defence Nahas Angula is championing. At an individual level one can point to the case of Prime Minister Hage Geingob, who, while as a Swapo backbencher, was paid US$300 000 (about N$3million at today's exchange rate) in 2006 or 2007, according to him, to advise the Namibian government to award a mining license to UraMin. UraMin is the company that, it has since become clear, overcharged the French parastatal Areva when it sold Namibia's Trekkopje and two other mines on the African continent for US$2.5b in 2005-7. Mining at Trekkopje is yet to take off. The two examples stand out, but there are many in between. Not least among those is the raking in of hundreds of millions of dollars through S&T claims. We stick to the abbreviation because S&T is now more than the 'subsistence and travel allowance' that it was meant to be - it is legalised corruption. Angula, the Minister of Defence, is arguing that he is undertaking a noble objective aimed at keeping the money within the military firms, which will in turn buy straight from suppliers of the foodstuff. The presence of private individuals as shareholders in those military companies and, especially, the secretive nature of how the deal was structured, makes it questionable. If the minister and his military generals have not broken the law, they will kid no one that what they did isn't at least morally and ethically corrupt. Similarly, Geingob's role in the awarding of a licence to UraMin and Areva and further favours extended to the French uranium company by the Ministry of Trade and Industry under his guidance are rotten, even if he later disclosed his dealings to Parliament and the President. Together with the S&Ts and other avenues that lend themselves to misuse, these are the areas that the government ought to tighten up, if only to provide confidence that our leaders will at all times act in the best interest of the country and the majority, and not a privileged few. The bill about government contracts that Minister of Finance Saara Kuugongelwa-Amadhila tabled in the National Assembly this week will no doubt improve on the deficiencies of the Tender Board Act. But it is lacking in transparency. We would suggest, for instance, that independent audits of any government contract be randomly and regularly undertaken [at intervals of three to six months]. The results must always be made public without the consent of politicians. The audits would, for instance, have helped in ensuring that the N$15 billion special job-creation programme, Tipeeg, or other government tenders, truly deliver on the intended purpose. Audits [not a mere look at the financials of the companies involved] would show whether the money was reaching the intended targets. At the moment many a tenderpreneur [colour notwithstanding] often rush to buy themselves luxury goods while state projects and objectives like job creation suffer. It is preposterous, for instance, that of the N$14 billion tenders government awarded last year, N$9.3 billion were "exempted" from public scrutiny and open bidding. Often security is cited as reasons for the exemption. The Ministry of Defence's claim of sensitivity to "national security" over its N$5 billion food contract will not wash. It is about time that at all public levels, the screws be tightened to put an end to legalised corruption.

TITLE: No Systematic Corruption in Namibia - Geingob
COUNTRY: NAMIBIA (94%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (94%); AFRICA (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (90%); PRIME MINISTERS (89%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (79%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); WAGES & SALARIES (71%); CRIME RATES (70%) Namibia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: PRIME MINISTER Hage Geingob last week told a visiting Tanzanian delegation that there is no systematic corruption in Namibia although there are perceptions. Geingob also told the delegation that corruption is a curse that needed to be fought. "There is no systematic corruption in Namibia, although perceptions are here and there," Geingob said. The Tanzanian delegation, led by Minister of State, George Mkuchika, paid Geingob a visit at his offices in a bid to share ideas and learn how to combat corruption. Mkuchika revealed that corruption in his country is on the rise hence his visit to Namibia. He said, among other responsibilities, he is expected to help the president with state issues, prevent corruption and other unethical things as well as participating in budget issues. "I hope during my time, I can help Tanzanians understand that corruption is number one enemy. I am not saying corruption is only in Tanzania, I know this is a global issue. Although we are fighting it, it does not seem to go down in our country but rather increases. The crime rate is increasing and so are corruption cases," he said, adding that every year, seven percent of the government budget ends up in procurement. Sharing the same sentiments as those of Mkuchika, Tanzania's director general for the Prevention and Combating of Corruption Bureau Edward Hosea said they are busy spending money on campaigns to fight corruption. Hosea believes there are two possible reasons for every corruption case, citing poverty as one of them. "Poverty is one of the reasons why corruption is on the increase. People are in need of money as their salaries can hardly take them through the month, much less afford basic needs," he said. Hosea also said another reason was pure greed from those in already high positions who want more money for themselves. But he said that he believes Africans need a leadership paradigm to fight corruption. "If you can't demonstrate that corruption is intolerable, then you are wasting your time trying to fight it. People understand what corruption is, but they need to be made aware that it is intolerable. Engagement of political masses must be seen. They must not appear fighting corruption but they should be seen fighting to encourage other people," Hosea said.

TITLE: Shun Corruption, Says Mutasa
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PRIMARY SCHOOLS (90%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); EXECUTIVES (77%); PRIMARY & SECONDARY EDUCATION (77%); LIVING STANDARDS (68%); LITERACY & ILLITERACY (65%); LITERACY RATES (60%); SECONDARY SCHOOLS (50%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: Presidential Affairs Minister Didymus Mutasa has urged public officials to shun corruption and be custodians of good practices to ensure the success of Government programmes. Officially opening the Herentals Tynwald Private Primary School in Harare yesterday, Minister Mutasa said President Mugabe was doing all he could to uplift the lives of Zimbabweans and the efforts should be fully complemented. The school, whose construction started in 2011, comprises two blocks with 10 classrooms, two smaller classroom blocks and an administration block. "We should have a corruption free Zimbabwe as we work hard to achieve the goals we have set as a Government for the next five years after our resounding victory in the harmonised elections," said Minister Mutasa. "The call begins with us public officials and should cascade down to grassroots levels. Everyone in Government should focus on uplifting the standards of living. The President is on record denouncing corruption for us to realise development and we should come in and support his efforts." Minister Mutasa said had the officials involved in the building of the school been corrupt, the project would not have been a success. "We never thought we would have such a day like this," he said. "But, because you were open in your operations and put your hearts towards the project, it is today a success. These are some of the signs where a corrupt free country will take us to." Minister Mutasa said the new school would go a long way in complementing Government efforts of improving school infrastructure countrywide. "This is a welcome gesture by Herentals that would assist Government because money that would have been used by the State to build such a school would now go towards other areas," he said. "As such, I urge the corporate world to extend such a hand to Government for it to achieve its targets outlined in the Zanu-PF manifesto. I am excited that such a model we are seeing here today is the one that is going to be used in the construction of Maturi Primary School in Headlines, which is my constituency. "I would be happy if this spreads to other parts of the country such that we maintain our control of the literacy rate level in Africa." The minister said Government would offer land to people willing to construct schools and institutions that benefit children. Herentals Group of Colleges and Schools executive director Mr Emmanuel Mahachi said education was pivotal to national development and the group would continue complementing Government efforts in the sector. He said the literacy level Zimbabwe boasts of was due to the people's love for books. "Resources permitting, we will continue establishing primary, secondary schools and colleges countrywide to ensure we reach out to all corners," Mr Mahachi said. "The more education we give to our children the more developed, as a country we become. Our advantage is that in President Mugabe we have a man who values education and would want to see more resources being channeled to the education sector." Herentals has three primary schools, 11 secondary schools and several colleges countrywide.

TITLE: United Nations of Corruption [analysis]
SUBJECT: ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (90%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (78%); HUMAN RESOURCES (78%); BANKING & FINANCE AGENCIES (76%); CIVIL SERVICES (76%); PUBLIC FINANCE AGENCIES & TREASURIES (76%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (76%); CONSULTING SERVICES (74%); ECONOMIC NEWS (71%) Ethiopia; Corruption; International Organizations and Africa; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: My severe reluctance to work for any of the United Nations organisations began during my early days of employment. The fundamental reason is my aversion of working for a toothless organisation with no significant leverage to push for its decisions in changing the lives of people. But, there is also a further reason - corruption. My five years at the Ministry of Finance & Economic Development (MoFED) have given me enough exposure to the workings of the various UN organisations. The crosscutting similarity between all of them, at least as far as I saw it, was the systematisation of corruption. Corruption in the UN system has many technical wraps, from retreat to consultancy. Any organisation that seeks to have a UN status seems also to copy the corrupt practices of the global beast. That seems to be why the African Union (AU), the New Partnership for African Development (NEPAD), the Intergovernmental Agency for Development (IGAD) and many other regional organisations that copy the status and structure of the UN remain as systemically corrupt as their mentor. At the heart of the corruption, in both the UN and its protges, is the human resource recruitment process. It is so spoiled that it is visibly disgusting. Competence has nothing to do with it. What matters is a good blood, as Ethiopians say, to express "good connection." During my days at the MoFED, I appraised many projects that the Ethiopian government works on in close collaboration with the various UN agencies. I have met many project coordinators from the UN agencies' side that improperly push for the continuation of projects simply to secure their high-paid jobs. In my informal discussion with them, most tell me how important the job is for them and for their families. I used to get confused about the paradox. An Ethiopian civil servant who often gets paid a meagre income fights about the impact of projects on the livelihood of citizens, while a UN employee, who grosses over 200pc more, worries about job security. It is only after some time that I came to understand the root cause for the worries of the project coordinators - systematised corruption. After all, they got the job not because they are competent enough, but because they have good connections. Recently, a friend of mine from one of the western African nations came toEthiopiato consult the African Union (AU) on issues relating to intra-African trade. He told me that he was being paid 20,000 plus dollars for a month, in addition to five-star accommodation, fancy transportation and cost for utilities. It is not his rather fancy recruitment that amazed me, however. Rather, it was his simple observation. He once asked me - "Why do Ethiopians work only as guards and gardeners in the major international and regional organisations based in Addis Abeba?" Isn't it logical that one would expect to see more Ethiopian professionals in these organisations, for the simple reason of physical proximity?" My answer was simple - "Yes. The question might be logical. But, the answer is not". The recruitment process of these organisations is spoiled with nepotism, corruption, racial short-termism and personal affiliations, which even highly educated and experienced Ethiopians could not access. This is unless, of course, they have the good blood. It all boils down to the type of blood one has. Even reformers, such as the newly appointed Executive Secretary of the Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), Carlos Lopes, are seen swayed by the decades-old culture of corruption in the system. Their approach continues to be based on employing their former colleagues as highly paid consultants, under the guise of institutional reform. What can signal the demise of an institution more than the systematisation of corrupt practices, though? I wonder how ordinary Africans, let alone Ethiopians, would accept the big words of integration, unity, development, poverty reduction, empowerment and so on, while the very preachers are unprincipled enough to live with sanity. How can institutional legitimacy be established under the waters of corruption? As a pacemaker of a system, recruitment ought to be free of nepotism. It ought to be established purely on the basis of competence. Salaries ought to be indications of professionalism and they ought to be earned. These ought to be more defining when organisations have no hard power to realise them. But, if the world is to follow the UN way, its end is certainly a train wreck. Incubating corruption at all levels will do nothing other than reducing an institution to a toothless, disrespected, inefficient and illegitimate beast. And, working for such an institution bears no pride. Of course, the trend applies to most of the bilateral development agencies too. But it is not as momentous as in the UN and its protges. If change is to come, then the movers and shakers of these various organisations with funny abbreviations ought to start baptising their system in the name of sanity, integrity, professionalism and impartiality. It all, however, ought to start from the top. Creating a culture that abhors favouritism could not be secured by reforming human resource departments only. It rather sits in bringing a new culture that stands in favour of competence. I see no more pertinent task than this for the toothless globalisers based in Addis Abeba and New York. Getachew T. Alemu Is the Op-Ed Editor for Fortune. He Can Be Contacted At Getachew@addisfortune.com

TITLE: Slow Progress in Corruption Fight - SRSG
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); RIOTS (86%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (78%); PEACEKEEPING (73%); SEX OFFENSES (69%); SEXUAL ASSAULT (69%) Liberia; Corruption; International Organizations and Africa; Peacekeeping and Conflict Resolution
TEXT: The head of United Nations Mission in Liberia (UNMIL), Ellen Landgreen, has said that progressive in the fight against corruption remains slow despite the government's effort to put in place anti-corruption institutions in order to minimize and curb the misuse of public funds by officials. Madam Landgreen made the comment Tuesday in Monrovia at UNMIL's regular press briefing. "We're aware that the government is doing well in the fight against corruption in this country. However, despite putting in place anti-corruption institutions, progress in this area remains slow, and we expect to see more progress in this fight because corruption undermines development," she said. UNMIL boss could not say which area the fight against corruption is taking slow pace, but cautioned the public to allow anti-corruption institutions to carry on their tasks in a more effective way and should not be undermined "Corruption is a major handicap to progress and it interferes with broad base functions and institutions in this country," Madam Landgreen said. She described the President's recent suspension and dismissal of some senior government officials as an important step in the fight against corruption. She, however, indicated that more has to be done in order to make significant progress in the fight against graft and misuse of public resources. "Progress remains slow though, and we would like to see more progress on this," she said. She also disclosed 25% increase in sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) across the country, and revealed that mob violence has increased to 40%. She warned those engaged in mob violence to desist and seek legal redress in handling their grievances. "We can talk about the need to punish or prosecute perpetrators, but it's very important to stress that these forms of violence must be rejected by society," SRSG Landgreen said. She added: "Once it's socially unacceptable to engage in sexual violence. Once, it's unacceptable to go after suspected perpetrators of crimes and kill them." If such acts are abandoned, she said the risk of sexual and gender based violence, including mob violence, she noted, "Will be significantly reduced."

TITLE: VP Mujuru - Pay Workers to End Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); AGRICULTURE (89%); AGRICULTURAL TRADE (89%); TOBACCO INDUSTRY (89%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (89%); TOBACCO FARMING (89%); IMPORT TRADE (85%); BANKING & FINANCE (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); PRODUCTIVITY (77%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (76%); ECONOMIC NEWS (76%); LIVING STANDARDS (75%); FOOD EXPORTS & IMPORTS (74%); RELOCATIONS (64%); GRAIN EXPORTS & IMPORTS (63%); EMBARGOES & SANCTIONS (63%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Vice President Joice Mujuru has called on organisations to rightfully reward people for their labour to minimise cases of corruption. She singled out the agriculture sector where she said farmers needed to fully enjoy benefits from their efforts. Speaking at a graduation ceremony for participants of the Tobacco Improved Productivity Sites at Kutsaga Research Station in Harare yesterday, VP Mujuru said despite the phenomenal growth registered by the tobacco industry in recent years, farmers were not enjoying the rewards for their labour. "Tobacco farmers work hard, plant crops and get to contribute to the national income, hence we expect them to be given a hand so that they can use other smaller portions on their farms to meet their daily food requirements," she said. "It is only through an evidently changed standard of living that agriculture can be appreciated by the different facets of the community." VP Mujuru said empowering people through giving them the rightful returns for their labour was one way of fighting corruption. "People are overcharging in health institutions, some are being corrupt at roadblocks," she said. "White collar crime has also taken centre stage in this country, and this should be condemned." VP Mujuru implored financial institutions to loan out money at reasonable rates. "Banks are enjoying the peace and security in our country and should, therefore, give farmers money at cheaper rates for our industry to grow. "We should show that we now own the resources," she said. "Let us conserve our land as the most precious thing. "No one will be relocated to better places having failed to properly use what they already have." VP Mujuru hailed tobacco farmers for being successful despite being adversely affected by the illegal economic sanctions imposed on the country by the West. She said it was gratifying to note that tobacco growing was on the rise again. "The rebound of the tobacco industry has resulted in much excitement with indications that tobacco contributed 10,7 percent of the GDP in 2012," said VP Mujuru. "There is still room for much growth and all stakeholders need to play their part to ensure that Zimbabwe not only produces the quantity, but also produces the quality desired by our markets." VP Mujuru commended the tobacco industry for "the sterling work that has allowed this extraordinary expansion" and urged the stakeholders to continue working together for the benefit of the country. Alluding to reports that farmers in some areas were now growing cash crops instead of grains to make more money, VP Mujuru said Government was determined for small grains to be sold at best prices . She said if farmers concentrated on crops that were ideal for their farming regions, the country would not import food. "The money we have been using to import grain from countries like Zambia should be used to pay local farmers," said VP Mujuru. "It should work towards ensuring job creation and making indigenisation a reality in all sectors." The training programme for the tobacco farmers was conducted by Kutsaga as part of efforts to improve productivity of tobacco growers through practical lessons on all aspects of growing the crop. Mr Suarance Matope of Omeath Farm in Mashonaland Central scooped the first prize in the farmers' category among the farmers in the 15 tobacco growing regions who took part in the training. Mr Matope's trainer and Agritex officer Mr Peter Tsungu won the first prize in the officers' category.

TITLE: Public Procurement Authority Versus Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (98%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (88%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); LEGISLATION (76%); PUBLIC CONTRACTS LAW (75%); POLICE FORCES (69%); CRIME PREVENTION (66%); PURCHASING & PROCUREMENT (60%) Zambia; Corruption
TEXT: THERE are widespread feelings that the fight against corruption in Zambia does not seem to be fully taken up by everyone in the country. By nature of things, it is almost impossible to exclude anyone except where positive opinions or evidence does not show. As it is not feasible or practical for everybody to issue a statement saying they are opposed to corruption or does corrupt acts which can tend to be judged as corrupt acts, we have to look at the whole issue as laid down under the laws of Zambia. Let us begin with an old saying "For evil to triumph all that is needed is that all good people do nothing." President Michael Sata, again, said in his address to the National Assembly on Friday September 20, 2013: "The fight against corruption remains one of the top priorities on our good governance agenda. Government will, therefore, strengthen and decentralise the operations of the Anti-Corruption Commission to enable it to effectively execute its mandate." He then announced that the Government had established a special investigations unit (like the old SITET) in the commission to deal with complex financial crimes. The basic issues affecting the fight against corruption are: Failure by those under whom activities take place but are unable, afraid, unwilling to prevent these crimes and lack of dedication to their duties. Other reasons given for failure to fight corruption are the alleged widespread corruption within the Zambia Police Service, Judiciary and politicians. There have also been allegations that some people have been 'visited' or threatened by the culprits, therefore, the tendency is to make general allegations naming no-one in particular. This is in spite of the various pieces of legislation which give some protection and authority to step forward and put a stop to the practice. The Judiciary does not help the fighters by the slow pace at which reports are handled. As the Government and local councils are the biggest spenders, there is belief that it is in the public service that the battle has got to be reinforced with change of attitude, fearlessness against undue influences and actually imposing the penalties. Following certain weaknesses discovered in the Zambia National Tender Board, which was replaced by the Zambia Public Procurement Authority, the new Act No 12 of 2008 restated the principal objectives thus: To revise the law relating to procurement so as to ensure transparency and accountability in public procurement; regulate and control practices relating to public procurement in order to promote the integrity of, fairness and public confidence in, the procurement process. Let us look at the Public Procurement Act, No 12 of 2008 which was supposed to process enquiries and downstream action more quickly. After President Sata announced enhanced action against corruption, British High Commissioner, James Thornton stated that there is too much corruption in Zambia. He is concerned at the lack of commitment by those who should do more. The British Government has been committing the British taxpayer's money to assist the Zambian Government in the fight against corruption for a long time. At the same time, a senior officer in the Zambia Public Procurement Authority (ZPPA) was issuing a statement that politicians' interference in the public procurement process which was making it difficult to fight corruption. The details he had seem not to have been passed on to the ACC to pursue further. It is this desire to issue statements rather than report to the ACC which prevent the general public from thinking that there is anything to expect in the ZPPA. For the removal of doubts about this image of the Authority the law says in regard to enforcement of integrity fairness and trust in the body... A few definitions will do: "coercive practices" means harming or threatening to harm directly or indirectly, a person or person's property, to influence participation in a procurement process or affect the execution of a contract." The statement explaining how senior officers and politicians influence the procurement process called immediately... why he had not given the details to the ACC or to the Zambia Police. "corrupt practice" means the offering, giving or receiving or soliciting, directly or indirectly, anything of value to influence the action of a public officer in the procurement process or in contract execution." "goods" means objects of any kind and description including raw materials, products, equipment, objects in solid, liquid or gaseous form, electricity and works and services incidental to the supply of the goods if the value of those incidental works and services does not exceed that of the goods themselves." The ZPPA officer who bemoaned the behaviour of politicians and public officers showed exactly why the fight against corruption cannot be defeated as long as such people continue to hold office. Without going into too many details, the senior ZPPA official referred to above, could not have been ignorant of: section 75 (2) (b) "A public officer commits an offence who uses the position as a public officer dishonestly or with the intention of directly or indirectly gaining an advantage for oneself or someone else or causing detriment to a procurement entity;" section 75 (2) (c) "Uses the position of a public officer recklessly without regard to whether the conduct may directly or indirectly gain an advantage for oneself or someone else or cause detriment to a procurement entity;" and is liable to the applicable administrative and legal sanctions applicable to public officers under the conditions of employment and any other written of law. With these provisions within the law which set up the ZPPA why does anybody especially a senior official in that organisation complain about political interference? To revisit some of the applicable considerations: (a) The Public Interest Disclosure (Protection of Whistleblowers) Act, No 4 of 2010 Section 10: 'An employer shall not subject an employee to any occupational detriment on account or partly on account, of an employee having made a protected disclosure or public interest disclosure". This reference should be well known by all employees, including the senior managers of ZPPA. Under the same Act (12 of 2008) the ZPPA should by now have written rules and regulations in the field of public procurement. For the official to say there is need for rules governing the code of conduct is laughable, because this is the basis on which the organisation can base its day-to-day activities. Another note of interest is the statement (or allegation) by the chairperson of the Zambia Chapter of African Parliamentary Network Against Corruption (APNAC) Hon Cornelius Mweetwa. Again we see the same inability to take action but resort to issuing statements. It is reported in the Post newspapers that there was considerable abuse of UNWTO funds before and during the UNWTO conference held in Livingstone and Zimbabwe, around Victoria Falls. Hon Mweetwa said that according to the information he had received, the companies that were given contracts were the same ones that were contracted as consultants. Surely APNAC should not have sat on their hands until after the meetings. It is totally irregular ... the management of resources could have seen the reported developments. This country has undertaken projects of this kind, but APNAC should have been in the forefront of ensuring that the resources would be properly managed. This is yet another of how NOT to fight corruption or abuse of funds and other resources. The Auditor-General reported these names to the Ministry of Tourism and the ACC, but nothing has been heard from APNAC - Hon. Mweetwa, what is going on? the Zambians want to see positive action on corruption. Reporting to the press or the National Assembly will not do. Like evaluating intelligence, the bodies concerned with preventing collusion, abuse of resources... official positions should organise themselves. We want to receive reports of action taken not to bewail the happenings. The Government should not be expected to restructure institutions when the aims are clear and accepted. It is essential that the ZPPA show capacity to defeat corruption. Nobody else will do it except the Zambians themselves. If appointed or nominated officials cannot show better dedication, they should be removed. There is need to shape up or ship out. The country's name and image can be damaged by the attitudes shown so far by people in high places, who do not seem to understand why they are in these positions.

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Fight Goes to New Level
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (91%); POLITICS (89%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (89%); ETHICS (78%); ELECTIONS (77%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (70%); INVESTIGATIONS (69%); ATTORNEYS GENERAL (68%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (60%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: After years of dilly-dallying, Zimbabwe's parliamentarians will finally be compelled to declare their assets as part of measures to curb corruption. Previously, the declaration of assets by Members of Parliament was done on a voluntary basis. And only a fraction of the parliamentarians took the bold step. But the game has changed. Members of the 370-seat Parliament are now mandatory to declare assets. Most of the Cabinet ministers are also parliamentarians. Speaker Jacob Mudenda said he expected measures to be put in place to compel parliamentarians to declare their assets during the first session of the Parliament. Zimbabwe's new parliament, with the ruling Zanu-PF party taking more than two-thirds majority seats, was mostly elected in the July 31 elections. The new parliament officially opened on 17 September, and the order to declare assets soon came in toe. "Only through that self-transparency will we deserve and live to that epithet. This will send a clear message that this Parliament will not condone any form of corruption," Mudenda said. While opening the session, President Robert Mugabe said the government would exercise "zero tolerance" to the scourge of corruption. Structures to combat it would be bolstered through the establishment of the National Prosecution Authority as prescribed in the new Constitution, the president said. This independent body is set to take over the functions previously performed by the Criminal Division of the Attorney General's Office. The composition of the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission will also be aligned to the new Constitution, while Anti-Corruption Commissioners will be required to adhere to a strict code of ethics and to also publicly declare their personal assets. In another show of zero tolerance to corruption, Mugabe also openly accused a former chairperson of a parastatal body involved in the mining development of graft. Such open accusation, especially from the president, is not common. The government has now instituted investigations against Goodwills Masimirembwa, who has professed innocence even though Mugabe mentioned him by name and accused him of soliciting 6 million US dollars from a Ghanaian businessman to facilitate his investment. The Anti-Corruption Trust of Southern Africa immediately welcomed Mugabe's utterances on corruption and said this virtual declaration of war was in line with the United Nations Convention Against Corruption. The convention refers to the critical role of prosecutorial services in combating corruption, the existence of a capacitated anti-corruption body and the importance of codes of ethics and the declaration of assets. Mugabe has in the past been accused of not taking a strong stance against corruption. Several people interviewed by Xinhua also welcomed the new requirement of parliamentarians and said politicians were more susceptible to corruption than ordinary citizens. "They know all the shortcuts and can facilitate illegal transactions using their political clout. We have seen some top people fleeing the country for allegedly being involved in shady deals such as money laundering and externalisation of funds," said Charles Mariga of Highfield, Harare. Faith Motsi, also of Harare, said it was disheartening to always see the well-connected enjoying public services while those who were not were left to fork out a lot of money in order to be served. "Why should I pay to jump the queue at the passport office? Why should I pay to get a place for my child at school, even at kindergarten level? And why should I pay to get Anti-Retroviral Drugs which should be given for free?" - Nampa-Xinhua

TITLE: New Measures Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); LOBBYING (76%); MOVIE INDUSTRY (75%); WRITERS (73%); HIP HOP CULTURE (72%); CHILD LABOR (72%); SLUM DWELLINGS (71%); STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (70%); FESTIVALS (70%); DOCUMENTARY FILMS (70%); FILM SCHOOLS (70%); RAP MUSIC (69%); COPYRIGHT LAW (69%); COPYRIGHT (69%); FREEDOM OF INFORMATION (68%); WOMEN'S HEALTH (67%); FILM (65%); ARTS FESTIVALS & EXHIBITIONS (65%); INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAW (54%); ENERGY SHORTAGES (50%) Liberia; Corruption
TEXT: Civil society group Accountability Lab has come up with a new way to raise awareness of how to combat corruption in Africa - bus tours. The non-profit is developing a series of tours of its grassroots work in Liberia and Nepal to give travellers a different experience of local culture, while helping to fight bribery, graft and promote transparent government. "Instead of tourists visiting slum dwellers, I want to show positive things that people are doing to change the quality of their lives in their communities," Blair Glencorse, executive director of Accountability Lab, said at an OpenGovHub luncheon in Washington. Tour highlights include a visit to Rappers Against Corruption, a group of singers who are lobbying the Liberian government to provide strong copyright laws for their work. In Nepal, visitors meet Rajneesh Bhandari who is building a network of investigative journalists to fight corruption, using the newly passed Right to Information Act. On the streets of Monrovia, tourists will get to read the Daily Talk, a citizens' newspaper displayed on a big chalkboard at a busy city intersection. It delivers bold headlines, news updates and useful civic information for those who cannot afford a daily newspaper. The most-requested story recently was one giving instructions on how to use the newly installed traffic lights, a novelty for the city. And Accountability Lab has a film school that puts cameras into the hands of Liberians. Their documentaries tell of child labour, electricity shortages, sexual exploitation in schools, water problems and maternal health. The winner at its first film festival in September was a young woman who exposed how teachers coerced sex from students in return for promises of good grades. Glencorse said his goal through all these projects is to have people take responsibility for creating change. "There is a lot of talk and shouting about corruption among public officials, but there is a sense of otherness about the way it is discussed. People say if someone else pays a bribe then its bribery, but if I pay a bribe, it is just me getting by," he said. "What I do is look at not only systemic and organizational issues around corruption but also personal accountability and responsibility. These are projects where people are doing something about it."

TITLE: Burglars steal sensitive data from anti-corruption NGO
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); BURGLARY (90%); NONGOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); WHISTLEBLOWERS (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (77%); PRESS CONFERENCES (70%); EXECUTIVES (68%); AIDS & HIV (67%); AIDS & HIV TREATMENT (66%); GOVERNMENT CONTROLLERS & AUDITORS (64%)
TEXT: Despite the development, ACCU's authorities maintain that they will stand their ground in the fight against graft in the country. Kampala- Burglars have broken into the Anti-Corruption Coalition Uganda (ACCU) offices and robbed the NGO of vital data on corruption cases. The Thursday night burglary left the NGO's offices on Kira Road virtually turned upside down, with more than 20 computers, sensitive data documents and server stolen. By Friday evening, police were still recording statements and seeking clues about the incident. "We arrived quite early for work as usual only to find our offices had been broken into. The door locks were all destroyed, drawers, files and documents turned upside down. The guard was not sober; it seems he had been chloroformed," Mr Felix Kafuma, the NGO's Information Officer, said. He added: "Obviously it is more than robbery; everything looks planned, we cannot even rule out an inside job. This comes at a time when ACCU is venturing into the dreaded area of unearthing theft of public funds. We have blown the whistle on scandals in influential offices." This week, the organisation addressed a press conference on what it termed as "blatant inaction by the Judiciary on corruption at the Law Development Centre court." FeudsIt has also had a long-standing battle with a local company over alleged inflation of costs of HIV/Aids drugs in which the Auditor General implicates the company of causing the government a loss of more than Shs48 billion. "Every office has its own locks but these were all broken, the server where we back up the information and hard disk were taken but shockingly, the projector was left intact. You cannot take anything for granted, we strongly feel it was targeted and specific." "Why would any thief leave a projector which was easier to carry and even more expensive than the computers and server? We are not making conclusions yet, let the police investigate but who would be interested in our nature of work?" Ms Cissy Kagaba, the ACCU executive director, told the Sunday Monitor by phone from Mbale. Ms Kagaba was defiant and said the burglary will not deter the NGO from its anti-corruption crusade. "If it was aimed at disorganising us, then they have failed. It actually gives us the zeal to confront the big monster of corruption in Uganda! It is an act of cowardice, we are not intimidated by an inch and we have all information backed up. They have thrown a stone into a hive of bees," Ms Kagaba said. Mr Ibin Ssenkumbi, the Kampala police spokesperson, said the case was under investigation but no arrests had been made by Friday. "But the information we have is that the guard was chloroformed and is not yet in position to talk but we hope to draw clues from him when he recovers which will inform the investigation," he said. Police says Mr Ssenkumbi dismissed suspicions of state-engineered break-in to destroy sensitive information under disguised burglary."I don't think so. Why would government do such a thing? Because of the press conferences they have been addressing about corruption to kill evidence? Even then they simply investigate and share their findings, they don't prosecute. Anyway I don't want to bias the investigations but all these suspicions will be considered," Mr Ssenkumbi said. editorial@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Why must the government persecute anti-corruption activists?
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (78%); POLICE FORCES (55%)
TEXT: The NRM government in its Ten Point Programme and its subsequent manifestos made a commitment to fight corruption at whatever cost, a good thing for all to pride in their government. It is noted world over that corruption is a vice that needs to be eliminated at whatever cost and this is evidenced by most states that criminalise the act. In Uganda, corruption in all its forms is illegal, to this effect, various institutions have been put in place like the IGG, Anti-corruption Police Unit, the Anti corruption Court among others. The NRM government in its Ten Point Programme and its subsequent manifestos made a commitment to fight corruption at whatever cost, a good thing for all to pride in their government. However, I am disheartened that in Uganda, it is almost a crime for one to fight bad things for example corruption. Lately, you are dubbed anti-state, a rebel and in opposition if you dared speak out against the vice. Why fight the anti corruption activists? Sensitizing masses about corruption is the sole responsibility of the state and if the civil society is sensitising masses about corruption and encouraging masses to shun corruption, then the government should instead be happy and join hands, however, this is the obverse; the activists are either arrested or threatened for doing their duty as the citizens of this country. This should stop, corruption affects everyone, therefore it needs collective effort to combat but for government to concentrate more on suppressing those fighting corruption rather than fighting it is disturbing.Let us all join hands to fight corruption. Michael Aboneka,abonex2007@yahoo.com

TITLE: 'Poverty, Corruption Promote Drug Trafficking'
COUNTRY: AFRICA (97%); ZIMBABWE (93%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (79%); KENYA (79%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (66%)
SUBJECT: CONTROLLED SUBSTANCES CRIME (93%); DRUG TRAFFICKING (93%); CORRUPTION (90%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (90%); UNEMPLOYED PERSONS (90%); CHILD POVERTY (89%); SOCIETAL ISSUES (78%); DRUG POLICY (78%); ILLEGAL WEAPONS (78%); CHILD TRAFFICKING (78%); TALKS & MEETINGS (77%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (77%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (77%); MONEY LAUNDERING (74%); CRIMINAL LAW (74%); INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORGANIZATIONS (73%); HUMAN TRAFFICKING (73%); EUROPEAN UNION (62%); TERRORISM (51%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Corruption, poverty and high youth unemployment in Africa is creating a breeding ground for drug trafficking on the continent, which is a major cause for concern, a senior African Union official has said. Speaking at the two-day continental experts consultation conference on drug trafficking and related challenges to human security in Harare, AU director of Social Affairs, Dr Olawale Maiyegun said there was an urgent need for comprehensive and organised interventions to combat drug trafficking. The two-day conference seeks to discuss improved responses to address drug trafficking and related challenges to human security. Also at the centre of discussion is the legislative and law enforcement responses and reporting frameworks, priority strategies and data collection and reporting. "In Africa we are faced or we are dealing with vast cross borders and coastlines. The presence of fragile and post-conflict States weakens criminal justice systems. "Corruption, poverty, high youth unemployment are all working together and serving as potential breeding grounds for criminality and a host of social problems. "We must have a balanced and integrated approach and if these challenges are not confronted we will not overcome," said Dr Maiyegun. He said drug trafficking was an organised crime linked to human trafficking, terrorism, trafficking of weapons, small arms which involved corruption and money laundering that serve as a common denominator to all of them. Dr Maiyegun said the devastating consequences of drug trafficking were a threat to democratic governments and stability of nations. "We are all affected. We are all living witnesses to what happened in Kenya and we can see it shows we are all vulnerable," he said adding that drug traffickers continued to seek for new markets and constantly changed their methods of operation. He bemoaned the lack of comprehensive reporting, data collecting and analysis as major challenges. Dr Maiyegun said despite the challenges, Africa had demonstrated a political commitment to address drug trafficking through a comprehensive adoption of the AU Drug Plan of Action. Dr Maiyegun said the AU Peace and Security Council earlier this year took a decision and gave the AU Commission a mandate to address the social and economic security challenges of drug trafficking in Africa. European Union special advisor Mr Giorgio Romano said the bloc was committed to working with Africa to fight drug trafficking. Officer in Charge, Regional office for the Southern Africa office of Drugs and Crime, Mr Ehab Salah Ahmed also said drug use in Africa was expanding particularly among young people and there was a need for countries to find new ways of combating drug trafficking.

TITLE: Former Nyamasheke Executive Secretary Rearrested Over New Corruption Charges
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); EVIDENCE (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); RESIGNATIONS (90%); BRIBERY (89%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (78%); INTERVIEWS (78%); CONSTRUCTION (74%); ACQUITTAL (61%) Rwanda; Corruption
TEXT: The former executive secretary of Nyamasheke District in the Western Province, Jean Pierre Ndagijimana, has been arrested days after he resigned from his position citing personal reasons. Ndagijimana had, on October 10, tendered in his resignation letter to the district mayor and officially handed over office on Tuesday. In an interview with this paper this week, Ndagijimana said he resigned his post to pursue post graduate studies. The Western Region Police Spokesperson Superintendent Hamza Vita confirmed the arrest, saying Ndagijimana was detained on Thursday after new evidence emerged linking him to a new corruption scam in the area. Ndagihimana is alleged to have received Rwf17million 'as a donation' from a construction firm which was hired to build the Hanika-Kivugiza road, according to Police. "Preliminary investigations indicate that the money was given to him [Ndagijimana] to gain [unlawful] favours," Supt Vita told this paper, without giving details. "That constitutes an act of corruption itself." The construction of the non-tarmac road is set to cost around one billion Rwandan francs. As the head of administration in the district, he headed the management and technical units and was the overall supervisor for the district staff. "We are still investigating the case to uncover more evidence. We are soon handing his dossier to the prosecution," Vita said. According to Supt Vita, police launched investigations in the new corruption allegations some days ago after a tip off from a well-informed area resident. It is the second time that the former Nyamasheke District employee is detained on corruption related charges in less than three months. In August, Ndagijimana was arrested and detained in Kigali on charges that he tried to bribe an official at the Office of the Ombudsman to cover up false declaration of his wealth. At the time, a spokesman of the Office told this paper that seemingly the idea to bribe their staff came as a result of their investigations which uncovered undeclared assets belonging to the Executive Secretary. However, a subsequent trial heard by a judge at the Nyarugenge Intermediate Court acquitted Ndagijimana of the charges. Supt Vita told Saturday Times that the new corruption charges are unrelated to the first case. Ndagijimana had served as the district executive secretary since 2007. Before he was the executive secretary of Ruharambuga sector in the same district Police called upon residents to continue their cooperation to ensure that corruption is driven out of the community. "The fight against corruption is a common responsibility," Vita said.

TITLE: Second Round of Investigations Complete for Renowned Corruption Suspects
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); ETHICS (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (90%); CORRECTIONS (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); ARRESTS (89%); DELAYS & POSTPONEMENTS (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (77%); LITIGATION (77%); IMPORT TRADE (75%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (75%); JUDGES (75%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (67%); EXPORT TRADE (64%); TEXTILES (50%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Meheretab Abraha - a businessman and the brother of former EPRDF strongman, Seye Abreha - may be transferred to a correctional facility pending possible charges by the prosecutors of the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission. At the same time, the architect, Begziabhere Alebel, will remain in police custody following the conclusion of investigations by the Commission. The conclusion of the second round of investigations on the corruption suspects indicated that the jurisdiction of Begziabhere's case lies with the Ministry of Justice (MoJ), Debebe Degafe, the Commission's investigator, informed the court on Wednesday last week. The investigation file of Meheretab has been transferred to the prosecution department, which will now decide whether or not to file charges. The investigator then requested that Meheretab be taken to a correctional facility until the Commission decides whether to file charges. He also insisted that Begziabher should remain in police custody until the case is transferred to the MoJ. Though hearing oral arguments from both sides, the presiding judge decided to abstain from giving a ruling, stating that the case should be seen by a regular three-member bench. This is the second time in a row that a ruling was postponed for both suspects due to an incomplete bench. Though the Federal High Court resumed its regular court sessions last week, after the annual month-long break in August, judges were still not assigned to the Second Criminal Bench, which hears corruption cases. It was after lawyers of the suspects complained to the Court's president that the case was heard by a single judge at the Tenth Criminal Bench. The postponement adds yet another week to the more than five months the suspects have already been held in custody during investigations. They were part of a group of more than 60 suspects, including top names in political and business circles, that the Commission arrested starting in early May 2013, as part of a corruption crackdown in the tax sector. Melaku Fenta, at the time the director general of the ERCA; Gebrewahed Woldegiorgis, his then-deputy of enforcement, and a slew of other top advisors and prosecutors at the ERCA were placed under arrest. Additionally, high-profile businessmen - Ketema Kebede, who is involved in the export, construction and textile industries through K.K Plc; Simachew Kebede, who runs intercontinental Addis; Nega G. Egziabhere, part-owner of Nega City Mall and shareholder in several import and export companies, and Fikru Maru (MD) who runsAddisCardiacHospital- were also arrested. Alleged corruption, including networking with government officials to avoid paying taxes and allowing goods to go through customs uninspected were reasons for the arrest, the Commission announced. After the arrests, the Commission went on to conduct a four-month long investigation, while most suspects remained in custody. They repeatedly asked the court for continuances. In August, investigators announced that they had finished discovery and passed on files to the prosecution to file charges. The prosecution department filed charges on close to 44 of the suspects within the following week. Suspects were not, however, given a chance to hear and respond to the charges, with the closing of the regular bench being cited as a reason. It also released close to 10 suspects on bail. For four of the suspects, including Meheretab and Begziabhere, however, the prosecution stated that investigation files were incomplete and ordered an audit report of their respective companies. The Commission's investigators were back in court again, asking for continuances and for suspects to remain in custody. Six continuances, with no bail granted to suspects, were approved for investigators during this second round, before they finally announced last week that investigations were complete. Meheretab and Begziabhere, as well as their lawyers, argued that there is no need for them to remain in custody from now on. "I have been in prison for five months at great cost to my business," a frustrated Begziabhere said to the presiding judge. "Is there such a thing as an investigation that takes half a year?" His lawyer also argued that it is no longer the Commission's mandate to ask for time extensions, if jurisdiction falls under the MoJ. The Commission's investigator, however, insisted that times is needed to hand over files, so it is still in charge until the case completely reassigned to the MoJ. Meheretab should also remain in custody until the prosecution decides to file charges. This is since discovery showed that the government lost nearly four million Birr in revenue due to his alleged corruption, argued Debebe, the investigator. Though taking time out to pass a ruling, the judge finally decided it best for a three-judge panel to oversee the case. Hearings to read and file charges on the 44 suspects already indicted, including Melaku Fenta, were also expected to take place last week. They were, however, postponed until Monday, October 21, when the bench is expected to be complete.

TITLE: Corruption Concern!
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); CONFERENCES & CONVENTIONS (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (89%); ETHICS (78%); HOTELS & MOTELS (78%); PUBLIC FINANCE (78%); PRIME MINISTERS (78%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (78%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (75%); EXECUTIVES (70%); TAX ENFORCEMENT (70%); ARRESTS (70%) Ethiopia; Corruption
TEXT: Just how much the government wants to emphasise that fighting corruption is one of its top priorities can be witnessed by the big names present at Sheraton Hotel, on October 17, 2013, for a two-day conference to mark the second Bi-Annual Anti Corruption Coalition General Assembly. The event started with Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn (middle right), who came in the morning to open the conference. In his speech, he referenced the current corruption crackdown on the tax and land sectors that led to the arrest of top government officials, including Melaku Fenta, former director general of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA). He stated that "in the last quarter of 2012/13, we have taken a strong legal measure against companies that are suspected of being a corruption hotbed, including senior government officials". He added that these officials and big businessmen had such strong ties that they 'were deemed untouchable' by some, but that corruption is something the government will fiercely fight against. That set the mood for the meeting, which focused mainly on mobilising the public to watch out against corruption. Heavyweights within the Oromia People Democratic Organisation (OPDO), Muktar Kedir (far left), minister of Civil Service with a prime minister's portfolio, and Abadula Gemeda , speaker of the House of People's Representatives, led the discussions during the second day. Comments, forwarded by many, including Sebhat Nega, founder of the Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) and executive director of the Ethiopian International Institute for Peace and Development, were answered by Ali Suleiman , commissioner of the Federal Ethics & Anti Corruption Committee, and Muktar. The consensus in the end was that more should be done on the public mobilisation front to fight against corruption. The Coalition, established five years ago, has 161 members from the government, private sectors, civil societies, media, religious institutions and different associations.

TITLE: Melaku Et Al Go On Corruption Trial, Today
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); INDICTMENTS (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (90%); INSPECTIONS (89%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (89%); TARIFFS & DUTIES (78%); ETHICS (78%); TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (78%); TAX ENFORCEMENT (77%); TAX FRAUD (77%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (77%); INVESTIGATIONS (76%); JUDGES (71%); ENGINEERING (64%); FREIGHT BROKERS & FORWARDERS (50%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Melaku, former director general of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA) and Gebrewahed W. Giorgis, the-then deputy to Melaku in the law enforcement division, have passed orders for the imports by some companies to get an inspection clearance without actually being inspected and thus avoid paying appropriate customs duties, reads the indictment presented today at the Federal High Court by the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC). This is the first of eight indictment files against the high-profile government officials and businessmen that the Commission started detaining in May 2013. The 84-page file, which was heard at the Federal High Court 15th criminal bench, named 31 defendants and included 26 corruption charges. Melaku, Gebrewahed, and Amogne Tagele, director of ERCA's Adama Branch Office, were included in the file. So were some of the big names in business, including Nega G. Egziabhere of Netsa Trading Plc, Ketema Kebede, of K.K. Plc, Getu Gelete, of Get-As International, and Gebreselassie H. Mariam, of Comet Trading Plc. Barring Amogne, only one of the 26 charges was levied directly against these big names. Senior ERCA officials were accused of relaxing the inspection procedures for undue benefits, by using the mutually beneficial relationship they established with these businessmen. The charge specifically mentioned the personal connections of Nega and Gebrewahed, as well as Ketema with Melaku. Other big name companies whose goods get inspection clearance with only invoices as proof rather than actual inspections, include PETRAM Plc, Nyala Motors S.C., Al-Sam Plc, Metals & Engineering Corporation (MetEC), Salini Construction, and Total Ethiopia, according to the indictment file. Most of these companies were declared by ERCA as Authorised Economic Operators (AEO), which can get preferential treatment in the customs process, including shorter clearance time, as an incentive to tax-compliant customers. The charge however states that these were companies selected by Melaku himself and that the system has created a convenient atmosphere for further corruption and fraud. The charge also accuses Melaku and Gebrewahed of contravening a law that instituted impromptu inspections at ERCA's Adama Branch, after a study revealed that the customs clearance system in Adama was looser than Kaliti and thus preferred by alleged tax evaders. The study was conducted to investigate why the Kaliti customs was gaining such low revenues. This has also led for corrupt practices to take root, the charge reads. The remaining 22 charges were made against mostly customs officials from ERCA's Adama Branch and Modjo Dry Port and Terminal, freight-forwarders and their family members. Federal judges Berihu Tewoldeberhan and Mulugeta Kidane alternated in reading the charges - a process that took the whole day after the court session started at half past 10 in the morning. Due to time constraints, pleas by oral arguments were rescheduled for tomorrow. So was the hearing for two other indictment files, which include 18 and 17 people respectively. Melaku and Gebrewahed are included in both these files; they are named in three of the eight indictment files that the Commission has registered in court. In the file that includes 17 people, other high-profile businessmen including Fikru Maru (MD), who runs Addis Cardiac Hospital, and Simachew Kebede of Addis InterContinental Hotel, as well as Ketema and Nega, are named.

TITLE: Court Grants Bail to Three Defendants in Corruption Probe
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); LAWYERS (90%); INDICTMENTS (90%); SENTENCING (90%); BAIL (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); EVIDENCE (89%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (89%); TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (89%); CRIMINAL LAW (78%); CORRECTIONS (78%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); ETHICS (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (77%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (76%); FREIGHT BROKERS & FORWARDERS (76%); STEPPARENTS (52%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Three people in the first indictment file read at the Federal High Court on Monday, October 21, which includes 31 people and 26 counts, were granted bail today in the high-profile corruption case launched by the Federal Ethics & Anti-Corruption Commission (FEACC). Semere Negussie, the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority's (ERCA) Adama Branch container inspection official at Modjo Dry Port & Terminal, Mareshet Tesfaye from M.D. Freight-Forwarding, and Dawit Mekonnen, a self-employed broker, can now post 15,000 Br and be released from custody. The defendants' lawyers argued that the crime they were charged with will not get them a sentencing of more than 10 years, which qualifies them for bail. The Commission's prosecutors did not put up any objections and the court accepted the request. The same arguments were also forwarded by lawyers of Zeleke Leyew, manager of Temcha Freight-Forwarders Plc, Degu Abicho, a driver at the Ethiopian Air Force, Shito Negash, stepmother of Amogne Tagele, ERCA's Adama Branch head, and Gebreselassie H. Mariam, shareholder in Comet Trading Plc. However, these arguments did not hold water for the court, which accepted the Commission's argument that these defendants were indeed charged for crimes that could possibly get them a sentencing of more than 10 years if convicted. The lawyers for the rest of the defendants, including Melaku Fenta, former director general of ERCA, and Gebrewahed, his then deputy, did not make requests for bail. Instead, they complained that the prosecution's evidence was not submitted along with the charges, which fails to observe criminal law. Any arguments should take place after the prosecution forwards the evidence, they argued. The court accepted this argument and adjourned the case until next week, Tuesday, October 29, while also ordering the Commission to submit evidence by then. Defendants who are not granted release or bail will remain in prison until then. The charges on Meheretab Abraha and the company where he is a shareholder, MFAM Trading, were also read out in court this morning. The file includes five counts. MFAM is charged with failing to declare 3.5 million Br in taxes, and later failing to pay this tax when ordered by ERCA. Meheretab, who was manager of the company during this time, also has two counts for not taking action when the company failed to declare and later pay taxes. Another charge is also levied on him, this time for attempting to avoid the unpaid tax as legal. Meheretab's lawyer has argued that he has complaints on the criminal code articles his client was charged with, which the judges asked he file in writing. The case will be heard after this complaint is filed.

TITLE: Uganda must get serious on corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (90%); INTERNATIONAL ASSISTANCE (89%); SCANDALS (89%); POLITICS (89%); APPOINTMENTS (89%); POLITICAL SCANDALS (79%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); BRIBERY (78%); LAWYERS (77%); VERDICTS (75%); SUITS & CLAIMS (74%); WITNESSES (74%); ARRESTS (72%); JAIL SENTENCING (71%); LARCENY & THEFT (71%); LAW SCHOOLS (70%); HUMAN RIGHTS (70%); RANKINGS (70%); APPEALS (66%)
TEXT: Government officials have made endless and strongly-worded promises to eradicate Uganda's endemic corruption. But the question remains: When will those commitments translate into concrete action, meaningful prosecutions of elites ... Government officials have made endless and strongly-worded promises to eradicate Uganda's endemic corruption. But the question remains: When will those commitments translate into concrete action, meaningful prosecutions of elites - such as political appointees and cabinet ministers - and jail time for those found guilty? Human Rights Watch and Yale Law School's Lowenstein International Human Rights Clinic published research this week detailing how the highest-ranking members of Uganda's government have eluded prosecution for corruption, despite scandal after scandal. We interviewed knowledgeable people fighting corruption on the front lines and examined over 100 judgments from the Anti-Corruption Court. We found that, since its founding in 2009, the court has predominantly heard cases of "small fish" involving relatively small amounts of money, while the "big fish" have gone free. Out of several hundred cases, the court secured the conviction of just one high-level official, later overturned on appeal after President Museveni commented on the case. Lamenting the impunity of so-called "untouchables," one prosecutor told us: "Come rain, come shine, they're never going to court, not while there's somebody close to them in power. That's because of the politics involved." We heard over and over again about political interference in cases involving elites. Politicians directed prosecutors to pursue certain cases and drop others. When instructions or bribes didn't work, they used threats to get lawyers and witnesses to see it their way. Over the past decade, international donors have pumped billions of dollars of aid into Uganda. Aid has slowed or halted because of high-profile corruption scandals, but resumes after largely cosmetic reforms. If the diverted money is returned to donor nations, that leaves Ugandans, particularly the poorest, without support to improve their lives and have access to essential services. After each scandal, international donors push the government to prosecute offenders, make reforms, and strengthen anti-corruption institutions. The government sometimes takes action - such as appointing the second deputy inspector general of government. But if Uganda's commitment to eradicating corruption is serious, anti-corruption institutions should be strong because it matters to Ugandans, not donors.  Vacancies in key positions shouldn't require pressure from the West to be filled.  And what reassurance is there that such vacancies won't cripple prosecutions in the future? Activists working to expose corruption and educate citizens about theft and diversion of state funds need public support. This year, 28 "Black Monday" activists have been arrested, some charged with inciting violence or unlawful assembly. This clampdown on information that should be publicly available calls into serious question the government's commitment to fighting corruption. Given Uganda's political patronage system and President Museveni's long stay in power, it has become highly unlikely that anything other than the prosecution of the high-ranking officials will fundamentally alter the deep-rooted patterns of graft and wealth accumulation by elites. Without substantial changes and follow-through on promises made, the injustices of Uganda's corruption problem will endure. Institutions are in place to combat corruption, but meaningful change can't happen without a sustained commitment from Ugandans themselves. Ugandans need to push both the government and donors to get serious about holding elites, including high ranking members of the government, accountable. Julia Brower, Sheng Li, Tiffany Ng, Jessica So, Yale Law School

TITLE: Crime, corruption are a leadership success for the Museveni regime
SUBJECT: RELIGION (90%); DEATHS & OBITUARIES (90%); CORRUPTION (89%); MOBILE & CELLULAR COMMUNICATIONS (78%); WEDDINGS & ENGAGEMENTS (78%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (78%); HUMAN RIGHTS (77%); BRIBERY (73%); CITY LIFE (72%); HUMAN RIGHTS VIOLATIONS (65%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (62%)
TEXT: At a recent church service in Kampala, a woman had both her cellphones stolen from her handbag. No surprise there, God's house has become one of the favourite hunting grounds for pickpockets and thieves. I was with a group of Ugandans when this theft was reported. What was revealing was the response of one of the good people I was with: "...and I noticed the priest forgot to warn the people about thieves at the service," she said.I have been at church services where priests warned the flock of pickpockets. However, it seems the warnings are formally becoming part of services, and a priest or pastor's failure to warm worshippers about thieves among them, is almost equivalent to him failing to say the Lord's Prayer! One of the Kampala Sunday papers then had a front-page story on criminal gangs with fancy names operating in the capital. Someone told me the story was "just the tip of the iceberg". In other words, there are very many lesser-known gangs active in the city. I too lost my phone at a funeral. My own sense was that it had dropped out of my pocket and was lying somewhere in the grass. No, people who know better told me. They told me thieves scour newspapers and listen to radio announcements for funeral announcements. They then hire a matatu and target selected funerals - and indeed weddings. Most funerals and weddings in Uganda, they said, end in tears for quite a few attendees. Pickpockets and thieves have always been there in Uganda. What seems to be happening is that there is a dramatic escalation. Why is this expansion of theft happening?Even though I was a victim, I am still rational enough to understand that part of this theft is driven by urban poverty (poor villagers don't resort to theft so routinely). At a higher level, it is part of the wider class struggle between those who have and those who don't. But that is a very small part of the reason why we are seeing growing crime. The bigger reason was again illustrated on the weekend by a report on corruption on Uganda based on research by the New York-based advocacy group, Human Rights Watch, and the Lowenstein International Human Rights Clinic of Yale University.It painted a bleak picture of corruption, saying that since President Yoweri Museveni came to power "waves of scandals" have hit his administration. The report faults Museveni personally for what it calls widespread "bribery, nepotism, and misuse of official positions and resources" in the country. Corruption has turned Uganda into a Mobutist state, where graft now accounts for most aspects of State failure. My sense is also that if you want to accurately predict how Museveni's regime will end, then study how corruption is working in Uganda today. One of the most successful foreign policy initiatives and military adventures of the Museveni government has to be its role in the African Union peacekeeping force for Somalia, Amisom. When no one dared, the Museveni government dispatched the UPDF to a Mogadishu that was still in the hands of al-Shabaab. They fought a long and brave campaign, paid very dearly, but together with Burundi that joined them later, they beat back the militants and made possible the establishment of the current government in Mogadishu. I thought because of what the UPDF mission meant for Africa, the world, and Uganda, it would become sacred...the one thing which would be insulated against the ugliness of Ugandan politics and power. I was wrong.We now know that commanders were stealing supplies for the troops and weapons and selling them to Somali bootleggers, and the very al-Shabaab militants they were fighting. Two things are happening here. One, the rampant corruption at the top over the years has led to what we might call a "routinisation" or "normalisation" of corruption.  Corruption and theft become the norm, integrity becomes the exception. But there is something else more fundamental at work. The spreading criminality is evidence of successful leadership from the Museveni government. A key element of political leadership is the ability of chiefs to get the country to follow their example, and to change national behaviour by rewarding and reinforcing the characteristics that they consider to be the best. Clearly, the government has done a first class of getting the country to follow is lead-by-theft example. Now public funds and assets are stolen. Votes are routinely stolen. Church collections are stolen. Soldiers' lives are stolen. Parliamentary voters are stolen. We steal each other's wives and husbands. Our children are violently robbed of their innocence. The Big Man hardly has any sense of shame and honour any more - I guess someone stole those too from him. cobbo@ke.nationmedia.com & twitter: cobbo3

TITLE: Anti-Corruption Commission Workers Attach Property
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); APPROVALS (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (89%); ALTERNATIVE DISPUTE RESOLUTION (89%); APPEALS (89%); HUMAN RESOURCES (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LABOR & EMPLOYMENT LAW (78%); COMMERCIAL PROPERTY (77%); APPEALS COURTS (76%); LAWYERS (73%); SHERIFFS (73%); INTELLIGENCE SERVICES (73%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (50%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: TWENTY-SIX investigators and intelligence officers employed by the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission have been given the green light to attach their employer's property to recover US$1,5 million owed to them in outstanding allowances and benefits. This comes after an arbitral award granted by arbitrator Mr Rogers Matsikidze early this year was successfully registered at the High Court. Justice Happias Zhou then issued a writ of execution allowing seven properties belonging to ZACC to be attached to recover the amount owed since 2009.
