"You are required and directed to attach and take into execution the movable goods of Zimbabwe Anti Corruption Commission of the above mentioned respondents whose address is No. 872 Betterment Close, Mt Pleasant Business Park, Harare, Zimbabwe and of the same cause to be realised the sum of US$1 530 624 30, which claimants recovered by judgment of this Hounourable Court dated 17th October 2013," reads part of the writ, which was addressed to the deputy Sheriff of Zimbabwe. The writ also instructed the anti-graft body to pay the workers or their lawyer Mr Joel Mambara of Mambara and Partners the sum due to them with costs. According to the writ of execution, immovable property includes the ZACC head office in Mount Pleasant and six other properties in Harare. These are stand 386 Quinnington, Borrowdale measuring 4 000 square metres, a stand in Glen Lorne measuring 5373 square metres, a stand in Bluff Hill measuring 4515 square metres, two stands in Greendale measuring 6172 and 4148 square metres, and another stand in Northwood, Harare measuring 4047 square metres. According to court papers, ZACC failed to pay the workers housing, transport, cellphone and risk allowances as well as medical aid since November 2009 to date. The workers approached the Labour Court and were granted an award, which they subsequently registered. However, the commission appealed against the arbitral award in favour of the workers to be paid their allowance. But Labour Court president Mrs Lilian Kudya ruled last month that the commission was in contempt of court after it failed to comply with the court order to pay the 26 workers. She said the fact that the workers applied for registration of their award at the High Court had no effect on the award which has been appealed against in the court. In its grounds of appeal, the commission had maintained that it had not applied for a stay of the arbitral award pending appeal because the respondents filed an application with the higher court to register the award in question. In March this year, arbitrator Mr Matsikidze ruled in favour of the workers and awarded each of them various amounts ranging between US$53 000 and US$61 000. He said the commission's human resources section was in shambles and that it was unfairly treating its workers. In the award, Mr Matsikidze urged the commission to take care of the staff, saying poor working conditions and poor salaries might tempt them to engage in corrupt activities.

TITLE: IGG investigating 100 cases of corruption in Karamoja region
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); GOVERNMENT BUDGETS (78%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); ASSET FORFEITURE (68%); BUDGETS (62%)
TEXT: The Inspectorate of government of Uganda is investigating 109 corruption cases in Karamoja sub-region. The Deputy Inspector General of Government (IGG),  Mr George Bamugemerere, revealed this during a workshop on the Northern Uganda Social Action Fund (Nusaf) in Moroto Town on Wednesday. The Inspectorate of government of Uganda is investigating 109 corruption cases in Karamoja sub-region.The Deputy Inspector General of Government (IGG),  Mr George Bamugemerere, revealed this during a workshop on the Northern Uganda Social Action Fund (Nusaf) in Moroto Town on Wednesday. The workshop, organised by the Inspectorate of Government, was aimed at improving community livelihoods through efficient implementation of the second phase of Nusaf (Nusaf II). It was attended by the First Lady and Minister for Karamoja Affairs Janet Museveni, Nusaf Director Robert Limilim and leaders of Moroto and Napak districts. Insecurity problemMr Bamugemerere said corruption cases in Karamoja had accumulated due to the insecurity which could not allow the auditors to carry out auditing in the region. Karamoja has been ridden with insecurity mainly caused by armed cattle rustlers. "Officials were swindling public funds and nobody could investigate them because of the insecurity," Mr Bamugemerere said. He said the corruption incidents under investigation by the IGG include cases in the first phase of Nusaf (Nusaf-I), National Agricultural Advisory Services (Naads) and Peace, Recovery and Development Plan (PRDP). "The region is rotten and once we conclude our investigations, I don't think there will be any leader who will survive arrest," he said. Dr Robert Limlim, the director of Nusaf-II, appealed to the IGG to complete the investigations quickly and have culprits prosecuted. Dr Limlim, who comes from Karamoja, said the area has lagged behind in development because of corruption. He called for confiscation of property of the culprits to recover the stolen money. Mr Bamugemerere said under-funding is hindering the IGG's efforts to sufficiently investigate corruption cases and prosecute the culprits. He said the Shs30 billion the IGG office receives from government in the national budget annually is too inadequate. He called on the government to increase the funding to at least Shs40 billion to enable the IGG improve its performance. editorial@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Import Mogul Joins Corruption Fray
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); TAX AUTHORITIES (90%); ETHICS (90%); TAX LAW (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); INVESTIGATIONS (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (89%); TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (78%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (77%); INDICTMENTS (77%); SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (77%); PUBLIC FINANCE (77%); MIXED USE DEVELOPMENTS (74%); SHAREHOLDERS (73%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (71%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (71%); CRIMINAL OFFENSES (71%); HOTELS & MOTELS (69%); PRIME MINISTERS (66%); FREIGHT BROKERS & FORWARDERS (56%); CONSTRUCTION (50%) Ethiopia; Trade; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Getu Gelete, founder and major shareholder of Get-As International Plc, became a last minute addition to the list of prominent businessmen recently implicated in a high-level corruption probe by the Federal Ethics & Anti Corruption Commission (FEACC). In his absence, he was named as defendant early last week in two of eight indictment files the Commission filed in court against tax officials, businessmen and freight forwarders as part of its corruption crackdown against the tax sector. As a defendant, Getu joins other prominent and wealthy businessmen included in these files, such as Ketema Kebede of K. K. Plc, Simachew Kebede of InterContinental Addis Hotel, Nega G. Egziabhere of Netsa Trading Plc, Fikru Maru (MD), who runs Addis Cardiac Hospital, and Gebreselassie H. Mariam of Comet Trading Plc. Except for Gebreselassie, the rest of these businessmen have been imprisoned since May, while the Commission was carrying out its investigations. The corruption crackdown, which has also engulfed senior tax officials including Melaku Fenta, former director general of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA), and Gebrewahed W. Giorgis, his then-deputy, has been depicted several times both by the Commission's officials and Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn as a move on its own to signal the seriousness of government in taking a hard line against corruption. No matter what their affiliations are with government, there are no untouchables when it comes to fighting corruption, Hailemariam had said at several occasions since he came to power back in November 2012. Getu, whose company also owns the mixed-use Getu Commercial Centre on Africa Avenue (Bole Road), one of the five prime properties in Addis Abeba, supported the Ethiopian Peoples' Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) during its election bid in 2005 and 2010. During the latter, he was part of a group of 60 business owners who mobilised a further 1,000 businesspersons to raise 20 million Br for the ruling party. A wealthy businessman with a modest beginning almost four decades ago, at his birth place 80Km south of Addis Abeba, Getu was also instrumental in raising funds from members of the private sector in Addis Abeba to finance the construction of the headquarters of the ruling EPRDF up at Arat Kilo, behind Parliament. This headquarters was designed by Begziyabher Alebel, an architect who is behind Ultimate Plans; the latter has been one of the suspects under the custody of federal authorities, and included in the probe in what the Administration of Hailemariam says was a network of high level graft, which embraces Getu beginning last week. Getu is now charged with eight counts of involvement in corrupt practices. His company, Get-As International Plc, a durable goods importing conglomerate, is also facing six counts of corruption as a separate legal entity. The businessman is to be tried in absentia as he is currently outside of the country, Fortune confirmed from sources. Family members were not available for comment on his whereabouts. In the first indictment file, Getu is charged for clearing imported goods using invoices without undergoing the mandatory inspections, through his personal connections with Melaku and Gebrewahed. These two, along with Ketema and Nega, also share this charge. The charges in the third file, however, are more numerous and include both the businessman and his company. Getu was one of the businessmen that transported cement which was imported duty free for government housing projects in Addis Abeba but later was sold to third parties, these charges read. While an investigation was launched on such transporters by the ERCA, a few, including Getu, Nega and Gebreselassie, were not included or indicted because of their connection to Gebrewahed, according to the charge. Getu sold 8,540ql of the 9,000ql of cement he imported, to a third party along with Gebreselassie, according to the charges, which also make Get-As International Plc criminally liable. In addition, the company is charged for not paying 22.8 million Br in profit tax from the import and sells of the cement sold to third parties, as well as money laundering, while Getu is charged as the general manager of Get-As International Plc, a company prosecutors indicted for failing to pay these taxes. Most of these charges, if found to be accurate, can lead to a sentencing of more than 10 years. Getu's case was heard at the Federal High Court's 15th Criminal Bench, on Chad St., in Lideta area, on Monday, October 21, and Tuesday, October 22, respectively. Upon request from the Commission's prosecutors, the bench has ordered that the investigation team of the Commission locate the whereabouts and summon the defendant at the next court date scheduled for October 29, 2013. This is not the first time Getu has been named as a defendant in a court of law. Federal prosecutors had charged him with fraud in 2010, following a contractual dispute with Helen Anbesso over a real estate property. But the charge was dropped later on after judges ruled that the suit was not one that was criminal in nature but a civil one. He was outside of the country when he was first summoned by the courts back then.tu Gelete

TITLE: Over Br800 Million in Gov't Revenue Lost By Corruption Defendants - Commission Claims
SUBJECT: SPECIAL INVESTIGATIVE FORCES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); PUBLIC FINANCE (90%); EXCISE & CUSTOMS (90%); TAX LAW (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); APPOINTMENTS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); TAX AUTHORITIES (77%); VALUE ADDED TAX (77%); TRANSPORTATION SUPPORT SERVICES (77%); ETHICS (76%); INDICTMENTS (76%); TAX ENFORCEMENT (76%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (75%); TAXES & TAXATION (72%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (71%); HOTELS & MOTELS (69%); LABOR DEPARTMENTS (65%); PRIME MINISTERS (64%); FREIGHT BROKERS & FORWARDERS (56%) Ethiopia; Governance; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: For the first time since he was escorted to prison by Federal Police on a late Friday afternoon in early May, Melaku Fenta, then director general of the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority (ERCA), was able to hear exactly what he and most of his colleagues at the helm of the Authority were implicated in. Indictment proceedings in the high profile corruption probe on the tax sector, which saw the arrest of over 60 tax officials, prominent businessmen, freight forwarders and their family members over the past six months, started on Monday, October 14, 2013. The nation's wealthy businessmen, Ketema Kebede of K. K. Plc, Simachew Kebede of InterContinental Addis Hotel, Nega G. Egziabhere of Netsa Trading Plc, Fikru Maru (MD) of Addis Cardiac Hospital, and new additions such as Gebreselassie H. Mariam of Comet Trading Plc and Getu Gelete, of Get-As International Plc, who is yet to be brought to court, were named as defendants in this trial, and stood alongside the public officials with whom they were accused of establishing connections for undue benefits. Maladministration, abuse of power and corrupt practices were rife within the ERCA during the time Melaku was director general of the institution between 2008 and 2012, was the gist of the numerous charges filed against him and his colleagues. Appointed first as a minister and director general when ERCA was reformed in 2008, Melaku came from a background in economics. Born in Gonder, he joined the ruling party in the early 1990s during the time when he had served the Ministry of Labour & Social Affairs. He was promoted to the Prime Minister's Office prior to 2000s, responsible for handling the affairs of the newly formed regional states. It was this background that eventually led to his appointment as a state minister of Federal Affairs, under Abay Tsehaye, then its minister, and one of the ideologues of the EPRDF to date. Transferred to the tax and customs sector in the mid-2000s, Melaku was trained in The Netherlands, where he received his post graduate degree in customs and revenues. He has seen through the reforms of the nation's tax regime and the introductions of schemes such as automation, VAT and sales register machines which are now numbered close to 63,000. First elected to the EPRDF Central Committee in 2006, he has been one of the most powerful government officials in whose watch the nation's domestic revenue mobilization drive jumped from 19 billion Br before his appointment in 2008 to 84.2 billion Br in 2012/13. Despite these successes, however, his period at ERCA has created a ground for many businessmen and their companies to underpay taxes, perpetuate fraud and avoid criminal liability through graft, accuses the Federal Ethics & Anticorruption Commission (FEACC). Its prosecutors now claim this had led the government to lose nearly 795 million Br in revenue, with 667 million Br down to unpaid taxes and revenues that should have been credited to the public coffer, while the balance is the tally of what the abuse of power has cost the government in general, according to officials from the Commission. How and when these losses were incurred tax notice to pay took a long time to process. Melaku, allegedly reduced nearly 100,000 Br outside of procedure for Mekdes, with whom he established a romantic relationship. Using public property to travel with her was also cited in the charge. Similarly for Gebrewahed, charges that startled the public were included in the third file. In this, Gebrewahed is accused of corrupt practices, including calling and threatening businessmen to pay bribes in return for dropping legal charges and reducing taxes. A specific instance mentioned in the charge is the case of Baheru Abreha, shareholder of Bisrat Plc, which operates Elfign Baheru Corrugated Iron Sheets Factory. While Baheru was under prosecution by the ERCA for allegedly conducting business transactions without VAT receipts, Gebrewahed allegedly called and threatened him to pay bribes or face maximum sentencing. He then met Baheru through the facilitation of Nega G. Egziabhere, in Yordanos Hotel, and took 250,000 Br in bribes, the charge reads. While taking the money, he then spotted a gold bracelet on Baheru's wrist and asked that he receive a similar kind, which Baheru gave him the next day, when the met inside InterContinental Addis Hotel, according to the charge. Other ERCA officials, including Markneh Alemayehu, former prosecutor for ERCA, are also accused of taking 100,000 Br in bribes and dropping the case for Baheru. Gebrewahed is also charged with possession of nine unlicensed weapons - Kalashnikov, Colt and Makarov - possession of goods from unknown sources and money laundering. While Gebrewahed and his wife had a salary of between 247 Br to 5,700 Br and 790 Br to 2,145 Br, respectively, throughout their working years, Gebrewahed was allegedly found to have 1.4 million Br in several bank accounts under his, his wife and children's names. This is in addition to being in possession of money in five different currencies, six laptops as well as property in Legetafo area, on the outskirts of Addis Abeba, in Oromia Regional State. Melaku was also accused of a similar charge for having nearly 3.2 million Br in cash and assets, including a two-storey house on a 659sqm plot that is estimated to worth 1.5 million Br. The charge for most of the wealthy businessmen was also included in the third file. The companies these businessmen run, including Ketema's K. K. Plc, Simachew's G. H. Tsemex Plc, Nega's Netsa Trading Plc, Getu's Get-As International Plc and Gebreselassie's Comet Trading Plc were also indicted as separate legal entities. The audit report of these companies reveals that nearly 237 million Br due to the government has not been paid, according to officials from the Commission. Most of the businessmen running these companies are accused of having charges and investigations on them and their companies dropped through graft. Ketema, for instance, was accused of having his loan-sharking charges dropped due to his special relationship with Melaku established for undue benefits. Simachew, on the other hand, is charged with having investigations on his alleged use of machinery and furniture imported duty free for the hotel, for other purposes, dropped. Similar investigations against Fikru, who was accused of an attempt to pass medical equipments which were not allowed through the customs, were also terminated for undue benefits by officials, according to the charges. Additionally, Nega, Getu and Gebreselassie, who allegedly transported cement imported for government housing projects to third parties, had investigations and charges against them dropped because of their affiliations with Gebrewahed and other officials, the charge reads. Gebrewahed and Woldeselassie W. Michael, a senior national security officer at the time, tried to twist testimonies of others and put the blame on three other companies involved in the transport of the cement, without bringing liability to the above-mentioned businessmen, the charge reads. Not much was heard from the defendant's side during court proceedings because prosecutors at the Commission did not submit evidence along with the indictments. Many of the defendants' lawyers appealed to the judges that they first read the evidence before making pre-trial arguments. Few of the defendants spoke, including Markneh. "Not submitting evidence along with charges is outside of procedure," he voiced his complaints. "Why did the court's registrar accept and seal the charges if they are incomplete in the first place?" The judges took these arguments in consideration and ruled that during their next appearance, prosecutors bring in evidence. The hearing for the three indictment files were adjourned until October 29 with a strict admonishment from the bench that prosecutors should bring evidence next time. Markneh also appealed to the court to monitor media and request that they present their stories in summarised manner. "If they do go into the details, it should be balanced," he appealed to the court. The bench deferred judgment on the matter for sometime but reminded reporters to write balanced news until such judgement is passed. Since most of the charges levied against defendants are punishable by 10 or more years of imprisonment, only three of the defendants, Semere Negussie, the Ethiopian Revenues & Customs Authority's (ERCA) Adama Branch container inspection official at Modjo Dry Port & Terminal, Mareshet Tesfaye from M.D. Freight-Forwarding, and Dawit Mekonnen, a self-employed broker, were granted on bail for 15,000 Br. No bail was granted in the second and third charge files. Outside of the three indictment files, however, Meheretab Abreha, brother of former TPLF strongman Seeye, was charged with corruption and not paying taxes along with the company he manages, MFAM Plc. Meheretab, along with Begziabhere Alebel, an architect and shareholder in the design firm, Ultimate Plan Plc, and businessmen Tekleab Zerabruk and Fitsum Gebremedhin, were not indicted with the rest of the businessmen they were initially detained with a month and a half ago. Instead, the Commission's investigators were asking more time to complete audit reports of the suspects' companies until last week. While Fitsum and Meheretab were charged, Begziabhere and Tekleab remain unindicted. The Commission itself has let out Tekleab on bail, whereas the court granted Begziabhere a 100,000 Br bond for bail last week, after the Commission's investigators announced that his case does not fall under their jurisdiction but that of the Ministry of Justice (MoJ) instead. It is not clear whether the MoJ will take over Begziabhere's case, nor has he been released from police custody. He is counted as a witness in the first count of the first indictment file, along with Eshetu Woldesemayat, chief prosecutor at the ERCA, who was initially arrested along with the rest of the ERCA officials, to testify against Melaku, Gebrewahid and Ketema. As Melaku et al. were being escorted out of the court on Wednesday the Commission's prosecutors, Ayele Tessema, Getachew Aga and Endale Tsegaye, stayed behind to participate in the hearing for the rest of the seven files, which include mid-level customs officials and businessmen from Adama, Mille and Dire Dawa. They will be back in the same place for week two of the trial.

TITLE: Uganda still tops EAC in corruption, says report
COUNTRY: UGANDA (95%); EASTERN AFRICA (94%); AFRICA (92%); KENYA (92%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (92%); RWANDA (79%); BURUNDI (79%)
SUBJECT: BRIBERY (92%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); CORRUPTION (78%); POLLS & SURVEYS (78%); RANKINGS (71%)
TEXT: The report by Transparency International says the police take 27 per cent of the bribes that exchange hands in Uganda. KAMPALA- The chances of forking out a bribe to access most of the crucial services in Uganda have dropped from 40.7 per cent last year, to 26.8 per cent in 2013, a report by Transparency International has revealed. However, the East African Bribery Index 2013 still finds Uganda leading the East African region in prevalence of bribery despite a series of laws mooted to combat the vice. Burundi comes second at 18.6 per cent. Tanzania and Kenya were the only countries to make progress in the anti-graft fight in the region, moving down a spot each, albeit with relatively lower aggregates. In 2012, Tanzania and Kenya posted 39.1 per cent and 29.5 per cent respectively. Though Rwanda maintained position five as the country with the least bribery incidences in the region, it was the only country to post an increased aggregate from 2.5 per cent last year to 4.4 per cent this year. Bribery proneThe report makes a particularly damning assessment at the police, with the Force ranked as the most bribery-prone institution in the country at 60 per cent as well as boasting of the highest prevalence of bribery at 47.8 per cent. Lands services and the Judiciary came in at position two and three, with an aggregate score of 46.7 per cent and 42.0 per cent respectively. And bribing a police officer does not come cheaply, with the average bribe an officer will take estimated at Shs900,000, according to the report.Yesterday, police spokesperson Judith Nabakooba did not respond to or return repeated phone calls. But Judiciary spokesman Erias Kisawuzi dismissed the findings as based on "perceptions". "I have not had a copy of the report but be that as it may, these are perception reports. I do not know whether its respondents reflected a cross section of Ugandans," Mr Kisawuzi said. The report further reveals that the police rake in 27 per cent of the bribes that exchange hands in Uganda.With the police, which is mandated to enforce the law, largely incriminated by the report, it is little wonder that 93 per cent of respondents in Uganda said they did not report the bribery cases they encountered. Victims of bribery, according to the report, opted to remain silent because they knew no action would be taken to resolve their complaint. sarinaitwe@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Mohadi Hails Stance Against Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (88%); ELECTIONS (79%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (79%); LOBBYING (79%); EXECUTIVES (78%); POLICE FORCES (78%); TOURISM DEVELOPMENT (70%); SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (70%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (63%); REFERENDUMS (60%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (60%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: GOVERNMENT has commended the police for its zero tolerance against corruption which has resulted in a number of officers being discharged from the force after being caught on the wrong side of the law. Home Affairs Minister Kembo Mohadi yesterday said society expected police officers to lead by example and to should shun all forms of corruption. He was speaking at the Zimbabwe Republic Police 2013 Senior Officers Conference in Harare. Minister Mohadi said corrupt activities denied the people justice and retarded development. "Accordingly, as the Ministry we are grateful to the command of the Zimbabwe Republic Police for maintaining a zero tolerance to corruption among police officers as well as members of the public. Quite a number of police officers who were caught on the wrong side of the law were discharged from the police service, a feat which mirrors the organisation's commitment to rid itself of unprincipled police officers," he said. Minister Mohadi commended members of the public for their unwavering support to the police. "It is important, therefore, that the police officers retain that support and trust from the members of the public by conducting themselves, as they discharge their duties on a high moral platform," said Minister Mohadi. "The society expects police officers to lead exemplary and unblemished lives, hence members of the organisation should shun all forms of corruption." Minister Mohadi said Government was mindful of the fact that policing the world over was an expensive exercise which required meaningful and constant injection of material and financial resources. He said the ministry would tirelessly lobby for resources to ameliorate challenges being faced by the force. These include shortage of transport, office and residential accommodation and poor remuneration. Minister Mohadi said apart from protecting lives and property, the force was expected to consistently support Government efforts to alleviate poverty and improve the lives of the people. He called the force to ensure a peaceful and tranquil environment in which the Government's new economic blue print, the Zimbabwe Agenda for Sustainable Socio-Economic Transformation (ZimAsset) could be implemented. Minister Mohadi commended the force for diligently policing the referendum, harmonised elections and the United Nations World Tourism Organisation General Assembly which was co-hosted by Zimbabwe and Zambia in August. The officers commanding provinces, police chief staff officers and directors are attending the three-day senior officers conference which is expected to end tomorrow.

TITLE: Why corruption thrives in cash-based economies
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); RESTAURANTS (90%); CREDIT CARDS (90%); DEBIT CARDS (89%); HOSPITALS (88%); MONEY LAUNDERING (87%); PAYMENT CARDS & SERVICES (78%); REAL ESTATE (78%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (77%); GAS STATIONS (77%); TAX FRAUD (77%); TAXES & TAXATION (73%); MONEY SUPPLY (72%); GROCERY STORES & SUPERMARKETS (69%); REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS (68%); BRIBERY (66%); TAX LAW (62%)
TEXT: On a recent trip to Uganda, the team I travelled with asked whether credit and debit cards would be used in restaurants or shops.  I told them that Uganda is still a cash economy and therefore cash would be the quickest option to access services and products.  Isn't it surprising that in this 21st Century, Uganda still depends entirely on cash for goods and services. On a recent trip to Uganda, the team I travelled with asked whether credit and debit cards would be used in restaurants or shops.  I told them that Uganda is still a cash economy and therefore cash would be the quickest option to access services and products. Isn't it surprising that in this 21st Century, Uganda still depends entirely on cash for goods and services. For instance, you need cash in your wallet to fill your vehicle tank, buying groceries in a supermarket, buying drugs or getting medical attention in hospitals, eating out, and so on. Cash-based economies describedCash economies are liquid, quicker, and also increase the money supply especially in countries where financial systems are shallow and with limited outreach. However, majority of places where card payments are unacceptable, corruption and bribery may be very rampant, simply because cash doesn't leave any trails behind. Could this be the more reason, corruption seems normal to us in Uganda? Have you ever noticed that when you go to a petrol station and request for a receipt, the pump attendant will normally ask the buyer what figures/he should write on the receipt? In the financial world, this is termed as fraud.  But imagine if you had paid using a card, the receipt would definitely have the details of the transaction which would help in balancing the books at the end of the day. This can eventually lead to tax evasion through understating cash receipts or overstating their business expenses. Cash economies can also be manipulative. The corporate class that religiously file their returns monthly to Uganda Revenue Authority contribute enormously to the development of the nation through tax payments. The collected taxes are then used for the public deliverables like roads, hospitals, and defence that are eventually enjoyed by the majority that never get taxed because there are operating using cash that cannot be trailed - no surveillance.  Isn't this selective taxing? Do we know how much income and economic activity goes unrecorded when cash is used for transactions? Money laundering havenMoney laundering is widespread in cash based economies due to lack of controls with cash transactions. How often, do you get asked the source of funds when purchasing a property in Ntinda or anywhere else? The majority of these property transactions are paid in cash. Property acquisition is the most preferred channel for money laundering and you don't need a prophet to confirm this - just look at the next mall or estate that is coming up in your neighbourhood. What is the origin of this cash and why pay in cash and not a cheque or a transfer? What drives cash based economies? Different factors like, deficiencies in technology, a large unbanked population , low income levels, high levels of illiteracy, weak institutions and legislations etc. If we encouraged more payments through electronic media, don't you think this would even save the tax payer more money in printing bank notes? Shouldn't we as Ugandans invest more in research & development especially in technology, encourage filing of annual tax returns for all citizens including the self employed? Investing more in electronic card readers in common business centres like restaurants, legal chambers, hospitals, supermarkets, petrol stations, among others would go a long way in fighting crime in the country. Maybe, we should all work collectively towards making Uganda a better place - crime free and less corruption. Knowing the start and end of every transaction can curb corruption in our country. Barbara Nantege is the regional head of customer due diligence risk, Standard Chartered Bank Africa.editorial@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Farmer's Diary: Corruption in farming households
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); AGRICULTURE (90%); FERTILIZERS (90%); POULTRY (89%); POULTRY & EGG PRODUCTION (76%); COMPANY PROFITS (64%); GENDER EQUALITY (50%); PRIME MINISTERS (50%)
TEXT: When we think about major hindrances to increased agricultural production, the issues that come to mind often tend to be the most obvious ones--lack of fertilisers, climate change, failure to carry out irrigation, difficulties in accessing credit and a whole wide range of other problems associated with Sub-Saharan Africa agriculture. But I would bet the biggest problem we have is lack of transparency and accountability among members of farming households. When we think about major hindrances to increased agricultural production, the issues that come to mind often tend to be the most obvious ones--lack of fertilisers, climate change, failure to carry out irrigation, difficulties in accessing credit and a whole wide range of other problems associated with Sub-Saharan Africa agriculture. But I would bet the biggest problem we have is lack of transparency and accountability among members of farming households. Bags of coffee are sold, a pig is sold, trees are felled and sold; but how is the money spent? Who keeps that money? Who decides what to be done with the money? Do both the husband and wife have equal say over that money? Are their grown up children included in the decision making? Does everybody in the home share a sense of ownership over its farming activities? When money meant to be used for the common good of the community is taken secretly and used selfishly by individuals to satisfy personal desires, we describe such behaviour as corruption. Distrust sets inIt resembles what is reported to have taken place in Office of the Prime Minister, the Ministry of Public Service, Global Fund, CHOGM and the rest. When a member of a household secretly or openly spends money earned through the toil of all family members to satisfy personal desires, he or she is not different from those individuals that steal funds from public institutions. The results can be very grave. The rest of the family members get demoralised and stop working as hard as they should. In case of a poultry farm, for example, the rest of the family members may stop taking good care of the birds after discovering that the father spends the money earned from the farm on alcohol and prostitutes. They may also resort to selling the eggs or the chickens without his knowledge to earn some money for buying text books or clothing. Distrust sets in, profit and loss accounts fail to add up, and finally the poultry project crumbles. Issues of gender equity in farming must be addressed together with all other problems facing agriculture today--biotic or abiotic--to improve production. ssalimichaelj@gmail.com

TITLE: Address the issue of corruption, corporate companies urged
COUNTRY: UGANDA (93%); AFRICA (90%); EASTERN AFRICA (90%); KENYA (79%); BURUNDI (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%)
SUBJECT: MONEY LAUNDERING (92%); FINANCIAL CRIME COUNTERMEASURES (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); CORPORATE GOVERNANCE (89%); ETHICS (78%); CONFLICTS OF INTEREST (78%); CORPORATE SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY (77%); BUSINESS ETHICS & CORPORATE CITIZENSHIP (77%); TALKS & MEETINGS (73%); STRATEGIC PLANNING (72%); BEST PRACTICES (72%); CONSULTING SERVICES (71%)
TEXT: He warned against the persistent money laundering cases and its effect on small economies but commended Parliament for enacting the new anti-money laundering law. Kampala- Proprietors of corporate firms have been urged to set up strategic plans to address growing operational risks and corruption. Mr Leo Kibirango, a former Central Bank Governor and proprietor of LK Consultancy firm, said there is need for proprietors to strengthen their institutions in order to address the challenges that are threatening ethical conduct. According to Mr Kibirango, companies need to employ best practices, including transparency through public procurement, accountability to stakeholders, responsible actions like environment conservation as well as corporate social responsibility activities. The vices"Poor accountability, low morals, abuse of office and conflict of interest dilemma coupled with low efficiencies and effectiveness in corporate performances, continue to cause major concerns to the general public," said Mr Kibirango, the outgoing head of the Institute of Corporate Governance of Uganda (ICGU). Speaking at the 10th annual general meeting of the ICGU in Kampala, Mr Kibirango said it was unacceptable for Uganda to continue being rated poorly on corporate governance performance in East Africa and the world over. He warned against the persistent money laundering cases and its effect on small economies but commended Parliament for enacting the new anti-money laundering law. Mr Kibirango's remarks come after the Transparency International report ranked Uganda the most corrupt in the East Africa region followed by Burundi, Tanzania and Kenya.  "We call upon government and institutions to support the Institute operations to promote and ensure good governance within the corporate sector," he added. ICGU promotes effective management emphasising transparency and integrity in the business community.ekasozi@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Federal High Court Finds Former Regional President Guilty of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTING (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); LITIGATION (90%); MANAGERS & SUPERVISORS (89%); ACQUITTAL (89%); DECISIONS & RULINGS (89%); SETTLEMENTS & DECISIONS (89%); EDUCATION SYSTEMS & INSTITUTIONS (78%); VERDICTS (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); ETHICS (77%); AGREEMENTS (76%); VOCATIONAL & TECHNICAL TRAINING (73%); BAIL (73%); BOARDING SCHOOLS (73%); CONSULTING SERVICES (73%); TEACHER EDUCATION (68%) Ethiopia; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Corruption
TEXT: The charges, which date back two years, were related to the tenders for the construction of three schools The Federal High Court's 15th Criminal Bench has found Yaregal Aysheshum guilty on corruption charges, which was one of four counts against him. Five of the six defendants in his file were also found guilty on the corruption charge. The corruption charges were related to the bidding procedure for the construction of three educational institutions at a total cost of 83 million Br, during Yaregal's presidency of the Benishangul Gumuz Regional State. The Federal Ethics & Anti Corruption Commission (FEACC) took the case to court two years ago, claiming the former regional president had a corrupt involvement in the construction of the Tana Beles Women's Boarding school, Gilgel Beles Teachers Training Collage and the Assosa Technical & Vocational Training Centre. These projects were awarded to Gedion Demeke Consulting Firm, Gad Construction and Colon Construction in a closed tender, however, they should have been conducted openly according to the region's construction directive amended in 2000 which requires open tenders for projects worth more than 300,000 Br. Those closed tenders led to the loss of seven million Birr, the Commission claimed, because of payments given outside of contractual agreements. Yaregal was also prosecuted on four other counts, including the collection of a large amount of wealth from an unknown source, as well as committing fraud while registering assets under his possession. However, he was cleared of these charges. The Federal High Court had frozen the assets of the defendant back in October 2011. These include a house built on 1,204sqm of land and a total of 4,132sqm of additional land in the region he led; a 500sqm plot in Bole District in Addis Abeba and a one-storey house resting on 500sqm in Oromia Regional State. On top of this, there was also a restaurant registered in his wife's name and a 1,490sqm plot in Benishangul Gumuz registered in the name of one of his children. In the hearing that took place on Wednesday, November 20, and Thursday, November 21, the judges read 170 pages of the charge file on the other six defendants under his file. The corruption count involved all six, which are Habtamu Hika, Regional Education Bureau head; Gedion Demeke, general manager of the Gedion Demeke Consulting Firm; Assefa Gebeyehu, agent at Gedion; Gezahegn Adgeh, general manager of Gad Construction; Mekbib Mogesse, general manager of Colon Construction, and Hailegebriel Hika, a businessman who is the brother of Habtamu. Among all these defendants, only Hailegebriel, who was attending court while out on bail, was acquitted. He was suspected of amassing wealth from an unknown source by using the powers and privileges of his brother in office as a cover. The Bench, however, acquitted him on Thursday, following his defense that that the wealth was generated though long years of saving. The Court will reconvene on December 28, 2013 to hear any appeals.

TITLE: Corruption consuming East Africa - report
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (91%); POLICE FORCES (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (73%)
TEXT: The report reveals that the police is the most corrupt sector in the region, followed by the Judiciary. Kampala- A new report has again pointed out corruption as the biggest problem Uganda and other East African countries are continuously grappling with. Just last month, Transparency International report 2013, showed a similar challenge across the five East African countries with Uganda setting the pace ahead of its regional peers. According to the new report launched last week by the Society for International Development, corruption continues to blight the landscape of East Africa's most important institutions, including those responsible for security and justice. The report revealed that the police account for 50 per cent of the most corrupt sectors in the region, followed by the Judiciary at 30 per cent. The police departments in all five East African Community states appear in the top 10 most corrupt institutions, something that points to what the report describes as the harsh reality experienced by many citizens while dealing with law enforcement institutions in the region. However, deputy police spokesperson Patrick Onyango said most reports are based on perception, implying that the report may not be entirely accurate. editorial@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Shun Corruption, Police Urged
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); BRIBERY (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); POLICE FORCES (90%); CRIMES AGAINST PERSONS (78%); SEX OFFENSES (78%); ELECTIONS (78%); NATURAL RESOURCES (76%); BUDGETS (74%); WOMEN (74%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (73%); CURRICULA (73%); REFERENDUMS (72%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (72%); FERTILIZERS (68%); NATIONAL PARKS (67%); TOURISM DEVELOPMENT (67%); FARMERS & RANCHERS (66%); CYANIDES (63%); POISONINGS (61%) Zimbabwe; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Vice President Joyce Mujuru has urged police to shun all forms of corruption and exhibit high levels of discipline and integrity on and off duty. Speaking at a graduation parade of 546 recruit constables at Morris Depot in Harare today VP Mujuru also urged the public to desist from bribing police. "As law enforcement agents, police officers should always stand on high moral ground and shun all forms of corruption. "I urge the Zimbabwe Republic Police to maintain the zero tolerance stance to corruption, and to us the public, we must also stop tempting our disciplined forces by bribing them at any given opportunity such as roadblocks, court cases and crime scenes to name a few examples. "I wish to call upon all Zimbabweans to rid society of social ills affecting our communities today by adhering to our values of ubuntu/hunhu," she said. Vice President Mujuru said she was impressed by the diligence and consciousness to duty exhibited by police during the referendum and the harmonised elections as well as the United Nations World Tourism Organization General Assembly held mid this year. She said it is laudable that human rights as a subject, has always been an invaluable component of ZRP training curriculum and human development programme saying it was testimony of the organisation's determination to uphold and respect human dignity at all times. "I, therefore encourage you to consistently and continuously uphold human rights. Indeed, our new people-driven constitution places value and importance to the upholding of basic human rights as espoused in Section 44 of the supreme law of our country," she said. VP Mujuru said Government has allocated a budget of US$161 million to finance the farming input scheme through provision of seed, fertilizer, chemicals and livestock to communal, small scale and A1 farmers imploring the corporate sector and partners to complement Government efforts through rendering support to A2 and commercial farmers. She said Government was saddened by the recent heartless and retrogressive acts, not only of poaching, where a large number of elephants were killed at Hwange National Park through cyanide poisoning but also "inhuman acts of rape and violence against women". "Some fathers are raping their own daughters. No! What has become of our country? To you the fresh graduands, I say batai munhu! Stop this insanity forthwith," she said. VP Mujuru deplored the continued destruction of the country's natural resources through veld fires and reckless cutting down of trees. She said she was gratified to note that ZRP was part of various institutions and individuals that are making a difference through sustained efforts in conserving the environment having planted 3 000 trees since 2009 at Ntabazinduna Training Depot. A total of 546 police officers comprising of 415 males and 131 female graduated.

TITLE: Declining forest cover blamed on corruption
SUBJECT: FORESTS & WOODLANDS (93%); FORESTRY & LOGGING (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); TIMBER TRACT OPERATIONS (90%); FORESTRY & LOGGING TRADE (90%); ILLEGAL LOGGING (90%); FORESTRY & ENVIRONMENT (89%); DEFORESTATION (89%); ENVIRONMENTAL DEPARTMENTS (78%); LOGGING INDUSTRY (78%); BUDGETS (75%); GROSS DOMESTIC PRODUCT (73%); ECONOMIC NEWS (73%); EXECUTIVES (70%)
TEXT: Meager resources allocated to the forestry sector have crippled activities. Kampala- The reduction of the country's forest cover is due to failure by government to implement laws, leading to persistent illegal timber trade in the country, anti-corruption crusaders have said. Under their umbrella body, Anti-Corruption Coalition Uganda (ACCU), the activists attributed the lack of implementation of the laws to meager resources allocated to the forestry sector which makes officials unable to supervise activities. According to the National Forest Authority (NFA), forests in Uganda contribute 5.7 per cent to the Gross domestic Product with a significant contribution found in the service roles including climate change mitigation, stabilisation of water supplies for domestic and agricultural use and soil conservation. Ms Cissy Kagaba, the ACCU Executive Director, argued that money allocated to the forestry sector is not enough for the officials to monitor all forests, leading to illegal acquisition of forests. "The certificates to permit timber harvesting are vague because they are not specific to tree species nor space to be harvested, which makes it easy for tree cutters to manipulate. These permits are not clear and they are issued without following the lawful procedure," said Ms Kagaba, accusing officials of conniving with timber harvesters. According to Ms Kagaba, the declining forest cover is as a result of the high level of impunity which has weakened the officials charged with protecting the country's forests. "A solution to this continued exploitation of the forestry sector is to increase budget allocation and desist from politicising the sector because this has led to invasion of the forests," she added. Mayuge has the highest deforestation rate with a 99.8 per cent loss of forest cover since 1990, this is followed by Wakiso at 86 per cent. In the north, Amuru has the highest forest cover at 3.3 per cent. In the west and eastern parts of the country, the forest cover is high in Kabarole at 22.6 per cent and 33.3 per cent in Bukwo. "If deforestation continues at the present rate, Uganda will have lost all its forested land by 2050," the National Environment Management Authority (NEMA) warned in its State of the Environment for Uganda 2008 report published in mid-Juneekasozi@ug.nationmedia.com

TITLE: Uproot Culture of Corruption [editorial]
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); BRIBERY (90%); CITY GOVERNMENT (90%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (90%); VEHICLE TRAFFIC (89%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (89%); INSPECTIONS (78%); POLICE MISCONDUCT (78%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (76%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (76%); MEDICAL EDUCATION (50%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: THE report that seven Vehicle Inspection Depot officers have joined 10 Harare Municipality Traffic Police officers under probe for corruption is very good news for Zimbabweans tired of graft. President Mugabe has called for zero tolerance to corruption, which is a problem we need to face head-on. It has become so ingrained in some of our institutions that some people believe that bribes are their rightful dues. Corruption bleeds the economy as resources meant to benefit ordinary citizens end up stashed in the pockets of a few ruthless individuals. Some foreign-owned companies siphon revenue into offshore accounts. Just getting service from some Government departments is frustrating as you are expected to fork out a bribe. Yet these are all funded through taxes paid by the ordinary citizen supposed to fork out a kickback. In the past many calls for the curbing of corruption have been made but it appears that the will and intention largely remained on parallel tracks. Some VID and traffic police officers from the national and municipal forces have repeatedly and publicly been declared as being very corrupt. Yet it appeared that those in charge could only watch helplessly while hapless motorists and other civilians were fleeced by some dishonest law enforcement officers. The inertia was puzzling, leading to speculation that the rot went all the way to the top. We need a new culture where corruption is not tolerated and the only way to do that is to send an unequivocal message that perpetrators will be caught and prosecuted. That is why we hope that these two developments signal a new era where the axe falls on perpetrators. The setting up of CCTV by the municipal authorities demonstrates a resolution to tackle the problem and we highly recommend the resourcefulness of whoever came up with the idea. We hope that the sweep in the two organisations is just the beginning. We hope to see more offenders named, shamed and punished, irrespective of their position and status. Let this not be the usual pretence where a few sacrificial lambs are offered before the campaign fizzles out. The efforts must be sustained, consistent and know no sacred cows. We hope those in charge of these institutions are serious about rooting out corruption and the public will soon be reaping the rewards of that as services are granted fairly. And it must not stop with the VID and Harare Municipal Police. Corruption is a cancer that has spread throughout the body of the country's operations and no single state arm can be said to be clean. The Registrar-General's Passport Office, ZRP Traffic and nurse training institutions deserve special mention as perceived bastions of corruption. Our columnist Mai Jukwa called for renewal in parastatal leadership at a time when some bosses have overstayed. ZBC is a case in point where the management and the board are alleged to have awarded themselves huge perks while the organisation became mired in debt, resulting in workers going for months without pay. We hope the forensic audit that Information, Media and Broadcasting Services Minister Professor Jonathan Moyo ordered at ZBC Holdings is already being carried out and the results will be made public soon. We also hope that similar sweeps will be executed at other under-performing state enterprises. There are several other places where Zimbabweans would like to see effective results, not the announcement of intentions: What happened to the call for a financial and means audit for police officers? What is the ZRP doing about their traffic police who stop the same kombis everyday without any apparent improvement in passenger safety? Why are touts back in the commuter omnibus ranks? What happened to the former MPs who reportedly abused the Constituency Development Funds during the tenure of the GNU? Were the accounts that they presented ever audited to verify the claims that they made? The list is endless and we intend to keep asking until we get answers.

TITLE: Corruption in Uganda is not a flu but a cancer
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (92%); DISEASES & DISORDERS (90%); INFLUENZA (90%); CANCER (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); AIDS & HIV (77%)
TEXT: In one of their campaign slogan posters, the Anti-Corruption League proclaims "Do not catch the corruption flu. It is everywhere in the country. Protect yourself with a mask. The mask provided for this flu is made of transparency, accountability, democracy, good governance, integrity and fairness". While most people would agree that the materials for which the mask is made are ideal, the diagnosis of corruption as flu is wrong. Corruption damages and eventually destroys a country like HIV/Aids damages and eventually destroys a human being. Corruption is a fatal state disease that severely damages and eventually destroys. In one of their campaign slogan posters, the Anti-Corruption League proclaims "Do not catch the corruption flu. It is everywhere in the country. Protect yourself with a mask. The mask provided for this flu is made of transparency, accountability, democracy, good governance, integrity and fairness". While most people would agree that the materials for which the mask is made are ideal, the diagnosis of corruption as flu is wrong. Corruption damages and eventually destroys a country like HIV/Aids damages and eventually destroys a human being. Corruption is a fatal state disease that severely damages and eventually destroys. Few people in Uganda today deny any more that the cancer of corruption is not only endemic but under the NRMO party government, it has spread nationwide and is accepted, if not encouraged, but has become the main political support machine of the ruling oligarchy. A country built on and sustained by corruption is like a house built on quick sand. Time will come, not later but sooner when a small wind blowing dissent will come and obliterate the sand and take with it those who foolishly constructed the house on sand. At one function which I attended and introduced President Museveni, who was the chief guest, I remarked that unless he and the government seriously fought against and marginalised corruption, the good deeds and record of his victorious speech when he first came to power on the strength of the barrel of the gun that his was not a mere change of guards but a fundamental change, will, if not already, be recorded in history as a sick political joke. However, on that particular function, the President agreed with my predication but protested very strongly that it could not endure under his leadership.  He explained, "Prof Kanyeihamba is, however, wrong, the NRM has defeated the bandits such as Kony, who were heavily armed how can we fail to defeat the corrupt, who are unarmed?" The President's question is very simple to answer. He and his government have totally failed to fight corruption. Several of his ministers and many more NRM party cadres and supporters are alleged to be thoroughly corrupt. President Museveni himself has publicly named many of them, but he continues relying on them for his prolongation in political office. Many Ugandans believe he is frightened of them. It is common knowledge amongst many of his ministers, party cadres and supporters that he is so much sustained by the corrupt in office that it is near impossible for him to survive politically without them. In the meantime, dozens and dozens of his former comrades and supporters have abandoned his corrupt-ridden political ship to wage war against it and piece gaping holes in its hull. The most important principle enshrined in the 1995 Constitution is that power is vested in the people who must be governed by their consent through their freely cast votes in elections or referenda or duly elected representatives. For decades now, the NRMO party has persistently but fatally undermined the same principle and governed by whims of the minority ruling class through mainly ignorance, fanaticism and greed all-trapped and propelled by intolerance and misrule. Most, if not all the fundamental safeguards enshrined in the Constitution, have been removed or stripped naked by an intolerant Executive. The fatal cancers of Kony and other groups of rebels against President Museveni and the NRMO party have not gone away. Like cancer cells, they are in hidden corners of the body in Uganda and Africa, anxiously waiting for the day when he and his band of corrupt singers are sufficiently weakened and hated by the anger of Ugandans, when they will strike back and seize power with no visible prospects that they will do any better or behave differently. There seems to be a curse thrust upon the destinies of the people and fortunes of the Pearl of Africa. Prof Kanyeihamba is a retired Supreme Court judge. gwkany@yahoo.com

TITLE: Corruption Ranking Improves Slightly to 57
COUNTRY: NAMIBIA (94%); LESOTHO (92%); AFRICA (92%); BOTSWANA (91%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (90%); MAURITIUS (90%); SEYCHELLES (90%); MOZAMBIQUE (79%); AFGHANISTAN (79%); ZAMBIA (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); MALAWI (79%); ANGOLA (79%); SOMALIA (79%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (79%); MADAGASCAR (79%); SWAZILAND (79%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (79%); ZIMBABWE (79%)
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (93%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); CAMPAIGN FINANCE (67%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (64%) Namibia; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: NAMIBIA'S corruption ranking, in this year's Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, has improved slightly from 58 last year to 57 out of 177 countries. The score has, however, remained at 48 while Botswana, ranked the best country in southern Africa at 30 has a score of 64. Seychelles is ranked 47 with a score of 54, Mauritius at 52 with a score of 52, and Lesotho is ranked 55 with a score of 49. Namibia is way ahead of economic powerhouse, South Africa, which is ranked 72 with a score of 42. Swaziland is 82 with a score of 39. Zambia, with a score of 38, is 83 while Malawi is 91 with a score of 37 and Tanzania at 111 has a score of 33 while Mozambique at 119 scored 30. Madagascar is ranked 127 with a score of 28. Oil rich Angola was ranked 153 with a score of 23. The Democratic Republic of the Congo is ranked 154 with a score of 22 with Zimbabwe ranked at 157 with a score of 21. Transparency said more than two thirds of the 177 countries in the 2013 index score below 50, on a scale from 0 (perceived to be highly corrupt) to 100 (perceived to be very clean). "The Corruption Perceptions Index 2013 demonstrates that all countries still face the threat of corruption at all levels of government, from the issuing of local permits to the enforcement of laws and regulations," said Huguette Labelle, Chair of Transparency International. Denmark and New Zealand tie for first place with scores of 91. Afghanistan, North Korea and Somalia this year make up the worst performers, scoring just eight points each. "The top performers clearly reveal how transparency supports accountability and can stop corruption," said Labelle. "Still, the better performers face issues like state capture, campaign finance and the oversight of big public contracts which remain major corruption risks." The Corruption Perceptions Index is based on experts' opinions of public sector corruption. Countries' scores can be helped by strong access to information systems and rules governing the behaviour of those in public positions, while a lack of accountability across the public sector coupled with ineffective public institutions hurts these perceptions. "It is time to stop those who get away with acts of corruption. The legal loopholes and lack of political will in government facilitate both domestic and cross border corruption, and call for our intensified efforts to combat the impunity of the corrupt," said Labelle.

TITLE: Corruption Hits Ariamsvlei Border Post
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); IMMIGRATION (92%); PASSPORTS & VISAS (90%); TERRITORIAL & NATIONAL BORDERS (90%); ARRESTS (90%); BRIBERY (90%); CRIMINAL INVESTIGATIONS (78%); LITIGATION (78%); LAW ENFORCEMENT (78%); INVESTIGATIONS (77%); TEXT MESSAGING (71%); MOBILE & CELLULAR TELEPHONES (71%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (64%) Namibia; Corruption; Migration
TEXT: AN immigration official stationed at the Ariamsvlei border post in the //Karas Region was arrested by officers of the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC) last Monday for alleged corruption. Muliza Godfried (39), was allegedly caught red-handed accepting a bribe from Zimbabwean national Vincent Ncube (33). This was after a member of the public had alerted the police and the ACC of the act. They also allegedly exchanged cellphone text messages. Confirming the arrest on Tuesday, the police commander in the //Karas Region, Commissioner Armas Shivute, said Ncube offered Godfried N$230 in exchange of an extra 36 days to be put on his visa. Ncube was coming from South Africa at the time. "We suspect that after the immigration officer agreed to take the money, Ncube placed N$ 230 inside his passport and handed it to Godfried. Before the transaction could be completed, the passport was confiscated, and both were arrested," Shivute explained. The police also learned with great concern that incidents of corruption such as receiving bribes from civilians is on the increase at the Ariamsvlei border post. "We do not have enough proof as yet, but we have noticed that this is not the first time such corrupt practices have taken place at that border post. We are now closely watching the immigration officers at that border post to make sure no corruption takes place," stressed Shivute. Ncube was charged with offering a bribe to a public officer, while Godfried was charged for accepting such bribe. The two appeared in the Karasburg District Court last Thursday and were remanded in custody while further police investigations continue. They are expected to make their second appearance in the same court next Wednesday. Nampa

TITLE: No Graft in 2014 - Govt Declares Corruption-Free Judiciary
SUBJECT: LEGISLATIVE BODIES (90%); CORRUPTION (90%); JUSTICE DEPARTMENTS (79%); LEGAL AID (79%); RULE OF LAW (79%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (74%) Zambia; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: JUSTICE Minister Wynter Kabimba has declared zero tolerance on corruption in the Judiciary in 2014. In a ministerial policy statement made in Parliament yesterday, Mr Kabimba also announced that Government would build more than six High Courts in selected parts of the country. He said the ministry would endeavour to uphold the rule of law and ensure justice for all next year. He said the ministry was determined to increase access to justice through construction of court buildings and the rehabilitation of existing infrastructure. Mr Kabimba said the Lusaka High Court building would be expanded, while other High Courts would be built in Chipata, Kabwe, Mongu, Choma, Mansa and Mazabuka. He said plans were also underway to construct High Courts in Chiengi, Chama and Chirundu. Mr Kabimba said that construction and rehabilitation of subordinate courts as well as outright purchase of buildings was underway to ensure quick disposal of court cases. He said his ministry would also continue to train staff to promote efficient delivery of justice in the country. United Party for National Development (UPND) Lukulu West Member of Parliament (MP) Misheck Mutelo said it was sad that corruption had found itself in courts of law. MMD Nalikwanda MP Geoffrey Lungwangwa called for independence of the Judiciary from the Executive so that it could uphold democratic principles. UPND Kalomo MP Request Muntanga called for renewed efforts in fighting corruption in the Judiciary. He said it was unfortunate that corruption had been noted in the Judiciary which was a noble wing of Government. In his response, Mr Kabimba said Government had a good programme to improve the disposal of cases. He said the Government was also working on modalities to upgrade the existing legal aid system so that the poor people could access justice. Earlier, Speaker of the National Assembly Patrick Matibini admonished Chadiza MMD MP Allan Mbewe for questioning the dignity of the House by directly attacking his integrity. Mr Mbewe raised a point of order against Dr Matibini alleging that the Speaker had not been consistent in his rulings on matters relating to the doctrine on separation of powers. The committee on privileges, absences and support services established a case against Mr Mbewe and called for him to be publicly admonished in the House. Mr Mbewe apologised to the Speaker and the House.

TITLE: 2013 Corruption Perception Index - S/Leone Ranks 119
SUBJECT: POLITICAL CORRUPTION (91%); CORRUPTION (90%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (74%) Sierra Leone; Corruption; Governance
TEXT: Sierra Leone has been ranked 119 out of 175 countries by Transparency International's Corruption Perception Index (CPI) for 2013 released yesterday. The Corruption Perception Index is based on experts' opinions of public sector corruption, and countries' scores can be helped by strong access to information systems and rules governing the behaviour of those in public positions; while a lack of accountability across the public sector - coupled with ineffective public institutions - hurt these perceptions. According to a release byTransparency International Sierra Leone, this year's CPI indicates that although the country improved in rank, its score reduced slightly in terms of progress made in the fight against sleaze. The organization noted that the reduction in score is a pointer to the fact that tremendous effort is still needed by government and citizens to curb graft, which, it said, is gradually becoming a prevalent norm in society and that despite the numerous efforts made to proactively address this scourge, public officials and those in positions of trust have decided to carry on with "business as usual". "The sources of data used for the rank and score for Sierra Leone were mainly derived from eight (8) sources (surveys). Transparency International Sierra Leone is of the firm conviction that unless and until corruption is effectively addressed and there is the will, determination and commitment across all sectors of society to effectively contribute to curb this menace, Sierra Leone's stride towards prosperity will remain a dream," it stated. The organization therefore urged government/public officials both at the national and local level to strive to demonstrate and be committed to a high level of integrity and patriotism in the execution of their duties, and to demonstrate the willingness to curb corruption to ensure that the country's development process will be meaningful to every Sierra Leonean. "We also continue to urge the general citizenry and civil society organizations to be more proactive and supportive in the fight against corruption, and more especially to refrain from any act that could condone it and to report any such known act," it concluded.

TITLE: 'Let's Promote a Corruption-Free Zimbabwe'
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (96%); LEGISLATIVE BODIES (89%); PUBLIC POLICY (78%); CURRICULA (78%); PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIPS (74%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (69%) Zimbabwe; Corruption
TEXT: PUBLIC-private partnerships, transparent policies and public awareness campaigns are key to the total eradication of corruption, African Parliamentarians Network Against Corruption chairperson Mr Willias Madzimure has said. Speaking at the International Anti-Corruption Day commemoration themed "Eradicating Corruption Starts With You" in Harare yesterday, Mr Madzimure said there was a need for the Government to work together with the public and other institutions to ensure the support of the positive and pro-active stance against corruption. "It is the Government's responsibility that it works hand in hand with its publics to ensure that it creates an environment that is zero tolerant to the scourge of corruption," he said. "It is my sincere hope that as the fiscus improves, adequate resources will be channelled to these key institutions that are pillars of ensuring the integrity of our country." Mr Madzimure expressed concern on the ignorance and lack of education in many societies which has resulted in a divided effort that has failed to promote a corruption-free Zimbabwe. "Other people are not fully aware of their role in society to fight corruption, therefore APNAC Zimbabwe calls for the inclusion of comprehensive anti-corruption education in the school curriculum as a way to instil awareness," he said. Various stakeholders including Transparency International Zimbabwe and the Anti-Corruption Commission of were represented at the commemorations. Member of Parliament representative from the Netherlands said drafting laws and policies that were never implemented or properly governed could not help eliminate corruption. "Malpractices, corruption and fraud cannot only be dealt with by drafting laws," she said. "The ultimate remedy is for members of parliament to stop funding organisations that have engaged in fraudulent activities." Commissioner Denford Chirindo of the Zimbabwe Anti-Corruption Commission said his organisation was one of the many institutions not fully performing their duties in curbing corruption.

TITLE: Combating the Scourge of Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (95%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (90%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (90%); ECONOMIC GROWTH (90%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (89%); PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION (78%); RAIL TRANSPORTATION (78%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (74%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (74%); TRAINS (68%); MANUFACTURING FACILITIES (67%); PRIME MINISTERS (67%); DAM & HYDROELECTRIC CONSTRUCTION (54%) Ethiopia; Corruption; Governance; Legal and Judicial Affairs
TEXT: Last week Transparency International, the global corruption watchdog, published the 2013 Corruption Perceptions Index, which ranks countries and territories based on how corrupt their public sector is perceived to be. Ethiopia's score on the index is 33, which is the same as 2012 and ranks it 111th out of 177 countries surveyed. The index yet again categorizes Ethiopia as a highly corrupt country. On the other hand, Ethiopia is also at the forefront of countries registering rapid economic growth. It launched the Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP) in 2010 to achieve its stated goal of joining the rank of middle-income nations by 2025. Accordingly, it is undertaking unprecedented and highly ambitious projects towards this end. The 6000 Megawatt Grand Renaissance Dam being built on the Blue Nile, a river which has not been harnessed despite its considerable potential, the national railway line being built in different parts of the country, the Addis Ababa Light Rail Train project, and ten sugar factories are part of the mega-projects intended to achieve the bold targets set by the GTP. Aside from these, a host of foreign companies are eyeing Ethiopia with a view to tapping its vast natural resources and other opportunities. All in all, the country is showing tangible economic growth across all sectors. It is, indeed, a paradox that Ethiopia ranks among the top in the rate of economic growth and the prevalence of corruption. This state of affairs is particularly unacceptable given that we find ourselves at a decisive moment in our history as a nation. Hence, we have to bear in mind that unless we resolutely combat corruption, one of the biggest impediments to development, the ambitious plans we have set out to accomplish, will remain a pipedream. It has been some time now since the government of Ethiopia declared poverty the topmost enemy of the country and waged war on it. Admittedly, there are signs that poverty can indeed be eradicated from Ethiopia. For instance, a recently released study found that Ethiopia beat all other countries in terms of the rate at which it produced millionaires in the past year. This testifies to the fact that the country is laying down the foundation for economic growth that has allowed many to become wealthy and improved the livelihood of millions of others. Thus, if Ethiopians do whatever it is within their power there is no reason why poverty cannot become a thing of the past. The rampant corruption prevailing in the country, however, threatens to undo the gains it has made on the economic front. The late Prime Minister Meles Zenawi once acknowledged the existence of corrupt elements within the ranks of the government, but passed away soon after. His successor, Prime Minister Hailemariam Desalegn, pledged to bring to justice these elements as he assumed office, and true to his word a number of senior government officials and employees were prosecuted on corruption charges this year. The fact that the majority of the accused are the top officials of the tax authority and prominent businesspersons reaffirms that corruption is one of the arch enemies of the nation and its people. The periodic reports of the Federal Auditor General regarding its investigation into the books of the federal government's various institutions are further proof of the level of corruption in Ethiopia. The measures the government are merely the tip of the iceberg. The Auditor General's reports have shown time and again that numerous government institutions are guilty of gross financial and property mismanagement. These reports have not resulted in the slew of indictments that should have been instituted by now. That they have not is a failure which needs to be addressed promptly. In any democratic nation, voters elect their government to serve them to the best of their ability. Accordingly, the government has to ensure that the sole yardstick it uses to appoint officials to positions of responsibility is merit. After all, a country must not be governed by officials who are appointed for the sake of taking a stab at ruling. Hence, government officials or employees who mismanage public monies and property should not be just moved laterally; they have to be held accountable on corruption charges for their misdeeds if the country is not to be derailed from its journey on the path to development.

TITLE: Institutions in Coalition to Eliminate Corruption
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (94%); PUBLIC CONTRACTING (89%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (89%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (78%); BRIBERY (78%); ASSOCIATIONS & ORGANIZATIONS (78%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (73%); ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT (71%); ECONOMIC NEWS (66%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (51%) Rwanda; Corruption; Legal and Judicial Affairs; Economy, Business and Finance
TEXT: A coalition bringing together various institutions has been formed to intensify the fight against corruption, especially in public procurement. The institutions include the Rwanda Association of Local Government Authorities (Ralga), Private Sector Federation (PSF), Rwanda Public Procurement Authority (RPPA) and Rwanda Governance Board (RGB). Others are Transparency International Rwanda, Rwanda Bureau of Standards (RBS), Institute of Engineers, Office of the Ombudsman, Rwanda Civil Society Platform (RCSP), and the National Public Prosecution Authority (NPPA). Speaking during the signing of the memorandum of understanding, Ombudsman Aloysie Cyanzayire said despite government efforts to fight corruption, there is still need to bring other parties on board to work toward a common goal. "Given the areas of interventions by the members of the coalition, I am sure that this initiative will effectively contribute to the fight against corruption, especially because it brings together key players in the private sector," she said. Cyanzayire said fighting corruption should not be left to the government but that it must be a collective responsibility given its negative impact not only to national development, but also on common folks at the grassroots. She said graft hinders economic development and denies citizens the chance to benefit from opportunities created by government, which plunges them into poverty. Coalition mandate Members of the coalition will have the responsibility of sharing relevant information concerning corruption cases, according to the memorandum of understanding. The coalition aims at establishing the partnership between the partner institutions with the purpose of ensuring that public tenders are issued and executed through a transparent, participatory approach and with accountability in the planning, bidding, awarding, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of the contracts tendered for. Marie Immacule Ingabire, the chairperson of Transparency International Rwanda, commended the initiative, saying it promotes and encourages other stakeholders in development to address the issues of corruption. "It is our obligation to detect and report cases of corruption in order to ensure zero tolerance for graft in every sector," she said. In October, Transparency International released the East African Bribery Index 2013, which indicated that despite Rwanda being the least corrupt country in the region, its index nearly double from 2.5 per cent in 2012 to 4.4 per cent in 2013. The findings cited local governments, banks, the judiciary, and the police as most corrupt institutions.

TITLE: Corruption suspects reappear in court
SUBJECT: CORRUPTION (90%); LAW COURTS & TRIBUNALS (90%); REGIONAL & LOCAL GOVERNMENTS (90%); SUITS & CLAIMS (89%); JAIL SENTENCING (78%); MAGISTRATES (78%); FRAUD & FINANCIAL CRIME (78%); CRIMINAL CONVICTIONS (78%); ELECTIONS (73%); CAMPAIGNS & ELECTIONS (73%); PRIME MINISTERS (73%); HEADS OF STATE & GOVERNMENT (73%)
TEXT: The suspects include OPM, Public Service and Local Government ministry officials. Kampala- The Anti-Corruption Court was yesterday a beehive of activities as several high profile government officials re-appeared before the court, five months after their case files were frozen. The Kololo-based court has been inactive for the past five months.Some of the suspects who re-appeared in court include; interdicted Public Service officials Jimmy Lwamafa, Stephen Kiwanuka Kunsa, (interdicted Director Research and Development), Christopher Obey, (interdicted Principal Accountant) and David Oloka Japians, (interdicted senior accounts assistant). Mr Lwamafa and group are accused of causing financial loss of more than Shs165 billion in connection with the creation of 2,605 ghost pensioners and their eventual payment. Presiding Magistrate Sarah Langa adjourned their case to March 3 for mention and April 3 for hearing. The other suspects who re-appeared in court included; former Local government permanent secretary John Muhanguzi Kashaka and five others.
